DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 17th graf, In remarks, to update with speech delivered
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, attacking Saddam Hussein from the campaign trail Tuesday, said Iraq's military must not be allowed to benefit frm any humanitarian shipments of food and medicine intended for innocent civilians. He also said there is no reason the Persian Gulf crisis should keep politicians from actively campaigning. ``I am sure every Democrat agrees - we will not allow our political life to be held hostage to a crisis,'' Bush said. Bush made his comments in GOP fund-raising events in Denver and Los Angeles at the start of a two-day trip. On Wednesday he will campaign in San Francisco before returning to Washington. ``We mean to keep the sanctions in place - to keep the pressure on - and prove to Saddam Hussein that aggression does not pay,'' Bush said. He said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has caused ``misery and suffering for millions.'' The chief beneficiaries of Bush's visits were Rep. Hank Brown, who is trying to move up to the Colorado Senate seat being vacated by Republican Sen. William Armstrong, and Sen. Pete Wilson, in a close race for governor in California. Wilson's race is the No. 1 target for the GOP this year, and Bush's appearances were expected to raise $2 million. In his speeches, Bush combined his assault against Saddam with standard campaign appeals to Congress for action on the budget deficit, anti-crime legislation and an overhaul of the Clean Air Act. `It's time to reach a binding budget agreement that shows the American people that we are serious about real deficit reduction,'' Bush said. He also called for energy conservation and development of alternative fuel sources to curb dependence on foreign oil. ``We've indulged a dangerous habit as a nation far too long,'' he said. Despite the partisan nature of his outing, Bush avoided any direct criticism of Democrats. However, Democrats seized on the occasion to twit Bush on allegations that his son, Neil, acted improperly in the $1 billion failure of a Denver savings and loan. Dick Freese, chairman of the Colorado Democratic Party, issued a statement challenging Bush to turn over the profits from Brown's fund-raiser to the savings and loan bailout. ``Any good father knows what needs to be done,'' Freese said. ``When our boys hit a ball through a neighbor's window, we don't make the guy next door pay to fix his own window. We get it fixed and work with the kids to make good on it.'' Bush did not comment in his speech on the S&L scandal. Discussing the Persian Gulf, Bush raised the possibility that humanitarian aid eventually may have to be sent to Iraq to offset hardships resulting from U.N. sanctions and a blockade on Iraqi commerce. ``Should aid become necessary,'' he said, ``it must be distributed under strict international supervision, to make certain that emergency aid reaches those Iraqis who need it most. ``We cannot allow Saddam Hussein to divert needed humanitarian aid in order to sustain his army of occupation,'' the president said. In a speech in Los Angeles, Bush said the gulf crisis requires that patriotism take precedence over politics. ``So it's good that politics stop at the water's edge, but that still leaves a lot of America in between,'' Bush said. ``From Long Beach to Long Island, we should and we will vigorously campaign right up to the November election. ``For those of us at home,' he added, ``we can serve our country by being the best candidates, the best citizens and, yes, the best Republicans and Democrats we can be.'' Struggling to maintain a global consensus against Iraq's aggression, Bush has kept the Persian Gulf crisis at the center of his public appearances. While Congress and the public stand united behind his policy, Bush has been expressing concern that the support might fade in a prolonged desert showdown with Saddam. ``Never before has the world community been so united,'' Bush said. ``Never since the invasion began has Iraq stood so isolated and alone. The key is collective action, sharing the responsibilities and the risks, the challenges and the costs.'' He said more than 20 countries have forces in the gulf. He said that despite the gulf crisis, ``we can all see the outlines emerging of a stronger, more peaceful world order. ... ``And let me be clear: With all that's at stake, the world will not allow one dictator's aggressive ambitions to stand in the way.'' Flying to Denver on Air Force One, Bush signed into law a bill allowing members of the armed forces in the Persian Gulf to send mail to the United States without cost. The law covers the sending of letters and recorded tapes.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Voters Limit Legislators' Terms
With AM-Primaries Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `With 39 ..., to UPDATE with 95 percent of precincts counted; pick up 4th graf, `Tulsa businessman ...
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma became the first state in the nation to put a limit on the length of service of state legislators by giving overwhelming approval Tuesday to a constitutional amendment. The amendment, which becomes effective Jan. 1, puts a lifetime cap of 12 years on legislative service. Legislators currently in office will be allowed to serve 12 more years. With 95 percent of the precincts reporting, ``yes'' votes outnumbered ``nos'' by 427,347 to 205,023, or 68 percent to 32 percent. Tulsa businessman Lloyd Noble II backed the circulation of an initiative petition to get the issue on the ballot. He contended that the term limitation was needed to keep legislators from becoming entrenched in office and beholden to vested interests instead of the people they were supposed to serve. Opponents argued that a remedy already was available - the ballot box. They pointed out that only 16 members of the 48-member state Senate and 14 of the 101 House members had 12 or more years of service at the end of the 1990 legislative session. The opponents also argued that voters would be giving up some of their rights by approving the term limitation bill. But most observers had predicted from the outset it would pass, particularly after the people approved another state question in 1989 that sharply limited the time the Legislature can remain in session. Although state legislators elected this year will take office in November, Noble said he believed the 12-year limit would apply to them. Colorado and California will vote on term limitation proposals Nov. 6, according to the National Council of State Legislatures. Similar legislation has been introduced in Florida and New York, the council said.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Indicted on Fraud Charges
With PM-Keating, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the events leading up to the indictment of Charles H. Keating Jr. stemming from the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan. -Feb. 22, 1984: American Continental Corp., formed by Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., buys Lincoln Savings and Loan for $51 million. -March 12, 1986: The Federal Home Loan Bank in San Francisco begins an examination into Lincoln's rapid growth and investment activity. -April 9, 1987: Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz., and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., who received large political contributions from Keating, meet with the San Francisco examiners. -May 1, 1987: San Francisco examiners recommend that Lincoln be seized. -Aug. 1987: M. Danny Wall, bank board chairman, orders his staff to conduct an independent review of the Lincoln examination. -May 20, 1988: The bank board in Washington signs a memorandum providing for a new examination to be conducted by officials in Washington. -Nov. 22, 1988: The second bank board examination is concluded. -Feb. 14, 1989: The bank board begins a third examination of Lincoln. -April 13, 1989: American Continental Corp. files for protection under bankruptcy laws. -April 14, 1989: The bank board seizes control of Lincoln. -May 12, 1989: Lincoln alleges that the seizure by regulators was illegal. -Sept. 15, 1989: The Resolution Trust Corp. seeks $1.1 billion from Keating, his relatives and associates in a fraud and racketeering suit alleging Keating diverted depositors' money for his own use. -Nov. 17, 1989: The Senate Ethics Committee decides to appoint an outside counsel to investigate the actions of the five senators. -Aug. 23, 1990: A federal judge upholds the government's takeover of Lincoln Savings and Loan. -Sept. 18, 1990: An indictment is unsealed charging Keating and three others with selling securities by false statements or omissions, selling securities without qualifications and lying to the California Department of Corporations. Keating is jailed on $5 million bail.

DOC.HEAD: City Faces-City Fears: One in a Series
A View From the Bench: `I Am Not Society's Avenging Angel'
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 34th graf. Also in Tuesday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto NY304 of Sept. 12
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NTE - The drama that plays daily in criminal courtrooms around the country is mostly tragedy, and Judge Earl Strayhorn knows its characters and sad speeches well. Still, in this second part of the series ``City Faces, City Fears,'' the jurist who grew up in the inner city says he cannot let his ``sorrow and pity'' cloud the tough judgments he must make. ---

It's late morning in Judge Earl Strayhorn's chambers and today's topic is wasted lives. One young man is dead in a shooting over drugs. Another, a 19-year-old gang member, will pay for the crime. Now it's bargaining time. The 19-year-old's lawyer pleads for mercy. The prosecutor talks of murder. Then the judge makes his offer: 20 years, take it or leave it. Minutes later, the boyish cocaine dealer, jaw jutting, head cocked back defiantly, pleads guilty to murder. His mother, straining to hear in the court's front row, cups her tearful face in her hands. As she leaves, she's comforted by a youth whose T-shirt has a moniker on the back: ``Killer.'' So goes another day in the Cook County courts, another day where dreams die, where mothers cry, where the strangest and saddest stories are told, where a few words from the honorable Earl Strayhorn can mean life or death. ``Yes, this IS justice,'' the judge says of the five-minute bargaining session he estimates saved seven trial days. ``He's not walking away with a slap on the wrist. Twenty years ain't chopped liver. The penitentiary is not a country club.'' For almost 20 years, Strayhorn has judged the crimes and misdemeanors of urban America. This tart-tongued veteran of the nation's largest court system says he's a pragmatist, not a dreamy-eyed crusader out to right every wrong. ``I am NOT society's avenging angel,'' he declares. ``I am NOT sitting in order to act as the conscience of society and to impose the horrible wrath of the Lord on people who commit horrible crimes.'' And he has heard his share: the teen who threw her baby down a garbage chute into a compacter, the guy who axed his grandmother to death, the man who hacked off his lover's head and toes and mailed them. ``Life in this day and age is cheaper than a piece of meat in the meat market,'' Strayhorn says. ``People will haggle over the cost of steak more than they will consider the worth of a human life. ``I cope with that. But,'' he adds slowly, ``I never get used to it.'' In fact, Strayhorn believes the world has turned harsher since he first donned black robes: more vicious crimes, more drug use, younger offenders. But this man who has climbed the steps of the Depression-era criminal courts building for 42 of his 72 years, as a prosecutor, defense attorney and now judge, decided long ago not to allow the cruelty eat him up. ``I put a shield on. I don't let it get behind that shield,'' he says, sitting in his chambers, lined with awards, memorabilia and photos of his wife, lawyer-son, doctor-daughter and grandchild. Strayhorn disposes of 500 to 550 cases a year, about 60 percent in pleas or bench trials. In 1989, 28,647 felony cases were filed in the county's criminal division, more than triple the number of a decade earlier, officials say. An estimated 75 percent were tied to drugs. Strayhorn says being a black raised in Chicago - he now lives a 15-minute drive from work - better prepared him to be a judge: He understands the environment and experiences of many who become court statistics. But when the white-haired, bespectacled judge takes the bench in his cavernous marble and wood courtroom, he's no soft touch. ``Why are you wearing that junk?'' he snaps at a bearded drug offender whose earring he takes as a sign of gang membership. ``When you come into court, you better take it out. You're caught with them, their dirt is going to spill over on you and I'm going to send you to the penitentiary. Do you understand?'' A suspected burglar fares no better. His lawyer wants his bond reduced, arguing that he supports four children. Strayhorn asks how much he gives the mother each week and questions his claim that a job's waiting. The man mumbles a confused answer. Strayhorn interrupts, snarling at the lawyer: ``Don't make him lie. Tell him to SHUT UP.... That's why he's here. He's a liar!'' ``You can't put anything over on the guy,'' says Jack Murphy, a prosecutor. ``He's seen it all. He's heard it all.'' But Strayhorn has a lighter side, too. He teases a balding lawyer: ``This case has got all the hair on it you lost off your head.'' He needles another, ``You're starting off on the short end of the stick. This one happened in my neighborhood.'' And at a civil marriage ceremony for a jail inmate, Strayhorn suddenly looks up from his paperwork and barks: ``Hey, man, kiss her!'' After a generation on the bench, Strayhorn says punishment remains the toughest part of the job. He has imposed the death penalty twice, though he morally opposes it, and once sentenced a gang rapist to 125 years, prompting the man to retort: ``I hope you croak in bed tonight.'' But he also acknowledges he probably gives more probation than other judges - in about 85 percent of his cases. ``My probation is harder to do than doing time,'' he argues. ``You have to use some self-discipline. ...That's punishment, particularly when they know what they've got hanging over their head is a big sword. ``If I send this malleable kid down to the penitentiary, all he's going to learn down there is how to be a bigger, worse crook,'' he adds. When ordering probation, Strayhorn always tells criminals what their prison sentences will be if they violate it. He gives no second chances. ``I'm arrogant,'' he says. ``I have confidence in myself. I feel I'm better than most and as good as the best.'' Still, he says, ``not a day goes by that I don't remember that I am black and being a judge really hasn't changed that.'' It becomes a theme when he speaks to groups of young people. ``When does a black person become a nigger in our society?'' he says he asks such groups. ``And their eyes widen and then somebody says, `I don't know, when?' I say, `When you leave the room.' '' ``The moral of the story ... I know I'm good, but I'm still black. That means I'm not going to receive the benefit of being good merely because I have been good. I'm going to have to be something more.'' Strayhorn says he knows racism and other urban ills often are factors in crimes. That doesn't sway him. ``All I can do is put a Band-Aid on the cancer,'' he says. ``If I allow my sorrow and my pity and my understanding that there is an explainable reason this person is just a step above an animal, if I allow the feeling to outweigh my judgment, I'm not going to be a good judge.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Sharon Cohen is the AP Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Cases Clog Courts, Justice System `Unworkable'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-City Faces-Judge
DOC.TEXT: Drug cases have clogged urban courts, delayed civil matters, overcrowded jails and stirred new debate over the best possible solution - legalization or more judges. ``If you want to look at the largest single cause of caseload glut, drugs are it,'' said Albert Alschuler, professor at the University of Chicago Law School. ``We're having fewer and fewer trials, particularly on the civil side. No one can afford to wait. The system's just become unworkable.'' Much of the impact is on state courts, which process about 97 percent of drug arrests. But the federal system also is feeling the crunch. Consider: - Drug cases in federal courts increased by 280 percent since 1980, Chief Justice William Rehnquist said last December in his annual end-of-the-year report. He urged Congress to act immediately on a proposal to create new judgeships. In July, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a measure to create 77 new judgeships. The bill is pending in the Senate. - Federal drug cases represented more than 26 percent of new criminal filings, and up to 60 percent in some districts, Rehnquist said. Nearly 55 percent of criminal appeals involved drug offenses, compared with 30 percent in 1980. - The drug caseload rose by 56 percent in 17 big-city courts between 1983 and 1987, according to a 1989 report, ``The Impact of Drug Cases on Case Processing in Urban Trial Courts.'' Among the major increases: Boston - 175 percent; Jersey City, N.J. - 114 percent; the Bronx borough of New York City - 109 percent; and Oakland, Calif. - 95 percent. - Drug-related cases made up about a quarter of felonies disposed of in 26 big-city courts in 1987, the report said. It noted that number actuallyis low because it doesn't count incidents in which drugs were involved but didn't constitute the most serious charge. The situation has turned even grimmer since then; in Detroit, the percentage of state court drug cases more than doubled from 1987 to 1989, said John Goerdt, the report's co-author and senior staff attorney at the National Center for State Courts. Drug cases, he added, are ``starting to show up in family courts, in juvenile courts, with abused and neglected kids.'' When courts are stressed, ``nobody can render the same quality of justice,'' said James Fyfe, a criminal justice professor at American University in Washington, D.C. ``We all know the old saw that justice delayed is justice denied. ... Evidence disappears. Recollections grow dimmer.'' Complicating matters, experts say, are new mandatory sentencing laws, leading some defendants to seek trial rather than pleading guilty, adding to the backlog. In Goerdt's report, jury trials in the 26 big-city courts disposed of only 6 percent of all felonies in 1987. While some propose more staff, U.S. District Judge Robert W. Sweet in New York last year became the first federal judge to publicly advocate drug legalization. The burden is so great, he said, that in September 1989, no federal juries in Manhattan were available to hear civil trials. Others who have previously supported legalization include Baltimore Mayor Kurt Schmoke and conservative columnist William F. Buckley. Regardless of different proposals, experts agree the impact is enormous. ``The taxpayers are spending lots of money to warehouse people in jail,'' Alschuler said. ``(Inmates) are sleeping on floors on mattresses. ... Everybody in the system suffers.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators In Virtual Impasse Over Capital Gains Tax ^Eds: Combines pvs, adds details of talks throughout; edits pvs to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration and congressional budget negotiators were an impasse late Monday after both sides made new offers that still left them far apart in the area of new taxes and with important disagreements over spending cuts. Congressional leaders of both parties and top administration aides planned to abandon the talks at nearby Andrews Air Force Base and, instead, were scheduled to meet at the U.S. Capitol on Tuesday in an attempt to get the discussions going again. Bargainers said they were not giving up hope that a deficit-cutting deal could ultimately be reached, but they expressed uncertainty over how that could be done. ``It's not quite an impasse, but its pretty close to one,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``After 10 grueling days, there are still major differences on dozens of issues, all the way from A for agriculture to Z for enterprise zones.'' ``It's going to be tough, but it's still not impossible and no one is giving up,'' Dole continued. ``The problem is we're running out of time.'' Asked if the talks had collapsed, Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, another negotiator, said, ``No, but at this point we've reached an impasse. We're apart on every major area.'' A Democratic official involved in the talks, speaking on condition of anonymity, declined to call the bargaining at an impasse. He said the only remaining areas of discord was over President Bush's insistence that the package include a cut in the capital gains tax. The lawmakers and administration officials had met for the last 10 days at Andrews in hopes the isolation from Capitol Hill might help them reach an agreement on ways to ease the deficit. Bush earlier Monday called on the bargainers to complete a deficit-reduction package, but reiterated that he wanted a capital gains tax cut to be part of the deal. ``We've made some headway recently in budget talks,'' Bush told reporters. ``But it really is time now to get an agreement now. I think we owe that to the American people.'' Negotiators at the talks, which entered their tenth day, have said the fight between Democrats and Republicans over reducing the capital gains tax rate is the key dispute blocking an agreement. Republicans have pushed to reduce that tax, which is charged on the profits from the sales of property, arguing that it would stimulate the economy. But Democrats have said the proposal would help almost exclusively the wealthy, and have insisted that if it is included in the package, there must also be a tax rate hike for the rich. The bargainers, meeting at Andrews om nearby Maryland, swapped new budget cutting offers late Monday. Both packages were aimed at reducing the deficit by about $50 billion next year and by $500 billion through 1995. The two sides both wanted about $25 billion of the savings next year to come from new taxes and fees. But the Democrat offer was contingent on not having a capital gains cut as part of the package, while the Republican offer contained the cut and offset it by eliminating the deduction for state and local taxes for people earning more than $200,000 annually, said one official close to the talks. But Republicans said there were major additional differences between the two sides that had caused the Andrews talks to end. They complained that while their package cut defense spending by $170 billion over five years, the Democratic plan specified cuts of only $10 billion next year and $23 billion in fiscal 1992. The reductions for the three years beyond that were left unclear. In recent days, Democrats had offered to cut military spending by $200 billion over the next five years. Republicans also complained that Democrats were not willing to cut domestic programs deeply enough. GOP bargainers wanted to pare benefit programs like Medicare by $123.3 billion over the money they would need to stay even with inflation over the next five years. Democrats wanted to limit the cut to $120.6 billion. Unless a deficit-cutting package is in place by Oct. 1, the beginning of the next fiscal year, the Gramm-Rudman law will automatically trigger about $100 billion in cuts in the $1.2 trillion federal budget, an amount considered high enough to seriously disrupt government operations. ``There hasn't been one darn thing since we started that anybody has agreed on,'' complained one of the bargainers, Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. earlier Monday. Conte and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said some lawmakers are beginning to discuss legislation that would temporarily postpone the Gramm-Rudman spending cuts unless a budget deal is worked out. Both men said they opposed the idea, but declined to say who was considering it. Ever since making it an issue during his 1988 election campaign, Bush has pushed to lower the top tax rate on capital gains, the profits from the sale of property. He has argued that a reduction would invigorate the economy by encouraging people to sell. Democrats have labeled the proposal a boon to the wealthy that would lower government revenues in the long run. They have said that if the tax cut is to be included in a deficit-cutting package, they want it accompanied by higher income tax rates on the rich. Without a budget deal, next year's shortfall is expected to exceed $250 billion, which would be the highest mark ever.

DOC.HEAD: Year After Quake, Homes, City Halls, Freeways Not Fixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto sent Sept. 17.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a year after an earthquake killed 67 people and jolted nationwide TV viewers expecting the World Series, San Francisco's supervisors still enter their chambers through an archway braced by timbers. The Embarcadero Freeway is still deserted, weeds sprouting from cracked concrete. An estimated 1,000 people left homeless by the 7.1-magnitude tremor sleep in doorways and shelters while the city negotiates redevelopment funds to rebuild hotels. In Santa Cruz, a seaside tourist town eight miles from the Oct. 17 quake's epicenter, chain-link fences ring downtown craters where the shuddering Earth crumbled Victorian buildings, cracking colonnades and toppling turrets. From San Francisco to Watsonville, businesses, homes and freeways severely damaged by the Loma Prieta quake remain in ruins, and officials estimate it will be five to 10 years before the worst of the $7 billion-$10 billion damage is repaired. None of the agencies involved was willing to estimate the final price tag, which will include seismic renovations to protect against the ``The Really Big One.'' ``It's one of the most depressing things I've ever been through in my life. It's like it was nuclear bombed. All the buildings are gone ... I can imagine going through World War II and coming home to see your city totally destroyed,'' said Bob Shepherd. He was Santa Cruz city finance manager until he resigned Aug. 17 to teach. Only one of the 15 buildings demolished in the town centerpiece, Pacific Garden Mall, is under construction. Five others have permits, said Ceil Cerillo, executive director of the city's redevelopment agency. More than 35 businesses sell their wares out of six tent pavilions. Ten miles south in Watsonville, a town of migrant field hands and cannery workers, the gutted Main Street has barely begun to revive. The largest retailer, Ford's Department Store, announced in mid-August it will rebuild with help from Federal Emergency Management Agency funds. In Oakland, where the quake stunned a downtown revitalization effort, several blocks of stores and office buildings remain boarded up. Oakland City Hall, which dates to 1914, is ringed with scaffolding and closed to the public while the city dickers with FEMA over how much of the $90 million renovation the agency will reimburse. San Francisco officials won't begin the $100 million repair of the Beaux Arts City Hall until they settle with FEMA. ``There is still no agreement. It's stupid to work on our buildings while we're negotiating what's eligible. ... We'd have removed the evidence,'' said Tom Jones of the mayor's Office of Community Development and Housing. Drivers in and out of the city continue to face traffic jams on U.S. 101 and Interstate 280, sections of which remain closed. The Embarcadero, the lifeline to Chinatown and North Beach nightclubs, remains a hulking ruin while the city decides whether to replace it with an underground expressway. Repairs to these roads are estimated at $160 million. That does not include $100 million to replace Interstate 880's Cypress overpass, where 42 of the quake victims died after it collapsed. ``When the freeways reopen, we'll be the foremost engineers in the world on earthquake repairs. We want to do it right; safety is the main issue,'' said Greg Bayol, spokesman for the state Department of Transportation. Some homeowners in San Francisco's heavily damaged Marina District, where only two of 54 demolished buildings have been reoccupied, found $500,000 Small Business Administration loans too little too late. One woman interviewed by the city received word she was eligible for a no-interest 20-year loan from CALDAP, a state program, one day after she agreed to sell her $2.5 million property for $1 million to pay her note. ``The earthquake happened at the same time as the savings and loan crisis,'' said Jones. ``Most lenders were willing to forgive one or two months, but when the crisis hit, the lenders starting calling their loans.'' Owners of transient hotels in Oakland and San Francisco found SBA loans inadequate to repair the dilapidated buildings that housed an estimated 2,500 elderly, mentally disabled and poor people left permanently homeless by the quake. Officials estimate it will be five years before the freeways are restored and at least three years before hotels are rebuilt with help of emergency redevelopment funds, said Bill Rumpf, chief of San Francisco's redevelopment agency. ``The process takes months and years,'' said Henry Renteria, Oakland's head of emergency services. ``In Whittier and Coalinga, their earthquakes were years ago and there are still buildings with issues not resolved.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Hatch Wins Praise for Compassion but Irks Old Backers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX10 of Sept. 14
DOC.TEXT: As one of the Senate's staunchest conservatives for a dozen years, Orrin Hatch might be expected to be among lawmakers campaigning to slash federal grants for the arts. But the Utah Republican who spent two years as a Mormon missionary is taking a pass. He shakes his head glumly at moves to curb funding for the National Endowment for the Arts on grounds that some of the money has gone to projects tainted by obscenity. ``No one is more against obscenity and pornography than I am, but I just don't believe that the Congress should impose censorship through the authorization process,'' Hatch said. ``Some of these people, if they had lived in the time of Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, the Sistine Chapel would never have been painted,'' Hatch says of lawmakers heading the drive. ``They wouldn't allow you to hang a Reubens in the Senate.'' Hatch is scrupulously polite and soft-spoken, although sometimes an emotional side surfaces unexpectedly. When the Senate debated rights for the disabled in July, Hatch was telling how his brother-in-law suffered as a victim of polio. Suddenly, he ``just broke down.'' ``I mean I just wept, tears rolling down my cheeks,'' Hatch recalls. ``I was embarrassed because I don't like people to know that side of me that much.'' From the scourge of the liberals to patron of the arts and other issues irksome to conservatives, Hatch's political persona is undergoing a distinct change. When Hatch arrived in the Senate in 1977, he was immediately accepted as one of the fiercest conservatives to prowl the floor. Over the last two years, though, he's been at odds with old allies more than once. Despite conservative opposition, he spearheaded in 1989 a $1.75 billion-a-year package of child-care grants. He's campaigned for escalation of the battle against AIDS. And he sponsored a Justice Department program aimed at fighting ``hate crimes'' motivated by racial and religious bias. The hate crimes bill put Hatch on a collision course with Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who called it ``the flagship of the gay rights agenda.'' Hatch, 56, scoffs at the notion that he's changed: He remains a supporter of capital punishment, a critic of gun control and an opponent of a major civil rights bill on Capitol Hill whose minority-hiring provision, he says, would inevitably lead to hiring quotas. All the same, a recent poll showed many Utah voters believe he's moved in a more liberal direction. And he's finding increasing favor with lawmakers he once fought. ``He is open on some things,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. ``He has grown, and I hope we can all grow. He was superb on the hate-crimes bill.'' Lean at 6-foot-4, with every silvery hair in place and a taste for conservatively tailored dark suits and blazers, Hatch likes to tell of his humble origins as the son of a Pittsburgh metal lather. ``I grew up on the wrong side of the tracks,'' he says. ``We were poor, poor people.'' He worked as a janitor to help pay his way through Brigham Young University, where he met his wife, Elaine. They have three sons, three daughters and 10 grandchildren. He graduated from the University of Pittsburgh Law School and practiced in that city before returning to Utah. In 1976, he upset incumbent Democratic Sen. Frank Moss, in part with the help of hundreds of Hatches in rural Utah, their numbers a legacy of the heavily Mormon state's polygamous past. Moss and other Democrats, however, blamed rough-and-tumble tactics by New Right conservatives - Washington groups whose trademark was mail-order campaigns designed to rise funds and energize voters around issues such as abortion and school prayer. In the Senate, Hatch is a vocal member of the Judiciary Committee where he ranks second behind Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. But his major post is that of top Republican on the Labor Committee, where he's often at odds with Chairman Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. But frequently, Hatch and Kennedy reach a compromise, as they did on a Hatch bill opposed by some liberals that allows export of pharmaceuticals not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in this country. Indeed, the Hatch record on such matters gives business little to complain about. He is a firm backer of bills to rein in court damages in product liability and medical malpractice lawsuits - major goals of the insurance industry. And he's sponsoring a bill to allow the federal government to pre-empt tough state standards governing pesticides in foods. Hatch scoffs at complaints from liberal consumer groups that his bill would allow unsafe concentrations of pesticides in foods. ``That's not based on science,'' he says. ``That's based on old wives' tales.'' Senate Republicans take little notice of strained ties between Hatch and conservative activists. They hail him as hard-working and effective. ``I'm a real admirer of Orrin Hatch,'' said Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo. ``He undertakes the toughest chores in the Senate because he is the ranking Republican on the Labor Committee,'' Danforth said. ``The issues he involves himself in are often hotly controversial and take up a good deal of the Senate's time, but he does his job with unflappable competence.'' But such testimonials leave hard-core conservatives unmoved. ``He has separated himself from us ... on social welfare legislation, on what we would call gay rights legislation, on a whole range of issues,'' said New Right pioneer Paul Weyrich. Weyrich says Hatch has been shopping for issues to help broaden his support and hopes for an appointment to the U.S. Supreme Court. Indeed, when Justice William Brennan announced his retirement, reporters were quick to corner Hatch and ask if he wanted the post. He said no. Hatch also says he's always been a champion of the underdog and that perhaps his conservative critics just haven't noticed. ``I have always been an advocate of those with disabilities, those who are downtrodden, who really can't help themselves,'' he said. ``What I have a problem with is people who can help themselves but won't.'' At the same time, he says his conservative critics should take a more careful look at his overall record. ``I wonder who they think took the lead in fighting for a lot of the changes around here,'' he said, his voice rising. ``I wonder who they think fought for fairness in the Iran-Contra hearings.'' That view is echoed by writer-activist Patrick McGuigan, author of a recent book on the battle over Robert Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court. McGuigan is an outspoken Hatch admirer, but says many would disagree. ``There are a lot ofconservatives who don't know him as well as I do who think Orrin Hatch has gone around the bend,'' says McGuigan. ``They think he isn't a conservative anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheers for Saddam Widen Gap Between Arabs and Jewish Majority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Children in this biblical Arab town used to copy stone-throwing Palestinians of the occupied territories in a game called ``Intefadeh.'' Now they play ``Burn the American flag.'' They are responding to what many adults in Kufr Kanna and other Arab towns in Israel have said since the U.S.-Iraqi showdown began: Saddam Hussein is a hero who will unite Arabs against the United States and its ally, Israel. Most Israeli Jews have been startled by such wide support for the Iraqi president among Israel's 800,000 Arab citizens. Liberals are disappointed and hard-liners cry ``treason,'' some even urging that Arab citizens be expelled. ``The Arabs in Israel are crossing a red line, support for an enemy who is threatening to annihilate half of Israel with chemical weapons,'' said Eliezer Tsafrir, Arab affairs adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. ``We used to say the majority of our Arab citizens are loyal to the state. We must go on saying that, but I'm not sure any longer how accurate it is.'' Tsafrir said ``Saddamania'' was further weakening Jewish-Arab coexistence already hurt by Israeli Arab support for the 33-month-old Palestinian intefadeh, or uprising, in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Support for Saddam among Israeli Arabs springs partly from anger about their treatment by the Jewish majority. They were under military government until 1966 and, today, their communities get only about one-quarter the government funds given to similar Jewish towns. Moslem fundamentalism also plays a role. The fundamentalists are angry that American ``infidels'' have been sent into Saudi Arabia near Moslem holy places. A study by Givat Haviva, a left-wing Israeli think tank, found that Israeli Arab intellectuals initially condemned the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, but rallied behind Saddam when U.S. troops entered Arab lands. Outspoken support for Saddam is the rule in Kufr Kanna, a hillside farming town of 12,000 north of Nazareth that is believed to be where Jesus changed water into wine. Two weeks after Iraq's invasion, about 2,000 people marched through town, carrying banners with such slogans as ``Saddam, hit the Americans and Israel with chemical weapons.'' The marchers burned an American flag and pictures of Hosni Mubarak, president of Egypt, who has cooperated with the U.S. defense of Saudi Arabia. Omar Saeed, a leader of the nationalist Sons of the Village movement, said the demonstration inspired the children's game of pretending to burn makeshift American flags. Saeed, a self-proclaimed socialist, sees Saddam as a fellow revolutionary because he ousted Kuwait's oil-rich royal family. ``Saddam is leading the revolution of the poor; he is the Arabs' Robin Hood,'' Saeed, 30, said in the living room of his father's two-story home overlooking the town. He has an apartment in Haifa, where he is studying for a doctorate in pharmacology at an Israeli university, and said most of his Jewish neighbors call him a traitor. ``They are saying, `If you are with Saddam, you are against us,' but my professor said he would fight for my right to speak my mind,'' said Saeed, who spent four years under house arrest and six months in prison for nationalist activities. His 65-year-old father, Radwan, described Saddam as a savior fighting to unite Arabs, in the tradition of the late Egyptian president, Gamal Abdel Nasser. Radwan Saeed, who been under town arrest for 10 years because of nationalist activities, pointed to a picture of Nasser on the wall and said: ``Tomorrow, we'll have a picture of Saddam up there as well.'' Jews are shocked by such sentiments from Arab countrymen, who remained silent during Israel's wars with its Arab neighbors. ``I didn't expect to find them on friendly terms with such a dictator,'' said Yossi Sarid of the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement. ``Maybe they haven't digested deeply the democratic rules of the game.'' Conservative Israeli newspapers suggested the government crack down on Arabs supporting Saddam. ``No one asks that they identify with Israeli policy, but no state that values its existence can accept the identification of its citizens with an enemy,'' said an editorial in the daily Maariv. ``One does not play with fire.'' On the extremist fringe, U.S.-born Rabbi Meir Kahane of the anti-Arab Kach movement said Israeli Arabs should be expelled. ``I saw on television, how the Arabs of Kufr Kanna . . . our Arabs, good Arabs, faithful Arabs, marched in support of this dictator,'' Kahane said at a rally. ``Friends, if we want a common policy, it is `Throw the Arabs out'.'' Tsafrir said there were no plans for action against Israeli Arabs unless they broke the law, but noted that growing resentment by Jews would make it more difficult to redress the imbalance in funding for Arab towns. In Kufr Kanna, Mayor Aref Hamdan said Arabs were angry over ``separate and unequal'' policies under which a permit for building a factory had been denied. The town's unemployment rate is about 25 percent, more than twice the Jewish rate. Mohammed Abbas, unemployed after losing jobs in his field of biology and as a waiter, said: ``The Jews think we are weak, inferior people. We have to explain ourselves to them all the time, say that we are loyal to the state. They never explain themselves to us.''

DOC.HEAD: 265th Arrives at Base Camp, Where One Day Can Last for Weeks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles has been with the 14 Guardsmen as they trained and deployed to the Mideast.

No one stays at this assembly area for more than a day, the sergeant major explained. Except that a day can sometimes last two weeks or more. This industrial area in the desert is first stop for many new troops arriving in Saudi Arabia. The gritty landscape of dusty mills and corrogated metal buildings is covered with long rows of olive drab tents. Units arrive here each day to receive their assignments. The expectation is they will quickly be shipped somewhere else. ``Welcome to Ellis Island,'' one officer said by way of explanation. The 265th Quartermaster Detachment, a South Carolina National Guard unit mobilized to run water purification equipment in this dry country, arrived over the weekend. But so far the only water the 14 men have seen is in the 1.5 liter bottles handed out to them several times a day. Like so many other units staying here, the 265th is an orphan looking for a home. ``We got to get going here,'' said Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, who leads the 14 men from Allendale, S.C. ``We need to go to a place we can start working.'' The urgency to get out isn't rooted in work ethic alone. As an intelligence officer pointed out matter-of-factly, this place is considered a prime Iraqi target. It doesn't take much to see that. There are no bunkers, no trenches; no where to run or hide. ``You get an air strike in here, this place will get torn up bad,'' said Jackson. So the sergeant spent his time looking to get the unit officially adopted, driving to various headquarters areas, trying to learn where his unit is headed. The wide, empty six-lane highways carried only a light traffic of U.S. troops in HUM-VEE's and pickups and Saudis in Toyotas and Mercedes. Many of the Saudis waved as they rocketed past at speeds well over 60 mph. Jackson's quest took him to a civilian airport still under construction. Inside the broad concourses and baggage areas, Americans with charts, lists and field telephones were busy keeping up with the paperwork of near-war. The initial news wasn't good. The battalion the 265th is assigned to hasn't made it in country yet. ``That's Uncle Sam for you,'' said Spc. Bobby Youmans. ``He'll put you on hold like a telephone.'' Back at the assembly area, the unit settled into temporary housekeeping in a 15-by-60-foot tent set in the sandy dirt. There wasn't much to do in the heat of the day. Mostly the men snoozed on their cots, listened to the radio, swapped portions of their rations and kidded each other about sex. The relative peace was broken several times a day as F-15s screamed overhead on their way to patrol duty to the north. Most were a little disappointed with their first glimpses of Saudi Arabia. ``This isn't what I expected,'' said Spc. Mark Rooker as he tried to clear the grit off his clothes. ``I didn't think it'd be this dirty.'' Youmans was waiting to take in the sights. ``I need to see a camel bad,'' he said. What passed for sightseeing was a stroll down sunblasted streets to a variety store off base. Latrines were down the street. So were a hastily constructed set of showers. Sunset came with a hint of relief from the day's dusty heat as three members of the 265th took up guard duty, stopping vehicles coming onto post. The M-16s on their shoulders weren't loaded. Clips of ammunition were in their pockets. Looking into the hazy night sky, Spc. Willie Badger pointed out the Little Dipper. ``It's the same sky as home,'' he said. ``But down here, it's not the same. Not by a long shot.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Barry Will Not Be Tried Again
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors are hinting they may seek a jail term for Mayor Marion Barry on his cocaine possession conviction, but they say he won't be retried on a dozen charges that deadlocked a federal jury. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens announced Monday that Barry would not be retried on the 12 charges, including one involving an FBI videotape of the mayor smoking crack cocaine. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson set sentencing for Oct. 26. Asked whether he will recommend that Barry be sent to prison, Stephens said ``the latitude is there for ... (sentencing) of a full year in prison, which we believe is an adequate basis of punishment for Mr. Barry.'' The prosecutor refused to elaborate, saying only that he will make a sentencing recommendation to Jackson. Under federal sentencing guidelines, Barry could face a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. ``I'm obviously relieved at this phase of the legal proceedings,'' Barry said after the U.S. attorney's decision was announced. He declined further comment. Barry is running for an at-large city council seat. Earlier, he had announced he would not seek a fourth, four-year term as mayor. During a five-minute court hearing, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin said simply, ``The government has made a determination not to seek retrial on the pending counts.'' The government's decision comes five weeks after Barry's two-month trial ended with his conviction on one misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, acquittal on another and a mistrial on the 12 remaining counts - three felony perjury charges and nine misdemeanor counts. Stephens said, ``Mr. Barry's political status and political future are not factors we considered when making decisions about this prosecution.'' The jury's verdict was widely interpreted at the time as a victory for the mayor. But Stephens said Monday, ``When all the dust is settled, in the final analysis, the ultimate truth will remain - that the chief executive of this city charged with the responsibility of leading the fight against illegal drugs and violence has himself been convicted of contributing to that human devastation.'' While Barry escaped conviction on most of the charges against him - including the three felonies, which carried mandatory jail sentences - he was forced to pay a political price. Current and former Barry administration sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said one reason Barry announced he would not seek re-election as mayor was to let the jury know he had already made sacrifices and cast himself in a sympathetic light. Barry's decision not to seek re-election opened the door for political newcomer Sharon Pratt Dixon, who won last week's Democratic mayoral primary. Dixon's pledges to clean up the government and reduce the city work force drew support that was interpreted by many as a sign that city voters want a change from Barry's ways. After Dixon's victory, the mayor acknowledged that ``the people have said they want something different,'' but he has stood by his decision to attempt a political comeback. The jury's decision followed a dramatic eight-week trial featuring a videotape of Barry smoking crack cocaine the night he was arrested in an FBI sting operation. Barry's lawyer argued that federal prosecutors had improperly trapped him by asking a female friend to invite him to the hotel and to press him repeatedly about whether he wanted drugs. Before Monday's status hearing, prosecutors gave no indication whether they would try the mayor again. Earlier this month, Terry Halperin, the U.S. attorney for the Virgin Islands, announced that she would not bring charges against the mayor there. One of the felony perjury charges and a conspiracy charge against Barry involved alleged drug activity in the Virgin Islands during 1986 and 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Chief Backs Senate Bill on `Obscene Art'
DOC.TEXT: The beleaguered chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts is applauding a Senate bill that would give the courts - not his agency - the burden of deciding whether some federally subsidized works of art are obscene. NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer said the Senate measure and a report by a bipartisan commission last week ``give us hope that the crisis will soon pass'' over federal support for controversial art. Frohnmayer refused, however, to scrap a much-criticized requirement that NEA grant recipients sign an anti-obscenity pledge before they can receive federal money. He said he would delay a decision on eliminating the pledge until Congress decides whether to impose new anti-obscenity restrictions on the endowment and a federal court in New York rules on the constitutionality of the pledge. At a news conference Monday at the National Press Club, Frohnmayer said there was ``zero truth to those rumors'' that he would resign soon, after a turbulent year as NEA chairman. The endowment is an independent, $171 million federal agency that supports a wide variety of artists and arts organizations. It has been the target of heavy criticism for the past 18 months from conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists who accuse the NEA of subsidizing obscene and sacrilegious works. Last week, the Senate Labor and Human Resources approved a bipartisan compromise bill extending the NEA for five years beyond Sept. 30, when its statutory authority expires. The bill would require the NEA to recoup funds from grant recipients who are convicted of violating obscenity laws. Frohnmayer said this provision ``puts the determination of obscenity in the courts, where it should be.'' Last October, at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Congress voted to prohibit the NEA from spending federal funds on any works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism and the sexual exploitation of children. A month later, Frohnmayer began requiring grant recipients to sign a pledge that they would not use federal money to produce works that might be deemed obscene. The anti-obscenity pledge stirred widespread protests in the arts community. A dozen grant recipients refused to sign it and forfeited their grants. Three federal lawsuits filed in New York and Los Angeles charge that the pledge violates First Amendment guarantees of free expression. The 12-member independent study commission created by Congress urged Frohnmayer last week to scrap the pledge. A similar plea was made earlier by the NEA's presidentially appointed advisory body, the National Council on the Arts. The study commission endorsed the NEA but recommended changes in its grant-making procedures to make the agency more responsive to the public's interests. The panel also urged Congress not to impose any new restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for NEA subsidies when the current anti-obscenity ban expires on Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Out to Claim Boggs' Black-Majority Seat in Congress
DOC.TEXT: Six blacks are among a dozen candidates scrambling to claim the House seat in Louisiana being vacated by Rep. Lindy Boggs, the only white in Congress who represents a district that is mostly black. Mrs. Boggs, 74, announced in July that she was stepping down for personal reasons after more than 17 years in the House. The popular Democratic congresswoman enjoyed strong support from New Orleans voters in all age, ethnic and economic groups throughout her tenure. But despite Mrs. Boggs' strong record on civil rights issues and her support in the black community, blacks were growing anxious to elect one of their own in the district, which has a 60 percent black voting majority. Many believe 1990 may be the last year a black can be elected from the district. Since New Orleans lost people in the 1980s, district lines drawn after the 1990 census are expected to reduce or eliminate the black majority. Even before Mrs. Boggs announced in July that she would retire at the end of this term, two prominent black Democrats had announced plans to run for her seat. But since she dropped out, race has not been much of an issue, since four of the five major candidates are black. One of them, attorney Michael Bagneris, has said that whites who live in New Orleans are starting to feel as disenfranchised as blacks did before the civil rights movement. Black political groups must work to include whites and avoid repeating the ``folly'' of the past, he says. ``I see as the major issue getting everyone to focus on the major issues and not to focus, as we have so often done in the past, on superficial things such as personality or race,'' he says. Mrs. Boggs had taken 75 to 90 percent of the vote in almost every race since she decided to run to succeed her husband, Rep. Hale Boggs, who disappeared on a plane flight over Alaska in 1973. Her most serious challenge was in 1984, after court-ordered redistricting to meet the requirements of the Voting Rights Act altered the makeup of her district and left it 60 percent black. In that race, Israel Augustine, a respected black judge, got 39 percent of the vote. Still, Mrs. Boggs' long record of work for civil rights and her political power brought her 38 percent of the black vote in that election. Mrs. Boggs did not elaborate on her reasons for retiring, but it has been widely reported that she wanted to spend more time with her daughter, Barbara Sigmund, the mayor of Princeton, N.J., who has cancer. Political observers say the leading black candidates to succeed Mrs. Boggs are state Sens. William Jefferson and Jon Johnson and attorneys Marc Morial and Bagneris. The leading white candidate is school board member Harwood ``Woody'' Koppel. All are Democrats. They and most of the other seven candidates are running on a pledge to improve New Orleans' economy, which never recovered from the 1980s collapse in oil prices. In all, six Democrats, two Republicans and four independents are running in Louisiana's open primary, in which all candidates are on the same Oct. 6 ballot regardless of party. If nobody gets more than half the vote, the top two will be in a runoff Nov. 6. With less than a month to go before the primary, it's too early to predict who will make a runoff, said Loyola University pollster and political analyst Ed Renwick. ``I think it's quite possible that a runoff would be between two blacks,'' Renwick said. Jefferson has been endorsed by Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, and Johnson by Gov. Buddy Roemer. Morial, son of the late former Mayor Dutch Morial, has his father's name and his mother Sybil's active and influential support. Bagneris is a protege of the elder Morial but has support from both blacks and whites. Koppel got 21 percent of the vote in the five-person 1973 Democratic primary for the special election that put Mrs. Boggs into the House. Currently, there are 23 black members of the U.S. House.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Chief Had Record of Rankling Pentagon Brass
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Remarks about plans for possible U.S. air assaults on Iraq cost Gen. Michael J. Dugan his job as Air Force chief of staff, but the incident was not the first time the four-star general rankled his Pentagon bosses. Dugan, fired by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday, said in a statement that he regretted ``any embarrassment'' his comments caused the Bush administration. Cheney said Dugan, 53, would be forced to retire, ending a 32-year Air Force career that included a stint as commander of U.S. Air Forces in Europe. Several days after President Bush committed U.S. troops to Operation Desert Shield on Aug. 7 to deter a possible Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, Dugan was quoted in a published report as saying the United States had ruled out using chemical weapons or battlefield nuclear arms if fighting broke out with Iraq. That comment caused a stir in the Pentagon, where military authorities have been careful not to preclude any options in order to complicate Baghdad's planning. Dugan also had been the object of private complaints by U.S. commanders in Saudi Arabia. An aide to Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a reporter during Powell's visit to Saudi Arabia last week that Dugan was one of several military authorities who were talking too much in public about contingency plans. ``Saddam already has you guys giving away the store, we don't need to help him any more,'' the aide said, speaking privately. In explaining his decision to dump Dugan, Cheney told a Pentagon news conference that the Air Force chief displayed a ``lack of judgment'' by engaging publicly in ``wide-ranging speculation'' about U.S. military options in Iraq. Dugan was quoted by the Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post as saying the Joint Chiefs of Staff had decided that U.S. air power - including a massive bombing campaign against Baghdad that specifically targeted President Saddam Hussein - was the only effective way to force Iraq out of Kuwait if war erupted. ``If and when we choose violence he ought to be at the focus of our efforts,'' Dugan was quoted as saying, referring to a military strategy known as decapitation. Cheney said Dugan confirmed to him that he had made the comments, which were reported by the newspapers during Dugan's visit last week to U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. In his brief statement issued through the Air Force public affairs office at the Pentagon, Dugan said his comments to the Times and Post reflected his personal views and ``should not be construed to reflect any plans or the position'' of the Bush administration. ``I sincerely regret any embarrassment that my comments may have caused the administration,'' Dugan said. Officials in his Pentagon office said he was not available for further comment Monday. Cheney told reporters he would recommend to Bush that Gen. Merrill A. McPeak replace Dugan. McPeak, 54, is commander of Pacific Air Forces, based in Hawaii. Dugan took the top Air Force job in July and quickly gained a reputation for openness with the news media and Congress. One gesture that illustrated this departure from past Air Force practice was his decision to give defense reporters laminated cards listing his office phone number and the numbers of his chief aides. An Irishman with a breezy personal style, Dugan's attempts at openness were a clear departure from the practice of his predecessors. A small example of Dugan's approach was his recent insistence that his public affairs office respond immediately to a published report in which an airman in Saudi Arabia complained of a lack of gear designed to protect against chemical arms attacks. Cheney lauded Dugan's long Air Force career but said the four-star general has no future in the military. ``He will be retired,'' Cheney said. ``Gen. Dugan is a fine officer with an outstanding record of 32 years of service to the Air Force and to the nation,'' Cheney said. ``This was not a pleasant action for me to take but a necessary one.''

DOC.HEAD: President Heads Out On Behalf of GOP Candidates
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush leaves 9:55 a.m. EDT for Denver
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is embarking on a heavy campaign schedule for GOP candidates, and nowhere is his stumping as important to his party as in the California gubernatorial contest he visits this week. Bush hopes to raise at least $2 million in a trio of appearances devoted to helping Sen. Pete Wilson become the next California governor. Bush told a news conference Monday that he hopes he won't be drawn anew into a controversy over drilling off California's coast. ``I've got enough problems right here in Washington without commenting on a provision out there,'' Bush said when asked about a proposed state initiative - opposed by Wilson - to ban offshore drilling. Bush has imposed a 10-year moratorium on new drilling off California. ``If the question is put to me at a press conference, `Do you want to ban offshore drilling' the answer will be no,''' Bush continued. But, he said, if he were asked whether he should change his decision on the moratorium, ``I'll say, `No, I don't think I need to do that.''' Before flying to the West Coast today, Bush planned to stop in Denver en route to lend a hand in Rep. Hank Brown's bid for the U.S. Senate. The two-day trip is one of several campaign swings the White House has scheduled for Bush between now and the November election. From Denver today, he was heading to a $1,000-a-person fund-raising dinner in Los Angeles, to boost Wilson's campaign coffers. On Wednesday, Bush attends a breakfast for the California Republican Party before heading to San Francisco for a $1,000-a-ticket luncheon that also benefits the Wilson campaign. The California race pits Wilson, the state's low-key, two-term U.S. senator, against the Democratic nominee, former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. Bush's help with fund-raising is key in a race that is based mostly on expensive, dueling TV commercials. Wilson plans to spend more than $15 million to defeat Feinstein, campaign aides say. Beyond keeping control of the governor's seat in the nation's largest state, national strategists are pulling out all the stops in the campaign because of its implications in the future makeup of Congress. California will gain seven new seats in Congress in the 1991 redistricting because of its population growth which now gives it one-ninth of the nation's population. The process redraws congressional district lines based on population, and the boundaries can determine which party will win the district's House seat. With California's Democratic-controlled legislature in charge of approving the new district boundaries, only a gubernatorial veto gives the Republicans hope of staving off a Democratic windfall in congressional seats. ``It is the motherlode of congressional seats,'' said Ed Rogers, who heads the White House political office. Wilson's race, he said, ``is the number one target'' for the Republican Party. Recent polls have shown the race a virtual dead heat, although the Wilson camp says its polling shows the senator is inching ahead. Bush made a political trip to Calfornia in February and is expected to return again before election day. He was expected to tailor his remarks in Los Angeles and San Francisco to coordinate with Wilson's current campaign emphasis on crime issues. Wilson is airing two tough-on-crime commercials: one spotlighting his advocacy of legislation to treat drug-addicted mothers who give birth to so-called crack babies, and his work for a successful state anti-crime initiative. In Colorado, Brown had no primary opposition and faces Josie Heath, whose only background in elected office was as Boulder County commissioner. Still the Republicans are not taking the race for granted, GOP strategists say, and are focusing on keeping the state's non-aligned independent voters from gravitating toward Heath, who ran a strong campaign. Brown and Heath are vying to succeed retiring Sen. William Armstrong, one of three Republican senators stepping down nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Study Recommends Closer Look at Alternative ancer Treatments
DOC.TEXT: Federal researchers should be more open-minded about unconventional treatments that show some potential to help cancer patients, a four-year congressional study concludes. The study by the Office of Technology Assessment found that none of the alternative methods it reviewed - including psychological, nutritional and herbal remedies - was obviously or dramatically effective. But the report also said these treatments have had little, if any, scientific review, which leaves patients with no guidance if they want to supplement or replace their conventional treatment. ``It's very hard to get information beyond promotional brochures,'' said Roger C. Herdman, who supervised the report, which was released Monday. ``There isn't a lot in the peer-reviewed literature,'' where scientific findings are reported. Yet, thousands of cancer patients have turned to alternative treatments, most after undergoing at least some conventional treatment for their disease, the report said. ``It's worthwhile to give serious thought to unconventional approaches to serious diseases,'' Herdman said. ``We suggested a more systematic and more aggressive look be taken by some of the responsible agencies,'' including the National Cancer Institute, provided there was reason to believe the treatment could benefit patients, he said. The report urges researchers ``to take a sympathetic and thoughtful look at some of these treatments,'' he said. Officials at the National Cancer Institute had not seen the report and therefore could not comment on it, institute spokesman Paul Van Nevel said. The study was not intended to evaluate the effectiveness of alternative cancer treatments, but rather to help members of Congress deal with such issues as insurance reimbursement of cancer treatments and research and development funding. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, requested the review in August 1986. Dingell called the report ``balanced'' and said it ``tells us that some alternative approaches to cancer treatment can have both physiological and psychological benefits, which should not be ignored by physicians. ``It is clear we need better information on these treatments, and that the federal government should consider its role in that effort,'' he said. Proponents of unconventional treatments had been very critical of an earlier, draft version of the report. It was filled with errors and failed to fault the current system of evaluating these therapies, they said. However, after hearing reports about the final version, the criticism softened. The report recommends that more information be gathered on the types of patients who use unconventional treatments. It suggests the federal government could start a registry for documented reports of tumor regression that appears to be unrelated to conventional treatment. The government also could collect information on documented adverse reactions, the report said. The report also urged federal funding of efforts to evaluate unconventional treatments. Some methods have been studied, but overall these reviews ``generally have not been well designed and have not met with the approval of academic researchers,'' the report said. Currently, cancer treatments that are considered ``mainstream'' and are usually covered by medical insurance include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy and immunotherapy, which involves manipulating a patient's immune system to fight the cancer. The report said that based on the little information available, most of the patients who turn to an alternative treatment have had at least some conventional therapy. Many continue the mainstream approach while incorporating an alternative method, the report said. Major clinics that offer unconventional therapies charge in the range of $5,000 to $40,000 for a course of treatment, the report said. Among the alternatives reviewed, the report found that well-designed studies are beginning to look at the potential of psychological interventions, like mental imagery and meditation. It called the results so far ``encouraging,'' but said the value of these approaches remain uncertain. The report also reviews dietary treatments, mixtures of herbal products and such biologic agents as laetrile, which was popular in the 1970s and is currently offered by several clinics in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Dugan Said Publicly What Other Commanders Will Only Say Privately
DOC.TEXT: Much of what Air Force Gen. Michael J. Dugan said that got him fired is indeed part of U.S. contingency plans for war with Iraq - but Dugan was the only military leader who discussed the plans publicly in such detail. The sheer numbers of the Iraqi military make air power vital for the United States to defend Saudi Arabia and to launch any offensive attack, U.S.military leaders have made clear in recent weeks. Interviews with American commanders, Pentagon deployment announcements and other information released publicly have indicated that U.S. contingencies include massive air strikes against Iraqi military and political targets. U.S. commanders have said privately that the politics of the Middle East made it preferable that any attack on Iraq avoid damage to religious and cultural monuments, so that the United States would not destroy any chances of diplomatic relations with any Iraqi government after Saddam Hussein's. ``This is Saddam Hussein's war, not the Iraqi people's,'' a senior Army officer said recently. ``They should not be punished for his madness.'' But, until Dugan gave detailed interviews about what he said were Air Force plans if President Bush ordered an offensive action, any detailed picture of contingencies for bombing Iraq was available only by piecing together information from a number of sources. Dugan was fired Monday as commander of the Air Force by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who said Dugan was relieved for discussing classified ``operational matters'' in great detail. Dugan, in interviews with The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post, said Air Force contingencies included bombing places frequented by Saddam Hussein and his inner circle, as well as military and economic targets. From the early stages of the deployment the United States had announced it was sending massive air power to the region. Some commanders have been willing to discuss the plans for massive air strikes, although none in the detail provided by Dugan. The publicly announced deployments to the region included F-111 bombers, now stationed in Turkey and Saudi Arabia, the F-117 stealth fighter-bomber and long-range B-52 bombers. Aircraft carriers in the Red Sea and just outside the Persian Gulf carry A-6 bombers. A squadron commander aboard one carrier said two weeks ago his unit had been briefed on possible bombing runs against Iraqi targets. The United States also sent several AWACS planes to help Saudi AWACS maintain 24-hour patrols. A U.S. Air Force officer said the large deployment guaranteed there would be enough AWACS available to monitor enemy activity in the Middle East and to direct offensive air activities if ordered to do so. In public statements, military leaders including Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Colin L. Powell and Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, have said air power is the only way the U.S.-led force could defeat Iraq's million-man army without overwhelming casualties and extended fighting. The Iraqi army's strength in the Iran-Iraq war was holding defensive positions. ``We will not start a war but we will finish one quickly in the air,'' Air Force Col. John McBroom said shortly after the first U.S. forces arrived in Saudi Arabia. But when asked to be more specific, McBroom chose a different course than Dugan, responding, ``I'm not going to talk about that.'' Within two weeks of arriving on Saudi soil, according to military sources, some U.S. commanders were being briefed on potential Iraqi targets, including military bases, munitions factories, power plants and other facilities considered vital to supplying the Iraqi army in general and its occupation force in Kuwait in particular. A map shown to an Associated Press reporter about two weeks ago had numerous potential targets in Iraq circled, some as far north as Baghdad; others in areas closer to Kuwait and Iraq's border with Saudi Arabia. A handful of Iraqi military bases were among the potential targets, according to an officer who briefed a reporter on the condition of anonymity. The officer insisted the specific locations and names of targets not be identified. ``We will use our air superiority to knock out their fighters and then clear a path allowing us to take out their command and control operations and supply lines,'' one senior military commander in Saudi Arabia said privately last week. ``Then we will be able to string them out,'' the officer said. ``Without orders and supplies the greater numbers won't be of much use to Iraq's ground forces.''

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Businesses Go Bankrupt Near Iraqi Frontier
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ten years of boom times have suddenly gone bad along the dusty highway to Iraq. The U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Turkey's neighbor has struck a devastating blow along the road to the border, forcing hundreds of merchants to close their shops and seek jobs elsewhere, local officials say. ``The highway was all they had. Now, of course, they will go,'' said Neset Okten, mayor of Silopi. A string of small businesses, including bakeries, groceries and car repair shops, are now empty, forming an extended ghost town along the route. Silopi, nine miles west of the Iraqi border and neighboring Cizre, 18 miles farther west, are on the only highway linking Turkey with Iraq. In the past decade as Turkish trade with Iraq grew, these once-sleepy towns of a few thousand population each enjoyed a boom and populations swelled to 30,000 for Silopi and 70,000 for Cizre. About 5,000 trucks and oil tankers passed through the towns daily, local officials said. Last year, Turkey earned $480 million from transit fees. The highway is two lanes in the border area but is also part of the E-5 international highway that runs from Western Europe through Turkey to the Middle East. Most of the trucks carried goods for Iraq - food, machinery, even parts intended for an Iraqi supergun that Turkish officials managed to intercept. Moving in the other direction, tankers carried crude oil from Iraq to Turkey. The local people, selling spare car parts, food, drinks and other goods to the drivers, reaped profits from the heavy traffic. Now the road is empty, save for some passenger buses and Turkish military vehicles patrolling the border area for Kurdush guerrillas. Merchants' losses, while devastating to local economies, are believed to be only a fraction of the $4 billion Turkey says it is losing this year because it closed two Iraqi oil pipelines that run through the country and banned all trade with Iraq. Bags of sugar, spaghetti, flour and spices were piled up against a wall at Mehmet Emin's shop in Cizre's market place. ``I haven't sold anything today,'' he said. Emin said he used to gross $110 a day before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and set the Persian Gulf crisis in motion. ``Trucks don't drive by anymore,'' he said. ``There are no customers.'' Resul Akyurek, who sells sugar, cooking oil, tea, lollipops, chewing gum and even shoes, said his earnings are down to about $7 a day from about $185 before the crisis. ``I cannot even pay my rent now,'' he said. The troubles also hit Silopi, an ethnic Kurdish town through which tens of thousands fleeing Kuwait and Iraq, mostly Asians, have been crossing into Turkey. ``You are the only person who has entered my shop today,'' Salim Guntas, who sells clothing and shoes, told a reporter. At Habur, the border crossing post between Turkey and Iraq, one man kept watch over arrivals and offered about 20 cents per Kuwaiti dinar. The dinar was worth $3.80 before the Turkish Central Bank stopped accepting Kuwaiti and Iraqi currency. The arrivals, mostly Pakistanis in cars and on foot, were happy to get anything at all for the money. As he counted the bills in the stacks of dinars he had bought, the money changer explained that he would become rich one day if the Kuwaiti dinar rose to its old value.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Promises to Put Schools First
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein promises that as governor she would uphold the provisions of a school financing initiative that Gov. George Deukmejian and others say contributed greatly to the state budget crisis. Democrat Feinstein said Monday she is committed ``to the carrying out of the spirit, the letter and the intent of Proposition 98'' and pledged to make education her top priority at budget time. ``No matter what, schools, aren't going to be shorted,'' Feinstein said. ``No matter what, schools, for the reason of survival of our people, have to be No. 1 among those budget priorities.'' By putting schools first, Feinstein drew a distinction between her agenda and that of Republican challenger Pete Wilson. The U.S. senator says public safety is his No. 1 priority, perhaps even at the expense of education. Wilson also says that in reaching budget reform, the state may have to rethink Proposition 98, which voters approved in November 1988. The measure inserted financial protection for schools into the state constitution.
DOC.HEAD: Crump Wants Name Removed From November Ballot
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. Dewey Crump, convicted last week on three felony drug charges, said he has asked the Missouri Democratic Party to do whatever it can to get his name off the November ballot. ``I believe my constituents are entitled to be represented by someone who is not the subject of such notoriety as I have experienced,'' Crump, D-Maryland Heights, said in a statement released Monday. ``Because in my professional life I have always tried to represent the people I have served to the best of my abilities, I believe that my recent personal problems would impair my capability to be the effective state legislator these citizens deserve,'' the 43-year-old lawmaker added. Republican Mark Holloway is on the Nov. 6 ballot for Crump's seat. Last Thursday, Democrat Robert Weatherly filed as a write-in candidate for the seat. State election officials said the deadline for Crump to get his name off the general election ballot was last Tuesday and that only death or disqualification could remove the lawmaker's name.
DOC.HEAD: Racing Groups Could `Own' State Government; Loftus
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's campaign has engaged in a ``systematic shakedown'' of racing interests while amassing a $4.6 million treasury, says his Democratic opponent for governor. The comment Monday by state Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus came after The Milwaukee Journal reported that dog racing interests had donated at least $286,00 to Thompson's campaign.
