Thompson's top adviser, Administration Secretary James Klauser, says Loftus' use of the word ``shakedown'' was a ``dishonest characterization in an effort to smear (Thompson) through innuendo.'' Scott Jensen, director of the governor's campaign, assailed the Loftus camp for hiring David Fechheimer, a San Francisco investigator, to review state Racing Board records. Michele Carrier, the top Loftus adviser, said Fechheimer was hired because of his experience in dealing with financial investigations and the racing industry. At a news conference, Loftus questioned why a Florida family seeking a track license would hire attorney Michael Grebe, chairman of the Republican Party of Wisconsin, to represent it. ``I think it has more to do with his position as Tommy Thompson's hand-picked chairman of the Republican Party and the influence he has with the governor than with his legal expertise,'' Loftus said.

DOC.HEAD: `Postcards' Sends No. 1 Greetings From Box-Office
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Postcards From the Edge'' put its stamp on the No. 1 spot at the box office over the weekend, while ``Ghost'' hovered in second place. ``Postcards,'' starring Meryl Streep and Shirley MacLaine as a drug-addicted actress and her hard-drinking mother, took in $7.9 million in its debut. The movie is based on the vaguely autobiographical novel by Carrie Fisher. ``Ghost,'' a quirky romance that beat out the guns-and-guts blockbusters as the summer's top-grossing film, sold $5.9 million in tickets, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The film has topped $141 million in 10 weeks of release. ``Death Warrant,'' starring kickboxer Jean-Claude Van Damme, was third. It made $5 million in its debut weekend. The courtroom thriller ``Presumed Innocent'' was fourth with $2.7 million. In limited release, the gangster film ``State of Grace'' made $179,927 on 14 screens, and Clint Eastwood's ``White Hunter, Black Heart'' grossed $165,450 in 24 theaters. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Postcards From the Edge,'' Columbia, $7.9 million, 1,013 screens, $7,771 per screen, $8 million, one week. 2. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $5.9 million, 1,756 screens, $3,337 per screen, $141.4 million, 10 weeks. 3. ``Death Warrant,'' MGM-UA, $5 million, 1,089 screens, $4,610 per screen, $5 million, one week. 4. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $2.7 million, 1,410 screens, $1,928 per screen, $75.7 million, eight weeks. 5. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $2.6 million, 1,483 screens, $1,784 per screen, $48.1 million, six weeks. 6. ``Hardware,'' Millimeter, $2.3 million, 692 screens, $3,324 per screen, $2.3 million, one week. 7. ``Darkman,'' Universal, $2.1 million, 1,668 screens, $1,445 per screen, $28.2 million, four weeks. 8. ``Men at Work,'' Epic-Triumph, $1.4 million, 1,035 screens, $1,312 per screen, $11.9 million, four weeks. 9. ``Young Guns II,'' 20th Century Fox, $1.2 million, 1,192 screens, $970 per screen, $37.9 million, seven weeks. 10. ``Problem Child,'' Universal, $1.1 million, 899 screens, $1,215 per screen, $45.9 million, eight weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Children: Innocent Smiles, Violent Images
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Abdullah Al Shabnan, smiling the smile of a 12-year-old, holds in his hand an image of war. Abdullah's drawing shows Saddam Hussein, a skull and bones insignia on his beret, a bloody knife in his hand. ``He will die. He will not live,'' Abdullah tells a visitor, speaking slowly and deliberately, still smiling. ``If I have to, I will go and fight.'' Abdullah should be in school back in Kuwait, but he lives these days as a refugee in a Saudi hotel, spending most of the day playing in the halls. For two hours each day, he gathers with other Kuwaiti children for a makeshift lesson. During a break, they gather on the floor around a table, joking among themselves as they reach for paper and crayons, rolling on the floor and running in circles. The art they produce is disturbing - dominated by violence, tanks, blood and destruction. ``Of course it bothers us,'' says Khadija, one of the Kuwaiti women who supervise the children. ``They are children, they should not have these feelings. But these memories will never go out of their minds.'' Khadija, who did not want her family name published because she fears for relatives still in Kuwait, said the children are not told what to draw. However, in daily lectures to the children women denounce Saddam and Iraq for invading Kuwait. The talks refer to Saddam as a killer, madman and thief. The children's art is full of the same message. Alah, like Abdullah, is 12 and should be in her first week in the sixth grade, learning English, science, math and other subjects. She pauses, darting her eyes around the room at the drawings on the wall, when asked if she enjoys living in a hotel. ``I want to go home,'' she says, ``to Kuwait.'' Her latest drawing shows a mosque. It also shows tanks rolling down a street, with bursts of smoke coming from the guns, and Saddam's head on the body of what Alah says is a wolf. ``Because he conquered Kuwait,'' is her answer when asked why she likens Saddam to a wolf. ``He is a bad man who has stolen Kuwait.'' She is grinning broadly and tugging at the dress of a friend when asked what she wants Saddam to do next. ``To die,'' she says. Alah was on vacation in Turkey when Iraq invaded her country six weeks ago. Her father, brother and sister are still there. She shrugs when asked if she thinks they are safe. A friend, 11-year-old Shaimaa, takes a visitor by the hand and shows her a drawing. It depicts a sword drawn in the colors of the Kuwaiti flag decapitating Saddam. ``The friends of Kuwait will cut his head off,'' she says. Does she expect to go home? ``Sure,'' she says. ``When Saddam dies, I will go back.''

DOC.HEAD: `Gumby'-Shaped Set of Valleys Seen in Magellan's New Venus Pictures
LaserPhotos LA16 and LA17 of Sept. 17
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A set of valleys said to resemble the animated character Gumby and a meteorite impact crater unlike any other seen in the solar system are visible in the Magellan spacecraft's newest pictures of Venus. The computer-assembled pictures, released by NASA Monday, were made from data Magellan collected Saturday as it started its 243-day mission to peer through the planet's thick clouds and map its rugged landscape. ``It's just excitement time. The scientists are in there like bees to honey,'' said Ed Sherry, a Magellan technical assistant at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. One picture shows a 40-mile-long set of valleys or troughs. ``It's a feature we nicknamed Gumby,'' said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist, referring to the animated clay figure from a children's TV show of the 1950s. Two valleys, each about three miles wide, look like Gumby's legs. The north end of the two valleys converge into a single trough, resembling Gumby's upper body. And the trough ends in a box canyon that looks a bit like Gumby's head. The Gumby-like feature probably formed when underground molten rock flowed out of the area, causing the ground above to collapse along fault lines and create the valleys, Saunders said. Similar features have been seen on Mars, he said. Another picture released Monday shows a meteorite impact crater about five miles wide and seven miles long. Large lobes of material ejected by the impact are visible north, south and east of the crater. That means the crater was formed when a meteorite slammed into Venus at a low angle, rather than from directly above, Saunders said. Shaped like a kidney, it is unlike any other impact crater seen in the solar system, NASA said. A possible explanation for the strange shape is that the meteorite broke into several large chunks just before it hit, Saunders said. Magellan, which was launched from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, was to have formally begun its $744 million mapping mission on Aug. 29, almost three weeks after it went into orbit around Venus. But engineers temporarily lost radio contact with the spacecraft on Aug. 16 and again Aug. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Montana is Proud of its Tyrannosaurus Rex
DOC.TEXT: When trucker Bill McKamey heard that Montana's Museum of the Rockies had found a Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton, he offered to make his vehicle and services available any time, anywhere. ``How many times in your life do you haul a dinosaur?'' he asked. The fossil T-rex found in the badlands of eastern Montana is the largest and most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus ever discovered. It also is the first of four T-rex skeletons discovered in Montana that will be staying here. That has become a source of pride for people in Montana. McKamey, for example, was one of scores of volunteers who helped bring the fossil of the meat-eating beast from its 65 million-year-old bed in the dry, rugged territory around the Missouri River to the display room in Bozeman. Although the Tyrannosaurus is the best known dinosaur, only eight have been found - four in Montana, two in Canada and one each in South Dakota and Wyoming. While Montana may be the most fertile hunting ground for the T-rex, none of the fossils has stayed in the state. ``Until this, I didn't realize how many people were upset about fossils going out of state,'' said Pat Leiggi, chief preparator of paleontology for the museum. ``A lot of people told me they had a ranch here and there, and certain people would come and take fossils out and they never heard about them again.'' He said that until the Museum of the Rockies opened its paleontology department eight years ago, the state had no facility to research the fossils. Now the museum has one of the largest palentology departments in the country, and it has more of a say. ``Now, we know who's doing what,'' he said. ``Montana is in this network of paleontology departments.'' The Tyrannosarus rex was the largest carnivore ever to walk the Earth. It grew to 35 to 40 feet long and up to 12 feet high, with teeth 6 inches long. Museum staffers dug up the 90 percent complete skeleton over four weeks this summer on federal land near the small farming town of Circle. Army Corps of Engineer engineers built a dirt road into the remote site and helped load the seven tons of fossils onto trucks. McKamey was waiting nearby with a flatbed truck and hauled the bones nearly 400 miles to the museum at Montana State University. The fossils, packed in plaster and caked with rock and hardened mud, then had to be unloaded, weighed and set up for display. But the museum worried that the floor wouldn't be able to support the 3{-ton pelvic section. ``We had a reporter in here and he wrote about it, and the next morning, we got a whole bunch of calls, saying, `What do you need?' It sure made my life easier,'' Leiggi said. Two state workers helped weigh the pieces, an architect volunteered to examine the floor, a rental firm loaned dollies, a construction company loaned a forklift and a driver, and a concrete casting firm brought in a crane. ``We read a little blurb in the newspaper that they needed to turn (the pelvis) over and that the largest forklift couldn't do it,'' said Steve Anderson of Bozeman, who operated the crane. ``So I called them and talked to them. ... It was a chance to see something really rare.'' Eventually, the floor was reinforced. Museum visitors can watch staffers cleaning and preparing the bones in a display room, a process that will take many months. The museum may eventually erect a mold of the skeleton or exhibit the bones themselves. The skeleton was discovered almost two years ago by two amateur fossil collectors, Tom and Kathy Wankel of Angela. Leiggi said a call came from the front desk of the museum that someone had some fossils they wanted identified. ``People ask us to identify bones all the time,'' he said. ``To me it was just another bunch of people who wanted me to look at their bones.'' But when curator and chief paleontologist Jack Horner confirmed that the Wankels had found the arm and hand of a Tyrannosaurus, ``our eyes were just popping out of our head,'' Leiggi said. Since the story broke nearly a year ago, reporters, scientists and dinosaur enthusiasts from around the world have focused their attention on Montana. ``When you find a T-rex, it turns out to be an overnight success internationally,'' Leiggi said. ``I never expected this.''

DOC.HEAD: Gen. Mike Dugan - Blunt, Frank, Fired
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf pvs, bgng: ``Dugan and...'' to correct spelling of daughter Colleen's name; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Mike Dugan's bluntness was apparent from the day he testified before a Senate committee judging his nomination as Air Force chief of staff. In the three months since, his plain spoken ways became even more obvious. On Monday, Dugan was fired by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for his frank description of U.S. strategic planning in the Mideast. In an interview published a day earlier in The Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times, Dugan said the military had contingency plans to ``decapitate'' the Iraqi leadership by targeting President Saddam Hussein, his family and even his mistress. President Bush's national security adviser immediately disavowed the statement. Cheney consulted with President Bush about firing Dugan and, by noon Monday, the 53-year-old, decorated ex-fighter pilot was history. His bluntness was apparent in June, when Dugan, then Air Force commander in Europe, testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee. He told the panel that as the service's European commander, ``I have been at the `front line' of change and have had the opportunity to witness and, in some regards, manage its initial impact on the United States Air Force.'' The overriding question among lawmakers was the word from the Pentagon that the Air Force had proposed to Cheney that the modernization of land-based missiles be delayed. Asked if the service had made the recommendation, Dugan replied: ``I understand that. I accept that, approve that and I support that. One needs to look at affordability issues in every regard.'' Dugan made it clear that the Air Force's No. 1 priority was the B-2 stealth bomber and that plans to build the single-warhead Midgetman missile and move the multiple-warhead MX missile from silos to rail cars could wait. In crafting its defense budget, the Senate responded to the signal from the Air Force, eliminating $1.6 billion in procurement money for the MX rail-garrison missile program. Shortly after taking over from Gen. Larry Welch on July 1, Dugan began an aggressive campaign to meet with reporters, giving reporters laminated cards listing his office phone number and the numbers of his chief aides. And he was quotable. On Sept. 14, he told reporters in Saudi Arabia that the United States had two possible courses of action, ``patience and sweat or ... violence and blood.'' He added: ``If there's any culture in the world that's impatient, it's mine, it's the United States.'' Asked at another time about Soviet military advisers still in Iraq despite the United Nations embargo on trade with Saddam's regime, Dugan said flippantly that he was ``more or less satisfied that the Soviets have decided they are on the same side as us.'' For weeks, commanders in Saudi Arabia criticized Dugan for his open assessment of U.S. military capabilities. By last week, even aides to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell, were saying that Dugan was among several military officers who were talking too much about U.S. plans. ``Saddam already has you guys giving away the store,'' one aide told reporters. ``We don't need to help him any more.'' Dugan, a graduate of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, flew more than 300 combat missions during the Vietnam war. He logged 4,500 flying hours. Among his decorations: The Distinguished Service Medal, Silver Star, Purple Heart, Distinguished Flying Cross and the Republic of Vietnam Gallantry Cross with Palm. Dugan and his wife, Grace Ann have six children. Two - daughters Colleen and Erin - are Air Force captains.

DOC.HEAD: Runaway Killed by Unknown Gunman is Buried
DOC.TEXT: Heather Anderson was buried in a pauper's grave under marker 609 in the city cemetery, laid to rest with her stuffed animals as tokens of the childhood the 16-year-old never had. Heather, a runaway who didn't run far, lived and died on the streets of this industrial city of 100,000 south of Boston where homicides are rare. A week ago, an unseen assailant sprayed gunfire at the teen-ager, her boyfriend and his roommate as they sat on a wall outside a row of stores. She died in surgery, an artery in her abdomen severed by a .22-caliber slug. Heather, who since age 7 had lived in a successsion of foster homes here but had been a runaway for nearly a year, was one of those street children who didn't seem to belong anywhere or to anyone. But at her graveside Friday, it was clear there were many who cared. One of her foster mothers, Mary Hatfield, dedicated a poem to her: ``How shall we explain the life that slips away like shadows fading into the black of night? She is not unrecognized. She will not be unremembered.'' Hatfield remembered Heather as both charming and difficult. ``She was starved for affection. She never knew the potential she had. She always had to ask, `Do you like me? Am I pretty?' '' she said. ``Heather had been without her family since she was 7,'' said Heather's aunt, Suzanne Gonsalves. ``She was left at a very early age. ... It's hard to be a teen-ager when you never got to be a child.'' In a eulogy, the Rev. Jeanne Bell said, ``We are overwhelmed by the tragedy of her violent and cruel death at 16. We think of her as loving animals and babies. We think of her with a good sense of humor and a winsome smile.'' Authorities would not disclose details about Heather's family history and how she ended up in foster care. Her friends said she was tough and self-reliant - or at least seemed that way. Social workers who tried to help said they were limited by Heather's resistance. ``It's very difficult when a child runs away from a system that is trying to help,'' said Lorraine Carli, spokeswoman for the state Department of Social Services. ``It's hard to deal with adolescents. You can't hold them down in one place.'' The killing remained a mystery. Police have so far drawn a blank on suspects. Heather was talking with her boyfriend, Jose ``Tony'' Pena, 19, and his roommate, Gary ``Danny'' Nelson, 26, when someone fired seven shots in their direction, hitting all of them. Heather stumbled across the street to a friend's house. ``She ran down my driveway,'' said Sara Fonseca. ``She tried to climb the back stairs but fell.'' As she lay dying, Fonseca said, ``she wanted to tell me something. She wanted to tell me who did it but she couldn't breathe.'' ``She had a rough life,'' Fonseca said. ``She always tried to make jokes about it, and laugh about it, but it really hurt her inside. All she wanted was for somebody to love her.'' The two men are recovering from their wounds. ``As far as I know, we don't know right now whether it was a drive-by or if someone walked up to them and shot them,'' said Sgt. Joe Silver. It was the city's second homicide this year. Another friend, Laurie Buckley, said Heather was attacked and beaten with a jagged beer can by two women last month and spent three days in Brockton Hospital. Police said they had no information about that incident. Heather's foster sister, Judy Darling, said, ``She was a happy person, she did have a lot on her mind. I've seen kids come and go. She was one that just stuck in my head. ``Heather was trying to get her life straightened out. She wanted to. She really wanted to.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Proposes More Reliance on Meat Packers in Beef Inspections
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department says it may be ready to put into use within two years a controversial proposal to streamline beef inspections, including the notion of putting greater reliance on packing companies. Officials hailed a report by the National Academy of Sciences as an important step in the development of the experimental inspection system for cattle slaughter plants. The academy's report generally supported adoption of the Streamlined Inspection System for cattle - called SIS-C - but had some important qualifications for its approval. For example, the report said, if the department does rely more heavily on private industry to maintain meat quality, the agency should ``concentrate its resources on safety'' to guard consumers against microbial and chemical contamination. ``The federal government should design its inspection programs to focus on contemporary health issues,'' the report said. ``It should insist that industry comply with policies and procedures required to protect public health and foster public confidence in the safety of the food supply.'' Although supporting the speeded-up inspection system for cattle, the report said the Food Safety and Inspection Service should develop methods for quickly testing carcasses for microbial and chemical contamination. The SIS-C plan was studied by a panel of the academy's Institute of Medicine under a $154,000 grant from the department. ``From a food safety viewpoint, SIS-C alone is probably no better, and in some situations can be less effective, than traditional inspection because the reduced oversight by government inspectors is not compensated by a total commitment to product quality on the part of the industry,'' the report said. But the report also called the streamlined system ``the most important change in bovine meat inspection'' since federal supervision was begun in 1906. ``For this system to work in practice, both FSIS and industry must fully endorse the philosophy of shifting responsibility for meat quality from FSIS to industry so that the government can concentrate on safety,'' the report said. The plan was officially proposed in November 1988. USDA spokesman Jim Greene said an amended proposal probably would be made based on the new study. Greene said the department plans to begin using the revised system within two years, but only in plants that slaughter ``fed'' cattle for the slaughter market. These cattle are mostly grain-fattened steers and heifers from feedlots. The report said about 80 of the nation's more than 1,300 USDA-inspected cattle slaughter plants would be eligible to use the system. Those account for an estimated 80 percent of the fed cattle slaughtered for the consumer market. Lester M. Crawford, FSIS administrator, said the 11-month study by the scientific panel ``confirms our ongoing commitment to modernize inspection at cattle slaughter plants is on solid footing.'' Crawford said the report shows the experts agree the proposed system ``is a single, successful step'' toward an optimal scientific inspection program that was envisioned by the academy in a 1985 report to the agency. Under traditional inspections, federal inspectors check bile ducts, heart, cheek muscles and numerous lymph nodes for disease and other abnormalities. They also are responsible for condemnation and disposition of diseased carcasses, as well as supervising the trimming of undesirable parts. But under SIS-C, plant employees would incise heart and cheek muscles, position parts for inspectors and assume responsibility for some trimming. Inspectors still would be responsible for condemnation and disposition of diseased carcasses, and still would examine every head, viscera and carcass. The streamlined inspection system is currently used experimentally in five meat plants using high-speed techniques to slaughter steers and heifers for the beef market. Agency officials said those include two Montfort plants, in Greeley, Colo., and Grand Island, Neb.; two Excel plants, in Friona and Plainview, Texas; and a National Beef plant in Liberal, Kan. The industry's American Meat Institute called the report ``an objective assessment'' of the new inspection program and said it may help to end the controversy over the merits of SIS-C. Tom Devine of the consumer-oriented Government Accountability Project, which has helped federal whistleblowers to criticize USDA inspection operations, said he was ``delighted'' by the report. ``It's a gratifying vindication for the concerns raised by whistleblowers'' who as USDA inspectors alleged there have been many slipshod, unsanitary practices in plants where the new system has been used, he said. Park Wilde of the Community Nutrition Institute, another advocacy group, said he had reservations about the academy committee's conclusions. ``The report was produced in a secretive manner, shutting out the concerns of consumer groups and the inspectors themselves,'' he said. Further, Wilde said a lot of the report's information about the suitability of SIS-C came from the department's inspection agency itself. Some of that, he said, included data that consumer advocates had requested but had not been able to obtain from the agency. Under such circumstances, he said, the report's ``conclusions have to be (considered) a charade.''

DOC.HEAD: Economists Expect Gulf Crisis Caused Inflation to Double in August
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led with 8:30 a.m. EDT release of report
DOC.TEXT: The turmoil in the Persian Gulf is hitting American consumers where it hurts - in their wallets. Energy prices began soaring immediately after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, crimping consumers' power to purchase other items and threatening to topple the nation into a recession. The government is scheduled today to release its first assessment of the inflationary damage at the retail level, where it counts for consumers. In advance, most economists were predicting the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index soared 0.8 percent in August, double the 0.4 percent rise in July. That's the equivalent of a 10 percent annual inflation rate and would be the steepest monthly increase since January when a cold snap sent fuel oil and vegetable prices skyrocketing and produced a 1.1 percent overall price rise. In a report last week, the department said wholesale prices paid to producers such as factories and farmers jumped 1.3 percent, the steepest rise in seven months. Georgia State University economist Donald Ratajczak, who conducts his own inflation surveys, was predicting about two-thirds of the August consumer price rise would be attributed to energy. He forecast a gasoline hike of 17 percent and a fuel oil rise of 26 percent. Analysts are divided over how long the inflation jolt will last. Some are predicting the bad news will continue for months as the inflation works its way into chemicals, plastics and other petroleum-based products. By the end of 1990, the inflation rate for the year will register at around 6 percent, Ratajczak predicted up significantly from the 5 percent expected before the invasion and from the 4.6 percent recorded in 1989. Others, however, believe the pain will be relatively short-lived. They say economic growth is too weak to support an inflationary spiral. ``The inflation climate will remain unpleasant for the next several months,'' economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said in a recent newsletter. But ``the economy is extremely weak, possibly recessionary. Within a year, the inflation rate is likely to be lower than it was just prior to the oil shock.''

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Voters Consider Limiting State Lawmakers' Terms
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma voters decide today whether to limit state lawmakers' terms, something no state ever has done. The proposed constitutional amendment would put a 12-year cap on service by members of the state House or Senate. Supporters argued it would keep incumbents from becoming so entrenched they no longer worked for the people. Opponents contended passage would concentrate power in the hands of non-elected career bureaucrats and lobbyists. Oklahoma is the first state to bring such a proposal to the ballot, said the National Council of State Legislators. Colorado and California will vote on similar proposals Nov. 6. Similar legislation has been introduced in Florida and New York. There have been no limits on the terms of state or federal lawmakers since the Constitution superseded the Articles of Confederation, which had limited House terms to three years out of every six. The Oklahoma proposal got on the ballot through an initiative petition circulated by Tulsa businessman Lloyd Noble II. He argued that legislators are so concerned about getting re-elected they ignore important matters, like waste in government. ``All our legislators talk about cutting waste, but they don't cut any waste that gets them elected,'' Noble said. Opponents said voters already can limit lawmakers' terms - by not re-electing them. ``I just basically hate to see any deterioration of the right of the voters to decide his or her own representatives,'' said Senate President Pro Tem Bob Cullison. Other opponents noted that only 16 members of the 48-member Senate and 14 of the 101 House members had 12 or more years of service when the 1990 Legislature adjourned. Legislators now in office would be allowed to serve 12 more years. The ballot measure also provided that the constitutional provision would not go into effect until Jan. 1. Although legislators elected this year will take office in November, Noble said he believes the 12-year limit would apply to them.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Weakened Economy Could Shrink Expected Growth in Trade Deficit
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be led with report at 8:30 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The weakening U.S. economy ironically could help soften the expected balloon in the nation's merchandise trade deficit brought on by the oil-price shock of the Persian Gulf crisis, analysts say. The price of oil has soared since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, driving up America's energy bill. The United States imports about 50 percent of its oil consumption. But while oil prices are rising, the U.S. economy is slowing, draining the amount of money consumers have to spend on cars made in Japan and computers shipped from South Korea. The deficit is the difference between imports and exports. Thus, trade deficit relief might be in the offing. Oil prices were rising even before the Iraqi invasion, however, and analysts were looking for today's Commerce Department report on merchandise trade to see what effect it had on the July deficit. Many analysts thought it would top $7 billion. The deficit totaled $5.07 billion in June, the lowest since June 1983 when it fell to $3.96 billion. ``Higher July imported crude oil prices ... are likely to boost the oil deficit by about $500 million,'' economists at Mitsubishi Bank wrote in their current Weekly Economic Indicator Report. Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said oil prices rose between $2 and $3 in July to about $17 a barrel. They had averaged $14.64 a barrel in June. Meanwhile, the U.S. economy is slumping, with growth in the first half of the year down to an annual rate of 1.2 percent from 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. Many analysts expect the business cycle to slide into a recession by the fourth quarter of this year - if it is not already experiencing one. And as the economy grows more sluggish, consumers are growing more reluctant to spend - not only on American-made goods but on items imported from overseas as well. ``If you look at imports of other commodities (other than energy), I would expect them to be fairly weak,'' said economist Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. ``That should hold (overall) imports down.'' For the first six months of 1990, the deficit averaged $7.64 billion a month, compared to $9.12 billion in 1989. And before Kuwait, many analysts and government officials were predicting the deficit would total less than $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. Whether that goal can be attained now is questionable. ``Unless we have a recession that really is pretty nasty cropping up, I wouldn't expect imports to fall sharply enough to allow us to get anywhere close to that number,'' said Robert Brusca, chief financial economist with Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York. At the same time, the United States ``will see a slowdown in export growth because economic conditions are deteriorating overseas,'' added Lawrence Chimerine, senior fellow at the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research organization.

DOC.HEAD: Pow! Another Pair of Shotgun Wash Jeans Rolls Off the Assembly Line
LaserPhoto NS1 of Sept. 16
DOC.TEXT: The targets lay spread-eagle on a mound of dirt. Sheldon Smith leveled his 12-gauge shotgun and gleefully pumped away, aiming mainly for the knees and ankles. When the smoke cleared, another set of blue jeans lay crumpled on the chewed-up embankment, riddled with holes. The 24-year-old Smith is a clothing designer. He sells Shotgun Wash Jeans and is making a fortune. His Jensen-Smith company is expected to gross more than $1 million this year, selling shotgun-ventilated jeans for $60 a pop. The tiny Chattanooga company made a flashy debut nearly three years ago with a line of snakeskin-and-denim jackets. ``Part of the image we portray is real bold,'' he said. ``It's almost reckless, like we'll do anything in jeanswear. We got that attitude when we started in the Western business, because they all thought we were crazy. ``From that time on, we've kind of kept on shaking people up with crazy things,'' he said. Which is why Smith and a couple of employees, loaded down with shotguns and boxes of blue jeans, recently traveled to a shooting range on Mowbray Mountain north of Chattanooga. ``You guys shoot the knees and ankles. I'll get the rest,'' Smith said as jeans were spread two-deep on the embankment. He advised them about different techniques. Stand close, and you make a nice, solid hole. A few paces back, and the result is an equally pleasing spray pattern. ``If one little pellet hits the zipper, it'll ruin them,'' he warned. ``Remember, knees and ankles. No crotches or butts.'' Once the bright new blue jeans are blasted, they are bleached and washed until they fray. An empty shotgun shell is added as a tag. Smith got the idea after his brother-in-law was wounded in the hip during a hunting accident. ``He was fine, but he had a hole in his jeans. My sister would always show people, and they were fascinated by them,'' he said. Sales have been good since Jensen-Smith began marketing the ventilated jeans about three months ago, even though it's mostly a gag on the current popularity of ripped denim. ``We want to have fun with it for a while, make a statement and let it run its course, then get back to our normal business - which is still not real normal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Tanks Aim at Kuwait Embassy; Puppet Government Disappears
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT typo in `emirate' SUB 5th graf, `Even the ... an interview.' Picks up 6th, ```They've gone ...' ^By NABILA MEGALLI
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi army has set up camp around the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, and tanks have their cannons pointed at the embassy premises and the nearby Egyptian mission, says a Kuwaiti who has just fled his homeland. The man, his wife, and four sons were among the first to cross into Saudi Arabia at Khafji. The only border crossing between Kuwaiti and Saudi territory, it was opened on Saturday for the first time in a month. The man would be identified only as a state technocrat, fearing reprisals against relatives he left behind. He said the Iraqis are rapidly changing the face of Kuwait, which Iraq's Saddam Hussein annexed after his troops seized it on Aug. 2, renaming streets and buildings. The Kuwaiti government-in-exile says Saddam is trying to depopulate the captive nation and move in Iraqis. Even the nine-member puppet government the Iraqis installed in the oil-rich emirate shortly after the invasion has disappeared, the man said in an interview. ``They've gone with the wind. I heard they hanged Alaa.'' He was referring to Col. Alaa Hussein Ali, the puppet government's prime minister. Alaa was last seen by the Kuwaitis via television about a week after the invasion, being received by Saddam in Baghdad. The man said the Iraqi occupation forces were out ``to demolish anything that has to do with Kuwait or anything to do with ruling (al-Sabah) family.'' They pull down street signs as they did on King Khaled Street, which they renamed Fao Street, he said. The al-Sabah Hospital was renamed Saddam Hospital. The traffic circle in Kuwait City opposite the Sheraton Hotel was being dismantled by the Iraqis, who were preparing to put up a life-size statue of Saddam in its place. the man said. ``It is all becoming Iraqi,'' he said, estimating that only 300,000 Kuwaiti nationals remain behind, with about half a million having fled. He said those remaining behind from the estimated 1 million expatriates were mainly Palestinians, with some cooperating with the Iraqis but some hostile to them. ``The Palestinians are split among themselves,'' he said. The man described an armed camp in the embassy district, where diplomats from more than a dozen countries including the United States, Britain and Egypt are defying an order by Saddam to leave. ``I saw the American Embassy surrounded by the army. Tanks are around most embassies, including the Egyptian and American, with turrets and cannons pointed at the embassies,'' he said. ``I do not know what is happening inside the embassies, but at the American Embassy the Iraqis are not allowing anyone in or out, there is only a one-way man-made path that they control.'' The man described Kuwait City as a ``ghost city, especially after dark,'' but said had wanted to stay on ``because it is my home.'' Then he heard that the Khafji border crossing was to be opened and decided to try his luck. He said Iraqi soldiers had broken into his 65-year-old aunt's home and searched it while she was on ground in Moslem prayer. He said he had been bombarded by tales from relatives and acquaintances about the Iraqis raping women and burning down the houses of those they suspected of involvement in the resistance. ``I want the world to know that the Iraqis threatened to take my 9-month-old baby boy from the lap of his mother at the border post if we would not give them our passports, all our identification papers including car registration,'' said the man. ``They insisted they take every document, anything that bears the name of Kuwait,'' he said. But he also suspected they could be using those papers to disguise Iraqis for sabotage in various countries. ``The world has to wake up,'' his wife said, almost screaming. ``Military buildup for what if they don't strike at Saddam Hussein.'' ``The soldier was pulling my baby from the head and I was pulling him from the bottom, screaming and crying, his three brothers in the car also screaming,'' she said. She said first they asked whether the baby was a boy or a girl and when she said boy, one replied: `we have orders to take away all Kuwaiti boys.'' Others among the thousands of Kuwaitis who fled their homeland through the Khafji border crossing after was opened on Saturday said the Iraqis were rounding up men between the ages of 17 and 35 who were trying to leave.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Could a generous donation from Bill Cosby be enough to stave off bankruptcy for his hometown of Philadelphia? Mayor W. Wilson Goode is open to offers from the world's highest paid entertainer. ``Maybe the answer to this problem really is to have Bill Cosby come here and just give us his salary for the next five years and we could bail our way out of this problem,'' Goode joked in an interview Monday on the Financial News Network. He was responding to a remark by the interviewer, who said the city's newspapers gave ``bigger play to Bill Cosby's salary than the problems of Philadelphia.'' On Monday, Cosby topped Forbes' list of the world's 40 richest entertainers with two-year earnings projected at $115 million Philadelphia projects a $206 million deficit in its $2.1 billion budget by June, and several banks have refused to guarantee more borrowing by the city. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Ol' Blue Eyes is miffed. Now that George Michael has made it to the top, Frank Sinatra says, he shouldn't squander his talent by withdrawing from public view. ``Come on, George. Loosen up. Swing, man,'' Sinatra wrote in a letter to the Los Angeles Times a week after the newspaper featured a complaining Michael. ``Here's a kid who `wanted to be a pop star since I was about 7 years old,' '' Sinatra wrote. ``And now that he's a smash performer and songwriter at 27, he wants to quit doing what tons of gifted youngsters all over the world would shoot Grandma for - just one crack at what he's complaining about.'' In an interview, Michael said he was releasing his new album without promotional videos or a concert tour and planned to keep out of public view to reduce the strain of his celebrity status. ``Those who who have talent must hug it, embrace it, nurture it and share it lest it be taken away from you as fast as it was loaned to you,'' wrote Sinatra, who will be 75 on Dec. 12. ``Trust me. I've been there.'' --- BOSTON (AP) - The case of Charles Stuart, who allegedly shot his pregnant wife, summoned police to the scene over his car phone and later killed himself, is the subject of a TV movie starring ``thirtysomething'' actor Ken Olin. ``Good Night Sweet Wife: A Murder in Boston,'' will be broadcast Sept. 25 on CBS. The movie was produced in association with Arnold Shapiro, who was taping a segment of the show ``Rescue 911'' in Boston when Carol Start was slain Oct. 30. Public interest in the crime was heightened by a dramatic, tape-recorded telephone conversation between Stuart and an emergency dispatcher who tracked down the Stuarts' location to send an ambulance. The crime shocked Bostonians and aggravated racial tensions, particularly after a black man was named as a suspect. The crime's hold on the public imagination grew greater still when it became clear that the prime suspect was Stuart himself. --- PHOENIX (AP) - Robert Redford has begun shooting ``The Dark Wind'' on the Hopi and Navajo reservations in Arizona despite threats of a blockade by leaders of a Hopi village. The film is based on a novel by Tony Hillerman. Tribal officials gave permission for filming on the reservation, saying they had been assured by Redford'sproduction company that the movie would be sensitive to Hopi culture and religion. But leaders of the Hopi village of Shungopavi claimed the script, which was not written by Hillerman, gives a sacrilegious portrayal of Hopi secret ceremonies and depicts Hopis as inept, profane, murderous drug users. Spokeswoman Bertha Torres said the script's ``underlying theme was that Hopis are not very bright compared to Navajo people.'' Village leaders want all aspects of Hopi religious beliefs deleted from the script, she said. The village has threatened a blockade, but Hopi police said they knew of no attempts to disrupt the filming, which began Monday. Some Navajos have objected to Redford offering the leading role of a Navajo policeman to Lou Diamond Phillips instead of a Navajo. Phillips says he is part Cherokee.

DOC.HEAD: Derwinski Upbraided by Candidate He Was Supposed to Help
DOC.TEXT: Ally Milder needs all the help she can get for her campaign to unseat Nebraska Democratic congressman Peter Hoagland. But she has no intention of asking Veterans Affairs Secretary Edward Derwinski for a return visit to Omaha. The former Illinois congressman said Monday that Milder's concern was ``understandable'' in the aftermath of his reference to illegal aliens as ``wetbacks,'' a remark he conceded was ``a dumb mistake.'' ``There's no place in government for people who have attitudes like this,'' said Milder, who said it was up to President Bush to decide whether the remark was enough to force the Cabinet secretary to resign. ``We're not going to comment,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Milder wouldn't discuss the incident which occurred Friday morning and stirred an unwanted controversy over the weekend. ``That's certainly not the way she feels in the least sense of the word,'' said Kent Grisham, a spokesman for the Nebraska Republican Party. ``I think she made an interesting point that being Jewish she has experienced a lot of prejudice first-hand.'' Riccardo Correa, an Omaha businessman who is active in Hispanic affairs, said Derwinski's remark had not altered his long-standing support for Milder. Correa said her apology was ``not for people like me but for people who would use this against her.'' Hoagland won the Omaha congressional seat in 1988 by a margin of fewer than 3,000 votes, succeeding Republican Hal Daub who ran for the Senate. Howard Schloss, spokesman for the House Democratic campaign committee, called the Hoagland-Milder contest ``a very tight race'' and he relished the opportunity to link Milder to Derwinski. ``It showed very bad judgment on her part to even invite him out there in the first place,'' he said. Calling Derwinski ``insensitive not only to minorities but to women,'' Schloss said Milder ``brought him out there regardless of his views on these matters.'' Derwinski aides confirmed published reports that the Cabinet secretary often refers to women on his staff by nicknames such as ``Little Miss Coffee Maker,'' ``Zsa Zsa,'' ``Little Miss Muffett'' and ``Lena.'' He also has nicknames for several male aides. Derwinski said the nicknames were part of his policy of running ``a completely informal office.'' He called it ``just one of my efforts to have one great big happy family on my staff.'' Derwinski aides refer to him as ``The Big Cheese.'' Sandy Peyton, a program assistant at the Department of Veterans Affairs, said Derwinski calls her ``Miss America,'' and ``I don't mind at all being called that.'' Peyton said there was ``a good warm atmosphere'' in the office and that the women employees ``were all livid'' to read a story suggesting they were offended by the secretary's habit of giving them nicknames. Derwinski said his use of the term ``wetback'' was ``just one of those dumb slips ... that law of averages you have them, I guess.'' He said he used the term during a breakfast meeting when he was asked what his department was doing to combat drugs. ``I just volunteered that one of the problems with drugs is they're so easy to smuggle and that therefore curing addiction in the long run was the way we had to go,'' he recalled. ``And then I just got so carried away with my subject that without even thinking of exactly what I said, I said the drug cartel even uses wetbacks to get drugs into the country.'' He said he hadn't realized what he said and ``the first opportunity I apologized ... I said, obviously, it was a dumb mistake. ... It was an inadvertent, almost unconscious comment.''

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Stops Aqaba Boom
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has cut short the economic boom of Jordan's only port and main tourist resort. Beaches normally packed with tourists are deserted. Aqaba's wide, tree-lined boulevards and once-crowded shopping malls have become the haunt of stray cats searching vainly for scraps of food. Until Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the resulting turmoil in trade throughout the Middle East, Aqaba was Jordan's fastest growing city and had a bright future. ``But now tourism is dead, the port is at a practical standstill and so is business in general,'' bemoans Bassam Kakish, president of the Aqaba Region Development Authority. Thewalls of Kakish's office are lined with colored architects' drawings of the tourism and other development projects along the sandy beaches and crystal-clear waters of the Red Sea. The port has been severely affected because 70 percent of its business was Iraqi imports and exports and that trade has been killed by the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq in retaliation for its seizure of Kuwait. Aqaba, with an estimated population of 45,000, is near Jordan's southern tip, sandwiched between Saudi Arabia and Israel; it sits next to the Israeli resort city of Eilat. Only two or three ships a day dock in the port, compared with more than 20 before the crisis. More than 7,000 of the 11,000 Jordanian trucks engaged in hauling goods to and from the port have been idled, Kakish said. ``Thousands of people have been flung out of work - dockers in the port, truck drivers and hundreds more providing auxiliary services. This has brought business in town to a virtual standstill.'' In the tourist sector, Kakish said, ``Aqaba catered to 150,000 European tourists last year and this year we expected even more. We were actually 5,000 beds short. ``All the local hotels are expanding and new ones are under construction. Yet now all the hotels are empty, and this is the beginning of the high season,'' he said. Hoteliers confirmed that with the outbreak of the crisis guests began leaving, fearing the region would be engulfed in a war. ``The only guests we have now are the occasional journalists that come down from Amman to visit the port and see how the sanctions are implemented,'' said a receptionist at one of the main hotels who gave his name as Mohammed. ``We've had hundreds of cancellations, and future bookings have dried up,'' he said. Kakish estimates that Aqaba will lose more than $1.2 billion from the combined collapse of its tourism and port business. No end is in sight to the falloff, which Kakish believes is unfair since Jordan is abiding by U.N. sanctions against Iraq. ``People talk without reason of Jordan as a war zone,'' he said. ``When will they regain confidence? How long will this period of uncertainty continue - one or two months, one or two years?''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the political career and drug case of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry: 1974: Barry, a civil rights activist, is elected to the D.C. City Council. 1976: Barry is re-elected to the council. March 9, 1977: Hanafi Muslims shoot Barry in the chest during their seizure of the District Building, the capital's city hall. The bullet barely misses Barry's heart, but he's back at work a week later. November 1978: Barry is elected mayor. January 1979: Barry is inaugurated, pledges that ``here in Washington D.C., we will be our brother's keeper.'' During his first term, the city deficit mushrooms, forcing him to cut jobs and services and press for more federal aid. He weathers a major snowstorm and a drawn-out teacher's strike. November 1982: Barry is re-elected. His second term sees improved fiscal health, renewal of the downtown area, a decline in unemployment and crime. Scandals begin to take their toll as 10 top city officials are convicted of financial crimes. Sept. 25, 1983: Barry is stricken with chest pains while attending a meeting in a downtown hotel; hospital officials blame the episode on a hiatal hernia. A physician not involved in his treatment tells police the mayor suffered a drug overdose, a report not revealed for six years. Police say they could find no evidence to support the physician. Nov. 4, 1986: Despite his mounting troubles, Barry is re-elected to an unprecedented third term, taking 61 percent of the vote. 1987: Jan. 26: Vacationing in California, Barry is hospitalized briefly after suffering chest pains, later explained as a flare-up of the hiatal hernia. May 22: U.S. Attorney Joseph diGenova announces a federal investigation into allegations of fraud in city government. June 18: Barry denies a local television station's report that he used cocaine with a former city employee. 1988: Dec. 22: Police officers planning to attempt a drug buy from Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands official and acquaintance of Barry's, are called back when it's discovered that the mayor is in Lewis' hotel room. Traces of cocaine are found in the room. Dec. 29: U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens announces plans to investigate Lewis episode. Dec. 31: Barry apologizes for ``bad judgment'' in the incident. 1989: Jan. 5: A grand jury investigating allegations of Barry interference in a police drug probe has the mayor's telephone logs subpoenaed. Jan. 6: Lewis denies ever using drugs with the mayor. Jan. 19: Barry appears under subpoena before the grand jury and testifies for three hours. He tells reporters he has done nothing wrong. April 24: Lewis is convicted in the Virgin Islands on four counts of possession of cocaine. Sept. 17: Barry responds to hecklers at an outdoor festival by making an obscene hand gesture. Nov. 6: Lewis pleads guilty in a plea bargain in Washington to two counts of conspiring to distribute cocaine and names Barry as a person for whom he bought crack cocaine while staying at the hotel where Barry visited him in 1988. 1990: Jan. 18: Barry is arrested on a drug charge in a downtown hotel. Jan. 21: Barry announces he will seek assistance ``to heal my body, mind and soul,'' but makes no mention of drug abuse. Jan. 22: Barry checks into Hanley-Hazelden Treatment Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. His spokeswoman says the mayor will be treated for alcoholism. Feb. 15: A federal grand jury indicts Barry on three felony counts of perjury and five misdemeanor counts of possession of a controlled substance. May 10: The grand jury indicts Barry on six more misdemeanor possession charges. June 4: Jury selection begins in Barry's trial. June 13: Barry announces he will not seek re-election. June 19: Opening arguments at the trial. June 28: The jury is shown a videotape in which Barry smokes crack cocaine from a pipe during the January FBI sting operation at a Washington hotel. Aug. 2: The case goes to the jury after closing arguments. Prosecutors say jurors should convict a man who ``smoked and snorted his way through 1987 and 1988 ... right into 1989.'' The mayor's lawyer says the jury should disbelieve witnesses he calls ``facile liars.'' Aug. 10: The jury convicts Barry of one drug possession charge, acquits him of another and says it is deadlocked on the other seven misdemeanor and three felony charges. The judge declares a mistrial on the unresolved charges. Aug. 13: Barry changes his political affiliation from Democrat to independent. Aug. 28: He files petitions that would allow him to run as an independent for the city council. Sept. 17: Federal prosecutors say they will not retry Barry on the 12 charges.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Says No Recall Warranted
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. says it is not recalling light trucks for gear shift repairs because there is no safety hazard if the levers break. That decision is drawing fire from a consumer advocacy group. The Center for Auto Safety, founded by Ralph Nader, asked the government Monday to order a recall of 240,000 Ford Ranger pickups and Bronco II utility vehicles from the 1986 and 1987 model years. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration launched an investigation in June of reports that the manual transmission levers were breaking off in the driver's hand. ``Ford's approach to such a blatant, widespread defect is woefully inadequate,'' said Samuel Cole, vehicle safety staffer for the consumer organization. Ford provided the government agency with a September 1988 internal report that disclosed 6,473 gear-shift lever failures on 1986 and 1987 Ranger pickups with manual transmissions made by Mazda. That translates into a failure rate of one in every 37 vehicles, the Center for Auto Safety said. The Bronco II has the same transmission as the Ranger, Ford spokeswoman Joy Stinson said. Ford began using an improved lever assembly with 1988 models. Ms. Stinson said the company did not consider the problem a safety hazard. Even if the lever breaks, the vehicle remains in gear and the driver is able to pull off the road without losing control, she said. ``Whatever gear it breaks in, it's driveable,'' she said. ``For that reason ... a safety recall is not warranted.'' Cole disagreed, saying that ``it will only be a matter of time before we begin seeing accidents attributed to the gear shift defect.''
DOC.HEAD: Hinckley Loses Bid to Vote in DC Election
DOC.TEXT: The board of elections in the District of Columbia has ruled that presidential assailant John W. Hinckley Jr. cannot vote in the city where he has been confined since the shooting of then-President Reagan more than nine years ago. In a petition arguing his right to vote, Hinckley claimed that he had resided and paid taxes in the District and should have been given the right to vote in the upcoming general election. But after a hearing Monday, the board concluded that a person involuntarily confined cannot change his address to the jurisdiction where he is being held. Hinckley, charged with the attempted assassination of the president, was found innocent by reason of insanity in 1982 and since has been confined at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington D.C.
DOC.HEAD: California Businessman Pleads Guilty to Bribery for Navy Contracts
DOC.TEXT: A California businessman has pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe two Navy procurement officials. Manuel R. Caldera admitted to paying the military officials more than $26,000 to help his company obtain lucrative electronics contracts. Caldera, 59, former chairman of Amex Systems, Inc., of Los Angeles, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to pay bribes and making an illegal payment to a public official. Together, the charges carry a maximum sentence of seven years imprisonment and fines of $500,000. The guilty plea before U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., marked the latest conviction in the government's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud. Thirty-nine defense consultants, procurement officials and contractors plus several companies have been convicted since the investigation known as ``Operation Ill Wind'' became public more than two years ago. Caldera, a Mexican-American who was honored in 1983 by President Reagan as a minority businessman, admitted paying bribes to former Navy procurement officals Stuart E. Berlin and James D. Sampson between 1978 and 1985. The two former officials, who worked for the Naval Electronics System Command in Arlington, Va., agreed to approve additional contract work for Amex in return for the money, according to court papers.

DOC.HEAD: Loyalists Set Fires, Air Attacks Reported in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: Liberia's civil war has entered a new phase of chaos, with encircled government soldiers setting huge fires around the capital and Nigerian jets bombing a rebel army, news reports and military sources say. Clouds of smoke hung over the ravaged capital, Monrovia, on Monday as rival rebel forces under Charles Taylor and Prince Johnson battled each other and loyalists of slain President Samuel Doe with artillery and machine guns. There were no immediate reports on casualties. The British Broadcasting Corp. said from Monrovia that Doe loyalists doused buildings with gasoline, setting huge fires that burned out of control. ``No Doe, No Liberia. No President, No Capital,'' it quoted the soldiers as chanting. The BBC said the remnants of Doe's army have decided to go down fighting, expecting no mercy from insurgents who have been hunting them down since Doe died this month in rebel hands. The rebels control most of the country and have confined government holdouts to a section of Monrovia. Military sources in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, said Monday that that country's jets had bombed strongholds of rebel leader Charles Taylor. The reports of those attacks Sunday were the latest indication that West African nations, who said they were sending a joint military force to Liberia to restore peace, were instead becoming more involved in the fighting. Over the weekend, Ghanaian warplanes also bombed Taylor's forces in retaliation for shelling that killed five people on a ship and at the West African force's headquarters in Monrovia. Herman Cohen, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Africa, met in Sierra Leone with Gambian and Nigerian officials to discuss a possible visit Wednesday to Monrovia. The State Department said Cohen's schedule had not been finalized. Nigeria sent 650 troops to Freetown, Sierra Leone, where they were waiting to board warships bound for Monrovia. They are to join 1,000 Nigerian troops already participating in the 3,000-member regional force, which also includes troops from Gambia, Ghana, Guinea and Sierra Leone. The new Nigerian contingent includes paratroopers. Military sources said they would be dropped into the port of Buchanan, southeast of Monrovia, and Kakata, north of the capital. Both are held by Taylor, who is opposed to the West African force. He has seized 2,000 West African citizens as hostages. The rival rebel leader, Johnson, has welcomed West African intervention and its call for an interim government followed by elections. Members of the West African force, and many Liberians, have criticized the United States for not sending troops to end the 8-month-old war. At least 5,000 people have died in the fighting, most of them civilians. The war began in December when Taylor invaded from the Ivory Coast. Prince Johnson, a former Taylor ally, formed a rival force over the summer. The rebels claimed Doe's government was corrupt and mismanaged, but the conflict has largely been fought along tribal lines. ``We've got to a stage where really we have to think deeply on what to do to bring a very bad, very confused and violent situation to an end,'' said Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara, the chairman of the Economic Community of West African States. About 2,100 U.S. Marines have evacuated hundreds of foreigners. They are also guarding the U.S. Embassy and residential compound in Monrovia, but they have orders not to intervene militarily. Liberia was founded by freed American slaves in 1847.
