DOC.HEAD: The AP
Columbia Launch Scrubbed Again, Put Off for Months
DOC.TEXT: After four failures, NASA gave up trying to launch the leaky space shuttle Columbia so that it can concentrate on getting Discovery aloft in October before the planets fall out of the proper alignment. NASA scrbbed the fourth attempt to launch Columbia about seven hours before it was to lift off at 1:28 a.m. today after a buildup of hydrogen, a highly flammable gas, was detected in the engine compartment during fueling. A baffled Robert Crippen, shuttle director, said: ``I do not understand it. Our plan is that we are going to understand it.'' Columbia was to have lifted off with the $150 million Astro observatory to study some of the hottest objects in the universe. Driven by the need to launch Discovery next month, NASA ran out of time and patience with Columbia. The Discovery mission has priority: its crew is to launch the Ulysses space probe toward the sun during an alignment of Earth, sun and Jupiter that won't reoccur for 13 months. Another effort to launch Columbia is not likely before November, if then, NASA said. Columbia's crew of seven, which includes four astronomers, was to head back to Houston today. Three of Columbia's scrubs were for hydrogen leaks; the fourth was because of a problem communicating with one of the four telescopes Columbia was to carry on a 10-day astronomical mission. The latest failure only added to what has been a difficult year for NASA. It means that nearly six months will have gone by without a shuttle flight if Discovery goes in October, the longest gap between missions since flights resumed after the Challenger disaster. The space agency planned on nine missions this year; so far it has had only three. This also has been the year when the Hubble Space Telescope was found to have blurred vision and when the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus twice slipped its communications bonds with Earth. ``I believe that we still have people out there who are capable of solving this kind of a problem,'' Crippen said. But he added, ``We certainly haven't done this in a very expeditious manner, I know that.'' Engineers had not decided on the next step, which probably will involve installing cameras and lights in Columbia's engine compartment and going through the tanking procedure again. Crippen said there may be three or more leaks. After a fueling attempt on May 29, when the first hydrogen buildup occurred both outside the shuttle and inside the engine compartment, NASA focused on a plumbing connection between the fuel tank and the shuttle. A similar leak was found in Atlantis, prompting NASA to ground the three-shuttle fleet temporarily. Engineers determined that microscopic glass beads somehow worked their way into Columbia's seals and provided a path for the leaks. The connecting pipe was replaced, but on Sept. 5 hydrogen flooded the aft compartment again. NASA replaced three small pumps and a damaged Teflon seal over a valve. Now, Crippen said, the leak may have had ``something to do with us going through, taking things apart,'' after Columbia returned from its last mission in January with some systems contaminated with an abrasive used to polish metal.

DOC.HEAD: Chocolates Yanked From Shelves Because of Asian Games Link
DOC.TEXT: Authorities ordered all packets of M&Ms candy withdrawn from Hong Kong stores today after an anonymous letter claimed one bag of the candy had been poisoned to punish the U.S. manufacturer for co-sponsoring the Asian Games in Beijing. The letter, delivered to several newspapers late Monday, says one packet of M&Ms had been laced with sodium cyanide, a deadly poison. The letter condemns Mars. Inc. of Hackettstown, N.J., which makes M&Ms, for sponsoring the games, which open in Beijing on Saturday. It criticizes China's Communist leaders for their bloody crackdown on a movement for democracy in China in June 1989. Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed then when the military cleared central Beijing of protesters. ``M&M chocolates, which called itself the official sponsor of the Games, is guilty of supporting the illegal regime,'' the letter said. Peter Maslen, a spokesman for the Effem Foods Co., which makes M&Ms in Hong Kong, said workers were removing several tons of the candies from stores throughout the British colony. Both plain and peanut varieties were being carted away, he said. Police warned prospective buyers of the candy to check the packets carefully. Mars Co. is one of three American companies officially sponsoring this year's Asian Games. The other two are the Coca-Cola Co. and American Express. M&Ms packets sold in Hong Kong come stamped with a logo of Pan Pan, the panda mascot of the Asian Games. Other major foreign sponsors of the event include the Fuji Photo Film Co. of Japan and Adidas AG of West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: S&P Lowers Philly Bond Rating
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. has dropped Philadelphia's bond rating ``about as low as you can go,'' and Mayor W. Wilson Goode appealed to the state for help in solving the city's deepening fiscal crisis. The Legislature must recognize that Philadelphia ``is the heartbeat of this commonwealth'' and give the city the authority to raise taxes, Goode said Monday. ``I think that had New York City not raised taxes by nearly $1 billion this past year it would be in the same position that we are in right now,'' he said. The bond rating agency downgraded its rating on Philadelphia's $1.3 billion of general obligation bonds Monday to the weakest credit rating short of default. Moody's, another national bond agency, took similar action on Friday. ``You can't lower it any more,'' said Hyman C. Grossman, S&P managing director. ``It's about as low as you can go.'' The credit rating makes it more difficult and more expensive for the city to borrow money. Philadelphia, starved for revenue because of the economic downturn in the Northeast, has been trying to sell $375 million in short-term notes but has found no banks to guarantee them. City Finance Director Betsy Reveal has said that without an infusion of cash, Philadelphia will be out of money by the end of the year or shortly thereafter. The Goode administration Monday ordered a one-week freeze on new spending, prohibiting hiring, executing new contracts and buying supplies. Reveal also instructed city department heads to defer payments if possible. The reduced rating - to triple-C from triple-B-minus - will stay in place until there is a ``solid, credible plan to restore Philadelphia's fiscal posture to a level where it can meet all of its financial obligations,'' Standard & Poor's said in a statement. During an appearance on Financial News Network on Monday night, Goode said the city had to find more revenue. ``I think you have an option,'' he said. ``You can cut your way out of this problem and therefore cut your services to a point where nobody wants to be around because your services are so far gone you can't resolve any problems. ``On the other hand you have to have sufficient revenue to maintain the quality of life,'' he said. Grossman said the city needs a special tax to pay its debt, in return for which it will have to give up some of its authority. ``The time is long gone,'' he said. ``There is no access to the (credit) market.'' He said he hopes the rating sends a ``message to the city and the state that together they need to construct a mechanism to enable the city to begin to address its chronic financial distress.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Referendum Call: Democracy or Morass?
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's unexpected call for a referendum on ending collectived farming indicates he is now having second thoughts about pushing ahead with a compromise plan to create a market economy. Gorbachev's proposal to put to the people whether to allow private ownership of land came Monday as Parliament opened debate on competing plans for salvaging the shortage-plagued and grossly inefficient economy. Gorbachev, speaking to Parliament, did not say when the referendum would be held, who would vote, or where he personally stood on the issue. He is apparently reluctant, either personally or politically, to part with six decades of Communist Party ideological opposition to private ownership of land, said Professor Murray Feshbach of Georgetown University in Washington. ``Gorbachev just can't bring himself to turn in his party card,'' Feshbach said in a telephone interview. Soviet peasants were coerced into collectivization and all land became state property during a 1929-1932 campaign led by Josef V. Stalin that is believed to have claimed the lives of between 5 million and 10 million people. The debate in the legislature Monday turned tumultuous as delegates and economists rose to attack parts of all three economic reform proposals presented in the past week. The compromise supported by Gorbachev was criticized by supporters of both the other plans, and the chances of a broad consensus appeared dim. The most radical proposal - known as the Shatalin plan for its principal author, economist Stanislav Shatalin - would in 500 days give land back to farmers, sell factories to private owners and move the Soviet Union toward a free market. It would shift most economic authority from the central government to the increasingly separatist republics and deprive the national government of the right to levy taxes. A more conservative proposal, supported by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, would retain central control over the economy and move more slowly toward a heavily regulated market. Gorbachev on Friday presented the compromise plan, written by Shatalin and another leading Soviet economist, Abel Aganbegyan. It contains many elements of Shatalin's radical 500-day plan but would move at a slower pace and not disturb the central government's power to levy taxes. The compromise proposal also backs away from private ownership of land. While Shatalin's 500-day plan calls for selling some land to individuals for nominal prices, the compromise calls for leasing it. Gorbachev has urged a compromise to avoid a split with the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics with half the country's people and three-quarters of its land. The Russian parliament overwhelmingly adopted Shatalin's 500-day plan last week. Thousands of people marched through Moscow on Sunday to demand the resignation of Gorbachev, Ryzhkov and the Council of Ministers for failing to solve the country's economic problems. Gorbachev rejected the calls Monday, saying reshuffling ``the top echelons of power ... would draw us into grim political battles, (and) would heighten confrontation in society at a time when we most badly need consolidation to carry out the market economy program.''

DOC.HEAD: Gubernatorial Voting in Massachusetts, Oklahoma
With PM-Boggs' Seat, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boston University's hard-bitten president battled a former attorney general for the Democratic nomination for governr today after a wild campaign that saw an attempted coup against retiring Gov. Michael Dukakis. In the nation's other gubernatorial contest, both parties in Oklahoma had runoffs for candidates to succeed Republican Henry Bellmon. He, too, decided not to seek re-election. Two political newcomers enlivened Oklahoma's Republican campaign, and the GOP race in Massachusetts took a surprising turn this month. But the Massachusetts Democratic race has been the most heated and, at times, bizarre. Turnout was expected to be huge. Earlier in the race, polls had shown John Silber, on leave as BU president, running neck-and-neck with former state Attorney General Francis Belloti. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy had lagged badly in fund-raising and in the polls. Then Murphy tried to grab control of the state's ailing finances from Dukakis while he was on a European trade mission earlier this month. What Republican candidate Steven Pierce dubbed ``mutiny on the Titanic'' wound up sinking Murphy's campaign. She withdrew from the race and threw her support to Bellotti, though her name remains on the ballot. Silber, a 63-year-old philosopher, gained a reputation for outspokenness as BU president for 20 years. He didn't tone down his style in making his first bid for public office. The ``Silber shocker'' that may have caused the biggest furor came when he suggested during a debate that the state may want to ration health care. ``When you've had a long life and you're ripe, then it's time to go,'' he said. Last week, asked about giving a crime control speech in an inner-city neighborhood, Silber said there was no point addressing ``a group of drug addicts.'' Silber criticized the news media for focusing on such remarks and not the substance of his speeches. Bellotti called Silber ``irrational'' and ``intemperate.'' A poll taken for WBZ-TV and The Boston Globe and released Sunday showed Bellotti leading Silber 50 percent to 39 percent. The poll by KRC Communications Inc. surveyed 696 likely Democratic primary voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The GOP race had been relatively sleepy until this month, when polls indicated former federal prosecutor William Weld overtook Pierce, the state House Minority Leader. Weld spent more than $1 million of his own money on the campaign. He also debated aggressively. The Globe-WBZ poll of 682 likely Republican voters showed Weld with 51 percent to Pierce's 41 percent, with a 4-point margin of error. All four remaining candidates all have pledged to turn around the state's deficit-ridden budget and an economy marked by rising unemployment and loss of businesses. The Massachusetts economy has been sliding since Dukakis won the Democratic presidential nomination in 1988 and then lost the general election that year. In Oklahoma, the GOP runoff will end a hotly contested race for the gubernatorial nomination between businessman Vince Orza and former U.S. Attorney Bill Price. Both are political newcomers. The Democrats were 1986 nominee David Walters and U.S. Rep. Wes Watkins. A big issue in the Republican race has been education. Price advocates repeal through a statewide vote of the $223 million education reform bill enacted earlier this year. Orza has aids that would be a mistake that would hurt the state's image nationally. He said he would work to change the measure. Watkins and Walters have taken similar stands on most issues. Oklahoma voters also were deciding whether to limit state lawmakers' terms. It would be the first time any state enacted such a limit. If approved, it would put a 12-year cap on service by members of the House or Senate. In Washington state, former Gov. John D. Spellman was trying an unusual political comeback. The Seattle attorney, an affable, pipe-puffing Republican moderate, wanted a seat on the state Supreme Court. He was challenging Justice Richard Guy, who was appointed last fall by Gov. Booth Gardner, the Democrat who ousted Spellman in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Sesson Opening to New U.N. Role
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats gathered today for a new General Assembly new session in an atmosphere of unprecedented cooperation among leading powers but unremitting tension over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The United Nations finally is achieving the purpose which was envisaged by its founders, and it is becoming a far more influential actor on the world stage,'' Ronald I. Spiers, undersecretary-general for political and General Assembly affairs, has said. The 44th General Assembly closed its final meeting Monday with a unanimous appeal to South African authorities to suppress the violence that has killed nearly 800 blacks the last six weeks. The 45th General Assembly was to convene today for its first post-Cold War session. The assembly is expected to be dominated by the Persian Gulf crisis and economic development, debt and the environment. At today's gathering, the new assembly was expected to elect as its president by acclamation Guido de Marco, deputy prime minister and foreign minister of Malta. The position rotates among regional groups each year. It is largely ceremonial, but the president has power to arrange the agenda and mediate among various interest groups. The annual general debate and speeches by world leaders begin Sept. 24, when President Bush is to address the 159-nation assembly. He is to be followed by 27 heads of state, 18 prime ministers and more than 100 foreign ministers. The assembly convenes at a time when the prestige of the organization never has been higher because of a series of tough Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and ordering an embargo on trade with Iraq. It also comes during unprecedented U.S.-Soviet cooperation and harmony between those two countries and the other three permanent members of the Security Council: France, Britain and China. The General Assembly, often likened to a global town meeting, cannot adopt legally binding resolutions, as can the Security Council. But its increasingly unified voice carries considerable weight as an expression of will of the international community. Monday's resolution on South Africa noted that country's progress over the last year, such as freeing Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners, and lifting the ban on the African National Congress and other organizations. South Africa's voting rights in the General Assembly have been suspended since 1974 for its refusal to abolish apartheid. The new session will admit Liechtenstein as the 160th U.N. member, but the reunification of East and West Germany on Oct. 3 and its membership with a single U.N. seat will keep the membership at 159. The Cambodian seat, previously held by the anti-Vietnamese coalition of Democratic Kampuchia, is to be filled by a member of a provisional government being formed to organize elections under U.N. auspices. Details of a Cambodia settlement and U.N. administration remain to be worked out. ``This is the first post-Cold War General Assembly,'' Spiers said. He said he expected the Middle East and especially the Persian Gulf crisis to be recurrent themes in speeches by world leaders, but he emphasized that the ``great issues'' of today and years to come are Third World debt and development, poverty, the environment, narcotics and other social issues. Except for the Middle East and the Persian Gulf crisis, few contentious issues remain on the U.N. agenda, as the Soviet Union seeks to end its involvement in regional conflicts and cooperate with the United States. But Cambodia, Western Sahara, Afghanistan and Cyprus remain trouble spots and unresolved conflicts. At a time when the United Nations is called upon as never before to make peace, it remains far in financial arrears, largely because the United States owes more than $700 million. For years, the United States withheld funds because it said the world body was biased against the United States and tilted in favor of the Soviet Union and the Third World. Bush has asked the U.S. Congress to restore funding, however.

DOC.HEAD: Chilly Morning in Northeast, Rain Elsewhere

DOC.TEXT: The Northeast shivered in record early-morning cold today. Rain was forecast today for the mountains of New England, some of which were sprinkled with snow on Monday. Rain also was expected in the Midwest, and Iowa, Illinois and Wisconsin were in for more cool weather. Rain also was forecast for Texas along the lower coastal areas, although portions of the area flooded by rain since Saturday were expecting drier weather. Temperatures dipped below freezing overnight as far south as Virginia. Isolated thunderstorms were forecast for the southern Rockies, but most of the far West - from Washington to Arizona - looked for dry, seasonable weather. Thunderstorms overnight in Colorado produced golf ball size hail at Haswell and 2{ inches of rain, causing minor flooding. The high for the nation Monday was 107 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Teen Charged With Killing Mom's Mugger
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager trying to avenge his mother's mugging was charged with manslaughter in the fatal stabbing of her assailant. Victor Lopez, 18, tracked Lazara O'Farrill to a drug-plagued park and stabbed him three times, hours after his mother, Maria Lopez, 37, was mugged early Saturday in the South Bronx, police said Monday. Lopez was jailed on $5,000 bail. ``A lot of people hurt for what happened to him,'' said Lopez's aunt, Mildred Maldonado. ``He was incarcerated for defending his mother.'' A tourist from Utah was killed earlier this month when he tried to defend his mother from muggers on a subway platform. Lt. Michael Bramble said he saw Lopez's situation differently. ``Basically, someone took the law into their own hands. Instead of coming to the police, they acted irrationally and emotionally,'' he said. O'Farrill, 25, died at a hospital after being stabbed in the chest, arm and leg, authorities said. Maria Lopez talked her son into surrendering after two area teen-agers were arrested and charged with the slaying. ``I believed it wasn't right,'' she said. ``I told him there's no need to be hiding.'' ``I feel guilty,'' sobbed Mrs. Lopez, a single mother who said she struggled to keep her nine children away from trouble in a drug-plagued neighborhood. ``If I hadn't called my son, this wouldn't have happened.'' Mrs. Lopez was mugged as she walked to the subway on her way to work as a nurse's aide at a hospital. She was approached by two men, one of whom grabbed two gold chains from her neck and put his hand down her blouse to see if she was carrying any money in her bra. ``I screamed, I was nervous, I called 911, then I followed one of them,'' she recounted. Mrs. Lopez also called home and told her sons Victor and Raymond, 21, what had happened. ``I never knew a killing would happen,'' she cried. She went to work while her sons found one of the muggers, who told them he only tagged along when O'Farrill mugged their mother to buy crack, police said. The sons found O'Farrill at a drug-plagued park. As they approached him, he swore at them and ``tried to pull something from his waist and that's when my son stabbed him in the arm,'' Mrs. Lopez sobbed. Victor Lopez told his mother he was too scared of O'Farrill to try to hold him until police came, Mrs. Lopez said. Mrs. Lopez said O'Farrill belonged to a neighborhood gang known as ``Los Machoteros,'' or the machete-wielders, who mugged women and children.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly lower against major currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was marginally higher. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.68 yen, up 0.68 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at 137.55 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5540 German marks, down from 1.5575 -1.2890 Swiss francs, up from 1.2865 -5.2045 French francs, down from 5.2160 -1.7535 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7550 -1,163.00 Italian lire, down from 1,165.00 -1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1593 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9115, compared with $1.9025 late Monday. ``Life insurance companies and securities houses bought (pounds) sterling and marks against the yen, so the dollar-yen (rate) was pushed up,'' said Tadashi Sazaki, assistant general manager in the foreign exchange and international treasury department at Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Short-covering lifted the dollar to its high for the day before life insurance companies began buying the U.S. currency, sending it back down again toward the end of trading, he said. Dealers in London said a surge in oil prices has undermined the yen. Meanwhile, interest in the dollar and the German mark remain low, prompting some investors to drift into high-yielding currencies, such as the Canadian dollar and the British pound. Many more players are simply bailing out, said Richard Wemsley, senior dealer at Fuji Bank in London. ``People are pulling out left right and center,'' he said. ``The market's gone into its shell,'' agreed Richard Longbourne, senior dealer at First City Texas Houston in London. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $390.55 per ounce at midmorning, up from $389.75 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $389.30, up from $389.00 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.48 an ounce today, to close at $389.85. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.81 a troy ounce, from $4.78.

DOC.HEAD: Man Questioned in Fire Kills Himself, Uses Ribbon to Lead Others to Body
DOC.TEXT: A man questioned about a forest fire in which a helicopter pilot died shot himself to death after leaving a three-mile trail of orange ribbon leading to his body. Lester W. Stensgar, 33, of Inchelium, whose body was found Friday on the Colville Reservation, also apparently set two small blazes nearby before killing himself, authorities said Monday. Stensgar had admitted setting fires on the Indian reservation in 1988 and 1989 but denied responsibility for a 915-acre arson fire last week in which a Canadian pilot died, investigators said. FBI agent Jeffrey John said the agency had questioned Stensgar, a nephew of Tribal Business Council Chairman Jude Stensgar, and evidence was to have been presented to a grand jury today. John Dick, acting reservation police chief, said Stensgar had stretched orange ribbon nearly three miles from a road to the spot where his truck and body were found. A note was found at the scene, but investigators would not disclose its contents. Two small fires were burning nearby, tribal spokeswoman Sheila Whitelaw said. The fires burned a tree stump and some brush, she said. Robert Wiebe, 54, of British Columbia, died when his helicopter crashed into a ravine while he was dropping 200-gallon buckets of water on the arson fire last week. The blaze started Sept. 10 and was declared controlled Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Marie Closes in on Hawaii Island
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Marie, downgraded from a hurricane, moved today toward Hawaii. Residents were advised to prepare for winds of up to 73 mph. Hurricane Marie was downgraded late Sunday after its top sustained winds fell from 85 mph to 70 mph. A storm must have sustained winds of 74 mph to be classified a hurricane. Marie's winds still gusted to 85 mph, the National Weather Service said. Marie storm was 210 miles southeast of Hilo on Monday night, heading for Hawaii at 9 mph, forecasters said. If it stays on the same course, the storm center would pass 130 miles south of South Point on Hawaii, known as the Big Island, this afternoon, forecasters said. A tropical storm warning, meaning winds of 39 mph to 73 mph were possible, was posted for Hawaii Island. A tropical storm watch was posted for Maui County, including the islands of Maui, Molokai and Lanai. There were no warnings for Oahu Island, where Honolulu is located. Gale-force winds, ranging from 39 to 54 mph, extend 140 miles from the center, the weather service said. High surf kicked up by the storm hammered the east and south shores of Hawaii Island, prompting the closing of Punaluu Beach Park with surf on Monday ranging from 8 to 10 feet where it normally averages 1 to 2 feet, said County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim. The southeast section of the island was already experiencing some strong gusty winds Monday, blowing debris onto some roadways, Kim said. There were no reports of any property damage related to the surf or wind, he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official: American Troops Could be Leaving Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Communists claiming responsibility for bombing; ADD figure for security forces. Picks up 7th pvs `U.S. diplomats...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States acknowledged today that the days of a large U.S. military presence in the Philippines are numbered, and asked for time to phase out its oldest and largest bases abroad. ``It is clear to me ... that the days of a very large presence of U.S. sailors and airmen in the Philippines are coming to an end,'' chief American negotiator Richard Armitage told the opening session of talks on the bases' future. ``What remains for us to determine is the rate at which this presence will be reduced and the nature of the relationship our two governments wish to pursue during and after this transitional period.'' It was the first time a U.S. official had publicly raised the possibility that Washington is prepared to give up the six bases. The talks continue negotiations begun in May on the future of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. Their lease expires in September 1991, and Philippine opposition to the installations is growing. On Monday, a bomb exploded at a Voice of America relay station 60 miles north of Manila, and Communist rebels claimed responsibility in a statement, saying they were protesting U.S. ``domination'' of the Philippines. There were no injuries, and U.S. officials said damage was slight. The talks are being held in the Central Bank building, guarded by more than 1,500 police and soldiers. About 1,000 leftist workers and students rallied near the bank today to protest the bases but dispersed peacefully after police refused to allow them to march to the site. At least 17 people were arrested and 14 injured during anti-bases protets in Manila on Monday. U.S. diplomats have said in the past that U.S. troops will remain in the Philippines only as long as they are wanted. On Monday, however, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Washington wants to keep its bases in the Philippines. In his comments today, Armitage did not propose a timetable for removing the 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents. But he hinted that the process could extend until the end of the century. He said the U.S. and Philippine military, Filipino base workers and other nations in the region need time to adjust to the possible closing of the bases. ``Let the voters of the 21st Century decide whether or not they believe a continued U.S. presence will be helpful,'' Armitage said. Rafael Alunan, spokesman for the Philippine negotiators, said Manila welcomed Armitage's ``willingness ... to discuss the crafting of a new relationship between our two countries.'' But he took exception to Armitage's call for voters of the next century to decide on the American presence. ``This matter is not to be decided in the 21st century,'' Alunan said. ``The time for decision is now.'' Rep. Stephen Solarz, chairman of the U.S. House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs, said Friday that U.S. officials were considering a 10-year phaseout. Last month, Manila newspapers quoted unidentified sources as saying the Philippines was considering allowing the Americans to remain in Subic for up to 10 years if they returned Clark and the other installations in 1991. Opponents believe the bases infringe on national sovereignty and represent a vestige of American colonial rule, which ended with independence in 1946. U.S. forces have been in the Philippines since the Americans captured the islands from Spain in 1898. During a nationally televised speech Monday, President Corazon Aquino said her government wants to maintain close ties with Washington. But she said the end of the Cold War and absence of any external threat to the Philippines made the bases less important. ``It is now necessary for our government to work with the United States for arrangements regarding the orderly withdrawal of their forces from our country,'' Mrs. Aquino said. She noted that a government committee is drafting plans to convert the bases into civilian use, including a commercial airport at Clark and a ship repair facility at Subic. The United States has strongly supported the Aquino administration since a 1986 revolution ended the 20-year rule of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, a longtime U.S. ally. In December, U.S. jets from Clark flew air cover for government forces during an unsuccessful bid by military rebels to oust Mrs. Aquino. American troops from the bases also provided help for the government during a July earthquake that killed nearly 1,700 people.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Senator Convicted of Corruption
DOC.TEXT: Former state Sen. Paul Carpenter faces up to 80 years in prison after being convicted of shaking down political lobbyists for campaign contributions. The 62-year-old Democrat from Long Beach, once a powerful figure in the state Legislature, was found guilty on racketeering, conspiracy and extortion charges stemming from a 5-year-old FBI investigation at the Capitol. He is the second California elected state official convicted on corruption charges. Joseph Montoya, a Democrat who was convicted in February while still a member of the state Senate, is serving a 6{-year prison sentence for racketeering, extortion and money laundering. Carpenter, who served 12 years as a state senator and was a Senate Democratic Caucus chairman, is expected to appeal, said his attorney, Gerard Hinckley. Sentencing was not immediately set for Carpenter, who for several years was one of the Senate's leading fund-raisers. He faces a maximum of 80 years in prison and $750,000 in fines. He also risks losing his seat on a powerful state tax board. He is up for re-election to the Board of Equalization in November. The jury deliberated for nearly two days before reaching verdicts on Carpenter, who was indicted in March. The charges arose from alleged wrongdong before Carpenter left the Legislature to join the tax board in 1987. They centered around $20,000 in campaign contributions that Carpenter received in 1986 from an FBI undercover agent posing as an Alabama businessman. The prosecution contended the money was a payoff to ease passage of a bill the businessman was sponsoring, supposedly to obtain financing for a shrimp plant in the Sacramento area. Carpenter acknowledged he took some steps that could have been interpreted as helping the bill. However, he contended that he did nothing for the bill in exchange for the money, saying he had been assured by an aide that the businessman agreed Carpenter could take the contributions without any strings attached.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Five-Year Sentence in Extortion Plot Against Anchorwoman
DOC.TEXT: A man who tried to extort $30,000 from a local anchorwoman to block publication of nude photos that did not exist was sentenced to five years in prison. ``He's a leech,'' KTLA-TV anchorwoman Jann Carl said after Superior Court Judge Jacqueline Connor imposed the maximum penalty on Gilbert Cabot. A jury last month convicted Cabot, 44, of attempted extortion and conspiracy in connection with the 1988 plot. Prosecutors described Cabot as a veteran con artist. They said Cabot called Carl and told her a woman planned to sell nude photos of the anchorwoman to a national magazine. Cabot said the photos were taken from a sexually explicit videotape, and that he could block their publication by paying the woman $30,000, prosecutors said. Carl, knowing the video did not exist, went to the police, who netted Cabot in a sting operation. Defense attorney Rowan Klein contended Cabot did not attempt to extort money.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan s Big Man On Campus At Moscow State University
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan lectured Moscow university students today on the virtues of capitalism, democracy and religion - and said he'd be following the same course as Mikhail S. Gorbachev if he were Soviet leader. During the question-and-answer session at Moscow State, Reagan also said he believes ``Germany has rejoined the civilized world'' and will not repeat Nazi atrocities. Reagan, in the Soviet Union at Gorbachev's invitation, said, ``We should be teaching our students the languages of each others' countries so that we can really cement the friendship.'' ``If young people like you, in the world, could get to know each other, there would never be another war,'' he said in the conference room of the university's mammoth administration building. Reagan went to the campus accompanied by U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock. During his remarks, the former president mused about Gorbachev's job. He said that if he were suddenly catapulted into the Soviet presidency and faced with the crumbling Soviet economy, he would act just as Gorbachev is. ``I'd be doing the things that President Gorbachev is trying to do to bring about private ownership, to bring about the free economy. ...,'' he said. Gorbachev's economic reform proposals were among the topics the two discussed in the Kremlin on Monday, including the possibility of a Soviet referendum on ending farm collectivization. A key to the reform, Reagan said, is a person's right to own land. ``Until you've done so, you can't realize the patriotism and the pride that you have when you can stand on a piece of land and say `this is mine,''' Reagan told the group. Asked how he maintained his psychological fitness during eight years in the White House, Reagan quoted another former president, Abraham Lincoln: ``He said at one point that he could not perform the duties of his office for 15 minutes if he did not know that he could call upon one who was wiser and stronger than all others,'' Reagan said. ``He was speaking, of course, of God. I learned while I was in the White House why he said that. I discovered that I had that same need.'' On Monday, Reagan, who used to call the Soviet Union an ``evil empire,'' urged those in the country's breakaway republics to keep cool heads. Visiting for the first time since leaving office, the former president made his appeal while speaking to lawmakers of the national parliament. ``Freedom can bring out passions between groups of people that may boil over,'' he said in a reference to the recent Soviet reforms. ``When they do, cool and calm decisions are called for by leaders, so as to lower temperatures all around.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATE with closing figures
DOC.TEXT: The chief index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell for the fourth day today, dropping at one point to its lowest level of the year because of worry over high oil prices and the Middle East, traders said. The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues plummeted in the morning, falling at one point to 23,308.31, its lowest level this year. It then climbed back in the afternoon to finish trading at 23,884.82, down 480.78 points, or 1.97 percent, from Monday's close. The index's previous low for the year was 23,405.71, reached briefly on Sept. 7. The Nikkei index fell 531.86 points, or 2.13 percent, on Monday. Stock traders said the same group of influences - high oil prices, rising interest rates and pessimism over the stalemate in the Middle East - discouraged investors today as on the previous three days. Also fueling the decline was an article in the respected economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun which suggested that long-term interest rates would be raised. Japan's official discount rate has been raised five times since May last year. The price of benchmark Brent crude oil for November delivery was valued this afternoon at around $33.53 a barrel, up from $32.30 a barrel in New York late Monday. Prices for Dubai crude soared at one point to an eight-year high of $31.10-31.20 a barrel, the highest level since November 1982, Kyodo News Service said. Volume on the stock market's first section was estimated at a moderate 400 million shares. ``There just weren't any buyers out there,'' said Chip Mesics, an equity salesman at Kidder Peabody International Corp. Traders said index arbitrage trading and the weak bond market sent stocks down steeply in the morning, but the Nikkei index headed up in the afternoon when major trading companies began buying up issues to support the market. The release in the afternoon of money supply figures, which were close to expectations, also helped pull the market back up from its morning fall, said Kazuhiro Nomura of New Japan Securities Co. Japan's broadly defined money supply, M2 plus certificates of deposit, expanded by 11.9 percent in August from a year earlier, the Bank of Japan announced. In July, the figure was 12.2 percent. On the foreign exchange market, the dollar finished trading at 137.68 yen, up 0.68 yen from Monday's close. The U.S. currency opened at 137.17 yen and ranged between 136.95 yen and 138.10 yen. ``Life insurance companies and securities houses bought (pounds) Sterling and (German) marks against the yen, so the dollar-yen (exchange rate) was pushed up,'' said Tadashi Sazaki, assistant general manager in the foreign exchange and international treasury department at Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Short-covering lifted the dollar to its high for the day before life insurance companies began buying the U.S. currency, sending it back down again toward the end of trading, he said. The yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.540 percent, down from Monday's 8.565 percent finish. Their price closed at 81.29 points, up from Monday's 81.19 points.

DOC.HEAD: A Judge of Many Colors
DOC.TEXT: Flowing black robes have no place in the courtroom of Circuit Judge John Ashworth. In Raleigh County Circuit Court, Ashworth wears a red robe at Christmastime, for weddings and occasionally, as he puts it, ``just for the devilment of it.'' But his favorite robe is electric-blue. ``I really don't like a black robe,'' he said. ``Why should you wear a black robe when you have so many other colors to choose from?'' His colorful taste extends to his regular wardrobe. He recently came to work in a lilac suit with matching suspenders and bow tie. He also favors hats, including a straw hat that he rarely is seen without during the spring and summer. ``I usually remember to wear a hat wherever I go,'' said Ashworth, who is known to friends as ``the Mad Hatter.'' ``I've got about 15 straw hats, three derbies, felt hats, wool caps and even a hat from Australia,'' he said. Lawyers say Ashworth's eccentricity livens up his courtroom. ``It adds a little color to the courtroom,'' Beckley lawyer John Wootin said. ``I think it's a nice change.'' Ashworth does own a black robe, but not the kind the hangs to the floor. ``I had the sleeves altered so they're not in my way, and the bottom shortened,'' he said. ``I like my sawed-off one very much. ... It can't get caught in my chair.''

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Teachers' Strike in Second Day; No End in Sight
DOC.TEXT: Teachers union leaders and rank-and-file members prepared for a long siege in their strike for improvements in pay and other benefits. ``This is a solid strike,'' said Nat Lacour, president of the United Teachers of New Orleans, which represents most of the 4,500 teachers in the state's largest school system. Lloyd Daly and his wife, Mary, both teachers and veterans of the last New Orleans teachers' strike 12 years ago, said they will walk the picket lines ``as long as it takes.'' School system figures indicated that 68 percent of the 4,500 teachers failed to report to work Monday. The union claimed the number was greater than 80 percent. A spot check of principals indicated most of the 84,000 students attended classes Monday. No new contract negotiations were scheduled. When negotiations broke off during the weekend, the teachers union reverted to its original demand for a $45 million package including 10 percent raises each year of a three-year contract. On the first day of school Sept. 4, teachers voted to postpone a strike and limit their demands primarily to better health insurance benefits and raises for clerical workers and teacher aides. On Saturday, the union made a new proposal, asking for $1 million to improve health benefits and agreeing to wait until later in the year for raises for aides and clerical workers. But the board rejected that, sticking to its offer of $600,000, union leaders said. Then on Monday, the School Board cut the $600,000 offer in half. Frank Fudesco, an associate superintendent and the board's chief negotiator, said the $300,000 pulled back would have come from the school system's self-insured workers' compensation fund. ``We cannot give what we do not have,'' Fudesco said. Sixth-grade teacher Katy Hall, picketing at Lafayette Elementary School, said the teachers are ``not striking just for money. ... We're looking for professional respect.'' In 1978, New Orleans teachers struck for 12 days, returning after they were promised a 7 percent pay raise. Most money for teachers' pay comes from the state, which now pays $14,472 for a starting teacher with a bachelor's degree and $25,737 for one with a doctorate and 25 years of experience, said W.J. Cleveland of the state Eduction Department. The state increased its share 7 percent this year. Some poor rural parishes don't add anything to that. Cleveland estimated that the average parish supplement is $3,500. New Orleans adds $4,983 to a starting salary and $9,374 at the top of the scale, so that starting teachers get $19,455 and someone with a doctorate and 25 years of experience gets $35,111. About 650 teachers' aides, who make about $10,000 a year, and 450 clerical workers, who make about $17,000, also are covered under the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MANAMA
Traffic Down To A Dribble As Iraqis Seize More Kuwiati Men
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with color, quotes, border situation today. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti refugees trickled across the border to Saudi Arabia today, their numbers sharply decreased after Iraqi troops began seizing young men from among the thousands wanting to leave a day earlier. Since Iraq unexpectedly opened the border Saturday for the first time in more than a month, about 6,000 refugees have entered Saudi Arabia. By mid-morning today, 100 cars had arrived at the Khafji border crossing in Saudi Arabia. Passenger said about 300 were waiting on the other side of the checkpoint, the only frontier crossing between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. More men under the age of 40 were grabbed as cars were picked to leave the country in a haphazard manner, the refugees said. The seizures began Monday with the Iraqis taking away men between the ages of 17 and 40 and sending them north in buses. A man who said he was 55 years old related how four men in their 20s were taken at gunpoint from his car as he approached the frontier today. He said he had not heard of the seizures the day before; otherwise he would not have brought the young men. ``I didn't get the news,'' he repeated, staring at the ground. He would not give his name. Some Kuwaitis said the young men would be forced into the military, others said they will be interned in Iraq. There was no explanation given to the men or their travel companions when they were seized. Today, Iraqi soldiers were allowing one car to cross into Saudi Arabia every 10 minutes. Six checkpoints on the 120-mile route from Kuwait City to the border eliminated the possibility of random escapes, the refugees said. In Kuwait, the refugees said, police and military officers, as well as any of the Westerners still left in Kuwait, were the particular targets of manhunts. They said the new Iraqi-appointed governor of Kuwait, Ali Hussein Abdel-Majid, had previously been in charge of eradicating Kurdish resistance in northern Iraq. Iraq was widely condemned for using outlawed chemical weapons in the crackdown on the rebellious Kurds in 1988. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after invading it on Aug.2. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein then declared the emirate Iraq's 19th province, and appointed Abdel-Majid its governor last week. One Kuwaiti who fled his homeland said the Iraqi army has set up camp around the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, and tanks have their cannons pointed at the embassy premises and the nearby Egyptian mission. The man, his wife, and four sons were among the first to cross into Saudi Arabia at Khafji. The man would allow himself to be identified only as a state technocrat, fearing reprisals against relatives he left behind. He said the Iraqis are rapidly changing the face of Kuwait, renaming streets and buildings. The Kuwaiti government-in-exile says Saddam is trying to depopulate the captive nation and move in Iraqis. ``It is all becoming Iraqi,'' the refygee said. He estimated that only 300,000 Kuwaiti nationals remain behind, with about half a million having fled. The man described an armed camp in the embassy district, where diplomats from more than a dozen countries including the United States, Britain and Egypt are defying an order by Saddam to leave. ``I saw the American Embassy surrounded by the army. Tanks are around most embassies, including the Egyptian and American, with turrets and cannons pointed at the embassies,'' he said. ``I do not know what is happening inside the embassies, but at the American Embassy the Iraqis are not allowing anyone in or out, there is only a one-way man-made path that they control.'' The man described Kuwait City as a ``ghost city, especially after dark.'' The refugees were not being allowed to leave Khafji while their documents were being checked. The Saudis are worried about infiltration of spies and provocateurs. Refugees were transported to air-conditioned schools where they were to be fed and housed until they had all been processed, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Fireworks Fill Atlanta Sky After Olympic Announcement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `It's not...', to DELETE incorrect reference to Young being in Atlanta; he was in Tokyo.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Olympics-Atlanta, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fireworks and balloons filled Atlanta's morning sky today when the International Olympic Committee announced the city will be the site of the 1996 Summer Olympics. Pandemonium broke out at the downtown retail-entertainment complex called Underground Atlanta, where thousands of people gathered to watch the announcement over televisions broadcasting the IOC meeting live from Tokyo. Bright orange and green fireworks lighted the sky even though the sun had already risen when the news came about 7:50 a.m. The boom of the fireworks could be heard throughout downtown. A band played the Olympic theme, and strangers hugged each other. ``This was exciting. This was unbelievable,'' Mayor Maynard Jackson said at a news conference in Tokyo just after the vote. ``This proves that if you don't run the race, you don't have a chance to win.'' ``It's not my victory, it's a victory for Atlanta,'' said former Mayor Andrew Young, who helped lead the campaign for the Olympics. ``We have to thank God and pray that we are worthy and that all of the things that we have said, we can make come true.'' He also was in Tokyo. Atlanta entered the race late by most standards - in 1987 - with nine volunteers. Some cities spent more money on the bids; for example, Athens spent nearly $30 million compared with Atlanta's $750,000. And some spent more time: Belgrade entered the race in 1985. To win, a city needed 44 votes from the 88-member IOC. The committee's choice basically came down to the history and tradition of Athens or the 21st century stadiums, communications and commercial appeal of its rivals, which also included Belgrade, Yugoslavia; Manchester, England; Melbourne, Australia, and Toronto. According to a study done jointly by an accounting firm and the University of Georgia, the Games would pump $3.5 billion over six years into Georgia's economy, add 85,000 jobs and create global exposure. ``It made me feel I was making the Olympic team again,'' said Evander Holyfield, the former Olympic boxer who is from Atlanta. Seconds after the announcement, crowds in Atlanta were six-deep at an Atlanta Organizing Committee cart selling T-shirts and hats with the city's Olympic logo. In the minutes before the announcement, the crowd alternated between nervous silence and good-natured jeers as IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranch fumbled with the card holding the name of the host city. ``I wanted this so bad,'' said Janice Stockard of suburban Decatur. ``I wanted it because Atlanta's great. This means a lot. We got the Superbowl (for 1994) and now we got the Olympics.'' ``I am absolutely amazed. I can't believe Atlanta has gone from a place nobody thought had a chance to really getting those games,'' said Michael Lomax, chairman of the Fulton County Commission. Afterward, many in the crowd headed for work, but others hung around to scoop up the last remaining souvenirs and to get started on an all-day party planned for Underground Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Holds Records for Most Launch Delays
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Feb. 28...', to CORRECT that five delays was one short of second-place record, sted record, which is seven.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Columbia, NASA's oldest and most delayed shuttle, has been grounded three times in four months by hydrogen leaks and once by payload problems. Columbia set the record for the most launch delays in January 1986, when it was delayed seven times before a satellite delivery mission. So far this year, only three shuttles have flown. NASA originally planned nine missions for 1990, but now is hoping for six. The following is a chronology of this year's shuttle flights and Columbia's delays since May: Jan. 9 - Columbia lifts off on a mission to retrieve a scientific satellite. The flight had been scheduled for Dec. 18, but its launch pad was being refurbished and not ready. Bad weather delayed a Jan. 8 launch attempt. Feb. 28 - Atlantis is sent on a secret military mission following five delays due to bad weather and the commander's cold. It was one delay short of tying the second-place record for launch postponements. April 24 - Discovery is launched with the Hubble Space Telescope. An April 10 launch attempt had been halted with four minutes to go because of a faulty valve in a hydraulic power unit. May 29 - NASA called off Columbia's May 30 launch attempt after hydrogen leaked during fueling. It was the first countdown for the astronomy mission. Aug. 30 - NASA halted Columbia's second countdown, canceling a Sept. 1 launch attempt, because of a failed electronic part on one of four telescopes inside the shuttle. Sept. 5 - NASA called off Columbia's Sept. 6 launch attempt after hydrogen flooded the aft compartment during fueling. Sept. 17 - NASA scrubbed the Sept. 18 attempt after a hydrogen buildup was detected in Columbia's engine compartment.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Fire Kills Two In Battle Around Sri Lankan Fort
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels pounded a government fort with homemade mortars, rockets and machine guns, killing two policemen and wounding three soldiers, military officials said today. They said army sharpshooters picked off 27 Tamil Tiger rebels in surrounding bombed-out buildings and underground bunkers during battles around 17th century Jaffna Fort. On Monday, the military evacuated the 200-member garrison that had defended the fort during a three-month rebel siege, airlifting it to medical facilities in outposts in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. They left behind 300 other men who had earlier broken the rebel siege on the fortress. A defense ministry communique said 28 men have been killed and more than 140 injured since Aug. 22, when a major operation was launched to relieve the government soldiers holed up in the fort. The latest casualties, which occurred Monday, included a pilot whose plane crashed into a lagoon when it failed to pull out of a attack dive against a rebel gun position. The rebels claimed they downed the plane with a SAM-7 missile. The officials also said the Tigers were using a new incendiary mortar shell. ``It is a nasty firebomb. It explodes and sets everything ablaze in a tremendously wide radius when it hits its target,'' said one official, speaking under standing rules of anonymity. The military said it has been consolidating positions and inching out of the star-shaped fortress towards Jaffna town, across a few hundred yards of no-man's land. The Tigers say they still have the fort surrounded and have beaten back some reinforcements. The Dutch colonial fortress is the only government stronghold in the rebel-held town 185 miles northeast of Colombo. It is the political and military base of the rebels, who seek a Tamil homeland independent of the Sinhalese-dominated government. In the eastern Ampara district, police commandos on a search and destroy mission shot dead four rebels and discovered a field hospital near the Kanjimadichiaru village, north of Ampara town, the military officials said. In northeastern Trincomalee, troops also killed seven rebels in a clash at a rebel camp near the Sri Lankan naval dockyard, the officials said. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the insurrection, which broke out in 1983. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, accuse the Sinhalese of discrimination. Sinhalese constitute 75 percent of the population of this island off the southern tip of India.

DOC.HEAD: Government Accused of Suppressing Report Implicating Libya in Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A year after a French airliner was blown up over the Sahara, killing 170 people, the government stands accused of suppressing a report that implicates Libya. The UTA DC-10 exploded Sept. 19, 1989, over Niger en route from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris. The victims included the wife of the U.S. ambassador to Chad and a Chadian Cabinet minister. According to the French news magazine Le Point, investigators have determined that three Congolese dissidents carried out the bombing on the instructions of Libyan agents. French officials have refused to comment on the article or a subsequent report in The Times of London that said Syria, as well as Libya, had been implicated. The Times said France is withholding the findings of the investigation because it does not want to upset relations with Libya and Syria at this point in the Persian Gulf crisis set off by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. The investigation of the bombing has been headed by Judge Jean-Louis Bruguiere, one of France's leading experts on international terrorism. He reportedly briefed President Francois Mitterrand on his findings in early August, about the time of the Iraqi invasion. The inquiry gathered momentum after search teams, working in scorching desert heat, retrieved the victims' remains and aircraft debris that were scattered over 150 square miles of moonscape terrain in central Niger. Investigators reassembled the plane in a hangar outside Paris and eventually concluded that the bomb exploded inside a Samsonite suitcase loaded aboard the DC-10 in Brazzaville. According to Le Point, investigators identified the probable chief suspect as Apolinaire Mangatany, listed as boarding the plane in Brazzaville. Investigators reportedly suspect that Mangatany got off the plane during a stop in N'Djamena, Chad. Only 105 of the bodies of the victims were positively identified, and Mangatany's was not among them. In January, according to Le Point, Congolese security officers arrested one of Mangatany's associates, Bernard Yanga, and learned the identity of a third possible accomplice. Yanga, whose current whereabouts are unknown, rportedly recounted how the bombing was planned under the guidance of a Libyan Embassy staff member identified as Abdallah Elazrag. Yanga reportedly said the motive was to punish France for supporting Chad in its war against Libya. Two other possible motives have been suggested - retaliation for perceived French aid to Christian forces in Lebanon's civil war or an attempt to kill exiled Libyan opposition leader Yusuf al-Magariaf. According to Le Point and The Times, al-Magariaf decided at the last minute not to take the flight. The government plans a memorial service Wednesday in Paris in honor of the victims, but some relatives are upset by the handling of the inquiry. Claude Peinchaud, whose daughter died aboard the plane, expressed his anger to the newspaper Le Figaro last week. ``We have the right to know all the results of the inquiry,'' he said. ``It's essential that they tell us who the masterminds are and that those responsible are caught and punished. Too bad if this doesn't suit the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Two of Six Winners Claim Share in $106 Million Lotto Jackpot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with spokesman saying no new winners coming forward by midmorning. SUBS 12th graf, `Mrs. Smith...', to CORRECT that she is unmarried and add that her mother shares her prize with Ms. Smith's stepfather.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lottery-Investments, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A former autoworker living in a rented mobile home since he was laid off has stepped forward to claim his one-sixth share of Florida's $106.5 million lottery jackpot. A woman who last week set up a legal partnership with 11 relatives and friends in case they won also had her winning ticket verified Monday. The holders of the four other tickets good for a share of the nation's second-largest lottery jackpot remained unknown as of midmorning today, said lottery spokesman Ed George. The winners have six months to come forward. Each winner will get $17.75 million, before taxes, over 20 years, or $887,500 a year. The winning numbers were drawn Saturday night. One winner was Richard J. Piasecki, 58, a car-body repairman. He and his wife moved to a mobile home in New Smyrna Beach after he had to take early retirement from Chrysler when its Kenosha, Wis., plant closed in 1988. He had worked for the automaker for 32 years. Piasecki and his wife, Jeanne, plan to split their winnings with their daughter and son. The daughter, Mary Jo Bednarski, met her husband with the news by running into the driveway of their Wisconsin home in her bathrobe yelling, ``We're rich! We're rich!'' Piasecki and his wife plan to buy a small home with a little land, as well as a bigger motor home and a boat. Mrs. Piasecki also said the they plan to travel throughout the United States. Mrs. Bednarski, 34, said she is quitting her job at Hardee's and that she, her husband and their four children might move to Florida. The other winner who came forward Monday, Kathy Smith of Longwood, also said she'd share her newfound wealth with family members and friends. Legally, she has to. Her brother, Scott, a Tampa accountant, came up with the idea of creating a legal trust in case they won. He and the others - mostly relatives - signed the formal agreement last week. The group bought 50 tickets. Ms. Smith will get one-fourth of the $17.75 million share. Her brother and his wife will get another 25 percent, and Ms. Smith's mother and stepfather will get another quarter. Seven others will split the final 25 percent. Ms. Smith said she would not quit her job as a nurse in a doctor's office because she loved her work. The 34-year-old woman said she would buy a car and some land for horses. She said when she realized Sunday morning she had a ticket with all six numbers, ``I shook so bad I dropped the ticket.'' Pennsylvania holds the record for the nation's largest lottery jackpot, $115 million in April 1989. The holders of 14 tickets split the prize. The record for a lottery prize to a single winner is held by Florida. Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs won $55.1 million two years ago. Ms. Ryan called the Lottery Department on Monday to wish the new winners well, Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Proposes Code of Rights, Apologizes to Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with renaming of square. Pickup 19th graf pvs, `Underlining her...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today proposed that a 35-nation summit this fall adopt a universal code of rights for Europe and North America. In a speech to Czechoslovakia's parliament - the country's first democratically elected legislature in five decades - she also urged that the 12-nation European Community offer full membership to Czechoslovakia and Eastern Europe's other new democracies as soon as they have introduced Western-style economies. ``If we can create a great area of democracy stretching from the west coast of the United States right across to the Soviet Far East, that would give us the best guarantee of all for security - because democracies don't go to war with each other,'' the British leader said. Mrs. Thatcher also apologized for the 1938 Munich Treaty, in which Britain endorsed Adolf Hitler's division of Czechoslovakia. ``We failed you in 1938, when a disastrous policy of appeasement allowed Hitler to extinguish your independence,'' she said. Although Britain's wartime leader Winston Churchill was quick to repudiate the agreement, the British ``still remember it with shame,'' she added. ``In contrast to 1938, the United States, Europe and, indeed, the wider world have responded with an impressive display of unity to Saddam Hussein's aggression,'' she said of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Turning to Alexander Dubcek, whose 1968 Prague Spring attempts to create ``socialism with a human face'' were crushed by Soviet tanks, Mrs. Thatcher also referred ruefully to the West's lack of action then. ``The pictures of that brave venture are etched in our memory, and our inability to help remains a burden on the free world's conscience,'' she said. Dubcek is now president of Parliament. Mrs. Thatcher, the first British prime minister to visit Czechoslovakia, is on a trip celebrating the downfall of communism in Central Europe. She will also visit Hungary. Her visit followed one last week by French President Francois Mitterrand, whose country also signed the Munich agreement endorsing Hitler's annexation of the Sudetenland in northern Czechoslovakia. A year later Germany invaded Poland and World War II broke out. After her speech, Mrs. Thatcher walked to central Wenceslas Square with Dubcek and President Vaclav Havel. The square is the heart of Prague's peaceful November revolution and the British leader laid flowers at the statue of Bohemian patron St. Wenceslas - the rallying point for most of the revolution's protests. Crowds gathered despite the drizzle and applauded as Mrs. Thatcher laid the flowers and then went over to shake hands with several well-wishers. Before leaving Prague for Bratislava, she formally renamed a nearby square Winston Churchill Square after Britain's World War II leader. It was formerly named after Antonin Zapotocky, a post-war Communist Party secretary. In Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, she planned to meet with Slovak leaders before leaving for Budapest late today. Underlining her proposal for a 35-nation universal code of rights, Mrs. Thatcher presented the assembly with a copy of England's 13th century Magna Carta, which guaranteed basic freedoms for the population. Mrs. Thatcher did not provide details of her proposal, but it seemed to involve a document guaranteeing basic human rights. She said she wanted a ``European Magna Carta'' adopted at the summit of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to be held in Paris in November. The conference includes all European countries, except Albania, in addition to the United States and Canada. Mrs. Thatcher has urged repeatedly that the group become a key consultative body for the new Europe and its relations with North America following the collapse of Communist rule in most of the East Bloc last year and reforms in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Attack Georgian KGB Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Nationalist protesters attacked KGB headquarters in the capital of the republic of Georgia, smashing windows and hurling documents into the street, Soviet news agencies and newspapers reported today. The attack early Monday in the city of Tbilisi followed a demonstration by members of the ``Round Table,'' who declared the formation of a ``Free Georgia'' bloc of political parties for elections next month, the Tass news agency reported. The demonstrators demanded the release of activist David Gelashvili, who was arrested on charges of illegally storing firearms and attacking a police station, according to Tass and the independent Postfactum news agency. Gelashvili later was freed on bail on Monday, Postfactum reported. According to the newspaper Red Star, marchers stormed the first and second floors of the KGB headquarters. They ransacked offices of the secret police's investigation department, broke windows, threw documents in the street and stole some papers, the newspaper said. Postfactum reported that some firearms were stolen. No arrests were reported. According to Red Star, the local police decided not to interfere in the demonstration. The Sunday evening rally was addressed by Zviyad Gamsakhurdia, who leads the ``Round Table,'' Red Star reported. The group's platform urges outlawing Soviet power in Georgia, proclaiming the republic's independence, and preventing Communist Party members from being elected to parliament, the newspaper said. Nationalists also want the KGB disbanded in Georgia, Postfactum reported, and it quoted Gamsakhurdia as saying demonstrations against the secret police will continue in the republic. On Oct. 28, Georgia will hold multiparty elections that were postponed in June to give parties time to organize against the ruling Communists. Pro-independence groups have done well in local elections this year elsewhere in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Prime Minister Threatens to Resist Radical Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th, `Asked by...' with Ryzhkov comment last week.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov indicated today he will resign or refuse to cooperate if the national legislature adopts radical economic reforms that he opposes. Ryzhkov's comments came during a break in the Supreme Soviet legislature's second day of debate over three competing economic reform plans, the most conservative of which Ryzhkov put forward last week. As prime minister, Ryzhkov, 61, oversees the government bureaucracy and could play a key role in putting any reform plan into effect - or obstructing it. Asked by a reporter whether he would step down if the legislature rejected his plan, Ryzhkov said: ``I will carry out that in which I believe. That's all. I will not carry out any other (plan).'' Ryzhkov also said last week that if his plan was defeated, he would ``take responsibility for it before the people and the Supreme Soviet.'' But he has avoided making a clear promise to step aside if radical reforms are enacted. Several leading reformers, including Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, have demanded Ryzhkov's resignation since he presented his plan, which envisions continued central control of the economy while slow moves are made toward a market-based system. By contrast, the radical reform plan adopted a week ago by the parliament of Russia, the largest Soviet republic, calls for switching to a market within just 500 days. It would retur land to private farmers, sell government enterprises to private stockholders and gradually remove state-controlled prices on many goods. Thousands of people marched through Moscow on Sunday to demand that Ryzhkov resign for failing to improve the Soviet economy, plagued by shortages of consumer goods ranging from tobacco to paper and shoes. But President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rejected those demands Monday, telling parliament that reshuffling ``the top echelons of power ... would draw us into grim political battles, (and) would heighten confrontation in society at a time when we most badly need consolidation to carry out the market economy program.'' Instead, Gorbachev proposed a national referendum on ending collectivized farming. He did not say when the referendum would be held, who would vote or where he personally stood on the issue. Soviet peasants were coerced into joining collective farms and all land became state property during a 1929-1932 campaign led by Josef Stalin that is believed to have claimed the lives of between 5 million and 10 million people. Gorbachev has backed a compromise economic plan that contains many elements of the radical 500-day plan but would move at a slower pace and not disturb the central government's power to levy taxes. The compromise proposal also backs away from private ownership of land. While economist Stanislav Shatalin's 500-day plan calls for selling some land to individuals for nominal prices, the compromise calls for leasing it. Gorbachev apparently is reluctant, either personally or politically, to part with six decades of Communist Party ideological opposition to private ownership of land, said Professor Murray Feshbach of Georgetown University in Washington. ``Gorbachev just can't bring himself to turn in his party card,'' Feshbach said in a telephone interview. Gorbachev has urged a compromise to avoid a split with the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics with half the country's people and three-quarters of its land. The Russian parliament overwhelmingly adopted Shatalin's 500-day plan last week.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-General Fired
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, tapped to succeed fired Air Force Chief of Staff Michael J. Dugan, is a much-decorated pilot who has flown combat missions in Vietnam and performed in daring air shows at home. McPeak, 54, is commander in chief of the Pacific Air Forces at Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii. His responsibility includes U.S. air operations over half the globe - from Japan to the United States. He commands over 60,000 people. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Monday he would recommend to President Bush that McPeak replace Dugan, whom Cheney dismissed for revealing to reporters U.S. contingency plans to bomb Baghdad and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Cheney said Dugan, a four-star general, displayed ``lack of judgment.'' McPeak entered the Air Force in 1957, getting his pilot wings a year later. In his 33 years of service, McPeak has flown over 4,000 hours on fighter planes and also became a skilled parachutist. For two years starting in 1966, he flew solo or the lead position in nearly 200 air shows as a member of the Thunderbirds - the U.S. Air Force Air Demonstration Squadron. The stunt flying was good preparation for his next mission: Vietnam. McPeak flew 269 combat sorties during the year he served there, earning several decorations. He then turned to the academic world, completing the National War College in 1974 and earning a master's degree at the same time. McPeak was assigned to command U.S. air bases in England and Spain, and was promoted to chief of staff of U.S. air forces in Europe. He subsequently held several command positions at home, assuming his current job in July 1988. He was made a full general at the same time. McPeak is married and has two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Soar From Gulf Crisis, Europe Strengthens Its Resolve
LaserColor DHA101, NY8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Japanese team arriving in Saudi Arabia, alleged Gorbachev quote about Saddam, edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: As European nations showed strengthened resolve in the Persian Gulf crisis, the United States today indicated the toll it has taken at home, reporting that soaring energy prices last month pushed the cost of living up by 0.8 percent. Members of nine European nations were meeting today in Paris to discuss building up their forces in the gulf. The meeting came as European countries joined President Bush in expressing support for expanding U.N. sanctions against Iraq to air corridors. The governments were angered by Iraq's rough treatment of Western diplomats in occupied Kuwait last week, when some had their compounds raided. The latest picture of the situation inside Kuwait, drawn from the tales of refugees suddenly allowed to flee via the lone border crossing into Saudi Arabia, was of a wealthy nation broken and in despair. Stunned refugees among the thousands who have fled their homeland since the border was opened Saturday told of husbands and sons pulled out of cars and hauled away by Iraqi troops. The Iraqis were not explaining what they intended to do with the men. Because of the apparently random seizures of men ages 17 to 40, the number of refugees crossing into Saudi Arabia had decreased to a trickle today. Iraqi soldiers were allowing one car across the border every 10 minutes or so. Refugees said today that the Iraqis had set up six checkpoints on the 120-mile route from Kuwait City to the Khafji border crossing. They said the Iraqis - seeking to break their spirit - had mounted an escalating campaign of torture, beatings and shootings. One fleeing professional said the Iraqis were out ``to demolish anything that has to do with Kuwait'' or its ruling al-Sabah family, changing the names of streets, hospitals, traffic circles. The al-Sabahs, forced into exile by Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion, say the Iraqi leader intends to empty their oil-rich land of its people. ``It is all becoming Iraqi,'' the professional said, estimating that just 300,000 Kuwaiti nationals remain behind, with about half a million having fled. Saddam has declared Kuwait part of Iraq and annexed it, and the professional said a prominent traffic circle in Kuwait City was being demolished to make way for a life-size statue of Saddam. In Washington, meanwhile, the government said the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 had sent gasoline prices up by 7.6 percent and fuel prices jumped 15.4 percent - the steepest rise in those categories since January. Economists said they believe more bad news is coming. They said crude prices continued to rise in September and the increase would be felt at the gas pump. Diplomatic activity continued today with the announcement that Syrian President Hafez Assad would make his first trip to Iran, a strong ally. Assad will fly to Tehran next week to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the issue of hostages in Lebanon and Iran's poor relations with Egypt and Saudi Arabia, now allied with Syria against Iraq, officials in Iran and Syria said. The visit was expected to boost Assad's drive to project himself as a dependable ally of the West and clean up his country's image. Also, PLO chief Yasser Arafat arrived in Amman, Jordan, for talks with King Hussein. Arafat arrived from Baghdad, where he met with Saddam to discuss ways to resolve the crisis. In Paris, defense and foreign ministers of nine nations were to gather to discuss building up Western European forces in the gulf following a dramatic rise in tensions between Europe and Iraq in recent days. The French navy, meanwhile, announced that France, Britain, Italy and the Netherlands have carved out patrol districts in the gulf region distinct from U.S. and Australian flotillas - part of France's quest to maintain military independence. Meeting in Brussels on Monday, foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community agreed to expel all Iraqi military attaches in retaliation for the Iraqi raids Friday on the French, Belgian, Dutch and Canadian embassy compounds in Kuwait. They also restricted the movement of Iraq's diplomats and called on the Iraq to ``realize the suicidal character of its behavior toward the international community.'' In addition, Britain ousted eight officials at the Iraqi Embassy and deported 23 other Iraqi citizens. France has expelled 29 Iraqis since Friday. A 17-member Japanese medical team flew to Saudi Arabia today, the first Japanese personnel sent to assist the U.S.-led force against Iraq. The five doctors, four nurses and eight support staff will visit the capital, Riyadh, and other major Saudi cities for about two months to study how a planned 100-member Japanese medical contingent will be able to contribute to the gulf force, the Foreign Ministry said.
