Japan, after being criticized for moving too slowly, has pledged $4 billion to the U.S.-led multinational gulf forces. President Bush on Monday endorsed expanding the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq to include air traffic. ``What we want to do is tighten up the United Nations sanctions so nothing is going in,'' he told reporters in Washington. ``Some countries ... seem to be more willing than others to avoid the sanctions.'' The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council have been meeting since the weekend, but Western diplomats say it will be difficult to achieve unanimity on the air blockade issue. The United States, Britain and France support the blockade, but China and the Soviet Union were said to oppose it. All five council members appeared to back a resolution that would take punitive measures against violators of the existing embargo. An air blockade is considered risky because halting planes is difficult without the use of deadly force. Bush said Americans were ``magnificently united'' behind the deployment of some 150,000 U.S. troops in the region to stand up to Saddam and forestall a possible invasion of Saudi Arabia. But he acknowledged: ``I'm not clear in my own mind how long this kind of support holds up.'' In an indication of the sensitivity surrounding the U.S. deployment, the head of the air force was fired Monday after discussing contingency plans for air strikes against Baghdad. Air Force chief of staff Gen. Mike Dugan, made the remarks while touring U.S. military installations in Saudi Arabia, and they were published Sunday in The Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times. ``There are certain things we never talk about,'' an angry Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters in Washington. Also today in Jerusalem, an Israeli Cabinet minister said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had called Saddam a ``wild beast'' during a meeting last week in Moscow with two Israeli officials. The talks were the highest-level encounter between the two countries, which have had no formal relations since Moscow cut the ties in 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Re-ignites on Saginaw River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with officials deciding today whether to let fire burn itself out, authorities fly over site by helicopter. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `The M.V. . . .'.
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline-laden tanker on the Saginaw River burned early today after a series of explosions reignited flames that firefighters doused hours earlier. The Coast Guard said it was too dangerous to try to put out the fire aboard the listing hulk in the dark. This morning, officials again were considering whether to let the fire burn itself out or apply foam to the blaze. And authorities flew over the site by helicopter to check for signs of environmental damage. The M.V. Jupiter, carrying 1 million gallons of gasoline, first exploded and burned while unloading at a pier Sunday, leaving one crew member missing and presumed dead. Three others remained hospitalized today in fair condition. The fire burned nearly 30 hours before specialists from Texas smothered it with foam Monday afternoon. But eight hours later, the ship exploded again. ``Obviously, the vessel was still hot and there was still fuel in the cargo bin,'' said Dan Lacy, a spokesman for Ashland Oil Inc. of Ashland, Ky., parent of Cleveland Tankers Inc., which owns the tanker. No new injuries were reported early today. Coast Guard Petty Officer Patrick Higgins said firefighters hoped to quench the flames again using foam. Authorities planned to inspect the crippled ship to gauge damage, how much fuel remained and how to remove the fuel and the tanker. State police Lt. Robert Nelson the Jupiter may have to be pumped free of fuel, water and firefighting chemicals before it can be moved. By the time the blaze was put out Monday, the rail of the ship where the fire was most intense had sunk to within 6 inches of the water's surface and some fuel splashed out and burned on the water, said Terry Walkington, spokesman for the state Department of Natural Resources. Barbara Singleton, a sheriff's emergency worker, was sitting in a car with a co-worker on shore near the ship when it exploded again. ``I went out one door and he went out the other,'' Singleton said. ``About a minute after the blast ... there came that smell again'' of burning gasoline. State specialists were awaiting results of air- and water-pollution tests after hundreds of dead fish washed ashore near the tanker but said there was little evidence of a big pill downtream. ``We don't know if it was the explosion, or if it was from the heat that caused stress on the fish,'' said Mike Moore, Department fo Natural Resources deputy director. The cause of the explosion was unclear, but Ashland spokesman Lacy said the wake of a passing ship could have parted some of the Jupiter's mooring lines and its gasoline transfer connection, spilling fuel that ignited the blast.

DOC.HEAD: Police Plan DNA Tests on Former Minister Suspected in Wife's Attack
DOC.TEXT: Blood and saliva taken from a former Dallas minister suspected in the near strangulation of his wife will be used for DNA profiling, a newspaper reported today. Federal and local authorities hope the scientific process will help identify the attacker of Margaret Railey, who has been comatose since the attack in April 1987, the Dallas Times Herald reported. Walker Railey, formerly a prominent Methodist minister, has been the only suspect. While maintaining his innocence, he has declined to testify before a grand jury, and a judge found him responsible in a civil proceeding. FBI agents in California on Friday took Railey to a detention center, where he gave court-ordered blood and saliva samples. FBI and Dallas police wouldn't comment officially, but sources within both agencies told the newspaper they were taking the body fluids for DNA testing. DNA - deoxyribonucleic acid - is found in every cell and is unique in each person. Its use as an identification tool is considered the most important development in criminal investigations since fingerprinting. Body tissue, such as hair, skin or blood, is often found at crime scenes. The Railey attack happened before DNA testing was available, but the technique can still be applied because ``there is a long shelf life of the physical evidence,'' the newspaper quoted an unidentified FBI agent as saying. Norman Kinne, the chief assistant Dallas district attorney, said DNA profiling of Railey was the FBI's idea. He added that if the testing links Railey to the crime scene, ``it certainly would be significant to the case.'' The FBI has been investigating the attack because of Railey's claims he received threatening letters before his wife was attacked. Police later concluded that they had been typed at Railey's own church. Mrs. Railey was attacked in the garage of the couple's home while Railey claimed to have been at a library. It was later determined he also had been at the home of his mistress, a Dallas psychologist with whom he later lived in California. At the time of the attack, Railey was pastor at the 6,000-member First United Methodist Church of Dallas. Subsequently, he left the ministry, gave guardianship of his two children over to friends, and moved to California. Railey was held responsible for his wife's attack in a civil trial and was ordered to pay $18 million. He has since filed for divorce from Mrs. Railey, who remains in a vegetative state in a nursing home.

DOC.HEAD: Assad to Visit Tehran to Discuss Gulf, Hostages
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs penultimate graf, `The United States...' to CORRECT name of group.
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad of Syria will make his first trip to his ally Iran next week to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis and Western hostages in Lebanon, diplomats said today. Official announcements in Tehran and Damascus said that Asasd will fly to Iran ``next week'' at the invitation of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Tehran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said, ``Observers attach special significance to President Assad's visit in the wake of the crisis in the Persian Gulf.'' It did not elaborate on the topics to be discussed nor mention the length of the visit. Diplomats in Damascus, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a number of sensitive issues were expected to be on the Assad's agenda - the gulf crisis, the plight of Western hostages in Lebanon, and Iran's poor relations with Egypt and Saudi Arabia, with whom Damascus is allied in the confrontation with Iraq. The visit was expected to boost Assad's drive to project himself as a dependable ally of the West and clean up his country's image after years of isolation because of its implication in terrorism. The trip follows talks in Damascus last week between Assad and Secretary of State James Baker III. That was the first major face-to-face contact between Damascus and Washington since President Bush was elected in 1988. On his trip, Baker won a pledge from Assad to commit more troops and armor to a U.S.-led multinational force that assembled in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. About 4,000 Syrian troops already had been sent to the region, and diplomats said Assad promised to send 15,000 more. Assad's stance on the gulf crisis, motivated largely by personal hatred of Iraq's Saddam Hussein and loyalty toward his Kuwaiti bankrollers, marks the first time that he has sided with the United States in a Middle East conflict. Baker said while in Damascus that he was concerned about Iranian calls for a jihad, or holy war, against foreign forces in the gulf. U.S. officials also have been alarmed by reports that Iran was punching holes in the emabrgo imposed on Iraq by the U.N. Security Council. Many foodstuffs tat had disappeared from the Iraqi market have reappeared in recent days and residents have said the goods are coming from Iran, Iraq's enemy in a 1980-88 war. Diplomats in Damascus said the talks with Iran may produce a breakthrough on the hostages in Lebanon, although Baker said Assad did not indicate a hostage release was imminent. Six of the 13 Western captives held in Lebanon are Americans. The others are four Britons, two Western Germans and an Italian. American journalist Terry Anderson, 42, is the longest-held hostage. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon with 40,000 of its troops controlling two-thirds of the country. But it has avoided a showdown with the Shiite extremists, mainly because Iran had been its only ally while the Western world rallied against Damascus. The Syrian government was implicated in the April 1986 attempt to blow up an Israeli jetliner at London's Heathrow Airport. The explosion of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in which 290 people were killed in December 1988, was blamed on the radical Popular front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. The United States urged Damascus to close down PFLP-GC bases in Syria and expel the group's leader, Ahmed Jibril, a former Syrian army captain. But Syria refused on the grounds the evidence implicating Jibril was not solid. Baker said before he left Damascus that the differences over terrorism and Jibril's presence in Syria remained unresolved.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Supporters Oppose Souter Nomination
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of abortion rights asked the Senate Judiciary Committee today to reject David Souter's nomination to the Supreme Court. ``The health and lives of millions of American women'' are at stake, they said. A leading conservative, meanwhile, said Souter should not be confirmed because he hasn't done enough to stop abortion. In three days of testimony that ended Monday night, Souter declined to disclose his views on abortion. The nominee said he had not made up his mind on whether to overturn the 1973 court ruling legalizing abortion. ``We consider placing Judge Souter on the Supreme Court to be too great a risk,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``The health and lives of million of American women, for generations to come, may depend on where David Souter stands,'' said Faye Wattleton, president of Planned Parenthood of America. Their testimony was criticized by committee members, including Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo., himself a backer of abortion rights. ``You're making a big mistake,'' Simpson said. ``There are going to be other Supreme Court cases, where you're really going to have to be in the trenches,'' he said. Simpson added that, as a federal judge, Souter could not answer the abortion question because of judicial ethics. A strong anti-abortion conservative, Howard Phillips, said in prepared testimony that Souter should be rejected as too pro-abortion. Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus, cited the fact that Souter served on the boards of two hospitals where abortions were performed and had gone along with the practice. ``He lacked the moral courage or discernment to help prevent the destruction of so many innocent human lives when he had the authority - indeed the responsibility - to do so,'' Phillips said. Committee members said Souter appeared assured of confirmation when his testimony ended Monday night. Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., told Souter his appearance had been ``a tour de force on your part.'' Biden said some senators, including himself, were still undecided on the nomination. But he told Souter, who marked his 51st birthday Monday, that cause to celebrate could come ``in two or three weeks'' - the presumed schedule for committee approval and Senate confirmation. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., who repeatedly probed Souter's suitability with questions on rights issues, including abortion, appeared to concede at the end that Souter would be confirmed. As the New Hampshire judge's appearance drew to a close Monday night, Kennedy told Souter that he would tip the balance in discrimination cases before the court. ``You're going to be, really, the swing (vote) on this issue as well as many others,'' he said. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., asked Souter to ``err on the side of freedom'' once on the court. Simpson, reflecting the apparent unanimous support of the six Republicans on the 14-member panel, told Souter he had impressed the nation during the televised testimony. ``Out in the land, there is a good feeling,'' said Simpson. ``A lot of people have the feeling that your confirmation processis over,'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., told Souter. In his testimony, Souter worked without the help of notes and displayed a vast knowledge of constitutional disputes. But he avoided giving the committee even a clue of how he would vote on the hottest issues before the court. All three days, Souter repeatedly pushed aside attempts by senators on both sides of the issue to extract his views on abortion. He maintained his mind was still open. On Monday, he expressed his appreciation for the gravity of the case, saying that overturning the 1973 Roe vs. Wade abortion decision would affect thousands of lives, could result in widely different laws from state to state, and could throw into question other rulings on privacy issues. On other topics Monday, he: -Said he believed the death penalty was constitutional and not prohibited by the ban on ``cruel and unusual punishment.'' -Stated that he wished he had insisted, while New Hampshire's attorney general, that the state return money to a utility that donated funds for prosecuting protesters at its Seabrook nuclear plant. -Repeated his aversion to being portrayed personally as an isolated scholar unaware of societal problems, and promised to learn more about the nation as he had with his native state. ``We cannot seal ourselves away,'' he said of the judiciary. After completing its hearings, the Judiciary Committee will meet to vote on the Souter nomination and send its recommendation to the full Senate. Sen. Herbert Kohl, D-Wis., the newest committee member going through his first Supreme Court confirmation process, said he thought Souter had gone far to ensure his success. But he expressed doubt the hearings had unveiled the nominee's thoughts. While Souter's record suggested he was very conservative, Kohl said, he appeared before the committee as a moderate. ``There's a certain mystery'' as to how he will appear on the court, Kohl said. ``We can't open up a person's mind.''

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Wins '96 Olympic Games
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for 14th, `Atlanta joined...' with 1 graf to ADD that St. Louis also hosted Summer Games, adds 4 grafs at end with background on how games will be staggered beginning in 1992. No pickup. ^LaserPhotos AX2,TOK10
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta brought the Olympics to the American South today, winning a long race over Athens and four other rivals to be host of the 1996 Summer Games. The victory in voting by the International Olympic Committee means the 100th birthday of the modern Olympics will be staged in one of the world's most modern cities and take the Games into their second century on a high-tech, big-money road. The decision, read from a sealed ballot by International Olympic Committee President Juan Antonio Samaranch, ended the hopes of Athens to stage the '96 Games in the country where the Olympics were born in 776 B.C. and reincarnated in 1896. Atlanta had entered the final days of the four-year contest generally rated among the front-runners. It received a boost in its formal presentation with a videotaped appeal by President Bush. It caught Athens on the third of the maximum five ballots, took the lead on the fourth and won it 51-35 as it picked up most of the 22 votes Toronto had on the previous round. Other runners-up, in order of their elimination, were Belgrade, Yugoslavia; Manchester, England; and Melbourne, Australia. Atlanta is world headquarters of Coca-Cola, one of the Olympics' biggest sponsors. It is the home of pro football, baseball and basketball teams, prestigious universities large and small, and the civil rights movement. It's ``Gone with the Wind'' and Stone Mountain, catfish and Cable News Network's Ted Turner. And now, it's also an Olympic city. In Atlanta today, fireworks and balloons filled the morning sky when the International Olympic Committee gave the city the Games. Thousands of people, gathered at the Underground Atlanta shopping and entertainment district for an Olympic party, shouted with joy when they heard the announcement over huge televisions broadcasting the committee meeting live from Tokyo. The boom of fireworks could be heard throughout the downtown area. A band played the Olympic theme, and strangers hugged each other. ``I am absolutely amazed. I can't believe Atlanta has gone from a place nobody thought had a chance to really getting those games,'' said Michael Lomax, chairman of the Fulton County Commission. ``It made me feel I was making the Olympic team again,'' said Evander Holyfield, the former Olympic boxer who is from Atlanta. Atlanta joined Los Angeles (1932 and 1984) and St. Louis (1904) as U.S. Summer Olympic hosts. The '84 Games ushered in an era of unimagined money for the International Olympic Committee, and holding the Games in Atlanta increased the chances for big money from American TV networks. The IOC announced last week the Olympic movement would make $1.84 billion in the four years leading up to 1992, not bad for an organization that was almost broke a decade ago. With solid facilities built or planned, impeccable hotels and infrastructure and glowing reports from various evaluation commissions, the International Olympic Committee decided to go for the gold again. ``The IOC awards the 1996 Olympic Games to the city of Atlanta,'' Samaranch said. The Atlanta delegation, led by chief organizer Billy Payne, appeared overcome by joy. Payne had left the session room in tears after presenting Atlanta's final report earlier in the day. The conference hall erupted in cheers. Greece was the birthplace of the Olympics, and staged their rebirth a century ago. Athens had good facilities, and it certainly had history on its side. ``We have sent the torch away 25 times in 100 years. We are only asking for it once,'' Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis told the members. But Spyros Metaxa, the leader of Athens' campaign, had upset some Olympic Committee members by saying that ``morally, the Games belong to us.'' The Greeks also were accused of arrogance and flouting the rules of the bidding. Exiled King Constantine of Greece, an International Olympic Committee member, said he was ``deeply disappointed along with all Greeks that the centenary Games were not awarded to Athens.'' ``But we must bow to the democratic process of the IOC and I congratulate the winner on its successful election,'' Constantine said. Beginning in 1994, the Summer and Winter Olympic Games will be staggered, rather than held during the same year. For example in 1992, the Winter Games will be held Feb. 8-23 in Albertville, France, and the Summer Games July 25-Aug. 9 in Barcelona, Spain. In 1994, the Winter Games will be held in Lillehammer, Norway, followed two years later by the Summer Games in Atlanta. The cities bidding for the 1998 Winter Games include Salt Lake City; Aosta, Italy; Jaca, Spain; Nagano, Japan; Ostersund, Sweden, and Sotchi, U.S.S.R.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Presidential Election Set for Nov. 7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf at end on earlier uncontested seating of president
DOC.TEXT: Ireland's first contested presidential election in 17 years will be held on Nov. 7, the government said today. A civil rights activist from Northern Ireland, a women's rights campaigner from Dublin and a popular defense minister are in the race to succeed President Patrick Hillery, who is barred from seeking a third seven-year term. Fianna Fail, the nation's largest political party, on Monday nominated Defense Minister Brian Lenihan for the largely ceremonial post. Fine Gael, the second-largest party, earlier selected Austin Currie, a Roman Catholic civil rights leader. The Labor Party nominated Mary Robinson, a lawyer and former member of the Irish senate. Lenihan, 59, was foreign minister from 1987 to 1989, and he is also the deputy prime minister. Currie, 50, was a leader in the Catholic civil rights campaign in Northern Ireland in the 1960s and a founder of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the largest predominantly Catholic political party in the province. He and his family moved to Ireland last year. He says that Northern Ireland will be an issue in his campaign, because ``it is one of the greatest problems facing this nation as a whole.'' Mrs. Robinson, 46, has been a champion of women's rights and of liberal social legislation such as the ill-fated attempt to legalize divorce in 1986. Last year, she successfully defended students at Trinity College against an anti-abortion group's attempt to prevent them from distributing information about abortion services in Britain. The incumbent, Hillery, was chosen under an all-party agreement in 1976, and was installed as president without an election. In 1983, parties also agreed on Hillery, and no polling was held for the post.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT. Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Carter Outpolling Reagan
With AM-Disenchanted Voters, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Carter is outpolling Ronald Reagan. A Times Mirror survey released Tuesday found that Carter gets higher favorability ratings than Reagan. Sixty-seven percent of the people questioned said they had a very favorable or mostly favorable opinion of Carter, while 62 percent had comparable views of Reagan, the man who defeated Carter in 1980. Despite recent favorable attention connected to the opening of his presidential library, Richard M. Nixon continues to be held in low esteem. Thirty-eight percent had favorable opinions of Nixon, while 58 percent viewed him unfavorably. The results were based on interviews with 3,004 adults and had a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Fire Tear Gas To Disperse Demonstrators in Burma
DOC.TEXT: Burmese security forces fired tear gas to disperse rock-hurling students and other demonstrators in a high school compound, Burma's state radio reported. Three security personnel were injured by the rocks during the clash Monday in Mandalay, the country's second-largest city, the radio said. It said several demonstrators were detained. A transcript of Monday's broadcast was seen in Bangkok on Tuesday. Accounts from Western diplomats in Rangoon suggest that the radio generally downplays the seriousness of demonstrations and the extent of injuries to demonstrators. The clash occurred on the eve of the anniversary of the brutal military takeover of Sept. 18, 1988. In it, Army Chief Gen. Saw Maung overthrew civilian President Maung Maung and his soldiers killed hundreds of unarmed pro-democracy demonstrators. In May, Saw Maung allowed the country's first free elections in three decades but he has not allowed the victorious National League For Democracy to form a new government. Instead, he has imprisoned the party's leaders as well as students and other supporters. Mandalay was a center of the 1988 uprising. The state radio said Monday's clash began when five students who had been expelled from the highs achool climbed over its back wall, wielding a sword, a dagger and slingshots. They joined students who were waiting for them and unfurled a flag, chanted slogans, made threats, and called on students in the classrooms to join in, the broadcast said. It said they then threatened the principal and a teacher with their weapons. In a field in front of the school, they burned examination papers they had seized from students. The broadcast said security personnel appealed to the crowd of about 50 onlookers to disperse before moving in. But it said students and others were ``bent on creating disturbances.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Timely Play Of Soviet Card By Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The restoration of diplomatic ties between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia further isolates Iraq and allows the kingdom to counter Iraqi charges that it is too dependent on the United States. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait helped speed the Soviet-Saudi agreement to exchange ambassadors for the first time in 52 years. The agreement was announced Monday in Moscow. ``This is a move that has been in the works for a long time and is the natural culmination of a series of events,'' said a Western diplomatic source. ``There was no question that it would come within a year, but the events of Aug. 2 accelerated it.'' The agreement also paves the way for arms deals between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia, which has long been allied with the United States. Prince Abdul-Rahman bin Abdul-Aziz, the deputy defense minister, made off-the-cuff comments to reporters Tuesday referring to the general Saudi military procurement policy of seeking ``developed weapons whatever the type.'' ``The Soviet Union is a superpower and events have proved it is an important element of the United Nations and its resolutions,'' Prince Abdul-Rahman said. The Soviets have endorsed seven Security Council resolutions against Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait. Moscow also has cut off arms shipments to its longtime ally. In Moscow on Tuesday, the Saudi foreign minister noted that, like the Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia had been a previous ally of Baghdad. ``Saudi Arabia stood with Iraq through many crises and we supported Iraq in every possible way,'' Prince Saud Al-Faisal said at a news conference. ``When these two countries stand together for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and for territorial legitimacy and identify their position in a common way, this, I believe, should give a message to the leadership of Iraq that their position is untenable,'' Saud said. Pro-government Saudi papers welcomed the diplomatic relations. The daily Okaz underscored the importance of the ties with a country ``of such important political weight ... which has has lately been clearly evident through the balanced policy that won wide international support.'' The Saudi newspapers noted that Soviet transformations on religious freedom and human rights were conducive to a policy ``much in harmony with the kingdom's policy,'' Okaz said. Riyadh-based diplomats said that while the Persian Gulf crisis has accelerated the re-establishment of formal relations, they were not surprised at the development. ``It was the most logical move,'' said one diplomat, who like the others spoke on condition of anonymity. When Saudi Arabia forged diplomatic ties with China in July, experts predicted that relations with the Soviet Union would follow within a year. During the Persian Gulf war, one source said, the Saudis realized the advantage of having diplomatic relations with all permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. With the formal exchange of envoys with the Soviet Union, the Saudis will have achieved that goal. The communique issued Monday stated that both countries would ``work actively to achieve settlements to regional conflicts, develop international cooperation, and strengthen overall peace and security.'' Sources here say the Soviet Union is not likely to contribute either militarily or monetarily to solve the gulf crisis. ``The Soviet Union is so absorbed in its own problems, they shouldn't be expected to contribute forces,'' one diplomat said. ``But what they're doing in the U.N. has been quite helpful. It's an extra show of solidarity.'' The Soviet Union, the first country to officially recognize King Abdul Aziz of Saudi Arabia, called back its last ambassador to the kingdom in 1938. He was later executed.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Years After His Death, Hendrix Fans Keep Guitar Great's Memory Alive
LaserPhoto SE3
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years after his death, legendary rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix still packs 'em in. They don't come in large numbers at any one time, but they come. Some bring guitars, some bring flowers. Visitors might spend a little time at his grave, strumming tunes. ``The crowds here have mellowed a bit, as has the mood of the country,'' said Hank Kerns, general manager of Greenwood Memorial Park, where Hendrix is buried. ``Once in a while they'll leave a beer can, but we're careful to get it picked up right away.'' Kerns said the number of visitors to Hendrix's grave has increased during the past few years, and the Goodwill Games brought more than usual. One national magazine, he said, listed visiting the gravesite as one of the things to do in Seattle while attending the international athletic contest. Hendrix died in London on Sept. 18, 1970. According to coroner's records, he died when he choked on his vomit. A non-lethal amount of barbituate drugs was found in his system. ``Forever in our hearts,'' reads his headstone, which includes an electric guitar carved in bas-relief. There is little to indicate he was the king of acid rock, but by the time of his death at age 27 he had forged a lasting legacy. ``I heard he was buried around here. I needed to make the pilgrimage,'' Peg Wood said Sunday during a visit to the cemetery. The 26-year-old recently moved to Seattle from Illinois to begin an internship with the Veterans Administration as she pursues a Ph.D. in psychology. Her ``other life'' is playing rock guitar. ``My parents named me Peggy Sue, for God's sake. I was destined for a life of decadent rock 'n' roll,'' she said, laughing. Hendrix, who grew up in Seattle's predominantly black Central Area, was about 14 when he talked his father into buying him a $5 used guitar, according to Al Hendrix. ``He wore that thing out,'' the father said. ``Later on I got him his first electric guitar and I got a sax. I didn't know much about the sax and he didn't know much about the guitar. So we'd make quite a bit of noise.'' At first, the young Hendrix was content to play along with recordings of blues greats B.B. King and Muddy Waters. ``So I told him, `Come up with something original,' and he did,'' recalled Al Hendrix. ``The first time I heard `Are You Experienced?' (the first Jimi Hendrix Experience album), it was something altogether different than what I was used to listening to.'' It didn't take long for the elder Hendrix to become one of his son's biggest fans. Innovative, sometimes outrageous and blaring with his music, Jimi was quiet and unassuming offstage, his father said. Al Hendrix still goes to his son's grave about once a month, still gets a kick out of recalling the times he has found fans sitting around the grave with guitars in hand. Fans frequently leave small items. Peg Wood added a guitar pick to the collection there. ``He was the most inventive guitar player I ever heard,'' she said. ``I like the blues. But I felt he rewrote them. He changed the rules so that there weren't any rules. He freed me up.''

DOC.HEAD: `Mother of the Nation' Faces Another Crisis
With AM-Winnie Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: She was once known as ``Mother of the Nation,'' a symbol of black defiance of South Africa's racial policies. Now Winnie Mandela faces criminal charges and an uncertain future in South Africa's anti-apartheid movement. The wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela has endured repeated hardships inflicted by the white-led government throughout their 32 years of marriage. But in recent years, her controversial statements and sometimes erratic behavior have put her at odds with anti-apartheid activists and blacks in her own community. The government said Tuesday that Mrs. Mandela, 56, will be charged with the 1988 kidnapping and assault of four young men, including 14-year-old Stompei Seipei, who was killed. The head of her bodyguard unit, Jerry Richardson, was convicted this year of murder and sentenced to death in the case. Mrs. Mandela has denied wrongdoing. She and her husband have accused the government of using its investigation as a propaganda campaign and said she would welcome a chance to defend herself. She will stand trial with seven members of the now-disbanded Mandela United Football Club, which played few matches but served as her entourage and bodyguard. Tuesday's announcement came as Mrs. Mandela appeared to have reclaimed a leading role in the anti-apartheid movement. After her husband's release in February from 27 years in prison, Mrs. Mandela was highly visible though silent as she accompanied him on international trips and to local rallies. She recently began to make strong anti-government statements that sometimes contradicted official ANC policy. The ANC last month named her social welfare director, a move criticized by some black leaders. It is the first official post she has held in any anti-apartheid group. Some anti-apartheid figures have privately criticized Mrs. Mandela for preferring the spotlight of international publicity to the less glamorous task of political organization. ``She is blunt, rash, emotional and speaks from the heart - that is why people respond to her and why she is controversial,'' said Fatima Meer, author of a biography of Mandela. Following her husband's imprisonment in 1962, Mrs. Mandela raised their two daughters alone while under constant restrictions, including house arrest. She was held in solitary confinement for more than a year, though never charged with a crime. She defied the government restrictions during nationwide unrest in the mid-1980s, making fiery speeches at public rallies and funerals of activists. Anti-apartheid leaders launched a campaign to promote her as ``Mother of the Nation.'' But a series of controversial statements and actions eroded her stature. She told a 1986 rally, ``With our boxes of matches and our necklaces, we shall liberate this country.'' The remark was a reference to ``necklacing'' - the killing of suspected government collaborators by setting ablaze a tire placed around the neck. The exiled ANC leadership disassociated itself from the remark endorsing the practice. Many of Mrs. Mandela's recent troubles have stemmed from her association with the soccer team. The Mandela home was burned down in July 1988 by a group of black youths that clashed with Mandela United. Then came accusations that Seipei and three others were abducted by soccer team members and brought to Mrs. Mandela's new home, where she allegedly beat them with a whip.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Prepared to Leave Philippines, But Hoping to Stay
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. negotiator said Tuesday Washington is prepared to give up its bases in the Philippines but wants a final decision delayed until the next century and voted on by the Filipino people. Chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage made the statement during the opening session of talks here on the future of the U.S.-run military facilities. ``It is clear to me ... that the days of a very large presence of U.S. sailors and airmen in the Philippines are coming to an end,'' Armitage said. ``What remains for us to determine is the rate at which this presence will be reduced and the nature of the relationship our two governments wish to pursue during and after this transitional period.'' ``Let the voters of the 21st century decide whether or not they believe a continued U.S. presence will be helpful,'' Armitage said. A spokesman for the Philippine negotiators, Rafael Alunan, welcomed Armitage's ``willingness ... to discuss the crafting of a new relationship between our two countries'' but took exception to Armitage's call for Filipino voters in the next century to decide on the American presence. ``This matter is not to be decided in the 21st century,'' Alunan said. ``The time for decision is now.'' The lease on the U.S. bases expires in September 1991. Any extension of the American presence after that must be approved by the 23-member Senate, where opposition to the bases is strong, and also by a national referendum if ordered by the Philippines Congress. Analysts say most Filipinos would vote for the U.S. bases to remain because of their economic benefits. The current talks are a continuation of negotiations that began in May on the future of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller U.S. facilities. U.S. officials previously stated U.S. troops would remain in the Philippines only as long as they are wanted. But on Monday, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Washington wants to keep its bases in the Philippines. Armitage's statement marked the first time a U.S. official had publicly raised the possibility of Washington's readiness to give up the bases. He did not propose a timetable for removing the 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents. U.S. sources said Washington hopes for continued access to the facilities, perhaps on a commercial basis, after relinquishing formal control. The United States has strongly supported President Corazon Aquino's administration since 1986 when a civilian-military uprising ended the 20-year rule of the late President Ferdinand Marcos. In December, U.S. jets flew air cover for government forces during an unsuccessful bid by military rebels to oust Mrs. Aquino. American troops from the bases also provided help for the government during a July earthquake that killed nearly 1,700 people. But opponents believe the bases infringe on national sovereignty and represent a vestige of American colonial rule, which ended with independence in 1946. U.S. forces have been in the Philippines since the Americans captured the islands from Spain in 1898, except for a period of Japanese occupation during World War II. Mrs. Aquino said Monday her government wants to maintain close ties with Washington but that the end of the Cold War and absence of any external threat to the Philippines made the bases less important. Mrs. Aquino said a government committee was drafting plans to convert the bases into civilian use, including a commercial airport at Clark and a ship repair facility at Subic. Meanwhile, Communist rebels claimed responsibility for a bombing late Monday at a Voice of America station 60 miles north of Manila. The insurgents said the bombing was to protest continued U.S. ``domination'' of this former colony. There were no injuries, and U.S. officials said damage was slight. Last May, Communist rebels killed two American airmen near Clark on the eve of talks on the bases. American troops and their families have been restricted to base to prevent possible attacks during the current negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam's Most Likely Successor: Another Saddam
DOC.TEXT: If the Persian Gulf crisis culminates with the removal of Saddam Hussein from power, experts on that part of the world say they wouldn't look for democracy to blossom under the Iraqi sun. Saddam's most likely successor would be a Saddam clone. The nature of any new government in Iraq, no matter what the denouement of the current crisis, is one of the puzzlements for those trying to visualize how the crisis might end. Saddam could lose his showdown with George Bush and hang on. But it is just as likely that he could not survive such a humiliating defeat. In that event, the experts suspect his successor would be someone from his inner military circles, someone much like him. In Eastern Europe in the winter of 1989 and the spring of 1990, the world saw one autocracy after another fall, to be replaced by governments responsive to the popular will. But democracy is alien to Iraq and most of the rest of the Arab world. Egypt is the only Arab country with a semblance of it. So the best betting is that whatever follows Saddam is likely to be ``a government similar to the one that exists now'' - an autocratic, one-man rule - says Herman Eilts, former U.S. ambassador to Egypt and Saudi Arabia, now a Boston University professor. ``Its presumably someone in the military,'' agrees Daniel Pipes, director of the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia. But, he says, the successor would probably only be a new face behind the same old iron fist. The next government, like the present one, Pipes says, is likely to be based on power, not principles. ``Saddam Hussein doesn't stand for anything,'' he says, and neither would his successor. By contrast, Iran, Iraq's neighbor, is a government based on ideology, the Muslim principles of the ayatollahs. The ``traditional'' way for governments to change in Iraq, former CIA Director William Colby has noted, is when ``the successor murders his predecessor.'' But Saddam has already survived dozens of plots against him and wiped out any visible opposition. The experts are uncertain whether Saddam can meet President Bush's demand for Iraq to withdraw ``completely, immediately and without condition'' from Kuwait and still survive. To find an ally for his conquest of Kuwait, Saddam gave back to Iran virtually everything gained in the bloody eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Buckling now to Bush's demands would make Iraqis look upon both the war and the invasion as worthless enterprises for which much was paid. ``The regime sustains power by doling out goodies and if he withdraws from Kuwait, it's another blunder; he won't have any goodies,'' says Laurie Mylroie, a fellow at the Harvard Center for Middle Eastern Studies. In that event, she posits, the military may move against him. ``If he were made to retreat with nothing to show for it, it would be a serious humiliation and weaken his position,'' says historian Shaul Bakhash of George Mason University in Virginia, author of ``Reign of the Ayatollahs: Iran and the Islamic Revolution.'' But Eilts says that as long as Saddam keeps control of ``the instruments of coercion'' - the army and the police - ``he can still control the situation.'' He notes reports that Saddam recently had 14 Army officers executed to remind their survivors in the officer corps of the price of dissent. There has been a spate of rumors of executions of generals for opposing the takeover of Kuwait. If war comes, Pipes says, and the United States and its allies defeat Iraq, Saddam of course would be removed by the victors, who would then have the duty of replacing him. In a society with no democratic tradition, installing a new government, one that will no longer be a threat to the region, will become a responsibility of America and its allies. ``It is,'' he says, ``a staggering thought.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Cut Off Aid to DeKalb County, Ga., Schools
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Department of Education has cut up to $7 million in aid to DeKalb County schools after a six-year battle over whether or not the school system discriminates against handicapped students. The school system contends the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights is overstepping its authority in investigating allegations of discrimination. Among other things, the fund cut announced Monday would affect special mathematics instruction for low-income pupils, assistance for the handicapped and programs for immigrant children. School Superintendent Robert Freeman and the system's attorneys went to U.S. District Court in Washington today, seeking a temporary restraining order on removal of the funds until a lawsuit being heard in that court is resolved. If that court rules against DeKalb, May said, the system would appeal to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court, said School spokeswoman Christine May. Freeman earlier acknowledged that the school system cannot sustain the programs for long without federal aid, and said the schools will back down if they lose in court. ``We can't afford to fight the U.S. government. We can't afford to surrender any of our federal funds,'' said Freeman. ``Taking funds away from a school district is the most drastic means for this office to enforce the law,'' said Michael L. Williams, assistant U.S. secretary of education for civil rights. ``But when it is necessary to guarantee the protection of civil rights for all, this administration will not hesitate to do so.'' The county school system, just east of Atlanta, has about 71,000 students. As of May, 3,200 of those are either in ``self-contained'' centers, or taking four or more courses in special education. Parents complained in 1984 the county refused to pay for private, residential placements for handicapped children. May declined to comment on the parents' complaint. The parents could have filed complaints under the Education of the Handicapped Act, which requires a ``free, appropriate public education'' for disabled students. But they filed complaints instead under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1983, a civil rights law barring discrimination against the disabled in federally funded programs. The county refused to cooperate with the Education Department's investigation of the complaints, saying the department had no jurisdiction. The state of Georgia also refused to cooperate. While the Education of the Handicapped Act covers a set list of disabilities, Section 504, school officials contend, could be used to cover a wide range of problems, including illegal drug use. In a 1987 ruling on a procedural issue in the DeKalb case, a federal judge in Atlanta said the dispute over authority under the two laws had not been resolved by the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Report Accidents Increase After Pilots Reach 60
DOC.TEXT: Pilots over age 60 have twice as many accidents as those in their 50s, but they're still safer than pilots in their 20s or 30s, according to a congressional report. The Office of Technology Assessment reached no conclusion on whether the Federal Aviation Administration should revise its regulation forcing retirement at age 60 for pilots on major airlines - those which operate planes with more than 30 seats. There is no such requirement for corporate, private or commuter-airline pilots. Critics have argued the age-60 rule for airlines arbitrarily grounds many healthy, experienced pilots and denies the traveling public the benefit of their skill. They have called for more flexible rules tied to stringent medical examinations, but the OTA questioned whether current testing techniques could adequately detect the subtle mental deterioration which it deems the principal hazard posed by aging pilots. The OTA's study, based on average accidents per 100,000 flight hours for all pilots with more than 1,000 hours of flight experience, found that ``pilots between ages 60 to 69 have an accident rate that is 2.1 times higher than the accident rate for 50- to 59-year-olds. ``However, the same data show that the accident rate for the 60-to 69-year-old pilots is less than that for pilots in the 30-39-year-old and 20-29-year-old age groups,'' the report said. It found that experience clearly counts, noting that pilots over 60 with more than 5,000 flight hours have a lower accident rate than pilots of any age with 1,000 to 5,000 flight hours. But in all experience groups, the accident rate goes up after 60, the OTA said. The congressional agency said the safety issue for major airlines has little to do with the vulnerability of aging pilots to sudden impairment - a heart attack, say - since a copilot and sometimes a third flight officer are on the flight deck and could take the controls in such cases. Rather, pilot-error accidents are almost always based ``on mental error rather than the pilot's incapacitation'' and the data showing higher accident rates for the over-60 bracket ``suggest that the increase ... may be due to subtle age-related deterioration in cognitive function.'' Thus, more stringent or frequent medical exams likely would have little effect on accident rates unless they involved more accurate neuropsychological measurements than currently available, the OTA said. The airline industry and the Air Line Pilots Association both support the age-60 mandatory retirement rule.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Temperature
DOC.TEXT: Here is the sky condition and temperature range forecast for the 24-hour period ending midnight Tuesday at Dhahran, staging area for the U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia: Clear, Low 75, High 106.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Orchestra Musicians Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with contract settled in second, last-ditch vote today. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The musicians'...'.
DOC.TEXT: Musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra today ratified a contract in a last-ditch vote scheduled just hours before the opening concert of the orchestra's 91st season. The orchestra had voted Mondaynight to reject the contract and go on strike. Orchestra spokeswoman Bonnie Arnold announced the union members' change of hear as musicians filed onto the stage of the Academy of Music for rehearsal. She said tonight's performance would go on as scheduled. She did not provide terms of the contract or the vote margin. The musicians' three-year contract expired at midnight Sunday. At issue were pensions, seniority, medical benefits and radio broadcasts. The last strike against the orchestra was in 1966 and lasted eight weeks. Last week, Wolfgang Sawallisch, 67, was selected as the sixth music director of the orchestra since it was founded in 1900. Sawallisch will succeed Riccardo Muti starting with the 1993-94 season. Muti announced in the spring he would not renew his contract, which expires in August 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Students Quiz Reagan at Gorbachev's Alma Mater
LaserPhotos MOSB2,4
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan tutored Moscow university students Tuesday on the finer points of capitalism and democracy and said he'd copy Mikhail Gorbachev's economic reforms if he were Soviet leader. Reagan also said during a question-and-answer session at Moscow State University that he believes ``Germany has rejoined the civilized world'' and will not repeat Nazi atrocities. Reagan met with about 45 students for an hour in the university's mammoth administration building in the Lenin Hills looking down on central Moscow. Later Tuesday, he met with the board of directors of The Associated Press. ``He's great! He impresses me. He radiates energy!'' Yuri Ammosov, a 21-year-old history student, said after listening to Reagan. ``He does not seem as old as he is,'' said another student, Edwin Lobinsh. ``I would think that he was about 60. He just keeps on going.'' Despite his hearing aid, the 79-year-old former president had trouble hearing some of the students' questions and had to be helped by U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock. But he had no trouble lauding Gorbachev, one of the school's best-known graduates, and said the two men continue to build on the relationship forged in front of a fireplace at their first summit in Geneva in November 1985. ``Who would have thought that the warmth of that fireplace in Geneva would melt the ice of the Cold War,'' Reagan said later in a luncheon toast at the U.S. Embassy. Reagan told the students that if he suddenly became president of the Soviet Union and had to salvage its crumbling economy, he would follow the same course as Gorbachev ``to bring about private ownership, to bring about the free economy that has proven so fruitful for our own country.'' Gorbachev's economic reform proposals were among the topics the two discussed in the Kremlin on Monday, including the possibility of a Soviet referendum on the decollectivization of farms. A key to the reform, he said, is a person's right to own land. ``Until you've done so, you can't realize the patriotism and the pride that you have when you can stand on a piece of land and say, `This is mine,''' Reagan told the group. Reagan said that while he wholeheartedly supported German unification, he understood the apprehensions of many Soviets who lost millions of people to the Nazis in World War II. He said the preservation of concentration camps as memorials sends a message to young Germans that ``this must never happen again.'' ``So I think that Germany has rejoined the civilized world and there will not be a repeat of the Nazi horror,'' Reagan said. Reagan urged more exchanges between Soviet and American students, saying: ``If young people like you, in the world, could get to know each other, there would never be another war.'' Asked how he maintained his mental health during eight years in the White House, Reagan quoted another former president, Abraham Lincoln: ``He said at one point that he could not perform the duties of his office for 15 minutes if he did not know that he could call upon one who was wiser and stronger than all others,'' Reagan said. ``He was speaking, of course, of God. I learned while I was in the White House why he said that.'' Reagan and his wife, Nancy, leave Moscow for Rome on Wednesday after a five-day visit at Gorbachev's invitation. The two couples dined together Monday night, but Raisa Gorbachev missed Tuesday's lunch because of illness, her husband said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Poor Management at USDA Could Add $55 Million to Computer Costs
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs graf 5, Thomas Burke, with Agriculture Department comment.
DOC.TEXT: The government could be stuck with a $61.9 million bill for computer systems originally priced at $7 million because of poor management in the Agriculture Department, says a congressional report. The General Accounting Office said the government is paying Andersen Consulting, a division of the Arthur Andersen accounting firm, for the systems to monitor billions of dollars worth of commodities inventories. ``One system was installed two years later than planned, and the other is scheduled to be installed in July 1991, which would be almost a six-year delay,'' said the GAO report. The report was being reviewed today by a congressional subcommittee. The GAO, Congress' investigative arm, put heavy blame on ``ineffective project management and oversight'' by the Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service, which commissioned the work. Sarita Schotta, deputy administrator of the service, told the House Government Operations subcommittee on agriculture she is now providing the supervision the project should have had all along. Schotta has been overseeing the project for a year. The costs have been piling up since 1983. ``The delays and cost increase since the awarding of this contract have been astonishing,'' said Rep. Robert Wise, D-W.Va., subcommittee chairman. He said the Agriculture Department's inspector general issued reports in 1986 and 1987 criticizing the agency and Andersen Consulting, but the ASCS never showed them to Andersen. The service deals with billions of dollars, administering farm commodity, conservation and emergency assistance programs, including commodity loans and price support payments to farmers. In 1989, for example, its program and administrative costs amounted to $13 billion. By the end of the fiscal year, its commodities inventories totaled nearly $4 billion. Since the 1950s, the service has used an automated system to track the acquisition, storage, movement, sale and donation of grain and processed commodities, but the computer system was becoming outdated. In 1983, the service awarded Andersen a contract to update its systems for $7 million. It tacked on a ``cost plus incentive fee'' because no one would take the job at fixed cost. ``Most agencies by now have learned that cost plus is a ticket for automatic disaster,'' said Wise. He noted that the provision has cost the taxpayers nine times the amount originally estimated for work that is not yet complete. He said users of one of the systems are moving data into personal computers to do sensitive reports. ``It seems the users do not feel that the system is reliable enough to do critical work,'' Wise said. Wise said he found the nearly $62 million in spending particularly troubling since the agency plans a massive upgrade of other systems. In May, the agency said it needed an additional $57 million in procurement authority for minicomputer equipment upgrades, maintenance and software between July 1990 and September 1992. The GAO questioned the $57 million figure, saying it made its own calculations and found the job could be done for about $25 million.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bans All Food Exports
DOC.TEXT: The government Tuesday banned food exports in an effort to improve domestic supplies in time for winter. Sugar, cheese, cooking oil and detergent have been rationed since late summer in most parts of Bulgaria as the government tries to alleviate shortages. Other foodstuffs and vital consumer goods such as soap and toilet paper are in short supply or unavailable. According to a government decree carried by the state BTA news agency, the export ban was imposed ``to ensure the supply (of) the necessary products for the population during the fall and winter period.'' ``Absolutely prohibited is the export of meat and meat products and milk and milk products until the end of March next year,'' the decree said. ``In addition, until the next harvest season, the export is prohibited of feed grain, cereals, sunflower, vegetable oil, soya, potatoes, onions and garlic.'' Petko Simeonov, managing director of the opposition newspaper Demokratsiya, told a rally Monday that ``we are in for hunger and darkness'' in coming months. Energy also is in short supply due in part to the Persian Gulf crisis, which cut into deliveries of Iraqi crude oil. Authorities have begun cutting off electricity several times a day. In downtown Sofia, the capital, power supplies were halted for one hour at 10 a.m., 2 p.m., and 6 p.m. Tuesday. The newspaper Duma of the governing Socialist Party warned recently of the possibility of famine.

DOC.HEAD: Civic Leaders Will Gather to Discuss Strategies to Fight Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush's drug advisory council Tuesday announced a fall conference of civic leaders to discuss strategies for winning the fight against illegal drugs in America's cities. The leadership forum, scheduled to be held Nov. 9-10, will be the basis for organizing a national coalition of the 200 local anti-drug organizations that have sprung up nationwide, the council said. It is ``based on an emerging belief that a priceless resource in our nation's war on drugs is a long list of local communities whose private-sector leadership is both organized and committed to initiate new activities, and to strengthen ongoing programs to reduce the use of illegal drugs in that community,'' said Alvah H. Chapman Jr., an advisory council member and former chairman of Knight Ridder, Inc., the Miami-based newspaper company. Coalitions of local business, civic and religious leaders have offered advice to schools and private firms about improving drug education programs, Chapman said. Others have launched anti-drug advertising campaigns. A group in Santa Barbara, Calif., has spurred anti-drug peer pressure among the city's youth, he said. Still others are fostering programs to promote drug-free workplace programs in private businesses. In Miami, the coalition that Chapman helped found pushed local officials to eliminate bureaucratic obstacles to efforts to enforce a law that allows demolition of crack houses in that city. Last year, 475 crack houses were demolished, he said. ``The coalition didn't run the bulldozers that knocked down the houses, but the coalition did use a bulldozer on the bureaucracy that was preventing the local law that was in effect from for two years from being really applied,'' Chapman said. Bush appointed the 27-member advisory council to help coordinate private-sector and non-profit drug programs and to help enlist volunteer organizations in the war on drugs, said the panel's chairman, William Moss. Chapman said he hoped that the effort will unleash private money to help expand drug-treatment programs, which he said must provide 24-hour service to those who want help. ``If you are making a decision to kick the drug habit and you find the right phone number to call and you decide to call at 5:05 on a Friday afternoon, you most likely get an answering service to tell you to call back on Monday,'' Chapman said. ``You can imagine what that does to someone who has reached that point of being willing to break with that drug habit,'' Chapman said. But Chapman said that he was aware of only one community, Miami, where such a service is being planned. The Miami program has not been implemented because the local government has yet to help finance it, Chapman said.

DOC.HEAD: Plight of Orphaned Wolf Pups Hits at Montanans' Heart
DOC.TEXT: Offers of food for six orphaned wolf pups are pouring in from Montanans moved by the animals' plight, but officials say the 4{-month-old animals are making do with some help from the government. ``The response has been amazing,'' said Ed Bangs, head of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's project to restore wolves in Montana. The animals, protected by the Endangered Species Act, are part of a federal program to establish 10 breeding pairs of wolves in Montana. One woman wanted to donate venison steaks from her freezer. Another had some chickens she didn't need. A man offered to set up a guard station to protect the pups in the Ninemile Valley west of Missoula. Bangs turned them all down. The pups are doing fine on road-killed animals and the surplus deer meat that officials are providing from the Lee Metcalf National Wildlife Refuge, said Mike Jimenez, the wildlife biologist who has monitored the litter since spring. Jimenez said the pups spend their days chasing grasshoppers, field mice and gophers. They weigh about 50 pounds and are about the size of German shepherds. The pups' mother was illegally shot to death last summer. The father fed and protected them until he was hit by a car on Interstate 90 two weeks ago. Federal officials then stepped in, but the animals will be back on their own by winter when they'll have to start killing their own game, Bangs said. He says some of them probably won't survive, falling victim to starvation, mountain lions or hunters' stray bullets. ``The pups will have more hard knocks than if there was an adult protecting them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates: Homeless Face Long Journey Back to School
DOC.TEXT: On her first day back to school, 7-year-old Wanda colored a mimeographed counting exercise, ate a hamburger for lunch and took the No. 4 bus home - to a city shelter. For Wanda, and for the thousands of other homeless children, just going back to school can be a lesson in survival. ``These kids have gone through a lot by the time they get into the classroom,'' said Michelle Linehan, director of the state Department of Education's Office for Education of Homeless Children in Boston. ``They're not homeless because they want to be,'' said Glenwood Elementary Principal Robert Kelliher, whose school is near the motel-shelter where Wanda lives. ``They want the same thing as other youngsters, a bed to sleep in at night ... a place to study, a place to play.'' As of November, 12,000 children were living in Massachusetts shelters, half of them school age, Linehan said. ``That's only the numbers that we know of,'' she said. The U.S. Department of Education estimated that at the end of last year, 200,000 of the 272,000 homeless children attended schools. Problems facing homeless children range from ragged clothes and no place to study to poor self esteem. Families driven to shelters by house fires often have trouble tracking down duplicates of birth certificates and immunization records required for school admission. Shelters report that more than 10 percent of their school-age children do not go to school and tests show that they have a harder time in the classroom. ``A lot of them are tired because they're living in crowded conditions. They seem distant,'' said Arlene Tanous, who works with homeless children for the Springfield Action Commission. For many parents, the chief concern is keeping their chldren in the school they attended before homelessness struck. The alternative is a fractured education, said Kelliher, recounting the story of a third-grader who had moved 13 times. Kelliher persuaded school officials to find money for private transportation back to Glenwood if the boy moved again. ``I was informed the other day that he's moved,'' Kelliher said. ``Utica, New York.'' A 1987 federal law gives children of homeless families the choice of going to the school in their last district or one closer to the shelter. However, the law doesn't provide for transportation to the old school. Then there's the stigma of homelessness. Desiree, a fourth grader, doesn't tell her friends that financial problems led to a change of address over the summer. ``I just told her if anybody asks you where you're staying, you're just staying with a friend,'' said her mother, Naomi, who spoke on condition that her last name not be used. Dealing with that sort of problem is one of the functions of Linehan's office, founded three years ago with an administrative budget of about $90,000 a year. In addition to collecting information and applying for grants for such things as home tutoring programs for the homeless, Linehan's office has prepared guidelines for teachers. ``It's just things such as being aware that if you have birthday parties, this kid may not be able to bring a treat so be aware of that,'' Linehan said. Teachers also should beware of the importance a homeless child may attach to seemingly meaningless possessions. ``When I used to teach, if a kid came in with a little car, after the third warning (not to play with it in class) it used to go in the bottom drawer until after May. You just can't do that to a homeless kid. It can devastate them,'' she said. At 7, Wanda is too young to worry about her classmates finding out where she lives. But her older sister, 12-year-old Wakena, isn't. Wakena, scheduled to start at a junior high school this fall, wasn't too sure last week if she wanted to go. ``Some of those kids are cracking on (teasing) you,'' she said. ``About clothes, you know, like $50 sneakers.'' The junior high would be her sixth or seventh school, she said. ``We went to a lot of schools. We never finished a year,'' she said. The family has had a succession of living arrangements during the past six years, said her mother, Betty Foster. She said she hopes to get more assistance from the state to get out of the motel-shelter and into an apartment. ``I want them to have good education. You got to find some kind of opportunity,'' she said. ``I tell them, `What are you going to do, clean somebody's bathroom?' ''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy, Bjt
Recession Fears Grow with Soaring Trade Deficit
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit soared 75 percent in July for its steepest increase in eight years, the government said, renewing recessionary fears even before the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis are felt. The Commerce Department said the deficit totaled $9.33 billion, up sharply from $5.34 billion in June and the worst imbalance since last January's $10.2 billion. The surge was the largest since the shortfall jumped 205 percent to $5.5 billion in August 1982, a spokesman said. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher noted the July report contained the last trade data unaffected by the disruptions caused by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``The rise in oil prices since then is likely to increase the average trade deficit for the last five months by an amount in excess of $2 billion per month,'' Mosbacher said. In addition to the effects of the oil-price shock, many private analysts pointed to a 6.4 percent decline in exports in July and questioned whether much improvement was in the offing. Over the past three years, fully one-third of overall U.S. economic growth has been supplied by surging export sales. That had become even more important recently as consumer spending faded in the face of adverse economic news. But Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said high interest rates and slower economic growth overseas are ``going to take a bite out of our export picture,'' he said. David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York securities dealer, added that ``while it's unlikely the trade numbers will continue to look as bad as they did in July, they do give us a hint that we have come to the end of major improvements in trade.'' In fact, the United States had a deficit of $1.33 billion with Western Europe because of falling exports, after posting a surplus of $806 million in June. ``Exports have been the only area of strength in the economy for several years now,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist for Merrill Lynch in New York. ``If they fall, there's no area of strength and that's very bothersome.'' Exports, which posted a record $34.3 billion in June, fell to $32.0 billion in July. Imports jumped 4.5 percent to $41.4 billion. The deficit is the difference between the two. Nevertheless, Mosbacher said exports were up 8.1 percent during the first seven months of the year while imports rose just 3.3 percent, meaning the 1990 deficit was running at an annual rate of $95.0 billion. The deficit last year totaled $109.40 billion. He remained optimistic that the non-oil deficit - which he called ``a better indicator of international competitiveness'' - would decline further from the current $45.8 billion rate. Oil imports in July rose 7.9 prcent to $3.98 billion, but that was due to increased volume rather than prices. Americans imported 8.85 million barrels a day, up from 8.40 million in June, while the average price per barrel edged down from $14.64 to $14.50. Since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, however, crude oil prices have surpassed $33 a barrel. Exports slipped in part because of a $500 million drop in aircraft shipments. But decreases also were posted in all major categories - capital goods, foods, automobiles, industrial supplies and consumer goods. At the same time, consumer and capital goods, automobiles and industrial supplies added to the import total. As usual, the biggest deficit was with Japan, a $2.97 billion imbalance, down from a $3.07 billion deficit in June. Other deficits included Taiwan, $1.14 billion; China, $1.13 billion; Canada, $992 million; Brazil, $335 million; Korea, $623 million, and Hong Kong, $439 million.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EDT. Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Growing Disenchantment With Both Political Parties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new grafs 15-16 with Dem Party chairman comments
DOC.TEXT: Americans are growing increasingly disenchanted with the two major political parties, associating Republicans with wealth and greed and Democrats with incompetence according to a survey released Tuesday. ``Since 1987, there has been a significant upswing in feelings of mistrust of political leaders, disillusionment with politics and feelings of powerlessness,'' said the Times Mirror survey titled``The People, the Press & Politics 1990.'' The study said the growing cynicism and economic polarization among all but the wealthiest Americans ``threatens to subvert traditional partisan politics or block the effective resolution of social and economic issues.'' Another finding was that while ``anti-communism is fading as a factor in American politics, anti-Japanese sentiment has soared as economic expectations plummet.'' Equally dramatic was the decline in support for Israel. ``Dislike for the Japanese has become more mainstream,'' concluded the survey. ``It is no longer primarily concentrated among the kinds of people who have been hit especially hard by Japanese competition.'' ``Growing dislike for Israel is evident across all demographic, political and social groups, except among American Jews,'' the survey said. But it also said that ``It is important to note that the sharp decline in identification with Israel has not been accompanied by a substantial identification with the causes of the Palestinians.'' President Bush fared as well in this as in other recent surveys, with 76 percent giving him very or mostly favorable ratings. The findings were based on face-to-face interviews in May with 3,004 adults. A random sample of 1,000 was reinterviewed between Aug. 19 and 25. The responses for the overall sample had a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. The responses were analyzed by Princeton Research Associates and compared to the findings of a similar study conducted in 1987. In the three years between the two studies, there was little change in Americans' affiliation with the major parties - the number of people identifying themselves as Republicans increased 3 percentage points, while those calling themselves Democrats declined 4 points. The survey found 33 percent of the respondents called themselves Democrats, 28 percent Republicans and 39 percent independents. ``Beneath this surface stability however, there are volatile forces at work,'' said the study. It concluded that ``both parties have declined precipitously in the public's estimation.'' Even among people who are the strongest supporters of the Democratic Party, the party was viewed as ``incapable of governing America successfully and unclear on what it should stand for.'' Despite the Republican success at holding the White House, the survey concluded the party ``has been unable to capitalize on these declining Democratic fortunes because the GOP itself is now seen by a majority of the public as the political instrument of the nation's rich and powerful.'' Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown said, ``I'm not at all disheartened by those findings.'' He noted that the survey was conducted at a time when the Republican president has very high approval ratings, but that nonetheless it ``reinforces the point that we've been trying to get across, namely, that the Republican Party is the party of the privileged few.'' Brown said his party must do a better job of getting across the point that Republicans ``have been in charge of government for the last decade. It hasn't been Democrats, and Republicans have failed totally in managing this government.'' The latest survey found growth in the already large numbers of Americans feeling alienated from their government. Among the findings were these: -- Thirty percent said they agreed completely with the statement that ``generally speakng, elected officials in Washington often lose touch with the people pretty quickly.'' Three years ago, 22 percent agreed completely. -- The majority that felt people like themselves have no say in what government does grew from 52 percent in 1987 to 57 percent in 1990. -- The number of people who said that elected officials care what they think declined from 47 percent to 44 percent. -- Thirty-eight percent said they agreed completely with the statement ``It's really true, the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.'' That was an increase from 31 percent in 1987. Drugs far outstripped other matters when people were asked to list the most important problems facing the nation. Thirty-six percent cited drugs, compared to 11 percent three years ago. The federal deficit was named by 11 percent, the same proportion as in 1987. Homelessness and the environment each were listed by 8 percent. Fewer than 1 percent named either matter three years ago. The proportion of people willing to spend more money to combat drugs increased from 66 percent in 1987 to 73 percent this year. In both surveys, 67 percent said they would be willing to spend more for the homeless and 35 percent would approve more funds to aid blacks and other minorities. On abortion, the survey found 55 percent saying they opposed restrictions on access to abortions. However, among Republicans and those who lean to the GOP, 47 percent opposed restrictions and 48 percent favored them. Democrats and those inclined to support the party opposed restrictions by a margin of 62 percent to 33 percent. When asked about attitudes toward Japan, 56 percent gave a favorable opinion and 39 percent unfavorable. Three years ago, 69 percent viewed Japan favorably and 27 percent unfavorably. The greatest increases in unfavorable opinion toward the Japanese occurred among whites, men, upper income earners and those in the Western United States, the survey found. On Israel, 44 percent rated the country favorably and 45 percent unfavorably. Three years ago, the split was 65 percent favorable and 27 percent unfavorable.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala a `Drug Problem' Country, US Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: A sharp increase in opium production in Guatemala has prompted the State Department to add that country to its list of ``drug problem'' countries, an administration official said Tuesday. According to official estimates, the Guatemala acreage devoted to opium is sufficient for a 12-ton yield. Any country with a yield of 5 tons or more is automatically placed on the State Department list. The official, who asked not to be identified, said that inclusion on the list does not constitute criticism of Guatemala's efforts to curb drug trafficking. He said smugglers send raw opium from Guatemala to Mexico where it is refined into heroin for shipment to the United States. Guatemala joins 10 other Latin American and Caribbean countries on the list - Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, Jamaica, the Bahamas, Belize, Paraguay, Ecuador, Bolivia and Panama. Fourteen Asian and Middle Eastern countries are also on the list. The only other hemispheric country where there is sizeable opium production is Mexico. But production in Mexico and Guatemala is minuscule next to such countries as Burma, Afghanistan, Iran and Laos, according to official statistics..
