A health and fitness buff, McPeak is married and has two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Ozone Hole Detected Early This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Antarctic ozone hole has been detected a month earlier this year than in the past, due to improved methods of measuring the chemical, federal officials said Tuesday. Instruments aboard a polar orbiting satellite detected the beginning of an ozone hole on Aug. 22, and the region of depleted ozone has enlarged since then, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. The thin layer of ozone high in the earth's atmosphere protects the planet from dangerous ultraviolet radiation from the sun. Manmade chemicals can damage that layer, however, and if it were thinned over populated regions scientists fear an increase of skin cancer and other damage to humans, animals and plants. The so-called hole, actually a region of depleted ozone, has been detected over Antarctica during several recent winters there. The seasons are reversed south of the Equator. In the past, however, instruments have been able to measure ozone only using visible light. Because Antarctica has nearly six months of darkness in its winter, detection of the ozone hole has been possible only after mid-September in past years. Now, NOAA reported, satellite-borne instruments have been used to measure ozone using infrared radiation, allowing the ozone hole to be detected during the darkness. The ozone hole is generally worst in October, which is springtime in that region. During that period a band of winds called the polar vortex encircles the region, preventing air there from mixing with the atmosphere in other parts of the world. During the period temperatures drop to -125 degrees Fahrenheit in the upper atmosphere, creating a situation where chlorofluorocarbons can react with the ozone and deplete it. Later in the year temperatures warm somewhat, the vortex breaks down and outside air mixes in restoring normal ozone levels. NOAA officials said that they have collected infrared measurements from the region for several years but only now have figured out how to use this data to calculate the ozone loss during the Antarctic darkness. That past data remains in storage and scientists hope that they can now use it to calculate dates and strength of the ozone hole for past years.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Ignorance May Have Cost Taxpayers Millions, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: Computer ignorance at the Agriculture Department cost the public nearly $62 million when $7 million might have been sufficient to cover the job, according to testimony Tuesday before Congress. At issue is a project started in 1983 when the Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service contracted with the Arthur Andersen accounting firm to design two nationwide computer systems to monitor commodities inventories. The firm wouldn't take the job unless the $7 million contract included a ``cost plus'' clause, or one that provides an open-ended contract in case unforeseen expenses arise. The firm said it needed that guarantee because of the vagueness of the service's request. ``Most agencies by now have learned that cost plus is a ticket for automatic disaster,'' said Rep. Robert Wise, D-W.Va., whose House Government Operations subcommittee on agriculture is investigating the contract. Basically, Andersen's job was to design a system for users who didn't know exactly what they wanted, said JayEtta Hecker a director at the General Accounting Office which conducted a review of the computer system for Wise. She said Andersen was not always required to correct defects at its own expense, but did nothing illegal under the contract. It was ``ineffective management and oversight'' along with poorly defined needs and inconsistent direction at the top levels of the agriculture service that caused costs to escalate, she said. ``In the last seven years, six people have served as the deputy administrator for management,'' Hecker said. ``This lack of continuity has contributed to decisions to start, stop and restart the project which has resulted in additional costs.'' Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., pointed out that administrator's job at the stabilization and conservation service has been filled by political appointees whose credentials have not always included computer expertise. ``Basically, we've had political hacks holding the job,'' he said. ``They didn't know enough about what they wanted and where they were going, did they?'' he asked Hecker. ``They were sheep to be shorn.'' ``That's a pretty good characterization,'' she said. Dr. Sarita Schotta, a computer expert who has been deputy administrator of the service for the last year, tried to assure the congressional subcommittee that she was providing the kind of supervision the project should have had all along. She said the computer system should be complete by next year. She emphasized that the technological advances involved 3,000 field offices. Part of the oversight problem came because the agency was ``so overwhelmed with getting software out in 300 counties,'' she said. ``The folks they were training already had 20 to 30 years in county office. The last they thought they'd be doing was using computers.'' The stabilization and conservation service is in charge of administering farm commodity, conservation and emergency assistance programs, including commodity loans and price support payments to farmers. It handles billions of dollars each year. In 1989, for example, its program and administrative costs amounted to $13 billion. By the end of the fiscal year, its commodities inventories totaled nearly $4 billion. Its automated system for tracking acquisition, storage, movement, sale and donation of grain and processed commodities had not been updated since the 1950s.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE TEXTILE IMPORTS
Honolulu Mayor Objects To His Appearance In Candidate's Ad
DOC.TEXT: Honolulu Mayor Frank Fasi is objecting to a campaign ad that shows him shaking hands with Republican gubernatorial candidate Leonard Mednick. Fasi says he voted for someone else. Hawaii's primary election is scheduled for Saturday but Fasi said he already has voted by absentee ballot for someone other than Mednick. There are six Republicans running in the primary, with state Rep. Fred Hemmings favored to win. Fasi said he also has a problem with a subtitle running on Mednick's ad, which states, ``Leonard Mednick, the Fasi-Republican for Governor.'' Gov. John Waihee, who is seeking election to a second four-year term, is favored over three challengers in the Democratic primary.
DOC.HEAD: Democrat Criticizes GOP's $300,000 Pledge to Taft Criticized
DOC.TEXT: A pledge of $300,000 from the Ohio GOP that helped persuade Robert Taft II to run for secretary of state rather than governor was a payoff, a spokesman for Democratic incumbent Sherrod Brown said Tuesday. ``Bob Taft became a candidate for secretary of state not because he thought the job was right, but because the price was right,'' said Dale Butland, a spokesman for the Brown campaign. Butland said a Dayton Daily News story about the state GOP's campaign pledge shows that Taft was pressured out of the governor's race by promises of campaign money. The newspaper reported Tuesday that Taft abandoned his bid for governor 12 days after being offered the check by Ohio Republican Party Chairman Robert Bennett. The check was voided after a Feb. 2 meeting between Bennett and Taft, which ended with Taft publicly maintaining he would remain in the governor's race. But about four months after Taft changed his mind, he received $300,000 in contributions from the Ohio Republican Party and the Republican National Committee. Brian Berry, executive director of the state party, acknowledged that Bennett had offered the check. ``It's no big surprise to anybody that the state party was ready to commit dollars. No big surprise. This is a phony issue,'' Berry said. Bennett told the Daily News the $300,000 check had been a prop for his meeting with Taft, designed to demonstrate the GOP's commitment to winning the Secretary of State's office. The meeting was aimed at avoiding a costly, divisive primary with ultimate GOP gubernatorial nominee George Voinovich. Taft told the Daily News the party's commitment of money helped persuade him to leave the governor's race. ``Certainly one factor in my decision was knowing what kind of support there would be from the state and national party,'' he was quoted as saying.
DOC.HEAD: Andrus Promises Tax Relief To Property Owners
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus on Tuesday pledged to use the Idaho's budget surplus to slash local property taxes if he is re-elected to a fourth term in November. Andrus said state budget analysts already were drafting the tax-cut plan. ``I believe we will have adequate revenue to target that tax relief to substantial reductions in local property taxes,'' the governor said in a statement. His underdog opponent, former Republican state Sen. Roger Fairchild, said this summer that he would use the state surplus to underwrite a revenue sharing program for local governments that would include property tax relief. Based on revenue estimates from administration economists, the state will have a onetime windfall of around $45 million. ``The property tax is for most Idahoans the most onerous tax,'' the governor said. ``It is time to return some of the budget surplus we have enjoyed to our citizens.''
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Accuse Gingrich Group Of Violating Election Law
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats filed a complaint Tuesday accusing a group headed by House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of violating federal election law. The complaint was filed with the Federal Election Commission by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. It said the Gingrich group, GOPAC, has been working to influence federal elections but has not registered with the FEC, as required by law. The complaint was based on a recent direct mail campaign in which GOPAC solicited contributions and urged people to sign a ``citizens veto'' to protest the congressional franking privilege. Letters used in the direct mail campaign stated that GOPAC hopes to raise $180,000 to campaign for a Republican majority in Congress in 1992 by fighting the franking privilege and the practice of gerrymandering in congressional redistricting. Under federal election law, any group that raises or spends more than $1,000 to influence federal elections must register as a political committee with the FEC. Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, is general chairman of GOPAC. He said the DCCC complaint ``is as phony and as inaccurate as everything else the DCCC has said about me in the last two years.''

DOC.HEAD: 45th General Assembly Opens, New President Elected
DOC.TEXT: The 45th U.N. General Assembly, the first of the post-Cold War era, convened Tuesday for a three-month session. The Persian Gulf crisis was expected to dominate the agenda. The 159 nations welcomed their newest colleague in the international forum, Liechtenstein, which became the 160th member. When East and West Germany unite in October and occupy a single seat, the membership again will fall to 159. Guido de Marco, the foreign minister of Malta, was chosen by acclaim president of the General Assembly, a largely ceremonial post, but one with influence on the agenda of more than 155 items. The presidency rotates yearly among regional groupings. De Marco, in his inaugural speech, called the forthcoming unification of Germany a sign of new optimism. He called it ``a symbol of the new healing role of Europe with its dismantling of barriers, the freeing of peoples, the reinstating of democratic institutions and the progressive abandonment of armaments.'' But the president said Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait was a sign of the dangers ahead. He called Iraq's attack on its neighbor not only ``an outrageous and illegal action in itself, but an action which also reflects the bitterness and turmoil, the hatred and injustice that prevail in the Middle East.'' De Marco told the assembly: ``The world is indeed at a turning point in history. The question is, ``In which direction are we turning?'' The Security Council, he said, has responded clearly and unequivocally in demanding the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces and restoration of the government of Kuwait. ``We cannot shirk our responsibities,'' he said, adding that people around the world were looking to the assembly for moral and political guidance. The General Assembly cannot adopt legally binding resolutions, but its statements carry weight as representing the will of the international community. In addition to the Persian Gulf crisis, he said, the international community faces continuing unsolved conflicts, such as the status of Palestinians, many living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``The Palestinian question has a dimension which goes far beyond the occupied territories,'' he said. ``It creates rancor, soul-searching, prejudices and, unfortunately, hatred.'' He said convening an international conference on the Middle East was a fundamental step to peace in the region. The current U.N. session, he said, must try to reach a comprehensive settlement of the Palestinian question. ``Delay in solving the Palestinian issue is a denial to the Palestinian people of the country which is theirs, and to Israel of those secure and guaranteed frontiers to which it is entitled.'' He also cited debt and development, poverty, terrorism, narcotics, the environment and the role of women as major issues confronting the forthcoming General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Antarctic Explorer Urges Protection For Continent
DOC.TEXT: Polar explorer Will Steger entertained members of Congress Tuesday with tales of his dog-sled trek across Antarctica. But his support for legislation to make the frozen continent a ``world park'' met with a cold response. Steger, of Ely, Minn., was the star witness when the House Interior subcommittee opened hearings on legislation sponsored by Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., that would ban U.S. mineral exploration and curtail other development damaging Antarctica's environment. ``Internationally we've been dragging our feet when it comes to the Antarctic issue,'' Steger told the panel. ``There's an opportunity to take a leadership role for the environment.'' Steger co-led a six-member international trans-Antarctica expedition which completed the longest unmechanized passage across the continent in March. He described the team's battle with a 2-month-long storm, when winds hit 35 to 50 mph, and their fears that they wouldn't find a companion who became lost overnight shortly before the end of the 3,741-mile trek. ``It's almost like crossing another planet,'' Steger said. The United States should take the lead to ensure the continent stays as pristine as it is now, even though it may contain valuable deposits of uranium and platinum, he said. ``In order to preserve this place it may be best that we leave it,'' said Rep. Jim Oberstar, D-Minn. But officials with the departments of State and Interior said other nations with interests in Antarctica must cooperate before the United States could agree to banning mining and turning Antarctica into a nature reserve. ``However unlikely it may seem now, it is possible to envision circumstances where shortages of critical mineral resources may force other nations to ignore a ban,'' said William Houston, a deputy assistant secretary of Interior. ``Negotiating an effective agreement to protect the Antarctic environment under these circumstances would be very difficult.'' The existing Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities prohibits mineral exploration on the continent unless there is a consensus that it would not hurt the environment, Houston said. Vento argued that CRAMRA, signed in 1988, ``was a step in the wrong direction'' in that it provided the basis for future mining. The United States instead should take the initiative in prohibiting Antarctic mineral development, he said. Peter Wilkins, director of polar programs for the National Science Foundation, said the Antarctic legislation could disrupt scientific research in the region at a time when NSF is remedying past environmental problems. The legislation would apply all U.S. environmental and historic preservation laws to the continent without regard to its unique situation, he said. For example, U.S. law could require chemical processing of waste water and cause more damage than current treatment methods recommended by scientists, Wilkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Primate Brings Politicians to `Tea' to Map Democratic Evolution
DOC.TEXT: Poland's feuding leaders, led by Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, agreed on the need for early, free elections but little else in meetings Tuesday, participants said. The six hours of discussions, called by the powerful Roman Catholic primate, brought together more prominent officials than any meeting since the spring 1989 negotiations that led to the downfall of the Communist regime. Participants had cautioned before starting that no decisions would be made behind closed doors, and indicated afterward they were divided on key issues concerning the nation's next steps toward democracy. They said the session served as preparation for Thursday's potentially fiery debate in Parliament on the schedule for post-Communist Poland's first fully democratic presidential and parliamentary elections. ``There couldn't have been any decisions because it was just a conversation,'' said Walesa - the only declared presidential candidate - as he left Primate Jozef Glemp's residence. Mazowiecki said there had been a ``broad exchange ... about all the problems Poland faces.'' But asked if there was a convergence of views, he said: ``I don't think so.'' Minister Aleksander Hall, responsible for contacts among political parties, said two concepts emerged: one to hold a presidential election first and the other to hold balloting for the presidency and parliament at the same time. ``All are of the opinion that those events should take place in the next few months,'' he said. President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader who has indicated he will leave office early, said the ``constructive'' exchange ``brings us closer to decisions.'' ``The primate's intention is to create the most civilized conditions for further political evolution in Poland,'' deputy government spokesman Edward Krzemien told Polish radio. ``The point is that the coming elections shouldn't divide and tear Poland apart but provide transition to democracy.'' The once-united Solidarity movement has split into two camps. One, Center Alliance, backs Walesa and is identified with workers and the Solidarity union headquartered in Gdansk. The other, known by the acronym ROAD, includes many intellectuals and supports Mazowiecki and the government in Warsaw. Leaders of both groups, evolving as political parties after four decades of one-party Communist leadership, were among the 25 people invited. Also included were other Parliamentary leaders. The session followed Walesa's announcement Monday that he will run for president in the elections expected as early as this fall and no later than spring. There has been no word on a bid by Mazowiecki. Walesa parted ways with his former adviser over the pace of reforms, saying the government has lost sight of the issues and that too many Communists remain in positions of power. A public opinion poll conducted Sept. 3-4 and published Tuesday showed Mazowiecki was supported for president by 48 percent of those surveyed, compared with 37 percent for Walesa. The rest had no opinion. However, Walesa's prominence, political instincts and authority are incalculable and he has said he is confident of victory. He received the loudest cheers from the crowd watching the arrivals at the primate's residence. Jaruzelski was greeted by derisive whistles. The poll also showed a drop in confidence in the government from 82 percent in January to 61 percent. About half of those questioned had never heard of either the Center Alliance or ROAD. The church's position in the election will be critical in overwhelmingly Catholic Poland. The Polish media first dubbed the session a ``small round-table,'' reminiscent of the unprecedented spring 1989 meetings of the former Communist authorities and the Solidarity-led opposition. The talks opened the way for reform in Poland and across Eastern Europe. But Walesa and others objected and the session became known as ``tea at the primate's.'' ``Free elections will become our new round-table, not any agreement behind the back of society,'' Walesa said. Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader who jailed Walesa and Mazowiecki during martial law, imposed in 1981, has said he is willing to resign early from his six-year term.

DOC.HEAD: 27 Become Citizens in Constitution Week Celebration
DOC.TEXT: Standing before the glass-enclosed original of the U.S. Constitution, 27 foreigners took the oath as American citizens this week to begin the annual ``Constitution Week'' celebration of the signing of the nation's charter 203 years ago. The former citizens of 27 countries, from Peru and the Philippines to Ireland and Africa's Ivory Coast, were sworn in Monday by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene in the rotunda of the National Archives, where the original Constitution, the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights are on display. ``The blending of peoples and ideas has brought vitality to our history and remains America's continued source of strength,'' said Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., who welcomed the new citizens to their adopted homeland. ``The decision to change one's citizenship must surely be accompanied by a bittersweet mix of cherished memories of the past and spirited hopes for the future,'' she said. ``Many Americans have a close relative who can recall these feelings.'' Thousands of communities across the country were encouraged to observe Constitution Week with parades, speeches, public readings of the Constitution, worship services, school assemblies and historical pageants. Some communities held bell-ringing ceremonies at 4 p.m. EDT Monday, the hour when the Constitution was signed in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, 1787. Constitution Week, an annual event established by Congress in 1956, is being coordinated this year by the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, which is sponsoring a five-year celebration of the beginnings of the U.S. government. ``Constitution Week is an observance not only of our freedoms, but of our responsibilities as citizens as well,'' said former Chief Justice Warren Burger, the commission chairman. ``Constitution Week enables us to involve millions of Americans in recognizing the significance of the Constitution in our lives and as a symbol of freedom to the world,'' Burger said in a message to Americans. The commission began in 1987 with a commemoration of the signing of the Constitution and will end next year with a celebration of the 200th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights. This year, the commission is focusing public attention on the convening of the Supreme Court in 1790 and the formation of the federal judiciary. Burger will address a national conference of bicentennial officials in Washington on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Seeks $1.2 Million Fine From Texas Company
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials proposed a $1.2 million fine Tuesday against a Texas metal company accused of failing to report workplace injuries such as amputations, cuts, fractures and eye injuries. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration cited Kaspar Wire Works, Inc., of Shiner, Texas, for knowingly and repeatedly violating federal laws governing the record keeping and reporting of workplace injuries and illnesses. Kaspar spokesman Dan Price said company officials would not comment until they could review the allegations. The company was cited for 385 instances of alleged ``willful'' failure to record or accurately record injuries and illnesses in 1988 and 1989, OSHA said. Other alleged violations included failure to provide medical records in a timely fashion and not reporting injuries to employees. In addition, there were several serious'' violations of OSHA standards governing handrails on stairs, air compressor alarms, containers for hazardous liquids, electrical grounding and labeling containers of hazardous chemicals. Willful violations are those committed with an intentional disregard of, or plain indifference to, federal job safety laws. A serious violation is one in which there is a substantial probability that death or serious physical harm could result, and the employer knew or should have known of the hazard. Kaspar, located about 90 miles south of Austin, employs about 850 workers. It makes newspaper vending machines and other metal products, including wire baskets and barbecue grills. Kaspar has 15 working days to contest the allegations before an independent review commission.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Controlled After Flare-up
DOC.TEXT: A fire aboard a gasoline tanker was declared under control a second time Tuesday and firefighters boarded the vessel to pump fire-retardant foam inside as a precaution. The fire erupted with a series of explosions Sunday aboard the M.V. Jupiter moored in the Saginaw River. One crewman is missing and believed dead. Private specialist firefighters working from a Coast Guard vessel at first declared victory over the blaze Monday afternoon, but it re-ignited that evening, burning all night and into Tuesday. On Tuesday, firefighters from the Texas firm Boots & Coots returned and knocked the flames down with fire-retardant foam. They believed the fire was put out Tuesday afternoon, said Tom Dalesio, a spokesman for Ashland Oil Inc. of Ashland, Ky., parent of the company that owns the Jupiter. After the flames appeared out, a crew boarded the mangled tanker to spray more foam inside the ship and begin inspecting it, Dalesio said. Damage estimates weren't expected before Wednesday, when experts would begin planning how to salvage the ship, he said. The tanker had unloaded just over half its cargo of 2.3 million gallons of gasoline when the fire broke out Sunday and raged for 30 hours, and officials are unsure how much, if any, gas may have leaked into the river. The tanker's bow was lodged on the river floor in a shallow spot but its stern remained afloat. The blaze erupted after a transfer hose snapped, spewing gasoline. Ashland blamed the accident on a passing vessel, saying its wake rocked the Jupiter, parting mooring lines and the hose. Ashland attorneys have written American Steamship Co., owner of the coal freighter Buffalo, to say ``we hold them responsible,'' said Roger Schrum, an Ashland spokesman. American Steamship spokeswoman Kelly Pezone denied the allegation. Some fuel splashed into the water Tuesday, prompting crews to pile absorbent booms around the tanker, said state Department of Natural Resources spokesman Terry Walkington. The Coast Guard is investigating the accident. No one is sure is how much gasoline remains on the ship or spilled, said Ashland spokesman Dan Lacy. DNR and state health experts were awaiting results of water- and air-pollution tests. At the height of the blaze, black smoke spread for 100 miles and hundreds of dead fish were found near the tanker. The test results were expected later in the week. Some residents were angry that evacuations hadn't been ordered. ``We have human health at risk here,'' said Terry Miller, chairman of the Lone Tree Council, an area environmental group. ``I would think just as a precautionary measure, they should have asked local residents to evacuate even if it's just gasoline burning.'' Tim Bosco, 29, owner of Bosco's fruit market located a half mile from the burning tanker, said the fumes gave him a headache. ``With all that raw gas burning, it was real bad. We couldn't get away from the smell,'' he said. Mike Lupo, 42, Bosco's cousin, said: ``It really shook up the city. There are a lot of people complaining that their houses and cars are covered with an oily soot. ``Yesterday it got so bad, there was this haze for three or four miles.'' Gov. James Blanchard, speaking on the banks of the river Tuesday, the state would review safety at the 13 Michigan spots where petroleum products are offloaded. The missing Jupiter crewman, Tom Sexton, 46, of Iowa, was believed to have died while trying to swim ashore from the burning tanker. Three other crew members, who were thrown or jumped from the tanker, remained hospitalized Tuesday in fair condition.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Official Meets With Rebel Leader in Monrovia
DOC.TEXT: The top State Department official for Africa flew into the burning capital of Liberia on Tuesday and met with a rebel leader at the U.S. Embassy as machine-guns rattled outside. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen arrived in Monrovia aboard a Marine helicopter and met rebel leader Prince Johnson, who he described later as ``helpful and pro-democratic,'' the British Broadcasting Corp. reported. Volleys of shots could be heard outside the white-walled embassy in the diplomatic enclave at Mamba Point. The embassy is guarded by part of a 2,100-member Marine contingent flown to Liberia in August to evacuate and protect foreigners. Cohen hoped to meet later with rival rebel leader Charles Taylor in neighboring Ivory Coast, to ``bring Taylor to the peace table or into the national interim government of Liberia,'' said a U.S. diplomat in Freetown. Taylor started the war in December when he invaded from Ivory Coast. Johnson, Taylor's former aide, split off to form his own group and managed to seize most of the capital before Taylor got there. His troops shot and captured President Samuel Doe earlier this month, and Doe died in captivity. Johnson has embraced a peace plan put forward by the Economic Community of West African States to install an interim government that would organize fair elections. But Taylor calls it a plot to install a puppet government. He has refused to talk peace before the departure of a 3,000-man West African peacekeeping force - which arrived in Monrovia on Aug. 24. Shelling by Taylor's troops left five members of the West African force dead last week. Ghana and Nigeria responded by bombing Taylor's troops. Meanwhile, the remaining soldiers loyal to the late president have run amok in the capital, looting and torching buildings and skirmishing with the rebels. Brig. Gen. David Nimley, who took over from Doe, said Monday his troops were fighting through downtown Monrovia toward the port to protect members of their faction waiting there to be evacuated, the BBC reported. Nimley accused the five-nation West African task force of failing to protect Doe's people from the rebels. The task force includes troops from Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea and Gambia. More than 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in Liberia's war.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Threaten And Temperatures Hit Record Lows
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures fell to record lows Tuesday from Michigan to New England and south to North Carolina, and rain fell from the Southwest across the Plains to the Midwest. Record lows were 36 at Allentown, Pa.; 27 at Alpena, Mich.; 36 at Atlantic City, N.J.; 41 at Baltimore; 35 at Beckley, W.Va.; 35 at Binghamton, N.Y.; 42 at Bridgeport, Conn.; 40 at Erie, Pa.; 35 at Flint, Mich.; 37 at Mansfield, Ohio; 44 at New York City; 46 at Raleigh, N.C.; 37 at Rochester, N.Y.; 36 at Syracuse, N.Y.; 51 at Wilmington, N.C.; and 34 at Youngstown, Ohio. Tuesday's official low for the Lower 48 states was 26 at Watertown, N.Y. Wilmington, Del., warmed up to just 66 Tuesday, the city's coolest high on record for the date. Advisories were posted for frost and freezing temperatures overnight over Vermont and sections of northeastern New York state. ``The air's coming from a large, high-pressure system in Canada that dipped down farther south than usual,'' said National Weather Service meteorologist Anthony Gigi in New York. Showers and storms extended from Arizona across northern New Mexico, southwestern Colorado, north-central Texas, south-central through northeastern Oklahoma, northern Arkansas, western Tennessee, western Kentucky, Indiana and Illinois. Locally heavy rain across central Arizona raised a threat of flooding, the weather service reported. Hail as big as golf balls fell at Oracle Valley, near Tucson. Showers and storms also spread across parts of Missouri, Iowa, South Dakota, North Dakota, Minnesota and Wisconsin. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 0.70 of an inch at Fargo, N.D., and at Springfield, Ill. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over southern Texas, the upper Texas Gulf Coast, southern Louisiana, and the southern third of Florida. Elsewhere, showers were scattered over the lower coast of Maine and northern Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 46 at Montpelier, Vt., to 95 at Fort Myers and Sarasota, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Second Summer of Alaska Beach Cleanup Ends, Buried Blobs Feared
DOC.TEXT: The second summer cleanup of beaches tarred with crude oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez ended with state officials still worried that buried blobs of oil could cause more environmental damage. Exxon crews scoured contaminated shorelines for five months, starting in April, to remove oil left through the winter after the 987-foot tanker slammed onto a reef in March 1989 and spilled nearly 11 million gallons into Prince William Sound. Most beaches still covered with oil after the agitation of typically violent winter storms were cleaned up, but many large collections of crude oil lie offshore, covered by shifting sand and gravel. ``The same forces that buried it can unbury it,'' state spokesman Ernie Piper said. Gov. Steve Cowper said he's worried that oil untouched by the cleanup will ``leach toxic substances for a long, long time.'' Initially, 1,245 miles were coated with spilled oil, Piper said. At the start of the 1990 cleanup, about 100 miles of beach remained tainted, he said. By Saturday, when Exxon shut down operations for the winter, only four miles were classified as heavily oiled, Piper said. Cowper commended Exxon and the Coast Guard for what was accomplished, but fretted about the environmental future of the area where thousands of animals live and breed. ``I don't think we'll ever see the point where the spiller and the regulator will ever agree to everything,'' Cowper said last week. ``It's our job to bark at the heels of everyone. It's our beach.'' There is no agreement about how to best deal with buried oil. Some say it should be dug up, others say environmental disruption caused by digging would be worse than leaving the oil untouched. Otto Harrison, Exxon's general manager in Alaska, said cleanup work and winter wave action produced ``a rapid recovery'' of Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska. The oil company pointed to a record 1990 salmon catch as partial proof. Fishermen hauled in 43 million pink salmon, nearly 50 percent more than the record set in 1987. The salmon have a two-year life cycle, meaning the ones caught this year were those that swam out to sea in 1989, during the height of the spill. Inspectors said this year's catch was high quality. Coast Guard Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini said he was happy with the second summer cleanup and discounted the flurry of state complaints accompanying its close. ``The controversy is over as far as I'm concerned,'' he said. ``Let's get out of here on a happy note and do whatever we have to do to finish up next year.'' Exxon said it would resume the cleanup in 1991 if the Coast Guard decides it is needed. The state plans to draw up its own list of areas to be cleaned. The oil company said it spent $2 billion on the cleanup in 1989 and $200 million more this year.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Alleged Comoros Plot Dies
DOC.TEXT: A suspect arrested last month in an alleged coup plot to topple President Said Mohamed Djohar has died in custody, official Radio Comores announced. Said Mlinde showed no signs of bruises or other signs of mistreatment when he was rushed from his jail cell to Al Maarouf hospital Saturday in a coma, the radio said Monday. It gave no other details. Mlinde, a postal worker, was one of about 20 people arrested for plotting against Djohar, elected in March to lead this string of islands in the Indian Ocean that became independent from France in 1975. Djohar became interim president in November when President Ahmed Abdallah Abderrahmane died in a dispute with French mercenary Bob Denard, who had been in charge of Abdallah's Presidential Guard. French Judge Chantal Pedrix last week charged one of Denard's men, Jean-Paul Guerrier, with assassinating Abdallah. Denard, who fled to South Africa, admits being in the room when Abdallah was shot but said he wasn't responsible for his death.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Syphilis Rate Increased 34 Percent Since 1981
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Especially worrisome...,' to CORRECT that syphilis incidence among blacks more than doubled sted nearly doubled. Schwarcz, Schwebke cq in 18th and 19th grafs
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. syphilis rate is at its highest level in 40 years, and the biggest increase in the sexually transmitted disease has been among blacks, according to a federal study. A separate study also published in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association says the common, inexpensive methods of treating gonorrhea should be abandoned because of sharp rises in both the penicillin-resistant and tetracycline-resistant strains of the disease. In the first study, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta report a 34 percent increase in the number of Americans treated for syphilis between 1981 and 1989. They said 18.4 of every 100,000 Americans were treated for syphilis last year, up from the 13.7 cases per 100,000 treated in 1981. The 1989 rate was higher than at any time since 1949, the study said. The overall rate has risen most sharply in the last four years, which may be an indication that precautions spurred in the early 1980s by the AIDS outbreak are on the wane, said one of the study's authors, Dr. Allyn K. Nakashima of the CDC's division of sexually transmitted diseases. ``Obviously the message has not gotten out to certain groups,'' Nakashima said in a telephone interview Monday. Especially worrisome though, the study's authors say, is the high rate among blacks. The study shows the incidence of syphilis among blacks more than doubled between 1985 and 1989, to 121.8 cases from 52.6 cases per 100,000 people. In contrast, syphilis rates among white males have dropped by 69 percent since 1982. The disease rate for white females remained low and unchanged. Data for the study came from quarterly and annual reports sent to the CDC by state health departments over the nine-year period reviewed. Researchers were unable to give concrete reasons for the differences between the racial groups, although they suggest that the higher rate among blacks may be linked to a higher incidence of drug abuse, poverty and homelessness. ``This is just one more problem that can be attached to that disenfranchised group,'' Nakashima said. Commenting on the new study, the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation said in a statement that it has seen ``a shocking 186 percent jump'' in the number babies born with syphilis passed on by infected mothers in the last five years. ``The ravages of syphilis among newborns closely follow trends in infection among women,'' said Dr. Reed V. Tuckson, a senior vice president at the March of Dimes in White Plains, N.Y. ``The resurgence of this disease among adults is clearly reflected by a rapid rise in the number of babies who develop serious disorders and die.'' The gonorrhea study shows that, although the incidence of the disease has decreased since 1975, there is an increasing problem with infections caused by strains that are resistant to treatment with penicillin and tetracycline. In the study conducted from September 1987 through December 1988, researchers examined 6,204 cases from 21 clinics nationwide and 21 percent showed potential for resistance to both treatments as well as two other often used drugs, cefoxitin and spectinomycin. Results of the study helped the CDC write new guidelines, which were published last year, for treating gonorrhea. The CDC recommends gonorrhea be treated with ceftriaxone. It's at least seven times more expensive and is the only treatment that all of the disease's strains have been susceptible to, said the study's primary author, Dr. Sandra K. Schwarcz, also of the CDC. But the practice has not caught on yet in many areas, said Dr. Jane Schwebke, assistant director of programs for sexually transmitted diseases at the Harborview Medical Center in Seattle. ``In the outlying areas a lot of people are still using penicillin, which can be a problem,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Seek Investigation Of Bone Marrow Foundation
DOC.TEXT: Five senators asked federal health officials Tuesday to investigate a California foundation that allegedly misused funds it raised to help patients needing bone marrow transplants. The senators said in a letter they were disturbed about complaints from transplant patients and their families who said they had difficulty getting Life-Savers Foundation of America to account for funds contributed for specific patients. By mid-1990, the foundation reported it had raised more than $7.6 million under a contract with the National Marrow Donor Program, the lawmakers said. Under the $500,000 contract signed in May 1989, the foundation was to recruit bone-marrow donors, conduct public education campaigns about the need for donors and raise money for testing of potential donors, said Douglas A. Shaw, executive director of the marrow donor program. The program terminated the agreement June 27 this year, charging the foundation breached the contract by failing to submit the names of thousands of recruited donors to the program's national registry. ``By withholding the names ... it meant that when we searched our computers (for names of potential donors) we were missing about 21,600 names,'' Shaw said. The donor program went to court to force the foundation to turn over the names. Shaw said it appeared the foundation was trying to start its own donor registry. He said about 10,000 names have been turned over, so far. Spokeswoman Susan Rafkin said officials at the Covina, Calif.-based foundation could not comment because they had not received the senators' letter. She said the foundation welcomes any inquiries into its activities. The program, established by Congress in 1984 and partially finance with federal funds, has about 200,000 names of potential donors in its registry. It is based in St. Paul, Minn. The foundation's contract involved working with patients trying to find a suitable bone-marrow donor, Shaw said. The funds raised by the foundation were to be used to offset laboratory-testing costs incurred by patients searching for an appropriately matched donor, Shaw said. However, families have complained that Life-Savers refused to pay some laboratory bills incurred by patients for whom the group had received contributions, and then refused to turn over the funds contributed for that patient to another organization, the senators said. ``We find such charges deeply disturbing,'' said the letter to Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. Sullivan's office had no comment. The letter was signed by Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., Al Gore, D-Tenn., Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Dave Durenberger, R-Minn.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs D.C. Budget
DOC.TEXT: The Senate passed a $4 billion spending bill for the District of Columbia Tuesday, but disputes over abortion language, gay rights and aid for artists at a city university must still be worked out between House and Senate lawmakers. The Senate version of the bill, passed without debate, contains abortion language that prompted President Bush to twice veto the bill last year. The bill also contains a controversial amendment that permits private volunteer organizations in the district, such as the Big Brothers, to set their own policies on whether to allow homosexuals to serve as mentors for minors. Gay rights groups vehemently opposed this measure, introduced by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo. The House version of the bill contains no such provision. The legislation passed by the Senate also restores $1.6 million for the University of the District of Columbia that the House had blocked. The House struck the money after some members complained that ``The Dinner Party,'' was erotic and should not receive federal support. The Senate bill restored that money and required the university to make quarterly financial reports to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. The Senate abortion language, however, may prove to be the most controversial amendment in the package. The bill would allow the city to use locally-raised tax money to pay for Medicaid abortions and would allow the federal government to reimburse the city for the costs of abortions performed in cases where the pregnancy either endangered the life of the mother or is the result of rape or incest. The White House has said that Bush's advisers will recommend a veto unless it prohibits the use of all funds - federal or local - to pay for abortions except where the mother's life would be endangered. The House version of the bill contained more restrictive abortion language. House and Senate conferees must meet to resolve these differences. The federal government will pay the city $430.5 million for tax revenue lost on federally-owned property. Congress has not increased its contribution to the city tax base since 1985, despite a surge in local property values. The Senate version of the bill would authorize $371 million more than the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Butte Supervisors Vote To Accept Bailout Plan
DOC.TEXT: Butte County supervisors narrowly averted the nation's first county bankruptcy Tuesday by approving an $11.1 million bailout offered by Gov. George Deukmejian. The board voted 3-2 to accept the Republican governor's proposal, which local officials said will avert immediate bankruptcy but won't stave off the possibility of bankruptcy next year. ``We're only putting off the inevitable,'' said Supervisor Hack McInturf. County officials blamed the expense of programs required by the state. Under the agreement, Deukmejian proposed deferring payment of more than $6.3 million owed the state for fire protection services, postponed the state's demand for payment of a $2 million matching share for a new Butte County jail and offered a $1.15 million direct cash grant. The proposal also calls for the county to raise some $1.65 million by boosting local fees, including property tax collections and jail booking fees. The payment deferrals will allow the county to use those funds for local programs and services. In return, the county agreed to scale back requests for new law enforcement services, increases in pay for county workers and other programs. The county said earlier it needed $14.1 million to keep from going bankrupt, a figure that included expanded jail facilities and more deputies. The agreement followed weeks of acrimonious negotiations between the state and the county, which is last among California's 58 counties in the amount of money it spends per capita on government services, and last in the proportion of sheriff's deputies to population. The county in northern Califrnia is largely rural, with an economy based on ranching and farming, and has less than 200,000 people. Oroville, the county seat, is 66 miles north of Sacramento. The crisis arose after county officials were unable to balance this year's $155 million budget. They complained that fully 85 percent of their money was locked into existing programs by state statute - such as welfare and health care for the poor, and fire protection services. Board chairman Ed McLaughlin, along with the County Supervisors Association of California, said that since the state didn't fully reimburse the county for the mandated services, the county was forced to cut local services in order to finance the state's demands. McLaughlin voted against accepting the agreement, saying the county had earlier pledged to declare bankruptcy unless the state offered the full $14.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Toothpaste, Mouthwash Makers Must Prove Plaque-Reduction Claims
DOC.TEXT: Makers of toothpastes and mouthwashes claiming to prevent plaque and other dental conditions must prove their products work, federal health officials said Tuesday. The Food and Drug Administration told manufacturers to submit data supporting their claims within the next six months. Several toothpaste and mouthwash manufacturers have been heavily promoting their products' ability to reduce or prevent plaque, tartar and other deposits on teeth and guard against gum disease and other dental conditions. The FDA said these statements amount to drug claims because they deal with the treatment or prevention of disease and because they affect the structure or function of the body. Under the federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, manufacturers making drug claims must show that the ingredients in their products are safe and effective, the agency said. If the claims cannot be supported with scientific data, manufacturers would have to remove such claims from the labels of their products, the FDA said. The American Dental Association welcomed the FDA's action. ``It's well known that many of these products are effective in reducing plaque and problems related to plaque,'' said Philip Weintraub, a spokesman for the association. The association has given its ``seal of acceptance'' to several toothpaste and mouthwash manufacturers that make anti-plaque claims, he said. ``We've looked at their extensive clinical data and determined (their products) are safe and will perform as the manufacturers say they will,'' he said. The FDA request for data was to be published in the Federal Register on Wednesday. The agency considered oral health-care products years earlier in its review of nonprescription drugs, but much research has been conducted since then on plaque and its prevention, an FDA spokeswoman said. Plaque is a thin deposit on teeth that promotes bacteria growth. Studies have implicated plaque in the development of cavities and to gingivitis, a painful inflammation of the gums. Some manufacturers claim that the abrasives in their toothpaste scrapes off plaque. Some mouth rinses claim to remove plaque through antimicrobial or chemical activity.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Prints Solzhenitsyn's View of Rebuilding Russia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf `Solzhenitsyn praised' to UPDATE with quote, edits to conform. Picks up 19th pvs, `Solzhenitsyn argued...'
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet newspaper Tuesday published an article by Alexander Solzhenitsyn urging a populist revival of democracy and spirituality in Russia without Western cultural ``garbage'' or capitalist exploitation. ``The time of Communism is over,'' the exiled Nobel laureate wrote. ``But its concrete structure hasn't collapsed yet. And let us not find ourselves under its rubble instead of becoming free.'' Solzhenitsyn, 71, wrote the article at his home in Cavendish, Vt. It was published in a special supplement to the reformist newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda and took up the equivalent of four full pages. The publication of Solzhenitsyn's hopes for his homeland represented another step in his official re-emergence in the Soviet Union. His long-banned books are being published in the nation that expelled him in 1974 for treason, and last month, President Mikhail Gorbachev ordered his citizenship restored. Komsomolskaya Pravda's circulation is 22 million. The article also will be published in this week's Literaturnaya Gazeta, a literary journal with a circulation of 4.5 million. individuals sick with severe illnesses such as lung cancer and in great financial need get paid before those with less pressing ailments. Weinstein appointed a former federal Judge, Marvin Frankel, to hold hearings on whether a class action is warranted on the claims against the Manville trust. After similar hearings, Frankel earlier this month ruled that Eagle-Picher qualified for a class action. The company, which makes industrial products, has more than 64,000 lawsuits pending and is being named in 20,000 more a year. Frankel said Eagle-Picher faces insolvency because of its liability. Weinstein is expected to rule on whether to approve a class action at a hearing next week, though lawyers for the company and plaintiffs have not yet agreed on how the money would be paid in such a settlement. In addition to a financial restructuring covered by Manville's $520 million infusion, Weinstein has ordered the trust to alter the way it pays claims to meet those with the greatest need first. Currently, claims are resolved based the time of filing.

DOC.HEAD: New Cast Members Bow for `Saturday Night Live'
DOC.TEXT: Somebody asked Chris Rock, one of two new members of the ``Saturday Night Live'' cast introduced at a news conference Tuesday, if he felt ``haunted by the ghost of Eddie Murphy.'' Rock looked nonplussed. ``Eddie's still alive, ain't he?'' he said. Rock, 23, a standup comedian since age 18, then allowed that he was bringing his own perspective to the 16th season of the late-night NBC variety show. ``I always wanted to be, like, a black guy on `Saturday Night Live,''' said Rock, an 8-year-old when ``SNL'' premiered in 1975. Murphy, who joined the show in 1980, went to become one of the nation's biggest box office draws. ``I always wanted to be on it, too,'' said stocky, blond, blue-eyed Chris Farley, 26, a former Second City trouper, and the other new member of the cast. A native of Wisconsin, Farley is a graduate of Marquette University. He joined the Chicago comedy troupe in the fall of 1988 and traveled with The Second City National Touring Company. Rock makes his home in Brooklyn's Fort Greene neighborhood ``a block over from Spike,'' he said, referring to moviemaker Spike Lee. Rock and Farley are replacing Jon Lovitz and Nora Dunn, who have left the show to pursue other ventures in the entertainment business. The returning cast members are Dana Carvey, Dennis Miller, Jan Hooks, Phil Hartman, Victoria Jackson, Kevin Nealon and Mike Myers. The two Chrises are ``featured performers'' with A. Whitney Brown and Al Franken. ``I think this will be a great season and I think you'll see lots of new characters,'' said the show's producer, Lorne Michaels. The season premiere with host Kyle MacLachlan, who plays demented FBI agent Dale Cooper on ABC's ``Twin Peaks, and musical guest Sinead O'Connor. Last season, O'Connor and departing cast member Dunn boycotted the show which had raunch comedian Andrew Dice Clay as its host. The show was the season's highest-rated. Other ``SNL'' guest hosts slated for the new season include ``All My Children'' soap opera star Susan Lucci, former New York Yankees president George Steinbrenner, musician Paul Simon, and actors Patrick Swayze, Christian Slater and Tom Hanks, Michaels said.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Commander of Saddam: `I Hope That He Dies'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The commander of Syrian troops in the Saudi desert described his men Tuesday as a buffer between the feuding Arab brothers of Arabia and Iraq, and said of Saddam Hussein: ``I hope that he dies very soon.'' Gen. Mohammed Deeb Dhaher, opening his camp to reporters for the first time, said his battle-hardened commandos could shift quickly into offensive posture if their orders were changed. ``The Syrians are here for the defense of Saudi Arabia, but if they have to go for offense they will be ready,'' said Dhaher, who said all of his men have experience fighting in Lebanon. The Syrians, who have photographs of President Hafez Assad at the entrance of their camp, are the fittest-looking and most experienced of all the Arab forces on the front lines in the multinational defense of Saudi Arabia. But their numbers are low pending reinforcements. While several hundred of his colleagues jogged across the desert in formation, soldier Ramzi Salim said the Syrians would have no problem fighting with Americans if hostilities erupt with the Iraqi forces to the north in occupied Kuwait. ``Everyone in the world is against Saddam Hussein,'' Salim said. ``Kuwait will be Kuwait again.'' Nodding nearby was another commando, Mohammed Nosra, who said the Syrians were ``proud to be in Saudi Arabia to defend the holy mosques and ready to stop any army that makes aggression against an Arab.'' Gen. Dhaher, wearing a skull and sword inginia on his uniform, nodded yes when asked if he would have fought wth Iraq if Assad had ordered him to do so. ``We are soldiers,'' he said, adding, ``We would not have been as enthusiatic about our mission.'' Saddam and Assad head rival wings of the Baath Party. Prior to the invasion of Kuwait, Assad figured more prominently on the list of U.S. troubles in the Mideast than did Saddam. U.S. administrations accuse Syria of harboring terrorists. The Saudi government the past month has been taking reporters on weekly trips to Arab camps near Hafr al Batin, in the northern Arabian desert about 65 miles from the Kuwaiti border. But until Tuesday the Syrians had not opened their camp, which is near camps of Saudi, Kuwaiti and Egyptian forces. The Syrians are about 1,200 strong, with armored units said to be on the way. At the moment the commandos have virtually no equipment other than what they carry on their backs and belts. For now, the Syrians and 2,000 Egyptian front-line forces are more a political statement than a military force. The American forces, which have been fortifying their forward positions with tanks and other heavy armor and artillery in the past two weeks, remain in most areas about 30 miles behind the Arab forces. At the Kuwaiti camp, officers acknowledged that about 70 percent of the 20,000-strong Army has been lost as a result of the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, including a good number of Kuwaiti troops who were on vacation when Iraq invaded. But the Kuwaiti commanders said they wanted to lead any offensive action to force Iraq from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Attacker Shoots, Seriously Wounds Former Gibraltar Governor
DOC.TEXT: An assailant shot and wounded the former governor of Gibraltar and his wife Tuesday night at their home in northern England. Police said the attack had the ``connotations'' of an IRA action. Air Chief Marshall Sir Peter Terry and Lady Terry were treated for gunshot wounds from the 9 p.m. attack at their home in Milford, a village near Stafford about 130 miles northwest of London. ``I understand that Sir Peter has sustained a serious gunshot wound ... but that Lady Terry has only a very slight injury,'' said Assistant Chief Constable Graham Goulding. Terry was governor and commander-in-chief of Gibraltar from 1985 until he retired in 1989. In March 1988, British SAS soldiers shot and killed Irish Republican Army guerrillas Mairead Farrell, Danny McCann and Sean Savage about 500 yards from Terry's home. British authorities said the unarmed rebels were apprehended planting a car bomb. Staffordshire police were searching for a man seen running from the Terrys' home. Asked if he thought the IRA was involved, Goulding replied, ``Maybe it's a little early to draw that conclusion, and no one has claimed responsibility at this stage. But of course it has the obvious connotations of similar events.'' The IRA has attacked British targets overseas in its campaign to drive the British out of the province of Northern Ireland and unite it with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: European Nations Agree to Air Embargo, Coordination of Ground Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8, bgng `The EC' with 5 grafs to CORRECT that raid on Dutch embassy occurred earlier, UPDATE with total of 28 warships in gulf, Dutch offer to send fighters. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `France and...'
DOC.TEXT: Nine European nations called on the U.N. Security Council Tuesday to impose an air embargo on Iraq and agreed to coordinate their air and ground forces in the Persian Gulf. Defense and foreign ministers of the Western European Union, meeting in Paris, urged the Security Council to quickly endorse closing Iraq's air routes to enforce the economic embargo imposed after the invasion of Kuwait. The Security Council has already endorsed the use of naval force to back up the embargo. The decision follows a dramatic rise in tensions between Europe and Iraq following raids last week by Iraqi soldiers on the diplomatic quarters of at least four nations in Kuwait. The meeting of the Western European Union follows agreement Monday by the 12-nation European Community to expel Iraqi military aides and restrict movements of Iraq's diplomats in their capitals. The EC also was acting in retaliation for the raids Friday on the ambassadorial residences or embassies of France, Belgium and Canada in Kuwait, and an earlier raid against the Dutch compound. The troops briefly detained the French military attache and took three other French nationals prisoner. France responded by expelling 29 Iraqis, proposing to extend the U.N. embargo of Iraq to air traffic, and promising to dispatch warplanes, tanks, helicopters and 4,200 soldiers to Saudi Arabia. France, current president of the Western European Union, called Tuesday's meeting. There are currently 28 warships in the gulf region belonging to the nine Western European Union nations. But only Britain and France have committed ground troops in the gulf. The Netherlands offered Tuesday to send a squadron of 18 F-16 jet fighters to Turkey if the United Nations declares an air blockade. France and Britain, the other Western European power with significant forces in the region, wanted their WEU allies to send at least token ground troops, according to diplomatic sources. The WEU is the sole European body dealing with defense issues. Its members include nine of the 12 European Community nations. Neutral Ireland, Greece and Denmark are not members. U.N. diplomats on Sunday began drafting a new resolution to close Iraq's air routes and punish nations flouting the economic embargo, U.S. officials said. An air blockade would involve the interception of planes approaching Iraq and would pose a far greater danger of triggering hostilities than the boarding of ships in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes on Garbage Ban Proposed by Coats
DOC.TEXT: The Senate endorsed a measure Tuesday that would allow states to close their borders to other states' garbage to protect shrinking landfill capacity. Sen. Dan Coats, R-Ind., said the proposal would give ``every state the right to determine its own destiny'' in managing trash through bans or higher fees for out-of-state waste. ``I wanted a fair shot at this,'' the freshman senator said after prevailing over the objections of New Jersey Democratic senators Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg on a 68-31 vote. ``I'm content with it.'' Under Coats' proposal, offered as an amendment to the District of Columbia appropriations bill, states could block garbage imports as long as they had a 20-year solid waste plan in place. Bradley and Lautenberg, concerned their state would be overrun by trash if the measure were to become law, promised to continue fighting when the appropriations bill reaches a House-Senate conference committee. The D.C. appropriations bill is also in danger of a presidential veto because it contains abortion funding language that led to two vetoes last year. Coats promised a tough fight to keep his measure alive. ``If it's knocked out, we'll be back next year. At minimum, we have established a 2-to-1 majority to do something about this problem.'' Lautenberg has accused Coats of playing election-year politics with the garbage issue. ``We knew we were on the less-popular side of the issue,'' he said. New Jersey is the largest exporter of solid waste to Indiana landfills, which are eight to 10 years from reaching their capacity, Coats said. ``The amendment would give any state the power to impose unlimited, punitive fees on out-of-state garbage,'' said Lautenberg, who said bans could be imposed suddenly and without Environmental Protection Agency review. ``A state writes its own ticket.'' Bradley and Lautenberg charged the Coats measure would block development of a comprehensive national solid waste policy by pitting state against state. They said it also would undermine recycling. New Jersey has set a 60 percent recycling goal by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Airways to Start Operations from Egypt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's national airline has moved its headquarters to Cairo and will start operating there next month, an airline official said Tuesday. Abdel-Razzak al-Otaki, manager of the Cairo office, said eight Boeing planes that were outside Kuwait when Iraqi troops invaded his country Aug. 2 will be used. ``The main goal is to keep the Kuwaiti flag flying in foreign capitals and countries,'' al-Otaki said in a telephone interview. On Monday, Iraq ordered the dissolution of Kuwait Airways and transferred all its assets to the government-run Iraqi Airways. Baghdad also dissolved all offices of the Kuwaiti flagship air carrier abroad and dismissed its personnel. The move to transfer the headquarters of the company to Cairo began even before the dissolution order was announced in Iraq, Al-Otaki said. He said destinations from Cairo would be the United States and countries in Europe, the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and Asia. The eight-plane fleet includes Boeing 747 jumbo and 767 airliners.

DOC.HEAD: 60,000 Troops to Leave Germany
With AM-Base Closings
DOC.TEXT: The United States is withdrawing about 60,000 of its quarter-million troops from West Germany as part of a major cutback of U.S. forces abroad, the West German Defense Ministry said Tuesday. A statement said most of the reduction would be completed by 1993. In Washington, the Pentagon said it was ending U.S. military operations at 94 sites and reducing them at 14 other locations in West Germany. The Pentagon said the disolution of Cold War conflicts was allowing cutbacks at 150 bases in 10 countries around the world. Many West Germans have chafed at the U.S. troop presence as an obstacle to achieving full national sovereignty. Residents near U.S. bases complain about the noise of training flights and the disruption caused by frequent exercises. West German officials have said the houses of the departing U.S. troops could be used by hundreds of thousands of immigrants from Eastern Europe who have flooded into the country the last year.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon President Hospitalized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LDS in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Ezra Taft Benson, the 91-year-old president of the Mormon Church, was hospitalized Tuesday for an unspecified ailment. LDS Hospital spokesman Tim Madden said Benson was admitted about 12:30 p.m. for observation and was in fair condition. Madden declined to detail why Benson, who served as secretary of agriculture in the Eisenhower Administration, was taken to the hospital. Church spokesman Don LeFevre said doctors expected to keep Benson overnight. He didn't know what the church leader's ailment was. Benson, who became president of the 7.5 million-member church in 1985, was last hospitalized for four days in June for treatment of a bacterial infection. In November 1986, Benson had a heart pacemaker implanted to control episodes during which his heartbeat was slowing. Frail because of his age, Benson has attended but hasn't addressed recent general conferences of the church.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Game Bill Clears House Committee
DOC.TEXT: The House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday approved a plan under which makers of computer softwear could bar video stores and others from renting them to customers. Manufacturers have complained that the rentals of video games are cutting into sales. The bill sponsored by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., is similar to a law already passed by Congress under which record manufacturers are allowed to bar rentals. The measure sailed through Judiciary Committee on a voice vote despite objections from video rental store operators. Sponsors are expected to push for early action on the measure, with Congress expected to leave Washington for the campaign trail in a matter of weeks. The Senate already has passed similar legislation. The idea behind the bill is that it is easy to copy both records and computer softwear stored on floppy discs. The rentals are therefore considered to undercut the copyrights held by the manufacturers. Games often cost between $40 and $50. Under the bill, manufacturers would have the option of allowing rentals or barring them. In the case of records, most makers do not allow rentals. Actually, the bill applies to a wide range of computer softwear in addition to video games, but the rental of games by stores that specialize mainly in renting movies is the main focus of the issue. The Japanese manufacturer Nintendo asked to have its games included in the bill, but the committee balked at that. Lawmakers said Nintendo games are not readily copied and therefore, the company's copyrights are not endangered by rentals. The bill specifies that the measure not only does not apply to Nintendo but also softwear embodied in machines, such as cars and microwaves.
