DOC.HEAD: Suspected Murderer of Presidential Candidate Escapes Prison
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of slaying a leading presidential candidate, whose death led to a year-old war between the government and drug traffickers, escaped Tuesday from a Bogota prison, police said. Jaime Rueda Rocha was one of three suspects being held in the shooting death of Liberal Party candidate Sen. Luis Carlos Galan on Aug. 18, 1989. Radio reports said Rueda Rocha used documents provided by his lawyer to persuade prison workers to let him leave the facility. A police spokeswoman said officials were investigating how Rueda Rocha escaped. She confirmed on condition of anonymity that Rueda Rocha's lawyer, Carlos Caicedo, had been visiting him at the time of his escape. Rueda Rocha was arrested a month after Galan's murder. The government blamed the Medellin cocaine cartel for masterminding the candidate's slaying, which led to a major crackdown on drug traffickers. One of the tactics used by the government in its crackdown that most angered the drug kingpins was extraditing traffickers wanted in the United States on drug-running and money laundering charges. The cartel responded with an assassination and bombing campaign, which in the past year killed about 550 people, including three presidential candidates. During that period, the group reportedly detonated 300 bombs nationwide. A domestic airliner also exploded in air shortly after takeoff from Bogota's airport, killing more than 100 people. On July 27, the Medellin cartel declared a unilateral truce in its war against the government. On Tuesday, a statement signed by cocaine barrons calling themselves ``The Extraditables'' said despite army claims, they did not intend to resume their bombings of government targets for now. Last weekend the army found 1,000 pounds of dynamite in a northeastern Colombian region where the leader of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar, is said to own vast tracks of land.

DOC.HEAD: Friends, Feminist Leader Disagree on Souter's Civil Liberties Stance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 21st graf pvs, bgng: Specter noted xxx to include conservative's abortion stance.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter was praised by friends Tuesday as a strong supporter of civil liberties, but a feminist leader called him ``a total disaster for civil rights and women's rights.'' The Senate Judiciary Committee, which completed three days of questioning Souter on Monday, turned its attention to about 40 witnesses testifying for and against him. His confirmation as the high court's 105th justice - and a key vote on such divisive issues as abortion, civil rights and church-state relations - seemed certain. Before Tuesday's hearings began, Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, told reporters her group had begun a major drive to block Souter's confirmation. ``We know that man will be a fifth vote to overturn Roe vs. Wade,'' Ms. Yard said, referring to the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. ``Our lives are on the line. Women in this country are going to die. We're talking about your daughters, your granddaughters. He is a disastrous choice, a total disaster for civil rights and women's rights.'' During the hearings, Ms. Yard appeared on the verge of tears as she told the senators, all of them men, ``None of you will ever face that problem (of an unwanted pregnancy). Not one of you.'' Eleanor Smeal of the Fund for the Feminist Majority held up a bracelet bearing the name of a 17-year-old, Becky Bell, she identified as ``a victim of the parental consent law of Indiana.'' She said the girl died after obtaining an illegal abortion. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said he was impressed by the testimony of Ms. Yard and Ms. Smeal, but added, ``There is another point of view that is equally as moving.'' Jerry Diamond, like Souter a former New Hampshire attorney general, praised his friend's honesty and integrity. Diamond added: ``His central tenet is the dignity and freedom of the individual. He is a strong supporter of civil liberties.'' Steven McAuliffe of the New Hampshire Bar Association, whose schoolteacher wife, Christa, died in the 1986 explosion of the Challenger space shuttle, spoke of Souter's compassion. ``I have some experience with personal pain,'' McAuliffe said. ``I know many of you share my pain as I share yours. I want you to know that David Souter feels and shares and understands the pain of others with great compassion and great dignity.'' The 14-member committee was expected to conclude its hearings Wednesday, and vote on Souter's nomination next week. The committee's recommendation then will go to the full Senate. Tuesday's first witnesses, Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights Action League and Faye Wattleton of Planned Parenthood, urged Souter's defeat. ``Judge Souter's personal qualifications are not at issue,'' Ms. Michelman said. ``The issue is whether or not the Supreme Court will continue to uphold the fundamental constitutional right to privacy, including the right to choose.'' Ms. Wattleton asked the senators to ``send a message that the period of tolerance for political gamesmanship around our fundamental reproductive rights has ended.'' In three days of testimony, Souter steered clear of giving his personal views on abortion or stating how he might vote if asked to overturn Roe vs. Wade. But some of his answers made him appear more moderate than his staunchly conservative reputation. In fact, several conservative senators appeared concerned by some of Souter's testimony. Two senators on record as supporting abortion rights said Tuesday the Souter opponents were engaging in poor strategy. ``I really believe you're making a big mistake,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. ``I'm on your side but I think you're hurting your cause.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said, ``It's not realistic to expect that if Judge Souter is turned down, we will get a nominee who ... will commit in advance to uphold Roe vs. Wade.'' Specter noted that President Bush, who nominated Souter, favors overturning the 1973 ruling. Howard Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus, said in written testimony prepared for delivery Wednesday that Souter should be opposed because he hasn't fought against abortion. Phillips cited Souter's tenure on a hospital governing board, during which he voted to allow abortions at the facility in light of the Roe v. Wade ruling. ``If... Mr. Souter believed each fetus to be a human person and failed to act against the performance of abortion, he was morally delinquent,'' Phillips said. Those testifying in favor of Souter's nomination were former Attorney General Griffin Bell and former Virginia Gov. Gerald Baliles. Bell said Souter ``has the right vision of our country and the law of our country.'' Baliles, who has known Souter since both men were deputy attorneys general of their respective states, said, ``I believe he will serve with distinction.'' Norma McCorvey, the woman who used the pseudonym Jane Roe when her challenge to a Texas abortion law led to the Supreme Court's 1973 ruling, attended the hearing and urged Souter's defeat. Ms. McCorvey's lawyer, Gloria Allred, told the committee: ``David Souter ... claims that he may or may not sign a decision returning millions of women to the fear and second-class status of 17 years ago. Perhaps he would relegate women to back-alley abortions and unwanted pregnancies. Perhaps not. He's not quite sure.'' The Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a leader in the successful campaign to defeat Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination in 1987, urged the Senate to recall Souter for more questioning. Joseph Rauh, the conference's chief lawyer, said Souter's testimony that New Hampshire ``has no racial problems'' indicates that Souter is insensitive to discriminatory practices and ``cannot see what is right under his nose.'' Rauh said there is ample proof that New Hampshire has racial problems.

DOC.HEAD: Five Permanent Security Council Members Agree on Iraq Air Embargo
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China have agreed on the basic guidelines for an air embargo on Iraq to cut it off from the rest of the world, a top Soviet official said Tuesday. Those nations, which are the five permanent Security Council members, are now refining the language of a council resolution so it conforms to international air traffic laws, said Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Vorontsov. ``We don't want anyone to be hurt,'' he said, and then added: ``We just want to hurt Iraq, just a little.'' U.N. diplomats and officials from the Permanent Five met Tuesday to continue refining the text of the resolution. Defense ministers from nine West European nations agreed Tuesday at a meeting in Paris to coordinate their air and ground forces in the gulf and enforce the U.N. air embargo when it takes effect. Vorontsov and other diplomats said the full 15-member Security Council is expected to pass the resolution within days, before French President Francois Mitterrand arrives to deliver a speech condemning Iraq on Monday before the General Assembly. Mitterrand was outraged by Iraqi raids last Friday on the French, Belgian, Dutch and Canadian missions in occupied Kuwait, in which three Frenchmen were abducted and diplomats were temporarily detained. The council passed its seventh resolution condemning Iraq last Sunday when it denounced the violation of diplomatic privileges. The next resolution, sources said, will extend the current naval embargo to air traffic, block Iraqi goods shipments among other nations, and call on all nations to restrict the operations of Iraq's embassies. All countries would have to close their airspace to planes approaching or leaving Iraq or occupied Kuwait. Only flights carrying refugees out of Iraq or Kuwait, or bringing in medical supplies and food specifically authorized by the Security Council would be allowed to travel to those nations. Planes could not be shot down; that is banned by the 1944 international civil aviation convention. The resolution would also make it clear that the trade embargo resolution adopted on Aug. 6 covers commerce in services, which will be specifically banned under the new resolution. At least one Western dredging company is still working in Iraq, and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said the 8,000 or so Soviet civil and military advisors in Iraq were working there on service contracts. Western diplomats said they hope the Soviet Union will use the new resolution as the pretext for withdrawing its advisors in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Chief: Saddam Capable of Terrorism, But Will He Attack?
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS lead to CORRECT that Webster determining Saddam's intentions is difficult sted CIA been unable to determine
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's terrorist capabilities, chemical weapons and missiles pose a serious international threat, but it is more difficult to determine whether Saddam Hussein intends to use them, the CIA chief said Tuesday. Even before the crisis triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the CIA was concerned about Saddam's links to Palestinian terrorists who have attacked Western targets, CIA Director William H. Webster said in the text of a New York speech. ``Now, he has both strong ties to Palestinian terrorists and an elaborate network within his own intelligence service capable of planning and carrying out terrorist attacks against a variety of international targets,'' Webster told the Foreign Policy Association. But the intelligence official added that ``capability - whether in Iraq or in other nations - is easier to measure than intent.'' ``Knowing the intent of world leaders requires the knowledge that comes from human intelligence, which is often difficult ot acquire,'' he said. Webster said h is putting additional emphasis on the CIA's ``human intelligence capability,'' to measure the intentions of leaders involved in conflicts. He gave no details of how such information might be acquired. Iraq's sizable stockpile of chemical and biological weapons is the largest in the Third World and can be delivered by a wide variety of weapons, including bombs, shells and artillery rockets, Webster said. ``What is even more troubling is Iraq's ambitious missile development program - the most aggressive and advanced in the Arab world,'' he added. In general, weapons of mass destruction are becoming easier to obtain and terrorism could ``extend the battlefield worldwide'' in future conflicts, Webster said. Based on intelligence assessments of Iraq, Webster said United Nations sanctions have cut off 95 percent of Iraq's oil exports and halted its efforts to recover from the eight-year war with Iran. The exodus of thousands of foreign workers, he said, has hampered nearly all of Iraq's domestic industries. Webster said the CIA gets regular reports on more than 60 Iraqi army divisions and on every tanker in Iraq's merchant marine fleet as well as information about the effectiveness of economic sanctions and the condition of foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. CIA agents also are looking at U.S. relations with other Arab countries whose populations Saddam is trying to influence. ``Saddam's ability to sway Arab public opinion - to convince them that he is the `hero of the masses' - could over time destabilize the region,'' Webster said. On U.S. relations with the Soviet Union, Webster said the recent Helsinki summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicates ``a new world order.'' But he said some concerns remain over Soviet actions, including concerns among some Asian nations over the fact that reductions of forces in Soviet Asia have been slower than those in areas near Europe. ``In this era of new relationships, however, an understanding between Moscow and some of these Asian countries is likely,'' Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: Tabloid Newspaper Workers Resign, Take Sweetened Severance Package
DOC.TEXT: The publisher who threatened to close the New York Post unless unions accepted $19 million in job and wage cuts predicted Tuesday that profits will soon begin rolling in. More than 30 employees resigned and took sweetened severage packages the day after the union holding up the concession deal voted to take the cuts. Those leaving will get standard severance pay, along with two months pay they would have received if the 189-year-old paper had shut down. Publisher Peter S. Kalikow, surrounded by union leaders and Post managers, said he expected the tabloid known for racy headlines and focus on urban crime to turn a profit by Oct. 1. If his prediction is correct, it would be the first time since the 1970s the paper became profitable. Kalikow said the Post has been losing about $27 million a year. To secure $19 million in union concessions, he promised the unions 20 percent of company stock and a representative on the board of directors. The remaining $8 million will be saved by other operating cost reductions, including management wage cuts. At a news conference in his office, he thanked those assembled for helping him save the nation's oldest continuously published daily paper. ``We sat in meetings with these guys, we sat in halls, we sat in bathrooms with them. They did a fabulous job,'' Kalikow said, also thanking more than 100 departing employees and the hundreds who will make less money. ``It's in no small part that we owe these people some thanks for the sacrifices they made,'' Kalikow said. ``The mortgage rate didn't go down. The price of food didn't go down. The price of gas didn't go down.'' The Newspaper Guild, which represents 350 news, advertising and clerical staff, voted Monday to accept job reductions and a 20 percent pay cut by switching to a four-day workweek. Top pay for reporters had been $853 a week. Ten other unions accepted concessions Friday. Kalikow said all the unions had to agree to concessions or he would shut down the paper. Two years ago, Kalikow won $24 million in concessions from the unions as a condition of his purchase of the Post. Some Guild holdouts had said they would rather see the paper close because they would get severance money and 60 days shut-down pay. Kalikow countered by offering severance and shut-down pay to anyone who resigns before 5 p.m. Wednesday. Daniel F. Cremins, Post executive vice president, said that in addition to the Guild offer, four other unions will receive a similar enhanced departure package. More than 30 Guild members had resigned by Tuesday afternoon, Kalikow spokesman Howard Rubenstein said, adding that an undisclosed number of executives would be let go and others face pay cuts. ``I can't see going through this again,'' said Henry Scott, 61, a publications clerk at the Post for 18 years who said he resigned although his wife is fighting cancer. ``I think it's my best bet to get out now. I can't take it anymore.'' He expects to get more than $30,000 plus the 60 days pay. Some Post reporters were in tears Tuesday and refused comment. Colleagues said they were upset because they were resigning. ``I have a morale problem right now. They're angry and they have a right to be,'' said editor Jerry Nachman. In the news business these days, he said, ``You learn sadly that the operational word is 'business.'''

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Deactivates Nuclear Test Site
DOC.TEXT: Brazil on Tuesday scrapped a nuclear test site at an air force base deep in the Amazonian jungle in a ceremony to show the government's peaceful intentions in its nuclear program. President Fernando Collor de Mello, acompanied by his three military ministers, tossed a handful of dirt into a 1,000-foot-deep, concrete- and steel-lined hole that officials said was constructed 10 years ago to test bombs. It was never used. ``The hole was adequate for an eventual nuclear test, but this will not occur in the Brazil of President Collor de Mello,'' said spokesman Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva. The hole on the Serra do Cachimbo Air Force Base, 930 miles northwest of Brasilia, was excavated in 1979 when Brazil was ruled by its last military president, Gen. Joao Figueredo. Its existence was a secret until four years ago. Even then, base officials claimed it was used for testing equipment for a Brazilian space program. Rosa e Silva said the hole was secretly constructed by the National Security Council, a military agency that has since been disbanded. Civilians took the reins of government in 1985 but full democracy was not restored until last December's election victory by Collor. The spokesman said Collor confirmed the existence of the hole last week and decided to go personally to the site to ``signal his position against secret military adventures.'' In 1987, Brazil developed the means to enrich uranium, a crucial step towards the construction of nuclear bombs, and the country now has the capacity to make such weapons, according to the Brazilian Society of Physics. Historically, the country's nuclear development programs have been under control of separate branches of the armed forces, independent of civilian control. Brazil has refused to sign the 1968 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and as a result its nuclear program is not monitored by the International Agency of Atomic Energy. Brazilian officials say the treaty is discriminatory because it discourages the transfer of nuclear technology to developing countries. Last week, Brazil and Argentina - the only two Latin American countries that possess nuclear know-how - released a statement promising not to utilize their knowledge to produce atomic wepaons.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Linked to Libya Poison Gas Checked For Toxic Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: A cherry-flavoring plant that may have been used by an Iraqi investor to acquire a poison gas ingredient for Libya has been inspected by local regulators looking for hazardous chemicals. But Louis Champon, owner of Product Ingredient Technology, defended his chemical productin process and waste-disposal methods during Monday's inspection, and once again said he had nothing to do with his late Iraqi partner's links to Libya. Champon opened the Product Ingredient Technology factory last year with $5 million from investor Ihsan Barbouti. Champon invented a process to extract bitter almond oil, a natural ingredient used in cherry flavoring, from apricot pits. A byproduct of the process is a cyanide compound. Champon said he unwittingly became involved in an effort by Barbouti to export the factory's cyanide compounds to Libya, where U.S. officials say they could be used in toxic weapons. Champon said he was unaware of Barbouti's alleged role as contractor for the Libyan chemical weapons plant at Rabta. But Barbouti, an Iraqi, made no secret of his affection for Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, Champon said. ``Dr. Barbouti wanted me to fly the Libyan flag next to the American flag at our building,'' Champon said Monday. ``He always said how friendly he was with Gadhafi. But we kept politics to a minimum.'' Champon said seven barrels that stored ferric ferrocyanide, the plant's byproduct, are missing. He was unsure if they were full when they left the property. Although that cyanide compound is relatively safe, environmental officials said it can be refined into deadly hydrogen cyanide and other toxic compounds. Champon said his cyanide disposal method was simple: He poured it down the drain. Boca Raton Fire-Rescue public information officer Mike Duane said Monday that could have been illegal, depending on the concentration of cyanide. Fire department inspectors and the state Department of Environmental Regulation took samples Monday of unidentified raw materials from the plant. Inspectors were uncertain when test results would be available. Fire inspectors on Monday cited the building's owner, Norman Stolack of Clark, N.J., for having a fire alarm system that doesn't work. Champon said the alarms don't work because electricity was turned off in July, when the plant closed for lack of money. Champon said he refused Barbouti's efforts to export the cyanide byproducts to West Germany. He said he also refused to increase Barbouti's share of the company from 50 percent to 80 percent. Disagreements between the men led Champon to file suit in July 1989 to sever their business relationship. Champon is seeking $100 million in damages, which he said is the potential value of his business. U.S. Customs Service officials interviewed Champon last week about his relationship with Barbouti. Champon said he had called the State Department two weeks earlier to tell them that Barbouti, who died in July and also has been linked to a chemical weapons plant in Iraq, was his partner.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Implement Makers Plead Guilty in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: Four manufacturers of smoking implements pleaded guilty Tuesday to conspiring to sell drug paraphernalia through the mail in the first court victory for the federal government in a nationwide investigation called Operation Pipe. Prosecutors said the pleas undermined the traditional defense among such manufacturers: that their products are meant to be used with tobacco, and how the buyers use them is their own business. The four businessmen and several others not yet prosecuted in a 302-count federal indictment, were wholesalers of water pipes, roach clips, crack pipes and other items they claimed were used for smoking tobacco. ``These people knew they were selling items used to ingest drugs. They can't hide it any longer,'' said Henry Hudson, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. The government agreed to drop charges of money laundering and conspiracy cases against other defendants in exchange for the four guilty pleas, said prosecutor Larry Leiser. Defense attorneys said their clients also agreed to the deal in light of the high cost of appeal. Randall Dyer, operator of Tobacco Accessories Distributing Co, doing business as Choice Supply, Inc., in Alexandria, Va., pleaded guilty Tuesday along with Page E. Weincek, William L. Love and John M. Burgess. Weincek is the principal in RPM Associates, Inc., doing business as Penguin Feather in Virginia and the District of Columbia. Love was doing business as Octopus Garden in Manassas, Va., with its principal owner, Burgess. All four defendants face a maximum of three years in jail, fines of $250,000 and forfeiture of up to 20 percent of their assets. Their businesses could be fined an additional $500,000, Hudson said. ``This case is significant because it's the first major prosecution of the purveyors of drug paraphernalia in the country,'' he said. Hudson said Operation Pipe has confiscated more than $100 million nationwide, with $3 million of that in the Washington, D.C. and Virginia area.

DOC.HEAD: 300 Rare Teddy Bears Bagged By Poachers
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of rare teddy bears worth thousands of dollars were bagged by thieves in a motel parking lot. About 300 stuffed toy bears, antiques and collectibles worth about $60,000 were stolen Monday from a trailer carrying them from a teddy bear convention in Baltimore, police said. The empty trailer and the truck hooked to it were found later in Bridegport, said Milford police Officer Edward Kelly. Owner Larry Idema, of Grand Haven, Mich., was headed to Boston when he stopped overnight at a motel, he said. Police had no leads Tuesday but were hoping the thieves would try to sell the bears on the open market. ``If they were amateurs and then discovered the loot, our chances of recovering of them are much better,'' Kelly said. ``But if it turns out that they're in the (teddy bear) business, then it will be much harder. They'll know where to sell them.'' Idema is offering a cash reward for one teddy bear in particular, a 1905 Steiff bear that is worth about $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Arrives in Budapest on Her Tour of Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, pressing for close links between Eastern Europe's new democracies and the West, arrived Tuesday in Hungary after a rousing speech to the new Czechoslovak parliament. In Budapest, Mrs. Thatcher inspected a guard of honor lined up in Kossuth Square before the ornate Parliament building. She dined later at a city restaurant with Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall. She received a standing ovation in the Czechoslovak Federal Assembly after apologizing for the 1938 Munich treaty and expressing remorse that the West did nothing when in 1968 Soviet tanks crushed the ``Prague Spring.'' She also told the assembly she would urge the 12-nation European Community, which so far has offered only loose association to the Eastern European democracies, to quickly offer them full membership. Apologizing for Britain's appeasement of Adolf Hitler before World War II, Mrs. Thatcher said the world was not making the same mistake over Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, with Europe, the United States and the Soviet Union acting in concert. ``In that new willingness to act together lies great hope for future peace, particularly here in Europe,'' she said. ``We failed you in 1938 when a disastrous policy of appeasement allowed Hitler to extinguish your independence,'' she said. ``Churchill was quick to repudiate the Munich agreement, but we still remember it with shame.'' The Munich treaty, signed by Britain and France, endorsed Hitler's invasion of northern Czechoslovakia. A year later, he invaded Poland to begin World War II. Turning to Alexander Dubcek, who led the 1968 reforms, Mrs. Thatcher said, ``The pictures of that brave venture are etched in our memory - and our inability to help remains a burden on the free world's conscience.'' Dubcek, now president of the newly elected Czechoslovak Assembly, made no reference to 1968. But he said Mrs. Thatcher's visit has ``put a full stop'' to the memories of Munich. Underlining the healing of pre-World War II wounds and the end of decades of postwar communist rule, Mrs. Thatcher was present for the renaming of a square in Prague after Winston Churchill. It was formerly named for a Communist Party chief, Antonin Zapotcky. She proposed to the Czechoslovak parliament that a 35-nation East-West summit adopt a universal standard of rights. ``If we can create a great area of democracy stretching from the west coast of the United States right across to the Soviet Far East, that would give us the best guarantee of all for security - because democracies don't go to war with each other,'' the British leader said. Before coming to Budapest, Mrs. Thatcher conferred with leaders of the Slovak assembly in Bratislava, capital of Czechoslovakia's Slovak Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Arens Asks U.S. for Additional $1 Billion in Military Aid
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens asked the United States Tuesday for a special $1 billion grant in military aid to defray the costs of an Israeli alert during the gulf crisis, Israel radio reported. The grant would be in addition to $1.8 billion in annual U.S. military aid to Israel, the radio said. The report said that Arens, who is in Washington, also asked U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney to increase Israel's yearly aid allowance to $2.5 billion. No other details were given. Arens' requests appeared to be also in addition to Israel's earlier appeals to lease more American fighter jets and other military equipment to balance out a proposed $18 billion U.S. arms package to Saudi Arabia. Israeli officials the past two days have spoken out strongly against the sale to the Saudis, announced last week. Also Tuesday, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai indicated he will ask the United States to forgive Israel's $4.5 billion debt with the United States if Washington erases Egypt's loans. Modai spoke at a press conference. Modai argued that Egypt received increased U.S. aid because it signed a U.S.-mediated peace accord with Israel in 1979. Egypt is the only Arab nation to make peace with the Jewish state. ``Can you imagine that now the Egyptians' loans would be waived and Israel would be stuck with its loans?'' Modai asked rhetorically at a news conference. Modai said Egypt faces rising military expenses because it has sent troops to assist in the Persian Gulf crisis. Israel, he said, also faces rising costs because of repeated threats from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Saddam's forces overran Kuwait on Aug. 2 and Baghdad later annexed the emirate. The United Nations has condemned the invasion and imposed economic sanctions on Iraq that also hurt several of Iraq's Arab neighbors. Modai reiterated the government stance that Israel, while not eager for bloodshed, would be unhappy with a negotiated gulf solution that leaves Saddam in power. ``What will happen next - everybody will go back home, the embargo will be stopped and Israel will have to face alone this wild beast,'' Modai said. President Bush earlier this month recommended that Egypt's $6.7 billion debt with the United States be forgiven to help the Arab state cover expenses incurred in the gulf crisis. The proposal already has run into opposition in the U.S. Congress, where legislators have said such a move would invite similar requests from Israel and other countries. Israel is America's largest foreign aid recipient, receiving, besides the military aid, $1.2 billion in economic assistance. Egypt is second, at $2.2 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Leader George Hardy, Dead at 79, Remembered For Toughness
DOC.TEXT: George Hardy, a Depression-era union organizer who died last week at age 79, was remembered for his dedication and tough-mindedness. ``He spoke up for people without power,'' state Assembly Speaker Willie Brown said at a memorial Monday, calling Hardy ``a labor leader of the old school.'' Hardy died Thursday at Children's Hospital. A union official in Washington said he died of respiratory failure. Former Gov. Jerry Brown, Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy and many of Hardy's friends in the labor movement attended the service at the Mission Dolores Basilica. Hardy began his career as an organizer for Theater Janitors Local 9 in San Francisco in 1932 and built the small regional union into the 935,000-member Service Employees International Union. The union represents custodians, health care workers and public employees. Hardy, a native of North Vancouver, British Colombia and son of labor leader Charles Hardy, was elected international president of the union in 1971. He retired in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: 11th-Hour Pact Avoids Philadelphia Orchestra Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, `The musicians...,' to UPDATE with vote count.
DOC.TEXT: A second ``final'' offer and a second vote headed off a strike by Philadelphia Orchestra musicians Tuesday, hours before the first concert of the orchestra's 91st season. With the contract dispute settled, the musicians made plans to go ahead with the performance. The musicians voted Monday night to reject what management said was its final offer and prepared to picket the Academy of Music on Tuesday. The old contract expired Monday. The union reported Monday's vote as 52-52. Tuesday's vote for ratification was 58-48. But negotiators returned to the bargaining table and worked into the early morning, and the union decided to call a second vote. ``It's the closest I've ever seen,'' John Hood, representative of Local 77 of the American Federation of Musicians, said of the second vote. He declined to release the vote totals or discuss how Tuesday's offer differed from Monday's The union cited unhappiness with benefits involving pensions, seniority, medical care and radio broadcasts in rejecting the first offer. The union represents 105 musicians and four librarians. Joseph H. Kluger, orchestra executive director, said the new contract provides 5 percent raises over the next three years in base salaries, which are now $1,100 per week. No other terms were revealed. The orchestra's last strike, in 1966, lasted eight weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Former Girlfriend Ordered to Return $15,000 Engagement Ring
DOC.TEXT: A man described as ``head over heels'' in love with a woman who dumped him should get his $15,000 engagement ring back, a jury has ruled. Robert Bowersox also should get back $7,200 in cash he gave Susanne Clair, the Douglas County District Court jurors said Monday. ``Bob Bowersox was very taken by Susanne, this man sort of tumbled head over heels with her,'' Bowersox's lawyer, Michael Lazar, said of the two Omaha residents. ``His heart was on the table, folks,'' Lazer told the jury. ``Where was her heart?'' But Ms. Clair's attorney, Warren Zweiback, said the nurse's aide made it clear she never planned to marry Bowersox and that he knew she was seeing another man. Bowersox, who is retired, also named Ms. Clair as a joint tenant on his home. The couple declined to give their ages. She testified Monday that she returned the interest in the house when she broke off their relationship in May 1989, but decided to consult with her lawyer about the money and the 3.23 carat pear-shaped diamond ring. Judge James Murphy told the jury during instructions that he knew of no Nebraska case law on the issue. ``Apparently, lovers in Nebraska never have fights ... or ask for the return of engagement rings, because our Supreme Court has not had the burden of laying down a path for me to follow,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Says Racial Tension Have Improved In Washington
DOC.TEXT: Despite tensions created by his drug and perjury trial, racial relations are better in the nation's capital than in ``Chicago, New York, lots of places,'' Mayor Marion Barry said Tuesday. ``I think race relations in America are getting worse,'' Barry told a mostly-white group of students at George Washington University. ``My trial certainly brought to the fore some tensions ... but if I were taken from here, I guarantee you, a year from now, you would still have racism.'' In his most expansive comments on racism since he was convicted of a cocaine possession charge last month, Barry stressed several times during a 45-minute speech that the atmosphere surrounding his legal drama was just another example of racism in America today. ``There are some people who would like to make Marion Barry responsible for this - but I'm not in Chicago, New York, lots of places where everyone thinks things are worse,'' the mayor said. But Barry, who was convicted of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and acquitted of another last month, acknowledged that his dwindling number of supporters now are mostly black. During the trial, his attorney complained repeatedly that Barry was prosecuted because of his position. Jurors later said they felt Barry was prosecuted because he is black. Barry did not make reference to recent criminal trials, like the Central Park jogger case, that have been blamed for heightening racial tensions. Instead, he listed only political examples: ``Take Andy Young,'' said Barry of the former civil rights leader and mayor of Atlanta who recently lost a bid for Georgia's Democratic gubernatorial nomination. ``Politically middle of the road, no controversy ... yet he gets only 14 percent of the white vote ... I believe race was a significant factor in that.'' Barry concluded his formal remarks by issuing a call for racial unity. This prompted a standing ovation from about two dozen black students scattered throughout the auditorium where the speech took place. About 200 whites sat quietly. ``There were more blacks who stood than whites,'' Barry said in response to a later question. ``What that shows, I think, is that we need to do some healing here at George Washington too.'' In his first public address since learning that he would not be tried on a dozen drug and perjury charges his jury could not resolve, the mayor seemed relaxed, and even made some unusual self-deprecating remarks. ``A lot of you have seen me from a distance,'' Barry said at the beginning of his remarks. ``Primarily on television ... or videotape.'' That comment, which referred to the undercover FBI videotape that showed him smoking crack cocaine on the night of his arrest, drew laughs from the crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Forces Tear Gas Mohawks; Indians, Soldiers Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `In one' to DELETE extraneous word `police.' Picks up 3rd, `One soldier...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MTL5
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers fired tear gas into a crowd of Mohawks and clashed with Indians at a reservation where soldiers were searching Tuesday for weapons. Three Mohawks and five soldiers were injured, authorities said. In one of the most violent clashes since the Mohawk standoff began more than two months ago, soldiers used rifle butts to keep back Indians protesting the raid on small Tekakwitha Island. One soldier was dragged to the ground, kicked and struck repeatedly over the head with his helmet. That soldier and at least four others were injured, according to military spokesman, Maj. Rusty Bassarab. A 15-year-old girl and two other Indians were injured, said Louis Montour, medical director of the nearby Kateri Memorial Hospital, located on the Kahnawake reservation south of montreal. At least 75 people, including several Indian children, received treatment for the tear gas, Montour said. Tuesday's clash began when about 200 Mohawks gathered on the bridge to the Indian island in response to the army search. About 25 soldiers had gathered outside the Kateri hospital, near the bridge. ``Tell them to get the hell out of here!'' one Mohawk man shouted at the soldiers, many of whom wore gas masks. Kahnawake Chief Joe Norton tried to calm the crowd, which instead grew more restless. ``Stay back, someone is going to get shot,'' Norton warned the crowd, which surged forward, pelting soldiers with rocks. Punches and shoves were exchanged as Mohawks battled with troops. The soldiers fired several volleys of machine-gunfire into the air and then shot tear gas into the crowd, forcing the Indians back across the bridge. But many of the gagging, coughing mob were unable to retreat because Mohawks inadvertently blocked their path with a dump truck they had brought in to blockade the bridge, witnesses said. Dozens of men, women and children leaped into the St. Lawrence River to escape the stinging gas. ``We jumped into river and tried to wet our clothes to get it off our skin and to hold wet cloth over our mouths and noses so we wouldn't be overcome,'' one person said of the tear gas. Struggling to overcome the effects of the gas, the Mohawks regrouped and made another charge as army helicopters buzzed back and forth. ``They are invading our territory, it is an outright invasion of our land,'' one Mohawk man said. Mohawk peacekeepers intervened to keep the crowd from the soldiers. Bassarab said about 50 weapons were discovered in the raid, including shotguns, handguns, hunting rifles and AK-47 assault rifles. Another military spokeswoman, Capt. Yvon Desjardins, said eight helicopters and about 100 troops participated in the search. The dispute came in the aftermath of plans by town officials in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, to expand a golf course onto what the Mohawks said was tribal land. Indians at Kahnawake and another Mohawk community, Kahnesatake, near Oka, built barriers that blocked traffic on an Oka highway and on the Mercier Bridge over the St. Lawrence, which connects Montreal with its southern suburbs. The dispute became violent after Oka obtained a court order demanding the Mohawk barricade be dismantled. Quebec provincial police tried, and failed, on July 11 to enforce the court order. A police officer was shot and killed in the attempt and Mohawks set up more barricades in Oka and around the Kahawake reservation south of Montreal, blocking traffic and holding off the police and army for more than six weeks. The Kahnawake barriers sparked an angry reaction from local residents who saw their 20-minute commute to Montreal grow to two hours. Several nights of protests and riots occurred during the blockade, removed a month ago after a deal was reached between the Indians and the Canadian Forces. On the Kahnesatake reservation, 50 Indian men, women and children have been barricaded behind army barbed wire since Sept. 1 in an alcohol and drug treatment center. The army has cut off supplies and communications from about 12 journalists with those Mohawks. On Monday, the federal government was officially registered owner of 92 acres of land near Oka that fueled the standoff. Ottawa paid $2.78 million for the property. The government now can offer it to the Mohawks as part of a package in a negotiated settlement. But Quebec has ruled the Mohawks cannot receive the land as long as the standoff continues.

DOC.HEAD: Geffen Records Drops Controversial Label
DOC.TEXT: Geffen Records no longer will distribute albums from a controversial label whose artists include comedian Andrew Dice Clay, the rap group Geto Boys and the hard-rock band Slayer. In its announcement Monday, Geffen said it would stop making and distributing albums from the Def American label because of differences in ``creative philosophy.'' The decision comes a month after Geffen decided not to distribute a new album from Geto Boys because it felt the group glamorized violence, racism and misogyny. Geffen also had declined to affix its name to Clay's raunchy comedy album. ``We find ourselves increasingly at odds with Def American's creative philosophy,'' Geffen said in a statement. ``A lot of soul-searching went into this decision.'' Founded by producer Rick Rubin in 1988, Def American's artists include Danzig, The Black Crowes, Wolfsbane, Trouble and The Four Horsemen. In a statement, Rubin said, ``I believe strongly in my artists, and am willing to personally defend them.'' Geffen Records was purchased earlier this year by MCA Inc. for about $550 million in stock.

DOC.HEAD: Former Caribbean Embassy Security Director Indicted for Arms Exports
DOC.TEXT: The former security director of two U.S. embassies in the Caribbean was arrested Tuesday on charges he exported guns illegally, federal prosecutors said. George R. Mitchell, 42, of Baltimore, presently assigned to the State Department in Washington, was indicted on eight federal charges last week. After his arrest, he was freed on $50,000 bond and will be arraigned Sept. 28. ``His position makes it a unique case,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Greg Welsh said. ``He was responsible for ensuring security both at the embassy at Santo Domingo and the embassy at Antigua. He oversaw private contractors, who are guards, and oversaw state department personnel.'' Welsh said Mitchell bought 37 guns in Baltimore and 25 guns in Miami. Guns and ammunition were sold to a contractor providing security at the embassies, as well as other buyers, Welsh said. The alleged crimes took place between August 1989 and April 1990, while Mitchell worked as a regional security officer at the embassies in the Dominican Republic and Antigua, Welsh said. David Denny, a State Department spokesman, said Tuesday the department had no comment. Denny said he did not know when Mitchell had been transferred to his administrative position in Washington. The indictment charges Mitchell with exporting weapons, money laundering, two counts of failing to declare cash brought into the United States, two counts of improperly accepting a gratuity, stealing more than 1,000 rounds of State Department ammunition in Santo Domingo and lying to a Baltimore arms dealer. He could be sentenced to a maximum of 59 years in prison and fined $3 million if convicted of all the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Republican Army Says it Shot Soldier
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility on Tuesday for shooting and wounding a British army sergeant outside a recruiting office in London. The outlawed IRA, in a statement released to news media in Dublin, Ireland, also claimed responsibility for three bombing incidents. Sgt. Bernard Cox was hospitalized with three bullet wounds following the attack Monday outside a recruiting office in the North Finchley area of London. Witnesses said a man in a red crash helmet fired several shots at Cox, who was sitting in a parked car. The gunman then jumped onto the back of motorcycle and was driven away by an accomplice. The IRA statement emphasized that the attack was in the parliamentary constituency of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``We take this opportunity to remind the Thatcher regime that they have it in their power to grant peace to Ireland and to end their futile conflict with our people,'' the statement said, referring to the conflict in the British province of Northern Ireland. Until Britain withdraws from Northern Ireland, the statement said, ``attacks such as that at Finchley will continue.'' The statement also asserted the IRA's responsibility for the bombing of an army recruiting office in Derby Sept. 10. No one was killed. The statement said IRA members had planted a bomb discovered Aug. 13 at the home of Gen. Anthony Farrar Hockley, a former commander of British land forces in Northern Ireland, and one that fell off a car in London on Aug. 6. Neither bomb exploded. The bomb at Hockley's home was attached to a garden-hose reel. The IRA statement said the third bomb was planted on a car at what was believed to be the London home of Sir Robert Armstrong, a former Cabinet secretary. However, Armstrong no longer lived there. Instead, the bomb was planted on a car owned by Cherry Freeman, formerly of San Diego. It fell off the car harmlessly as she drove to work. On July 30, an IRA car bomb killed Conservative Party lawmaker Ian Gow, a close friend of Mrs. Thatcher. The IRA, outlawed both in Britain and Ireland, says it aims to unite Ireland under a socialist government.

DOC.HEAD: Brick Wall Collapses, Killing Three People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `At least...,' with three grafs to UPDATE with licensing official saying signs and gates apparently were improperly attached to wall. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Alom Kadosh...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX6
DOC.TEXT: A two-story brick storefront collapsed onto a busy downtown sidewalk Tuesday, crushing three people to death and injuring eight others, authorities said. Among the 11 caught in the collapse were four police officers who had been walking their beat, authorities said. The facade apparently was weighted down by metal signs and security gates that had been anchored in the wall, said Fire Commission Roger Ulshafer. The collapse occurred shortly before 2:30 p.m. between 9th and 10th streets on the south side of Market Street, one of the city's main arteries. ``I looked up and saw a wall of bricks coming at me and all I could do was close my eyes,'' said Neil Daniel, who was fixing his car. ``I heard people start screaming.'' ``I just turned around and the whole thing came tumbling down,'' said David Miller, a passerby. At least two people were trapped for a time, police said. Don Kligerman of the Department of Licenses and Inspections said the facade apparently was improperly affixed to the building. ``The cumulative effect of that sign, the iron shutters and the wall that was just free standing - it was really just a matter of time until it fell over,'' Kligerman said. Further inspection could lead to criminal charges, he said. Alom Kadosh, manager of the Stereo Sound store said he was sitting in the front when the wall gave way. ``It happened so fast you couldn't see anything. But as soon as it happened people went outside and everybody pitched in to help pull off the bricks and the metal that covered the people that had been trapped underneath,'' he said. All of the dead and injured were on the sidewalk. There were no injuries inside the three different buildings that shared the brick facade, authorities said. One woman died of a crushed chest and another of head injuries; a man died of a crushed chest, according to a hospital spokeswoman. The three were dead on arrival at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, said spokeswoman Sue Bluemle. Five other people also were brought to the hospital, one 23-year-old man in serious condition with head and chest injuries, she said. The four injured police officers were treated for minor injuries and later released, she said. A woman was brought to Hahnemann University Hospital with leg injuries, said Linda Clossey-Connelly, a hospital spokeswoman. The two who were pulled from the rubble were taken to other hospitals, said Police Commisioner Willie Williams. Cynthia Bayete of the city Licenses and Inspections Department said the businesses included an electronics store and a check-cashing agency. ``We tried to make a run for it, and that's when the sign hit the top of my head. And I fell to the ground. ``I turned around and looked. That's when I noticed my partner was down,'' Davenport said. Davenport and others pulled Ms. Shears free of the rubble. Officer Paris Davenport, 21, who joined the police force just five weeks ago, said she was walking by the store with another rookie officer when they heard a rumble and saw the store sign falling down. ``We tried to make a run for it, and that's when the sign hit the top of my head.''

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Son Convicted of Four Killings
DOC.TEXT: The teen-age son of a religious cult leader was convicted Tuesday of helping his father kill a man and his three children. Jurors acquitted him of the slaying of the children's mother. Damon Lundgren, 19, listened to the verdicts with his head bowed. He could be sentenced to death. The jury deliberated for about 11 hours over two days before convicting Lundgren on four murder counts and four counts of kidnapping in the deaths of Dennis Avery and his three children. He was acquitted of murder and kidnapping counts in the death of Avery's wife, Cheryl. Prosecutor Joseph Gurley said he was satisfied with the verdict.Lundgren's attorney, Albert Purola, declined comment. The trial's penalty phase was scheduled to begin Monday. The convictions came the same day Lundgren's father, Jeffrey Lundgren, 40, appeared at a sentencing hearing. He was convicted last month on five murder and kidnapping counts. The same jury that convicted the elder Lundgren must decide whether to recommend the death penalty. Other sentencing options included life in prison without parole for 20 years, and life without parole for 30 years. Damon Lundgren's mother, Alice, last month received five consecutive life sentences for her conspiracy, complicity and kidnapping convictions. The Averys were killed April 17, 1989. Each was been bound and gagged, shot to death and dumped into a common grave under a barn at a farm in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland. The elder Lundgren is a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, in Kirtland. He was defrocked in 1988 for inappropriate conduct and later formed his own sect.

DOC.HEAD: House Slashes More Than $2 Billion from Strategic Defense Initiative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th graf pvs, bgng, `Approved by,' with defeat of measure that would have eliminated funds for company that suffered property loss during U.S. invasion of Panama. Should stand for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic-controlled House on Tuesday slashed more than $2 billion from President Bush's budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative in fiscal 1991. Rejecting Republican arguments that SDI could thwart Iraq if it develops the capability to unleash ballistic missiles, the House voted 225-189 to make a deeper cut in the program than its Armed Services Committee approved last month. In crafting a $283 billion defense bill, the panel adopted a budget for SDI in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 of $2.9 billion. The House agreed to reduce the program's budget by an additional $600 million for a spending level of $2.3 billion. Bush has requested $4.7 billion for the anti-missile shield commonly known as Star Wars. Twenty Republicans joined 205 Democrats in voting for the measure while 39 Democrats and 150 Republicans voted against passage. The House also: -Narrowly defeated, 216-200, an amendment to allow abortions at military hospitals abroad. Currently a ban exists on using Defense Department money to pay for abortions, except when the life of the mother is in danger. The ban does not say whether military personnel who pay for the procedure can use government facilities. ``It is simply to give our military personnel the same rights that the rest of us have as long as they're willing to pay for it,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif. But a longtime abortion opponent, Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., questioned his colleagues, ``Will the U.S. government provide the facilities to destroy children at will?'' The Senate, faced with a similar measure to its bill, sidestepped the issue in their rush to adjourn for the summer recess. -Approved a measure using $200 million in Defense Department funds to create a program to assist workers, communities and businesses hard hit by reductions in military spending. The vote was 288-128. -Approved by voice vote a measure transferring $46 million that was unused in fiscal 1990 for the MX nuclear missile, rail-garrison program to environmental cleanup. -Turned back an attempt to eliminate $357,000 the Army will have to reimburse North American Van Lines for property losses incurred during the U.S. invasion of Panama last December. The government does not reimburse claimants who suffer losses or damages in a combat situation, but Indiana lawmakers urged their colleagues to help this ``Hoosier company.'' The reimbursement stands based on a 228-189 vote. On SDI, the House approved the lowest level for the program since 1985 when a spending level of $1.4 billion was adopted. ``We know that nations around the world are going to have the capacity to target our cities. Mr. Hussein said five months ago `if I had one missile I would hit New York,''' said Rep. Bob McEwen, R-Ohio, referring to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Rep. Jon Kyl, R-Ariz., said the United States should not be ``held hostage by some tinhorn dictator'' with an arsenal of missiles. But Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., a member of the Armed Services Committee, questioned why only a fraction of the administration's request for SDI would go to ``research that would knock down or intercept missiles.'' Terrorist delivery of a nuclear weapon would likely come by aircraft or a ship sailing into a U.S. harbor, Dellums said, quoting testimony from U.S. military officials before Congress. ``Face the reality,'' Dellums urged his colleagues. The vote to reduce significantly spending levels for SDI provides House members with a bargaining position in negotiations with the Senate on the final defense bill. The House is expected to complete action on its version of the defense bill on Wednesday, and talks between the House and Senate will begin later this month. The Senate adopted a $289 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991 that trimmed about $1 billion from the SDI budget proposal. Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., argued that the SDI budget should total about $3 billion. Traditionally House and Senate negotiators have agreed to a number midway between the two budget totals. ``This figure, compromised with their figure, would give us $3 billion,'' Bennett said of the $2.3 billion total. The cut in the SDI program marked the second time in two years that lawmakers have targeted the system. Last year, Congress approved the first reduction in the program since former President Reagan introduced it seven years ago. The fiscal 1990 budget level for SDI was $3.8 billion. Earlier Tuesday, the House rejected, 338-83, an amendment by Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif., to increase the SDI budget in the House bill to $4.2 billion. It also turned aside, 285-136, an attempt by Dellums and Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., to cut the program to $1.5 billion. The vote was 285-136. A measure that would provide $3.6 billion for the program, the amount approved by the Senate, failed, 273-141. The House also approved by voice vote a measure requiring the Defense Department to submit two SDI budgets for fiscal 1992 - a spending plan for six years and an alternative which keeps the budget at fiscal 1991 levels for the next five years. Originally, Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C., proposed a line-item for the SDI program, a more stringent approach than that adopted by the Senate. However, Spratt modified his measure in anticipation of the House-Senate conference.

A golfer died after being stung inside the mouth by a bee that was in his beer bottle, authorities said. Officials said Elmer Kurzka, 60, apparently suffered an allergic reaction to the sting, but were awaiting the results of toxicology tests to be sure. Kurzka, of Arlington Heights northwest of Chicago, was stung when he took a drink from the bottle and the bee entered his mouth, said Du Page County Coroner Richard Ballinger. He was stung as his party prepared to tee off Saturday at the Medinah Country Club, authorities said. His partners teed off and returned to their golf cart to find Kurzka slumped over and having trouble breathing, said his wife, Arlene. Kurzka's family said he had been stung numerous times in the past but never had an adverse reaction. Ballinger said Saturday's sting may have had a greater impact because the mouth is especially sensitive.

Remarks about plans for possible U.S. air assaults on Iraq cost Gen. Michael J. Dugan his job as Air Force chief of staff, but the incident was not the first time the four-star general rankled his Pentagon bosses. Dugan, fired by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday, said in a statement that he regretted ``any embarrassment'' his comments caused the Bush administration. Cheney said Dugan, 53, would be forced to retire, ending a 32-year Air Force career that included a stint as commander of U.S. Air Forces in Europe. Several days after President Bush committed U.S. troops to Operation Desert Shield on Aug. 7 to deter a possible Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, Dugan was quoted in a published report as saying the United States had ruled out using chemical weapons or battlefield nuclear arms if fighting broke out with Iraq. That comment caused a stir in the Pentagon, where military authorities have been careful not to preclude any options in order to complicate Baghdad's planning. ---= CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) - After four failures, NASA gave up trying to launch the leaky space shuttle Columbia so that it can concentrate on getting Discovery aloft in October before the planets fall out of the proper alignment. NASA scrubbed the fourth attempt to launch Columbia about seven hours before it was to lift off at 1:28 a.m. today after a buildup of hydrogen, a highly flammable gas, was detected in the engine compartment during fueling. A baffled Robert Crippen, shuttle director, said: ``I do not understand it. Our plan is that we are going to understand it.'' Columbia was to have lifted off with the $150 million Astro observatory to study some of the hottest objects in the universe. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal researchers should be more open-minded about unconventional treatments that show some potential to help cancer patients, a four-year congressional study concludes. The study by the Office of Technology Assessment found that none of the alternative methods it reviewed - including psychological, nutritional and herbal remedies - was obviously or dramatically effective. But the report also said these treatments have had little, if any, scientific review, which leaves patients with no guidance if they want to supplement or replace their conventional treatment. ``It's very hard to get information beyond promotional brochures,'' said Roger C. Herdman, who supervised the report, which was released Monday. ``There isn't a lot in the peer-reviewed literature,'' where scientific findings are reported. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Methadone can break the opiate drug habit and help stem the spread of AIDS, but many patients are being given doses too low to be effective, according to a study released today. The report by the congressional Office of Technology Assessment said methadone programs differ widely, including the doses of the synthetic narcotic given to heroin users who can benefit from methadone. An average daily dosage of 80 milligrams of methadone is considered sufficient to wean most users from their heroin habit. The lowest effective dose is believed to be around 60 milligrams, the report said. However, a recent survey of 24 methadone programs found the average daily dosages ranged from 21 to 67 milligrams, the report said. Twenty-one of them gave an average daily dose of less than 60 milligrams. ---= NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Six blacks are among a dozen candidates scrambling to claim the House seat in Louisiana being vacated by Rep. Lindy Boggs, the only white in Congress who represents a district that is mostly black. Mrs. Boggs, 74, announced in July that she was stepping down for personal reasons after more than 17 years in the House. The popular Democratic congresswoman enjoyed strong support from New Orleans voters in all age, ethnic and economic groups throughout her tenure. But despite Mrs. Boggs' strong record on civil rights issues and her support in the black community, blacks were growing anxious to elect one of their own in the district, which has a 60 percent black voting majority. Many believe 1990 may be the last year a black can be elected from the district. Since New Orleans lost people in the 1980s, district lines drawn after the 1990 census are expected to reduce or eliminate the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: New Free-Market Economy Confuses Shoppers in Peru
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Elvira Elguera wants to wash her hair. Store owner Ricardo Correa would love to sell her shampoo. But there'll be no sale today. The shampoo has no price. ``Absurd!'' Miss Elguera declares as she stalks out of the shop. ``I don't know what my costs are,'' Correa tries to explain. ``It's better not to sell than to sell at a loss.'' Peruvians have lived for years under the shelter of price controls and subsidies. But when President Alberto Fujimori took office in July and 11 days later announced sweeping reforms, Peru took a dizzying leap into the economic unknown - a free-market economy. Peruvians are baffled. Neither stores nor consumers seem to know what things should cost. At first, prices soared: a pound of beans from 40 cents to $3, a bottle of beer from 33 cents to $4. But when sales lagged, many storeowners dropped their prices. Still, prices in one store can be five times higher than those in a shop across the street. And, as in Correa's store, many products simply have no price. ``Chaos!'' read a recent headline on the front page of a top Lima daily. Even before the reforms, Peru's economy was headed for disaster. Inflation averaged more than 3,000 percent a year and only one in five workers had a steady job. The country's gross national product has shrunk 20 percent since 1988. Fujimori's reforms were aimed at halting rising prices by drastically cutting consumption and closing a large fiscal deficit, caused in great part by subsidies. Previous governments have bridged the gap simply by printing more money. Prime Minister Juan Carlos Hurtado, who also is economy minister, predicts the economy will stabilize by yearend. ``But the first 45 days of the plan will be tremendously recessive,'' said Felipe Ortiz de Zevallos, an economist close to the government. Government services such as telephone, water, light and fuel cost 10 to 30 times more. This has pushed prices skyhigh throughout the economy. Inflation in August was nearly 400 percent, highest in Peru's history. Supermarkets are spilling over with unbought goods. Stores in luxury shopping centers are boarded up. Many factories are closed and others are preparing to shut. ``It's no longer a matter of lowering prices. People just don't have money,'' said Carlos Chavez, whose men's clothing store is full of sale signs. ``The only thing anyone thinks about is eating.'' Graciela Elias' shoe store hasn't sold anything in days. ``If things continue as they are, we'll all go under,'' she said. A small-business association warns that thousands of companies verge on bankruptcy. The measures will kill off all but the most efficient companies, says Javier Silva Ruete, economy minister in a military government from 1978 to 1980. ``What about the workers? And the violence? The only way to impose this plan in Peru is with a dictatorship,'' he said in an interview. The measures have left millions of Peruvians hungry. With wage increases far below inflation, they simply can't afford sufficient food. So far, there have been few violent protests. But just how long poor Peruvians will wait for any improvement is unknown. The actions of wealthy industrialists may presage problems. After the new measures were announced, Peru's six main pharmaceutical manufacturers jointly raised prices six to 10 times. This put many life-saving medicines out of reach of all but the rich. The prices have not dropped despite complaints even from Fujimori. Silva Ruete says price-fixing by Peru's many monopolies and oligopolies will continue until protectionist tariffs are reformed to allow imports to compete. Fujimori has promised such reforms, but so far there has been no change. Even some retailers have trouble coming to terms with the ways of supply and demand. ``I don't understand where my customers went,'' said one restaurateur, staring at trays of pasta that he's charging five times more for than before the reforms. Across the street, a restaurant is packed. Prices there have only doubled. Other retailers have adapted. Once-dour market venders now smile more often at prospective customers. Waiters seem more solicitous. And some private bus companies have begun offering candies to attract riders.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Perceived as Source of Resentment, Unrest in Caribbean
DOC.TEXT: Efforts by the International Monetary Fund to restructure the economies of struggling Third World countries have led to widespread resentment and even domestic upheaval in the Caribbean. Several of the 14 nations in the region have undertaken belt-tightening programs designed and monitored by the IMF in conjunction with the World Bank. Many of the countries complain they are being forced to impose unpopular measures to qualify for loans and foreign investment. ``Unless we are committed to a fund program, our debts will not be rescheduled, we will not have access to the resources of multilateral financial agencies . . . donors will not support us and investors will tend to shy away from us,'' said President Desmond Hoyte of Guyana. Guyana, a founding member of Caricom, Haiti, Jamaica, the Dominican Republic, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago have signed agreements or begun talks with the IMF to implement programs of currency devaluations, price hikes and wage freezes in hopes of cutting inflation and promoting economic growth. Critics say the price of a blessing by the IMF is too high: social unrest, radical politics and a sharp decline in living standards. ``The IMF says, `Either you swallow that bitter pill or we won't give you a cent,' '' said Paul Latourtue, a Haitian economist at the University of Puerto Rico. ``But you can't give medicine that's worse than the disease and you can't kill the patient to save it.'' In its 1989 annual report, the IMF said its economic surveillance programs are designed to help impoverished developing nations ``to raise domestic savings, reduce inflation . . . and foster growth.'' With economic growth, creditors respond by rescheduling or reducing debts and granting new loans, the report said. It added the Washington-based institution is increasingly aware of the social implications of economic reforms. Dennis Pantin, an economist at the West Indies University in Trinidad, said the IMF only provides limited relief because it doesn't take social factors into account. ``The IMF option is the most attractive in the narrow sense of permitting debt rescheduling,'' said Pantin. ``But will today's relief turn out to be tomorrow's burden?'' In August, the Dominican Republic was rocked by violence after President Joaquin Balaguer imposed belt-tightening measures recommended by the IMF. At least 11 people were killed and 50 were injured in protests against food and gasoline price hikes. Balaguer has said he will have to sign an IMF agreement to qualify for new loans and meet payments on a $4.1 billion foreign debt. ``Signing a new accord with the fund will mean total misery for Dominicans,'' warns Francisco Antonio Santos, secretary of the Central Worker's General, the country's largest labor union. Elsewhere in the Caribbean: -Trinidad and Tobago, one of the region's most stable democracies, was plunged into turmoil in July by a coup attempt. Moslem insurgents blamed the government for widespread poverty in the once oil-rich nation off Venezuela. An IMF agreement to reschedule the country's $2.4 billion foreign debt brought sharp devaluations, wage freezes and cuts in social programs. - Guyana, which has had one of the steepest economic declines among Western nations the past decade, signed a three-year IMF accord in June 1989 to reschedule its $1.9 billion foreign debt. The currency was devalued 70 percent and salaries for public workers were slashed by half. But a year later, the economy of Guyana shows little sign of improving. - Jamaica, with a foreign debt of $4.5 billion, 45 percent of which is owed to the IMF, the World Bank and other lending institutions, is the Caribbean's most indebted country. In January, Prime Minister Michael Manley imposed harsh austerity measures, including a 19.5-percent increase in basic food prices, as part of a 15-month standby agreement with the IMF. Manley says Jamaica is recovering because of a tourism boom but complains that virtually all the island's earnings are used to pay its debt. - In Haiti, one of the world's poorest and most politically volatile nations, a 50 percent currency devaluation based on IMF recommendations was not publicly announced for fear of strife at a time when the provisional government was trying to organize elections. The government recently said it had a $31 million budget deficit and was unable to collect sufficient taxes. Haiti's foreign debt is relatively small, $16 million, because of a suspension of foreign aid in retaliation for rights abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Two Factors That Might Cushion The Fall of Stocks
DOC.TEXT: If it weren't for two unusual factors that developed during the 1980s, the sharp decline in popular stock market averages since midyear might have been sharper still. Not much attention is given to these factors, important as they are. But were they absent, it is likely that the latest slump might have seemed more like a collapse. - Factor one is the concentration of investments in big-cap stocks. In the 1980s the big institutional investors concentrated their funds more narrowly than ever in the stocks of the biggest companies, those with the greatest capitalization and sales reported in nine digits or more. This concentration might have had the effect of pushing up prices of the big stocks which comprise the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock average. But it also put a cushion beneath them. The latter effect results from the narrowing of institutional investment parameters. Rather than moving funds to other stocks when bad news hit, the institutions simply shifted their money from one big-cap stock to another. Asa result, many of the largest companies fared better than their smaller cousins. Small stocks indicators, for instance, trailed those of big-cap stocks in 24 of the past 28 quarters. Why the concentration? In part, at least, because of the tendency of many institutions to index portfolios to the popular averages, thereby assuring themselves that they won't fare any worse than the averages. Some critics regard this as a copout, contending that fund managers should do more than ``average'' to earn their keep. Others defend the practice as simple common sense. They argue that if an institution's wealthy neighbor is buying huge blocks of certain stock, it is smart to jump aboard for the ride. - Factor two is the shrinking supply of stocks. Yes, the supply of equities declined during the 1980s, and it might still be declining. That was the direction through the first quarter of this year. Shares available for trading decline for two major reasons: Companies may buy back shares if funds are available and they feel the shares are a bargain; and corporate mergers and acquisitions often substitute debt for equity. Since 1983, more than $500 billion of U.S. equities have disappeared from the stock market. That's the net amount - after accounting for new stock issues brought onto the market. The decline may continue for many months more. But merger mania may have run its course. The common denominator of merged companies is a debt burden that becomes heavier during economic downturns, such as now. Many companies have learned a painful lesson. Conceivably, there could even be a reversal in the trend, with privately held companies - companies that had been removed from the market through leveraged buyouts - once again seeking to sell shares to the public. Meanwhile, the narrowed universe of investment possibilities - resulting from institutional indexing and from the substitution of debt for equities - may be cushioning the decline in the popular stock averages.
