DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Down Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices plummeted on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday morning, with the key Nikkei Stock Average falling 3.82 percent. The dollar was slightly higher against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei lost 932.53 points to move to 23,433.04 by the close of morning trading. The index fell 531.865 points, or 2.13 percent, on Monday. The dollar was changing hands at 137.50 yen after opening at 137.17 yen, up 0.17 yen from Monday's finish. It had risen against the yen in New York, ending at 136.55 yen compared to late Friday's 136.45. Morning trades in Tokyo ranged between 136.95 and 137.60. Meanwhile, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was 8.640 percent, up from Friday's 8.565-percent finish. The price stood at 80.89 points, down from Friday's 81.89-point closing price. Stock traders said high oil prices, rising interest rates and pessimism over the situation in the Middle East discouraged investors. Benchmark Brent Sea crude was valued at $33.50 a barrel in Tokyo early Tuesday afternoon, up from $32.30 in New York on Monday. Falling prices on the bond market also pushed the market down, they said. ``Prices fell across the board,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst for Nomura Securities. The market also was awaiting for the release of the U.S. consumer Price Index later Tuesday in Washington, he said. Trading was ``very light'' according to Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader for Daiwa Securities. ``Everything is the same as yesterday,'' when investors were sidelined because of pessimism about the delcining market, he said. Currency dealers said the dollar's higher opening in Tokyo followed its overnight gain in New York. ``The dollar is recovering its strength in the last couple of days as investors started buying it back to make technical adjustment by reducing their yen holdings,'' said Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo dealer. He said U.S. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford's comments Monday discouraged some investors from buying the dollar. Mulford said the dollar's recent declines would contribute to further improvements in the U.S. merchandise trade deficit. Market players took the comment to mean the U.S. would allow the dollar to fall, he said. Hayashi said the dollar would remain in a 136.50-137.50 yen range because there are selling and buying interests on both ends of the range.

Heightened uncertainty in the Mideast propelled oil futures prices up almost $2 a barrel to nearly $34, shattering the previous record and leaving traders wondering where the market was headed next. Light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange, hit an all-time high of $33.75 a barrel for October-delivery contracts Monday before settling at $33.63 a barrel, $1.87 higher than Friday's close. --- DETROIT (AP) - General Motors Corp. is free to close plants but will spend $4.2 billion to protect the income of employees affected by cutbacks under its new labor agreement, a newspaper said today. The contract contains $4.2 billion in income guarantees, eliminates weak plant-closing prohibitions from the previous agreement and increases wages by 3 percent the first year, the Detroit Free Press reported in today's editions. The agreement also provides for lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years and increases monthly pensions from $1,500 to $1,800 for workers who retire after 30 years, according to union and company officials who spoke to the newspaper on condition of anonymity. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Business inventories rose 0.7 percent in July, the biggest pileup in a year, and sales fell 0.5 percent, the government said in new signs of economic sluggishness. Although the level of inventories reported Monday by the Commerce Department is not recessionary, economists said surging stockpiles are a clear danger sign that could signal manufacturing cutbacks and greater unemployment. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Trans World Airlines, Northwest Airlines and United Airlines joined other major carriers in imposing an additional 4.2 percent fare increase that will raise domestic tickets by 9.5 percent since the Persian Gulf crisis began. The higher rates disclosed Monday go into effect on Oct. 1 and mark an attempt by the airlines to recoup some of the extra money they spend on jet fuel, which has risen by about 50 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration, spurred by events in the Middle East, set forth an ambitious negotiating schedule aimed at completing a comprehensive free trade agreement with oil-rich Mexico by the end of 1991. Administration officials said Monday that President Bush in the next few days would ask Congress for authority to negotiate an agreement dismantling barriers to the free flow of goods and investment between the two nations. --- NEW YORK (AP) - IBM and Microsoft Corp. sought to dispel industry talk that the world's largest computer company and one of the largest software companies were parting ways after years of successful collaboration. A rift between International Business Machines Corp. and Microsoft could have a major impact on the millions of personal computer users worldwide who use machines designed to IBM and Microsoft standards. But the two companies said Monday their relationship has never been better. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A bill letting regulators tap banks and savings institutions to shore up the dwindling government deposit insurance funds passed the House. The measure approved Monday favors removing the legal ceiling on insurance premiums levied by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The Senate is scheduled to consider the measure later this month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department should adopt a controversial proposal to streamline beef inspections, including a feature putting greater reliance on packing companies, the National Academy of Sciences said. But its report released Monday said the department, if it relies more heavily on private industry to maintain meat quality, should concentrate its resources on safety to guard consumers against contaminated meat. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A longtime top executive with Turner Broadcasting System Inc., Gerry F. Hogan, has resigned to become a vice chairman at Whittle Communications. Hogan, 44, has been associated with Turner Broadcasting founder Ted Turner for 19 years during which he helped Turner build one of the nation's most formidable cable television operations. His move to Whittle, a smaller media concern known for innovative marketing, was announced Monday and marked the third major Turner executive to leave that company in the past 13 months. ---

NEW YORK - The stock market made little progress Monday, restrained by rising oil prices and other inflation worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 55.44 points last week, rose 3.22 to 2,567.33. Elsewhere, bond prices and the dollar weakened, gold, livestock and meat futures rose sharply, soybeans fell and grain futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Denies Rift With Microsoft, But Some Analysts Unconvinced
DOC.TEXT: IBM and Microsoft Corp. say their relationship has never been better as they sought to quiet talk that a rift was developing between the computer hardware and software giants. Millions of personal computer users worldwide use machines designed to IBM and Microsoft standards. ``IBM today reaffirmed its relatioship with Microsoft,'' the computer company said Monday. Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates said in a separate statement: ``Microsoft and IBM have played a key role in the development of the PC industry and we will continue to cooperate to provide the best operating system solutions to our customers.'' Talk that IBM and Microsoft were at odds has peppered trade journals in recent weeks. In an interview, Steve Ballmer, a Microsoft vice president, disputed reports that the two companies had stopped working together on new versions of operating systems, the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. But the companies announced they would divide responsibility for developing new versions of two operating systems: OS-2, used on IBM's Personal System-2 computers, and DOS, the operating system for IBM's older personal computers and many brands of IBM-compatible machines. Previously, each company worked separately on developing new versions of OS-2 and DOS. Under the new arrangement, IBM will have primary responsibility for developing OS-2, while Microsoft will have the primary role in improving DOS. William Bluestein, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., interpreted that as an admission the two companies had gone separate ways. ``It basically is a form of divorce,'' he said. ``What really is being fought over is who controls the industry, who controls the direction.'' By controling the development of operating systems and the timing of their release, Microsoft could influence sales of IBM computers, while IBM could affect sales of the applications software Microsoft makes, analysts say. But Aaron Goldberg, an analyst at International Data Corp., said he believed the explanation by IBM and Microsoft that they only wanted to improve the development process for operating systems. ``They have agreed to split the load a little better,'' he said. ``Microsoft doesn't have all the resources to chase every product. ``This to me is a perfect case in where our comptuer industry trade press is trying to find a fire where there is no smoke,'' he added. As part of the new arrangement, Microsoft will have the main responsibility for developing a version of OS-2 for computers whose central processor uses a technology called reduced-instruction-set computing, or RISC, which primarily is used in powerful desktop workstations. Bluestein called that a bone IBM threw Microsoft. OS-2 was jointly announced by IBM and Microsoft in 1987 as their answer to the ease-of-use of Apple Computer Inc.'s popular Macintosh. But the operating system has been slow to catch on, in part because it can't be used with applications software, such as spreadsheets, designed for DOS. It also is limited because it must be used on machines that have a certain memory capacity - more than many older computers have. Additionally, Microsoft has been heavily promoting a software product called Windows that provides much of the Macintosh's features on a DOS-equipped machine. IBM also said Monday that it would license the Windows software from Microsoft, however IBM did not say whether it would provide the feature with their machines. Last fall, to dispel similar rumors of a rift, IBM and Microsoft jointly announced their strategy for OS-2 and Windows. They said Windows was aimed at less-powerful computers using DOS, and OS-2 was designed for machines with greater memory. But IBM has said it is developing a version of OS-2 for older computers that have less memory. That decision caused some industry-watchers to question its support of Windows. Analysts also say Windows poses a threat to OS-2, since it gies owners of older machines less incentive to upgrade to models that could use OS-2.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Experts Advise Lottery Winners To Take Things Slow
With PM-Florida Lottery, moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Winning a lottery jackpot such as Florida's $106.5 million bonanza drawing can be a sweet dream, but for the average person the temptations and mysteries of new-found wealth can become a nightmare. The advice from most financial experts after all the hoopla dies down is simple: take things real slow. ``Preserving your capital is the first thing you've got to do. You'll have plenty of time to invest it,'' David McLaughlin, a financial adviser with Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottseville, Va., said Monday. ``You must make sure your money is safe and earning something.'' Such is the ``problem'' for at least half a dozen Florida Lottery players. Six tickets matched the winning numbers drawn on Saturday in the Florida Lottery estimated at $106.5 million - a state record and the second largest in U.S. history behind Pennsylvania's $115 million jackpot last year. Each Florida ticket is worth about $17.75 million over 20 years, or $887,500 annually before taxes. Many investment counselors suggest that for the first couple of years lottery winners - or anyone with a sudden windfall, for that matter - keep a portion of their loot in liquid assets, such as certificates of deposit or Treasury bills, until they can figure out what they want to do with it. Some banks, such as Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, even offer special accounts for clients who suddenly have $1 million or more and need a place to park it. The rest can go into longer-term bonds, including tax-free municipal issues, or growth stocks, experts say. For McLaughlin, the mix would be divided equally among Treasury bills, Treasury notes or bonds, and stocks for the first few years. Of course, a very small portion may be splurged, he said. Charles Clough, the chief investment strategist for Merrill Lynch & Co., would recommend that 45 percent of the winnings go into intermediate- and long-term bonds, 10- to 15 percent in cash or 90-day T-bills, and 40- to 45 percent in stocks. ``But stay away from stocks (of companies) that depend on cyclical consumer spending,'' he warned. State lottery officials often don't provide financial advice to winners, except to sometimes explain tax liabilities and urge winners to hire a good accountant. Those who fail to take such advice run the risk of falling prey to peddlers of bogus investments. But among the biggest problems most lottery recipients will face is having to sift through all the solicitations from various financial brokers. ``They're going to be getting a lot of calls,'' said McLaughlin, who recommends winners get an unlisted telephone number for starters. ``There will be a lot of pressure,'' added Michael Naste, an independent financial planner from Deland, Fla., and a $2.5 million lottery winner himself. ``If they're not careful, they can easily overextend themselves.'' Such was the case of a young New York beautician who won $7 million about five years ago, said Naste, who says he has 73 lottery winners as clients. Before the young woman came to him for help, he said, she had made several poor investments like putting her money into strip shopping centers. ``She's half a million (dollars) in debt right now . . . and she'll barely come out ahead,'' even after receiving all her lottery payments, Naste said. ``She had quit her job and now she's gone back to work.'' A middle-aged construction worker who won $4 million in the New York lottery four years ago also ran into probolems, said Naste. After receiving a check for around $148,000 - the first of his 20 annual after-tax installments - he quit his $38,000-a-year job, threw a party and put $10,000 down on each of 10 new Cadillacs, he said. But in the next eight months, six of the luxury cars were repossessed and the man had to borrow $200,000 to hold him over between lottery checks, Naste said. Most big-lottery winners, though, are fairly conservative, financial advisers and state lottery officials say. Michigan, for example, found in a 1987 survey that nearly three quarters of its $1 million-plus lottery winners had sought expert financial advice. The majority used their first check to pay bills or splurge on a new home or car, but later, most made long-term investments, saved for retirement, or established trust funds, the survey showed.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Department Checking on Banks' Handling of Proxies for Pension Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department says it is examining whether banks that hold securities for pension funds are getting proxy ballots to the funds' managers in a timely fashion. Assistant Labor Secretary David George Ball said the department also will examine whether the proxies - absentee ballots for shareholders - are being delivered to the person responsible at a fund for voting them. Shareholders are entitled to a say in the running of a company through their vote at annual shareholders meetings. Proxy ballots are sent to those not attending a meeting in person. ``Like political democracy, for corporate democracy to work well, persons entitled to vote need to be able to get relevant information in a timely fashion and to receive their ballots in time to cast them,'' Ball told a meeting in Washington of the United Shareholders Association on Monday. The association is a grassroots organization founded by Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens in 1986 to fight for shareholder rights. The group has sponsored numerous proposals at the annual meetings of large corporations. Ball said the Labor Department's office of enforcement will be contacting a small sampling of bank trustees to see how they handle proxies for pension funds. He added that if past experience is any indicator, ``I would expect that the fact that we are making these inquiries will lead to an internal review of procedures by bank trustees to assure compliance with the law.'' After his speech, Ball explained that the Labor Department was focusing on banks ``because banks are the custodians of the large (pension) plans.'' He said department statistics show that 90 percent of the assets, representing 85 percent of plan participants, are concentrated in just 6 percent of the nation's pension plans. Ball said the review, to be completed by year's end, will screen 200 or 300 banks. ``It'll be the big ones, the ones that are likely to have the custodianship of pension plans,'' he said. The Labor Department maintains that those who invest the money of pension funds have an obligation to manage the assets so they retain or increase in value. That includes carefully voting their proxies. ``Therefore a fiduciary would be derelict in his or her duty if he or she did not vote plan shares on matters which might affect the value of shares,'' Ball said in his speech.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Regulators Reach Accord on Minimum Capital Holdings Standard. Also moved on the general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators are avoiding a potentially chaotic standoff by compromising in a dispute over the most important soundness standard for financial institutions. Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke announced Monday that he was backing down in his contentious feud with other banking agencies over how much capital banks must hold as a cushion against losses. Clarke had pushed for a slightly more lenient standard. If he had stuck to his position, the nation's banks would have faced the confusing prospect of having different standards apply to different institutions, depending on which agency served as primary regulator. The comptroller oversees about 4,000 nationally chartered banks, including the nation's largest institutions, while the FDIC supervises about 8,000 state-chartered banks. The Federal Reserve regulates some of the state and federal banks, already overseen by the other two agencies, if the institutions are members of its system. Capital, representing the investment of a banks' owners, is the basic yardstick for measuring a financial institution's soundness. The more capital a bank has, the more losses it can absorb without failing and requiring money from the federal deposit insurance fund. Meanwhile, the House on Monday put aside its normal order of business and by voice vote adopted legislation removing the legal ceiling on insurance premiums levied on banks and savings institutions by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The Senate is expected to begin considering the measure next week. Congressional leaders, the Bush administration and the FDIC are supporting passage before Congress adjourns early next month. Starting next year, banks will have to pass a two-part capital test. On a risk-adjusted basis, they will be required to hold capital equivalent to 7.25 percent of their asses. After 1992, that will rise to 8 percent. The risk-adjusted capital offers institutions a break for holding low-risk investments such as home mortgages and government securities. Regulators have agreed on that part for months. However, they have been feuding over the so-called ``leverage ratio'' which represents the smallest amount of capital a bank may hold no matter how safe its investments. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman had been pushing for a 4.5 percent minimum, while Clarke wanted 3 percent. Seidman argued that Clarke's proposal would lower capital for 90 percent of the nations banks and would permit the industry's capital to shrink by $8 billion. He said that was the wrong move in the wake of the savings and loan crisis. One of the causes of that debacle was lax standards which allowed S&L owners to operate their institutions with little of their own money at risk. Clarke had argued that setting the leverage ratio too high would negate the beneficial effects of the risk-based standard designed to nudge banks into safer assets. The Federal Reserve, in a compromise adopted last month, said only the strongest banks - about one in five - would be permitted a 3 percent minimum. Others would have a minimum ranging between 4 percent and 5 percent. The FDIC is scheduled to pass the compromise at a board meeting today. The new guideline would become effective Jan. 1. Meanwhile, the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings and loans, announced it would tighten its rules to conform with the new commercial bank guidelines. Currently, it's ``core'' capital requirement, analogous to the leverage ratio, is 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Credit Ratings Downgraded
DOC.TEXT: Two credit rating services have lowered their assessments of Sears, Roebuck and Co.'s ability to repay its debt. Jerry Buldak, spokesman for Chicago-based Sears, said Monday that the giant retailer doesn't comment on ratings adjustments. In New York, Moody's Investors Service lowered Sears' long-term debt rating from A1 to A2, while Duff & Phelps Inc. of Chicago downgraded the company's senior debt from AA-minus to A-Plus. Also lowered were some debt ratings for Sears subsidiaries, including Discover Credit Corp., Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp., Sears Overseas Finance and Allstate Insurance Co. ``The rating actions are based upon Moody's opinion that improvement within the intensely competitive merchandising sector has not been nor will be achieved as quickly as originally anticipated,'' Moody's said in a statement Monday. Duff & Phelps said its rating changes will affect about $28 billion dollars of debt securities. ``The reason for the downgrades is the continued subpar performance of the merchandising group,'' Duff & Phelps said Monday. In July, Sears reported a 39 percent drop in second-quarter profits, blaming high insurance payouts and a decline in retailing income.

DOC.HEAD: NCR To Announce New Computer Line Based on Intel Chips, Open Systems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with announcement. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Dayton, Ohio-based ...'.
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. said today it would become the first computer maker to offer an entire product line, from laptop computers to giant mainframes, based on Intel Corp. microprocessors and standardized software. Using the same type of microprocessors, the ``chips'' that are the brains of computers, would make the entire line compatible, meaning a laptop computer could get at information stored on a mainframe. The computer lines of most major makers are divided between proprietary, or company-specific, processing systems and ``open'' systems such as those based on Intel chips. The differences mean various computers sold by the same company often are incompatible. The industry has moved toward open systems in recent years as companies want to use the same applications software, such as spreadsheets or word processing programs, on all computers no matter what the brand. In addition, computer users increasingly want to connect machines in networks, which can be troublesome with incompatible models. NCR, though not a major player in general-purpose computers, could reap major rewards from its new direction, said analysts. ``You can't write these guys off as a non-factor anymore,'' said Don Young of the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. ``I think it's a pretty bold move on their part.'' NCR said it eventually would provide computers in seven ``levels,'' or performance and size ranges. Today it announced six machines in three of those levels, including workstations and ``servers,'' powerful computers that link networks of less-powerful machines. The models released today cost $10,000 to $800,000. The higher-end models of the new line derive their power by linking multiple Intel microprocessors in a technique called parallel processing. NCR says it will power the giant mainframes at the top of the line by hooking together thousands of the same chips that run tiny laptop computers. Dayton, Ohio-based NCR long has specialized in computers for banks and retail stores, and is a major maker of cash registers and automated teller machines. In recent years it has enjoyed success with a line of personal computers built to industry standards using Intel chips. It now plans to phase out its old computers and use those standards and Intel chips on its entire product line. NCR would become the first company to sell high-end mainframe computers based on open systems, analysts said. The models would be NCR's entry into the market for extremely powerful computers. The new strategy ``will potentially open up their rather narrow market into a broad market,'' said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``The question is, can they be one of the major players? The answer is you just don't know.'' In coming weeks, NCR also is expected to announce software and networking systems that will allow the new computer line to be connected throughout a company, Martin said. NCR's new direction would be another boon to Intel, the Santa Clara, Calif., chip company that is enjoying phenomenal success. Its chips are so popular with computer makers that it can't make enough to satisfy demand. But the news could be troubling to Motorola Inc., which makes the chips used in some NCR computers. NCR's move signals the increasing dominanace of Intel's chips in computers - already, Intel chips are the dominant processors in desktop machines. ``Motorola's microcomputer business is headed for some tough times,'' Young said. NCR sells less than $5 billion worth of computers a year, out of a global market of $200 billion, he said. By comparison, International Business Machines Corp., the industry leader, has sales of about $60 billion. Earlier this month IBM announced a new generation of mainframe computers based on a proprietary standard. IBM also said it plans to provide systems that would allow the mainframe computer to coordinate corporate-wide computing networks. Next month, Unisys Corp., the No. 3 computer maker, also is expected to announce products for connecting computers throughout a company.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Seek Direction As Talks End in Impasse
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic congressional leaders today blamed the Bush administration's demand to slash the capital gains tax for the breakdown of budget talks just two weeks from the start of the new fiscal year. But President Bush, asked if capital gains was the stumbling block, told reporters, ``not as far as I'm concerned.'' Bush said he talked with his budget negotiators today and ``we're going back. We're staying with it. I can't really predict what's going to happen.'' ``The problem is the insistence of the administration to reduce the capital gains tax,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters. ``The real difficulty and the major obstable to agreement is the tax issue,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``The rest would come together quickly.'' Participants said they still hoped to try to work out a budget deal, but it was unclear how quickly they could do so. Congressional leaders planned to meet in the Capitol today with top administration officials to discuss the impasse. ``It's not total gridlock,'' said Foley. Asked whether he was optimistic, Bush said everybody involved ``agrees we've come quite a ways, but it's not done by a long shot.'' Republicans insisted that there were other important differences between the two sides over spending cuts, but Democrats insisted these were relatively minor. Democrats harped on their oft-repeated theme that a capital gains tax cut - which Republicans say would spur the economy - would simply cut taxes for the wealthy. ``It's not quite an impasse, but it's pretty close to one,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said after the talks ended. ``At this point we've reached an impasse,'' said another bargainer, Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. Today's session in the Capitol took on a sense of heightened urgency. On Oct. 1 - the start of fiscal 1991 - the Gramm-Rudman law will slash the $1.2 trillion budget by about $100 billion unless a deficit-cutting deal is in place. A cut that deep would violently disrupt government services. The breakdown of the talks at Andrews represented a major disappointment to budget bargainers who initially hoped that three or four days of meetings at the airfield would solve the fiscal standoff that has lingered all year. But after meetings scheduled during varying intervals since Sept. 7, neither Dole nor Gramm would rule out an eventual budget pact. But neither could suggest how it could happen. ``It's going to be tough, but it's still not impossible, and no one is giving up,'' said Dole. ``The problem is we're running out of time.'' The most profound gap between the two sides was over President Bush's insistence that the package include a cut in the capital gains tax rate. The tax is levied on sales of property. Supporters say the reduction would invigorate the economy by spurring sales. Democratic leaders have long insisted that the idea would be a windfall for the wealthy who own most property. They have said they would only accept a capital gains tax cut if other taxes on the rich were boosted. In their final offer Monday, the Democrats demanded that the capital gains rate remain unchanged. ``The only way you can say we're at an impasse is if you know you won't back off from the capital gains demand,'' said a Democratic official involved in the talks, who asked to not be identified. Republicans complained that there were other important disagreements as well. Democrats wanted to rely on higher energy taxes for about $49 billion during the next five years, seven times the amount Republicans sought. The GOP offered to cut Pentagon spending over the next five years by $170 billion below the amount needed to stay even with inflation. Democrats said their reduction would be close to that figure, but offered to lock in cuts for only the first two years: $10 billion next year and $23.2 billion the following year. Republicans wanted to hold domestic programs to the rate of inflation over the next five years. Democrats wanted to increase that amount by $5 billion. For benefit programs like Medicare and farm price supports - one of the fastest growing parts of the federal budget - Republicans wanted to reduce growth by $123.3 billion through 1995. The proposed Democratic cut was less deep, to the tune of $2.7 billion. The two sides also never reached agreement on how to control spending in future years. For example, they continued to clash over whether and how the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law should be extended beyond its scheduled 1993 expiration. Despite those differences, the two sides had moved closer in a number of areas. For example, they had tentatively agreed to about $59 billion in tax increases, said one official who demanded anonymity. These included higher levies on beer, wine, spirits, tobacco and luxury items such as fancy cars, private boats and planes, electronic equipment, furs and jewelry. They also agreed that about $25 billion in first-year savings would come from new taxes and fees. Democrats wanted $130 billion in new taxes and fees over five years, Republicans $138.1 billion. And although the two sides still differed over the size of spending cuts, the gap between them in each area was dramatically smaller than it was when the bargaining at Andrews began. Without action, next year's federal deficit is expected to be a record $250 billion or more.

DOC.HEAD: Former SEC Official Named Shareholders Rights Group Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Charles C. Cox, an economist and former Securities and Exchange Commissioner, has been named chairman of the United Shareholders Association, a nationwide shareholders' rights group. Cox will succeed Texas oil man T. Boone Pickens, who founded the group in 1986. Pickens will continue his affiliation with the 64,000-member group. The appointment of Cox, who will take over Oct. 1, was announced late Monday at the group's annual meeting in Washington. The group also announced its latest list of 50 major U.S. corporations targeted for shareholder activism. The 1991 Target 50 list, ranges from aerospace and automotive manufacturer Allied-Signal Inc. to Xerox Corp. United Shareholders Director Ralph Whitworth said the group plans to concentrate on four reforms: confidential voting in corporate elections; elimination of ``poison pill'' anti-takeover devices; shareholder approval of lucrative benefits - known as ``golden parachutes'' - paid to top management who lose their jobs as a result of a takeover - and requiring companies to exempt themselves from state anti-takeover laws that may apply to them. Those proposals will be introduced at the annual shareholders meetings of the targeted 50 companies. ``Through the Target 50 program, we are encouraging companies to enter into a constructive dialogue with their shareholders,'' said Whitworth in a statement issued by the group. Cox, 45, the first economist to be appointed a member of the SEC, stepped down in September 1989, to join a Chicago consulting firm. He had been a member of the independent commission for nearly six years. Before that he had been the SEC's chief economist since September 1982. Before joining the SEC staff, Cox served from 1980 to 1982 as a professor of management at Texas A&M University and from 1972 to 1980 as an economics professor at Ohio State University.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Futures Edge Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and corn futures prices edged higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government reported that development of those crops continues lag behind the normal pace. Wheat futures were fractionally lower in trading described as boring by Paul Sylvester of Gerald Inc., a commodities trading firm in Chicago. The soybean market's early gains represented a turnaround after Monday's steep losses. Analysts said the corn and soybean markets drew support from the Agriculture Department's weekly crop progress report, which showed leaves dropping in 22 percent of the soybean crop as of Sunday compared with an average of 39 percent for that date. Thirty-three percent of the corn crop was in the mature stage as of Sunday compared with the average pace of 61 percent, the USDA said. The soybean complex also was supported by rumors that Pakistan bought U.S. soybean oil overnight and that Taiwan may be in the market for soybeans. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.60{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with September at $2.36} a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with September at $1.10{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 2\ cents higher with September at $6.17\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, extending Monday's strong gains amid continued strength in the cash markets. Live cattle futures were .18 cent to .35 cent higher with October at 79.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .33 cent higher with September at 89.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .60 cent higher with October at 53.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent to .95 cent higher with February at 57.60 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: THE POST LIVES!: Union Agrees to Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 3rd to update with publisher news conference. Pick up 4th graf pvs, ``You feel...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The New York Post trumpeted ``YES!'' one day after its front page had asked: ``Will the presses ever run again?'' The affirmation in today's editions of the saucy tabloid came after Newspaper Guild members voted 242-45 Monday night to accept a four-day work week, which will mean a 20 percent pay cut. Publisher Peter S. Kalikow had threatened to close the nation's oldest continuously running daily immediately if the 350 Guild members - news, advertising and clerical workers - rejected the concessions. The paper is losing $27 million a year. Today, speaking in his office, Kalikow praised the unions for accepting his conditions and predicted a bright future for the paper. The Post should begin turning a profit next month, he said. ``Of the three tabloids in New York, you're now standing in the only profitable one,'' Kalikow told reporters at a news conference. ``You feel like the executioner has loosened the noose,'' said Jill Brooke, a Post TV and radio reporter who voted for approval. ``But we still have a life sentence: a 20 percent pay cut.'' Nearly 1,000 people would have lost their jobs had the 505,000-circulation paper known for dishing up stories of sex, murder and mayhem under screaming headlines had gone under. ``Let's go to press,'' Kalikow said after the vote. ``This is not a management victory. It is not a labor victory. It is a victory for all New Yorkers who deserve the honesty and diversity offered in the pages of the New York Post.'' The Guild was the last of 11 unions to approve concessions designed to help Kalikow break even. He is said to have lost more than $100 million personally since buying the paper from media baron Rupert Murdoch in 1988. Two years ago, Kalikow won $24 million in concessions as a condition of the purchase. Monday's vote was taken by hand after a 90-minute meeting punctuated by boos, applause and speeches for and against the proposal. ``There was some blood on the floor,'' said reporter Kieran Crowley. Reporter Peter Moses voted for the pay cut despite reservations. ``We accepted a package that none of us liked, we accepted a package that made no sense to any of us and we accepted a package that makes us less than middle class,'' he said. Before the pay cut, top salary for reporters was $853 a week. Kalikow promised the unions 20 percent of company stock and a representative on the board of directors. In exchange he got $19 million in union concessions and $8 million in other cost reductions, including management wage cuts. Sentiment swung in favor of the concessions when Kalikow also said employees could approve the plan, then resign by Wednesday and receive the same severance and termination pay as if the paper had shut down. Theodore Kheel, an adviser to the unions, said Kalikow also dropped his demand that 43 jobs be eliminated. Instead he will settle for how ever many resignations he gets, Kheel said. ``A diversity of editorial voices is important in a democratic society,'' Daily News publisher James Hoge said in a statement congratulating the Post. That diversity may be diminished yet, however. A regional economic slump has hurt advertising revenue at all the city's papers. Newspaper analysts say that in the long haul there aren't enough ads to keep all four major dailies alive. The New York Times is in the black but turning less of a profit than a year ago. Times spokesman William Adler said the newspaper would seek some of the concessions the Post got. The Daily News, a tabloid like the Post, said it has a ``me, too'' clause in contracts with its unions that entitles it to the concessions the Post got. Talks at the money-losing News have stalemated and unions are urging advertisers to boycott it. New York Newsday, the city's third tabloid, is losing money also, but its profitable parent, Times Mirror Co., is keeping the paper alive. The Post has a long history of money woes - and owners with the deep pockets and the patience to take heavy losses. Its founder, Alexander Hamilton, was in debt in 1801 when he persuaded a group of merchants to finance the paper. Banking heiress Dorothy Schiff bought the Post in 1939, turned it into one of the nation's most liberal newspapers and brightened it up with a tabloid format. It was losing money when she sold it to Murdoch in 1976. The Post's fortunes seemed to have dimmed for good in the 1970s as much of its audience moved to the suburbs. Recently, the slump has deepened as an economic decline in the New York City further cut advertising revenues. Murdoch transformed the Post into a politically conservative paper, albeit one that featured sexy pictures, racy headlines - like the famous ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' - and lots of crime stories. In the past year, the Post ran such headlines like ``BASTARDS'' over a photo of a hanged hostage and ``BEST SEX I EVER HAD'' accompanying a picture of a smirking Donald Trump. Murdoch said the paper lost $150 million before he sold it for $37 million to Kalikow, a real estate developer. Post Editor Jerry Nachman on Monday likened the Post to a bumblebee. ``Aerodynamically, bumblebees ought not fly; the ratio of their body weight to wingspan would make it physically impossible,'' he said. ``But they absolutely refuse to understand that. So they fly. That's the Post.'' ``And like the bumblebee,'' he added, ``we keep stinging people.''

DOC.HEAD: Request to Forgive Egypt Debt Meets Opposition in Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS spelling of Broomfield in 7th graf bgng, Israel, Poland... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's urgent request for $1.9 billion to help pay for the U.S. military deployment in the Middle East is running into trouble on Capitol Hill among lawmakers of both parties. The biggest obstacle is a White House plan to forgive $6.7 billion in debts Egypt owes the United States for past military equipment purchases. But lawmakers also are objecting to a proposal to set up a ``National Defense Gift Fund'' to receive money from allies that then could be spent by the Pentagon, apparently without any control by Congress. Rep. William Broomfield, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, dealt th package a blow on Monday when he announced his opposition to canceling Egypt's debt. Broomfield, R-Mich., said the debt forgiveness would prompt a wave of requests from countries that see it as a way to get more foreign aid as budget negotiators seek to cut the deficit. ``I can't imagine a worse time for the administration to be recommending forgiveness on this debt,'' he said in an interview. Asked to assess the proposal's prospects on the House floor, he said: ``I would say it would go down the tubes'' in its present form. Israel, Poland and other countries already are lining up for similar treatment, Broomfield said. In a statement on the House floor, he added: ``The simple fact is that America can't afford outright cancellation of Egypt's debt.'' Broomfield's opposition came on the heels of skepticism by the Democratic chairmen of the House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees that must approve the package - Sen. Patrick Leahy of Vermont and Rep. David Obey of Wisconsin. Obey said Monday that new figures from the Congressional Budget Office show the debt forgiveness would cost $2.4 billion in lost payments over the next five years, in contrast to the administration's assertion that the move would have no budget impact. Other influential lawmakers, including Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., have expressed wariness about seeking contributions from other countries to offset the cost of the Persian Gulf military mobilization. They worry that the situation smacks of the mechanism used during the Iran-Contra affair to insulate executive branch decisions and actions from congressional oversight. ``Ollie North would have absolutely loved it,'' Obey said of the administration's proposal to set up a new fund at the Pentagon out of Congress' reach. When Bush sent his request to Congress on Friday, the request to cancel Egypt's debt was linked to the supplemental money bill for Operation Desert Shield. A senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the link was intended to improve the prospects for forgiving the debt, which the White House knew would be unpopular so close to congressional elections. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger sought last week to persuade key lawmakers that Egypt's support in the gulf was crucial to U.S. success, according to participants in the discussions. Egypt has led the way in providing Arab troops to the deployment in Saudi Arabia and has lobbied other Arab states to isolate Iraq's Saddam Hussein, Eagleburger pointed out. Broomfield said he welcomed those moves, and added, ``I am sure there are other ways America and other nations can help them alleviate some of the economic problems caused by this crisis.'' Perhaps the debt could be restructured, or the United States could waive a requirement that all payments be up to date before a country can receive new foreign aid, he said. To forgive all the debt, however, would be a sign that ``we may have lost our senses,'' Broomfield said. ``This comes at a time when our budget negotiators are figuring out ways to squeeze a few more tax dollars out of America's sales clerks and farmers and mechanics.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Shock Sends Consumer Prices Soaring 0.8 Percent in August
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 11 grafs new with reaction from economists, market and real earnings report, Picks up 9th pvs, A bright . . . Also moving on general; news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent energy prices spiraling, pushing the cost of living up a steep 0.8 percent in August, the government said today. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the U.S. merchandise trade deficit jumped a dramatic 75 percent to $9.33 billion in July, the month before the invasion. Analysts expect the deficit to climb further as the oil shock drives up imports. The gain in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was double the 0.4 percent rise in July and the largest since January, when a severe cold snap pushed costs up 1.1 percent. Financial markets turned down in response to the double dose of bad economic news. In the first 90 minutes of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 23.77 points to 2,543.56. ``I think we'll have two, maybe three more months of high inflation numbers,'' said economist Mark Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. The department attributed nearly half of the August increase to the oil shock. Excluding energy prices, which jumped 4.3 percent, consumer costs rose 0.4 percent. The Aug. 2 invasion sent gasoline prices up 7.6 percent, while fuel oil prices jumped 15.4 percent. It was the steepest increase in those categories since January. For the first eight months of 1990, prices rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.2 percent, up sharply from the 4.6 percent rise for all of 1989. More bad news is coming over the next several months, economists believe. Crude oil prices have continued to rise in September and will work their way through to the gasoline pump. Increases are also ahead for chemicals, plastics and other petroleum-based products. However, many analysts believe economic growth is too slow and demand too weak to support a sustained inflation burst once oil prices stabilize. In another report, the Labor Department said American's inflation-adjusted earnings fell a seasonally adjusted 0.6 percent in August. Earnings fell 0.5 percent in each of the two previous months. A bright spot in the August report was a moderation in food price inflation. Food prices, held back by a decline in fruit and vegetable prices, rose 0.3 percent, the smallest since May. Fresh fruit prices tumbled 4 percent, but dairy costs rose 1.3 percent. Prices in other food categories were up. The cost of housing, up 0.7 percent, and transportation, up 1.8 percent, were both driven by rising energy prices. Gasoline accounted for nearly 90 percent of the transportation rise, the department said.

In other categories, medical care rose 0.9 percent, in line with a long string of sharp increases; tobacco was up only 0.3 percent after having risen more than 2 percent in both July and June, and clothing and upkeep costs were up a slight 0.1 percent. The various changes put the index for all consumer goods at 131.6 in August. That means that a hypothetical selection of goods costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period cost $131.60 in August, up from $7 from a year earlier. The recent combination of oil-induced inflation and slow economic growth has put monetary policy-makers in a quandary. The Federal Reserve normally pushes interest rates higher to fight inflation and lower to stimulate lagging growth.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Down Slightly Today After Monday's Big Rise
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices dipped this morning after reaching record highs in the previous session. Prices were trading above the day's lows, however, as crude rebounded a bit on an unconfirmed report that Iraq had killed a civilian on the Kuwaiti border. ``The market seemed to take that and run with it a little bit,'' said Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Light sweet crude was trading at $33.50 per barrel for October contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange late this morning, down 13 cents from Monday's record close of $33.63. Oil opened lower today as traders sold futures, but it soon began rallying on the bullish news from the Mideast. The November contract for crude was higher today, up 59 cents to $32.75 per barrel in late morning trading. Dolan said November crude, which was limited to a rise of $1 in Monday's trading under the exchange's rules, was catching up with the higher price of October contracts. Other crude futures were higher on near months and lower for distant months. Petroleum product futures were higher today. Unleaded gasoline was up 1.28 cents to 92.95 cents per gallon on October contracts, while home heating oil was up 2.39 cents to 87.70 cents per gallon on October contracts. Traders say heating oil has been outpacing oil because winter is approaching. Natural gas prices showed little change, rising to $1.540 per 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.537 on October contracts. On Monday, crude oil hit its all-time intraday high on the Mercantile Exchange, trading late in the day at $33.75 per barrel on October contracts. The previous high, $32.35, had stood since Aug. 2, 1983, and was matched once since Iraq invaded Kuwait last month. The rise to a new record left traders wondering where oil will go after heading into uncharted territory amid the volatility of the persisting Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: GM Reportedly Can Close Plants at Will Under New Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with meeting under way, detail from contract summary. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is free to close plants at will but will spend $4.2 billion to protect the income of employees affected by cutbacks under its new labor agreement, a newspaper said today. The tentative agreement covering 300,000 workers in 29 states was reached early Monday after 41 hours of non-stop talks between the United Auto Workers and the world's biggest automaker. This morning, the 300-member GM Bargaining Council met to discuss the contract, the first step toward submitting the pact to the membership. The meeting was closed, but a summary of contract details given to group members included wage increases of 3 percent the first year and lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years, and increases in monthly pensions for workers with 30 years on the job from $1,500 to $1,800. The summary also cited $4.2 billion in income guarantees, and indicated that language curbing the company's right to close plants was eliminated. The Detroit Free Press reported today that the new provision in effect gives GM the right to close plants at will. Pete Kelly, president of Local 160 at GM's Technical Center in Warren, Mich., had some criticism for the settlement but said today that he expected it would be overwhelmingly approved. ``I think for what general motors got, the economic package was not sufficient,'' Kelly said. Under the pact, GM will guarantee workers laid off for up to 12 weeks in a year 95 percent of their wages by supplementing their unemployment benefits, the newspaper said. Anyone laid off for more than 12 weeks will be guaranteed full pay for the duration of the contract, the paper said. Many analysts say GM will have to close at least four assembly plants and lay off tens of thousands of people in an industry threatened by a sluggish economy and foreign competition. If the bargaining council approves the agreement, it will be put to a rank-and-file vote to be completed by the end of the month. ``We're all starving for information over here,'' said Joe Garcia, financial secretary for Local 645 in Van Nuys, Calif. Assembly workers earn $15.27 an hor at GM, and cost-of-living allowances that carry over from the previous contract would add $2.15 an hour by 1993 if inflation runs at 5 percent a year, the Free Press said. The 1987 contract expired at midnight Friday and negotiators worked under a day-by-day extension through the weekend. The union's contracts cover more than 450,000 active workers at GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. Talks between the union and Ford and Chrysler have been on hold while the union concentrates on GM, hoping to use the pact reached there as a pattern for agreements with the other automakers. Chrysler and Ford said they would not comment on the UAW-GM agreement until it was ratified. Ford is dealing with a strike at its Canadian plants by the Canadian Auto Workers union that entered its fourth day today. The principal issue in Canada is money; in the United States it is job security. Some Wall Street analysts said the chances for a strike this year at GM were the best in years. But GM Vice President Alfred Warren said Monday the talks signaled a new era of cooperation between the union and the automaker. ``We feel the spirit we developed during the negotiations bodes well for General Motors, the customer and the marketplace,'' Warren said. While union members waited anxiously to hear what gains, if any, had been made, most said they were happy a strike had been averted. ``I was kind of scared we were going to be off today, but since we settled I'm glad,'' said J.D. Boatman, 61, who works at GM's Cadillac plant in Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: Power Failure Delays Trading at Board of Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, The power . . . and 7th graf, Grede said ... to CORRECT that trading starts at 7:20 a.m., not 6 a.m. and to UPDATE with trading under way
DOC.TEXT: Trading was suspended today at the Chicago Board of Trade after an electrical problem knocked out power to most of the 40-story downtown building, officials said. The power failure hit about two hours before the first trading of the day was scheduled to begin at 7:20 a.m. CDT in financial contracts such as Treasury bonds, said Frederick Grede, the exchange's vice president of administration. Most of the building's electrical systems were knocked out of commission, including electronic trading mechanisms, phones and elevators, Grede said. Power also was out on the building's fourth floor, where the trading pits are located, he said. Although few people were in the building initially, employees and traders began arriving for work a short time later and scores of them waited in the lobby rather than attempting to climb the stairs to their offices, he said. No one was stuck in any of the elevators that stopped when the power went out, Grede said. Commonwealth Edison Co. blamed the failure on a possible electrical cable malfunction, and had restored power to all but three floors by 7:40 a.m., said utility spokesman Bill Harrah. Trading began in financial contracts at 8:45 a.m., more than an hour late. But trading in agricultural contracts began on time, at 9:30 a.m. The power failure was confined to the BOT building, which houses offices of the exchange and member firms, Harrah said. ``There appears to have been a cable fault of one kind or another inside the building,'' he said. Edison crews ``have done some switching around a damaged section of cable,'' and were working on a transformer in an effort to restore power to the remaining three floors, Harrah said. The power failure was the latest of several glitches that have hit the Edison system this summer. The previous problems affected several residential neighborhoods and knocked out power to thousands of residents.

DOC.HEAD: Say UAL Unions Preparing New Bid for Carrier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, In a . . . to make it Employee sted Employment.
DOC.TEXT: The unions at United Airlines plan to meet with banks this week to discuss a new offer of as much as $3.92 billion for United's parent, UAL Corp., according to a published report today. The Wall Street Journal said the new offer, the latest in a series of on-again, off-again deals for one of the nation's biggest airlines, could amount to $175 a share to $180 a share, or $3.82 billion to $3.92 billion. That would be well below the $201 a share, or $4.38 billion, offer from a labor group that UAL's board accepted last April. That pact has been scuttled by the financial uncertainty created by the crisis in the Middle East. Citing unidentified officials close to the proposed deal, the newspaper said the new offer probably will include participation by a foreign airline. The story said a logical possibility would be British Airways PLC, which was a principal equity investor in a $300-a-share labor-management bid that collapsed last October. The Journal story said British Air declined to comment and leaders of the buyout group declined to identify the foreign carriers they say have expressed interest in backing the new offer. Last week, a United Airlines workers group announced it was ending an agreement with an investment partnership to acquire UAL. In a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worker group, United Employee Acquisition Corp., said it was still interested in acquiring the Chicago-based airline, however. The disclosure ended an agreement between UEAC and Coniston Partners in April to help UEAC, a company formed by United's unions, acquire UAL. The Wall Street Journal story said the unions have invited about two dozen banks to this week's meeting where their financial advisers are expected to outline plans for a new offer consisting of cash and securities. One individual familiar with the agenda, the story said, cautioned that plans for the new offer are ``still evolving and are subject to change.'' It also noted that it was unclear how the UAL board will greet a lower offer.

DOC.HEAD: Jobs' Big Bash For Next Products
DOC.TEXT: Computer pioneer Steve Jobs unveiled four new products today that he hopes will salvage his new company, Next Computer Inc.. The products included a more powerful, color-screen version of the Next computer as well as an entry-level, under-$5,000 model - half the cost of the current machine. Jobs said the company already has received orders for more than 15,000 of the new products. In addition, Lotus Development Corp., creator of the popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet, announced a new spreadsheet for the Next computer, called Lotus Improv. The product provides a new approach to spreadsheets by enabling users to click a mouse to view information. The software, designed specifically for the Next computer, uses plain English formulas. Many other software developers were expected to announce new applications programs for the Next throughout the all-day news conference. The new products were designed to answer critics who say the Next is too expensive, too slow, in need of a color monitor and lacking imaginative software that would give people a compelling reason to buy it. The Next machine was supposed to revolutionize personal computers, much as did the Apple computer invented by Jobs and Steve Wozniak in 1976, and Jobs' later Macintosh. To store data, the Next uses a removable optical disc, which provides far greater capacity than the magnetic floppy discs found on most personal computers. It also can reproduce sharp graphics and has a built-in system that makes it easier for software developers to write new programs. While Next has been praised for these high-tech innovations, only several thousand of the machines have been sold, and Next has failed to generate great interest among bread-and-butter corporate computer users, analysts say. Businessland, a computer store chain that signed an exclusive deal with Next in March 1989 to sell its machines domestically to corporations, had predicted sales would hit $100 million in the first year. But International Data Corp., a high-tech research firm, estimates that fewer than 7,000 Nexts were sold as of June. At less than $5,000, the price tag makes the new machines competitive with both the high-end personal computers of Apple Computer Inc. and International Business Machines Corp. and the low-end workstations of companies like Sun Microsstems Inc. Next, which is privately held, does not disclose its sales or finances. Despite its sluggish start, no one is predicting Next's demise. The company is heavily capitalized, and one of its principal owners, the Japanese high-tech company Canon Inc., paid $100 million for a one-sixth share last year. Jobs founded Next in 1985 after leaving Apple in a dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Drop Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices nationwide fell slightly in the last week to about $1.29 a gallon, the American Automobile Association said Tuesday. The average retail price of a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded was 21.7 cents higher than on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and sent world oil prices skyrocketing, the AAA said. In its latest spot check of stations, the AAA said the price of a gallon of self-serve unleaded gasoline fell 0.2 cent to $1.292 a gallon. AAA also reported these national averages for other fuels by the self-serve gallon: regular leaded, $1.325; mid-grade unleaded, $1.365; and premium unleaded, $1.461. Prices fell slightly in the Midwest, the Southeast and the West. Small increases were found in New England and the Mid-Atlantic and Great Lakes regions. The previous AAA gasoline survey was on Sept. 11.

DOC.HEAD: Redwood Summer Gives Way to Corporate Fall
DOC.TEXT: Redwood Summer will turn to ``Corporate Fall,'' a new series of anti-logging protests to be staged at logging company headquarters and executives' homes, organizers announced. The protests will denounce ``corporate greed and corruption,'' Earth First! activist Darryl Cherney said Monday. Unlike the Redwood Summer protests, which were held only in California, Corporate Fall protests will be held nationwide, Cherney said. The first protest is scheduled Sept. 27 at Maxxam corporate headquarters in Houston. Timber officials doubt the success of the new strategy. ``The name `Corporate Fall' doesn't have a good ring to it,'' said Georgia-Pacific spokesman Dave Odgers. ``They're going to have a hard time selling it. Redwood Summer had a good ring.'' Most of the 70 Redwood Summer protests were held in Humboldt County, which had to lay out an estimated $400,000 in law enforcement and court costs.

DOC.HEAD: United States Modifies Demands on Abolishing Farm Export Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: A top American trade official said Tuesday that the United States is ready to relax its demands for abolishing farm export subsidies, a step that could help resolve a dispute threatening world trade talks. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said that Washington would propose reductions of up to 70 percent in domestic farm supports and import duties, and more than 70 percent in export assistance. The proposal is to be submitted to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is sponsoring the latest Round of trade liberalization talks. The talks are to conclude early December. The 105-nation negotiations, launched in Uruguay four years ago, are deadlocked because of disagreement between the United States and the European Community over farm supports. There also are significant differences on how to liberalize trade in textiles and over the scope of new rules to cover trade in services such as banking. On textiles, Hills said that the United States was ready to accept that the existing system of protection should be phased out. But she defended the U.S. view that aviation should be exempt from a services agreement. At the heart of the farm trade dispute is the EC's refusal to dismantle its system of export subsidies to help farmers compete on foreign markets. The United States, backed by farm exporting nations led by Australia, has until now insisted on a complete phaseout. A text being used as the basis of negotiations in Geneva provides for ``substantial, progressive reductions'' in support, with the greatest cuts in export subsidies. Hills said the U.S. proposal would achieve the goal. All proposals have to be submitted to GATT by October 15. Trade ministers are to meet in Brussels for final talks in less than two months. Hills was in Geneva with a delegation of top U.S. businessmen on the first leg of a week-long European trip. She dismissed an EC proposal for overall reductions of 30 percent as inadequate, adding that the 12-nation trading bloc wanted to use as abase year 1986, when levels of support were particularly high. Hills said the United States would compromise on a method of liberalizing trade in textiles ``if that pushes us further down the road'' toward an agreement. Third World textile exporters have argued that trade, worth some $177 billion annually, should be liberalized by winding down an existing system under which import quotas are fixed in bilateral deals.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Bounce Back on Frost Talk
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose moderately Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, recovering most of the ground lost in the previous session amid talk of possible frost in the Midwest early next week. Most corn futures also advanced but wheat futures retreated slightly. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president for grain trading with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said some private forecasters predicted frost in the Midwest by Monday, fueling fears of damage to the slowly maturing soybean and corn crops. A weekly government report on Monday showed leaves dropping in 22 percent of the soybean crop as of Sunday compared with an average of 39 percent for that date. Thirty-three percent of the corn crop was in the mature stage as of Sunday compared with the average pace of 61 percent, according to the Agriculture Department report. Even before frost entered the forecasts, traders were concerned that the current spate of cool, rainy weather in the Midwest would continue to slow crop development. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.59{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.37 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $1.10\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 7 cents higher with September at $6.22{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: EC Ministers Say Gulf Crisis Shouldn't Derail Trade Accord
With AM-Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: The European Community declared Tuesday that the Gulf crisis should not be allowed to derail an international free-trade accord due to be reached this December. ``The message we wish to pass to everyone is that this crisis cannot have a protectionist response,'' Italy's foreign trade minister, Renato Ruggiero said. The foreign trade ministers of the 12 EC members met to discuss the latest round of trade liberalization talks. The talks is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The 105-nation negotiations are blocked mainly because of disagreement between the United States and the EC over farm supports. EC members fear that some countries will be reluctant to commit themselves to strict trade agreements when their economies are suffering from higher oil prices due to the crisis prompted by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. To resolve the problem, the EC ministers discussed providing greater access to the markets of industrialized countries for textiles, a major product of the developing world. ``Certainly we are ready to move on access to our markets, but on this question we need the cooperation of other industrialized countries,'' Ruggiero said. He singled out the United States, which he said had maintained too many barriers to textile imports. Ruggiero spoke on behalf of the 12 ministers since Italy holds the presidency of the EC. Frans Andriessen, the vice president of the EC Commission, told reporters the willingness by the United States to move away from a system of global textile quotas had brought Washington and the EC closer together on the issue. Under the system now in place, the Multifiber Arrangement, import quotas are fixed in bilateral deals. The EC wants to dismantle the system gradually.

DOC.HEAD: Another Top Turner Executive Resigns
DOC.TEXT: A top executive for media mogul Ted Turner resigned unexpectedly in the latest departure by officials who helped build Turner Broadcasting System into a $1.2 billion cable television giant. Gerald F. Hogan, 44, resigned Monday to become vice chairman of Whittle Communications L.P., a Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company. Hogan, a 19-year veteran of Turner Broadcasting, was president of Turner Entertainment Networks, a member of the company's executive committee and a company director. His resignation follows by a year the resignation of Turner's former No. 2 executive, Robert J. Wussler, who quit to head Comsat Video Enterprises. Several other top executives have left or announced retirement plans since Wussler departed. ``Gerry has played an important role in the success of our company. We wish him well in his new endeavor,'' Turner said in a statement. Hogan joined Turner Broadcasting in 1971 as an advertising account executive for WTCG, the independent station that now is SuperStation TBS. He worked on the sales side of the company before becoming president in 1987 of the entertainment networks, TBS and Turner Network Television. Hogan's departure leaves Terence F. McGuirk as the No. 2 man at Turner Broadcasting. McGuirk, who joined the company in 1972, is president of Turner Cable Network Sales and Turner Sports. Hogan and McGuirk functioned as operational heads of the corporation, their roles increasing in stature as Turner withdrew from the day-to-day running of the company.

The stock market remained lower in late trading today but an afternoon rebound enabled the blue chips to gain back most lost ground. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was off 1.24 at 2,566.09 with five minutes left to go in the session.
