DOC.HEAD: Alternative Card Company Sets Lofty Goals
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the fiercely competitive greeting card industry, Among Friends is a grain of sand on a beach dominated by giants like Hallmark Cards, American Greetings and Gibson Greetings. But the alternative card company, which was formed two years ago by three women in this Lake of the Ozarks community in central Missouri, has set some lofty goals. ``People say, `Oh, is your goal to have Hallmark buy you out?' I say, `no, our goal is to buy Hallmark,' '' Claudia Parrish, one of the company's founders, said with a poker face. She quickly breaks into a smile and laughs at the thought of the tiny, anonymous firm gobbling up Hallmark, the industry leader, which reportedly notched $1.25 billion in greeting card sales last year. But Parrish and her partners, Roxie Kelly and Shelly Reeves-Smith, are serious about carving their own niche in a market ruled by huge corporations. In just a couple of years, Among Friends has expanded from selling a few cards in local shops to marketing a line of 36 all-occasion cards, gift tags, decorative bags and a card-organizing notebook in 48 states, Japan and England. The company is working to expand that line. Parrish, the company's business manager, says Among Friends tripled its sales in the past year and now has about 1,300 accounts. She refused to disclose any figures. ``We don't even want them to know we exist,'' added Reeves-Smith. Rudolf Hokanson, who tracks the greeting card industry for Blunt Ellis & Loewy in Milwaukee, said the company has one advantage: alternative cards are the fastest growing segment of the industry. ``It's impossible to say whether (Among Friends) will survive,'' Hokanson said. ``It's a competitive field, and there are a lot of quality players. Like with any business, if they have a good management team and marketing people . . . I think they've got a chance.'' The women say they are somewhat surprised at the company's limited success considering the mistakes they made in the early going. ``We knew nothing about the greeting card industry,'' Kelly recalled. ``We made some of the worst mistakes you can imagine. But the cards sold anyway. It was amazing how much people liked them.'' The women say the company name was a natural because of their long friendships. Kelly, 35, a former physical education teacher, used to own a popular restaurant and a combination gourmet bakery-gift shop at the lake. She handles marketing duties and maintains contact with about 35 sales representatives. Parrish, 49, was a hostess at the restaurant and a business partner in a cookbook Kelly wrote and sold. She keeps a close eye on the finances. The artist, Reeves-Smith, 24, was a student of Kelly's and later worked in her restaurant and bakery. A longtime friend of the Parrish family, Reeves-Smith also designed the cover of her friends' cookbook. Kelly and Parrish credit Reeves-Smith, a 1988 art graduate, for much of Among Friends' success. Reeves-Smith works with colored pencils and ink to design ``subjects that conjure up soothing, pleasant feelings, like a hat box, an old clock, a New England house - that's the style I feel most comfortable with.'' The result is detailed, intimate cards featuring a soft, water-color appearance. The message inside is often inspirational, featuring classic poems or a verse the women came up with themselves. Some contain a favorite recipe, like Kelly's blueberry-peach-cinnamon muffins. The women say that even though they work so closely together they've managed to stay good friends. ``We don't always agree, but we respect each other for our individual talents and opinions,'' Kelly said. ``We were friends before we were partners and we want it to stay that way.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday Sept. 24

DOC.HEAD: Stock Moves Higher on Word of New Offer
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. stock jumped Tuesday on a report that unions might propose a new buyout offer for as much as $3.92 billion, once again prolonging the takeover maneuvering for the parent of United Airlines. The Wall Street Journal said a union group seeking to acquire the company might propose buying it for $175 to $180 a share in cash and securities, about $20 a share less than the group's earlier $4.38 billion offer that collapsed last month. But the Journal said it could include participation by British Airways PLC, a financially powerful foreign airline that could make the takeover offer more feasible. British Airways had an equity stake in a $300-a-share offer for UAL that died last October, partly because it heavily relied on debt financing. Officials at the unions, United and British Airways declined comment on the Journal story, and industry analysts expressed skepticism about the latest reported offer. ``The lower the price the more difficult it is for the board to justify taking it, having already said $300 (per share) was adequate,'' said Robert J. Joedicke, an airlines analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. Still, word of a possible new deal boosted the value of UAL stock, which has languished since the last offer fell apart. The Journal said the unions planned to meet with banks this week to discuss the idea. UAL advanced $8.25 a share to $105.62{ in late-afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The new proposal would be the latest in a series of on-again, off-again deals for one of the nation's biggest airlines. It would be well below the $201-a-share, or $4.38 billion, offer from a labor group that UAL's board accepted last April. That pact has been scuttled by the financial uncertainty created by the crisis in the Middle East. One individual familiar with the agenda, the newspaper said, cautioned that plans for the new offer are ``still evolving and are subject to change.'' It also noted that it was unclear how the UAL board would greet a lower offer. Last month, UAL directors gave the union group until Oct. 9 to secure financing for the deal. But they also indicated that any restructured offer would have to retain the shareholder value contemplated in the $201-a-share bid made in April. Some analysts said that any participation by British Airways likely would help the unions secure additional financing. ``If that's true and if British Airways puts some equity into the deal, that will make it easier to sell to the bank group,'' said Robert Decker, an industry analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. But Decker added, ``My impression is that it's going to be difficult for the unions. I think they have to bring a done deal to the board.'' According to the newspaper, the unions have recruited First Chicago Corp. to join three other institutions as lead banks for a proposed bank credit of about $2 billion. First Chicago spokeswoman Lisabeth Weiner would neither confirm nor deny the report.

Bad news on inflation and trade unsettled the stock market today but an afternoon rebound enabled the blue chips to eke out a small gain. Two government reports released before trading opened intensified anxiety over the economy's condition. The Labor Department said consumer prices rose 0.8 percent in August, pushed up by the energy price spiral set in motion when Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. The gain in the Consumer Price Index, which was within the range of market expectations, was double the 0.4 percent rise in July and the largest since January, when a severe cold snap pushed costs up 1.1 percent. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the U.S. merchandise trade deficit jumped a dramatic 75 percent to $9.33 billion in July. ``I think we've had a whole series of economic disappointments.,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst at Oppenheimer & Co. ``The question is whether the Fed opts to fight inflation or fight a recession.'' The Federal Reserve Board is widely believed to be weighing whether to pump life into the economy by lowering interest rates. The central bank has indicated it would be inclined to relax its monetary policy if White House and congressional negotiators agree on ways to trim the budget deficit. But inflation considerations might stay the Fed's hand - especially if the Middle East crisis drags on and keeps oil prices rising. Activity in the stock market eased this afternoon from a moderate pace earlier in the session. Trading is expected to remain slow later in the week when some participants take off Thursday for Rosh Hashana, the Jewish new year.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Announces New Computer Line Based on Open Systems
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. said Tuesday it would replace its entire computer line with industry-standard machines that all could communicate with each other - a first for an old-line computer maker. The new models from a company better known for its cash registers and automated teller machines could strenghten NCR's presence in the computer industry, where it has only done well among retailing and banking customers, analysts said. ``What we are about to see is whether a standard, open-systems product line can get them into the mainstream or not,'' said Rick Martin, who follows computers for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. NCR said it would produce the entire computer line, from tiny laptop models to extremely powerful mainframes, from the same Intel Corp. computer chips. That would make NCR the first company to use the same microprocessor for a product line this broad, analysts said. Using the same microprocessor, the computer-on-a-chip that is the brain of modern computers, would make the line compatible, meaning a laptop could get at information stored on a mainframe. NCR also said the computers would run industry-standard operating systems, which control a computer's internal functions. The computer lines of most major makers - including NCR - are divided between proprietary, or company-specific, processing systems and ``open,'' or industry-standard, systems. That means various models sold by the same company often are incompatible. Applications software, such as database or word-processing programs, must be tailored to a specific operating system. If the software is designed for a proprietary system it can't be used on any other type of computer. But corporations increasingly want to be able to use the same applications software on all their machines and to connect computers in networks, which can be troublesome with incompatible models. NCR executives, speaking at a New York news conference, said their new line would address those concerns. The Dayton, Ohio-based company said it eventually would provide computers in seven ``levels,'' or ranges of performance and size. On Tuesday it announced six machines in three levels, ranging from desktop workstatons to mainframe-class machines, priced from $10,000 to $800,000. The higher-end models of the new line derive their power by linking multiple Intel microprocessors in an emerging technique called parallel processing. NCR said it will power the models planned for the top of the line by hooking together thousands of microprocessors. However, NCR didn't say when those models would be available. NCR said the most powerful model will process more than 100,000 million instructions per second, or mips, a standard measure of computing speed. By contrast, IBM's new top-of-the-line model, announced earlier this month, will operate at about 230 mips, analysts say. But operating systems and applications software need to be developed to exploit the parallel-processing technology, analysts say. Software used for standard mainframes, which have up to eight processors, would not run on machines with thousands of processors. In related news Tuesday, the Unix development unit of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said would modify the Unix operating system for use on multiple-processor computers. Unix was created by AT&T. In coming weeks, NCR said it will announce software and networking systems that will allow the new computer line to be connected throughout a company. NCR sells less than $5 billion worth of computers a year, out of a global market of $200 billion, according to the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. By comparison, IBM, the industry leader, has sales of about $60 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Stotler Securities Subsidiary Settles SEC Charges
DOC.TEXT: The government securities subsidiary of Stotler Group Inc. has lost its registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of a settlement of regulatory charges, the SEC announced Tuesday. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Stotler and Co., the affiliate of the troubled Chicago futures concern, settled an SEC administrative action brought last month. As a result, Stotler's SEC registration as a government securities broker dealer was revoked. Stotler and Co., which was also a major futures brokerage until earlier this summer when it ran into money and legal problems, settled a similar administrative action with federal futures regulators. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission still has a civil lawsuit pending against another Stotler subsidiary, Stotler Funds Inc., that alleges misuse of $5 million in customer funds. Stotler Group and Stotler and Co. last month filed for liquidation under federal bankruptcy law. Stotler Group was headed by former Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten ``Cash'' Mahlmann until a day after the CFTC sued alleged misuse of customer funds. Mahlmann, who resigned as head of the world's largest futures exchange the same day, has not been accused of any illegal activity. The SEC began administrative proceedings Aug. 21 against Stotler and Co. charging the concern with violating regulations concerning the sale of government securities. The SEC accused Stotler and Co. of selling or trying to sell government securities since November 1988 without being a member of a registered securities association, such as the National Association of Securities Dealers. The SEC also accused Stotler of failing to maintain a minimum amount of cash and assets to offset risks, the so-called net capital requirement. Stotler and Co. also was accused of not keeping proper records, including filing financial reports with the SEC. Ron Peterson, a Chicago lawyer appointed trustee of Stotler and Co. by the bankruptcy court, did not immediately return a telephone call Tuesday seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Turmoil Should Help Big Oil's Bottom Line, But Amount Unclear
DOC.TEXT: The jump in oil prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis should make big oil companies at least a little fatter, but the size of any windfalls will vary, experts say. Companies that pump plenty of their own crude should bring in the most extra cash for the third quarter. Those more heavily involved in selling refined products such as gasoline will not fare as well. Major oil companies, like other corporations, refuse to make public predictions of their earnings. But this fall, when big oil reports its profits from the weeks following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, industry observers will have a heightened interest in the bottom line. The political turmoil in the Mideast has pushed oil prices to the highest levels since the mid 1980s, and there have been warnings of a public outcry if oil companies appear to be making too much money by exploiting the situation. Analysts predict stronger earnings, although the size remains uncertain. Some say oil companies might try to lessen the potential negative publicity from higher earnings by setting aside more money into reserve funds that will be used for such items as future litigation or oil-spill containment. ``The companies are going to be very sensitive to the public view of making profits or larger profits in this environment,'' said Jim Murchie, an oil analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Inc. ``They will scour their liabilities and reserve requirements and maybe ... take larger reserves for cleanups and that kind of thing so as to serve, if you will, to dampen the reported earnings,'' Murchie said Tuesday. ``They have to not be seen to be profiteering from this, and they're really not. If you look at these earnings, they're really getting hammered at the pump.'' Although oil companies are making more money for the crude they sell, they also end up paying more for the oil they buy. The full costs of higher crude have not been passed on to consumers who buy gasoline, which cuts the profit margins of retail operations. Other industry observers doubt the companies will seek to dilute higher profits through fancy accounting techniques, saying such a move would be easily detected by critics. ``I don't think there'll be any special shenanigans among the big guys,'' said Professor James M. Patterson of the Indiana University School of Business. ``That would be so obvious that it would be more trouble for them than to just show the increased profits.'' Even though the price of oil has shot up from about $20 per barrel to more than $30 per barrel since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, analysts are divided over how much money that will mean for the majors. ``For companies that are sensitive to crude oil prices, it's going to be very good,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``For refiners it's going to be temporarily lower. For the quarter, they haven't been able to pass on all the increase.'' Robin Shoemaker at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. does not think the companies will be able to turn profits that are notably bigger. ``In terms of earnings, they're going to show very modest if any improvement over the second quarter,'' Shoemaker said. But even companies that are heavily involved in the less-profitable businesses such as retail gasoline sales should come out of the oil crisis with a better bottom line, Patterson said. ``Basically, there's been a windfall due to the increase in price and the increase in demand as well,'' Patterson said.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Workers Union Head Renews Call for National Energy Union
DOC.TEXT: United Mine Workers President Richard Trumka, rebuffed in efforts to merge with the main oil industry union, said Tuesday a national energy union is the only way to win concessions from big business. Trumka, addressing the UMW's 100th anniversary convention, said only a unified labor organization can combat multinational oil and coal conglomerates with diversified interests. He said it unions had to ``do what we must to challenge those corporate Goliaths on their own turf, not only as the union of the coal fields, but as the union of energy workers.'' Dividing workers in oil, coal, power and petrochemical industries ``is the modern equivalent of craft unionism,'' Trumka said, referring to the policy of having a separate union for every task at a job site. At its 1986 convention, the UMW gave its governing body, the International Executive Board, authority to seek a merger with other energy unions. A proposed merger with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers, however, collapsed in 1987 when the OCAW's board balked at the proposal. Talks between the unions later resumed, but the two sides were unable to reach an agreement before the coal miners' convention began Monday. Also Tuesday, the UMW's chief financial officer asked the 1,000 convention delegates for permission to use interest from a strike fund to pay legal, advertising and negotiating costs associated with strikes. The strike fund, at $57.4 million as of Aug. 31, was set up during the 1983 convention, but it was limited to paying strike benefits directly to miners. UMW Secretary-Treasurer John Banovic said those pay and health benefits totaled $5 million during 1989, including payments to workers during the 10-month strike against The Pittston Co. in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky that ended last February. But he said the total cost of strikes in 1989 was $60 million to $70 million. In addition, the union faces $52 million in fines levied by a Virginia judge for Pittston-related strike activities. Banovic said the strike fund generates about $4 million a year at current interest rates. Delegates are to vote later on that proposal, plus another that would give the union's international executive board authority to close or merge some of the 21 union districts in the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: African Producers Call for Return of Export Quotas
DOC.TEXT: African countries Tuesday appealed for the return of export quotas to lift and stabilize the depressed price of coffee, because of the huge losses they are suffering in the present free market for beans. The objective of the continent's producers was a new International Coffee Agreement among exporting and importing countries to regulate supplies and prices, said Filomeno Ceita, the Angolan president of the 25-nation Inter-African Coffee Organization. He said African producing countries had lost $1.2 billion in export revenue since the suspension 15 months ago of the present coffee agreement's export quota system, which stabilized prices by matching supplies to demand. Colombia - the world's second-biggest producer behind Brazil - also wanted to see quotas back under a new pact, said Jorge Cardenas, the country's chief coffee executive. The main obstacle to the opening of negotiations on a new coffee pact was uncertainty over Brazil's position, said Ceita, who is attending a two-week meeting here of the 72-nation International Coffee Organization. No new pact could work effectively without the participation of the world's biggest producer and exporter, delegates said. Brazil is expected to disclose its attitude toward calls for negotiations on a new international agreement next week, when the head of its delegation arrives for producer-consumer talks. The coffee organization meeting opened Sept. 17, and is scheduled to end Sept. 28. The present coffee agreement, which lacks powers to regulate supplies and prices, expires Sept. 30, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Tumble After Squeeze Fails to Develop
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange after an expected rally linked to the expiration of copper options in London failed to materialize. On other commodity markets, precious metals, energy futures, grains and soybeans, and livestock and meat futures all were mixed. Copper futures settled 2.35 cents to 3.95 cents lower in Chicago with the contract for delivery in September at $1.30 a pound. The September contract traded as low as $1.282 a pound during the session, following a sharp decline on the London Metal Exchange that analysts attributed to disappointed selling by traders who had expected strong gains. Those expectations stemmed from perceptions that a ``squeeze'' or partial corner of the copper market was developing in London, where options on September copper deliveries are nearing expiration. But analysts said it became apparent Tuesday that the squeeze play had fizzled, prompting many traders who had bet on higher prices to exit the market. ``They all started liquidating because it wasn't going up,'' said Susan Kashan, a copper trading assistant with PaineWebber Inc. in New York. She said selling accelerated when the heavily traded December contract hit $1.23 a pound, 4.75 cents below Monday's settlement. December copper fell as low as $1.217 before bouncing back to end at $1.24. William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch said copper's supply-and-demand factors remain bullish, although the market has fallen substantially since the spot price represented by the September contract reached a 12-month high of $1.384 a pound on Sept. 12. O'Neill said Tuesday's action was typical. ``We hear talk all the time of these types of squeezes, both in London and New York,'' he said. ``Normally the fears are exaggerated and this is such a case.'' Gold futures fell moderately on the Commodity Exchange, ending a five-day rally amid selling that O'Neill attributed to a lack of significant developments in the Persian Gulf. Gold settled $1.40 to $1.90 lower with September at $387.60 a troy ounce; silver was 2.4 cents to 2.8 cents higher with September at $4.79 a troy ounce. Near-term crude oil futures ended modestly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange while contracts for deferred deliveries rose. The pattern was similar in the gasoline market but heating oil futures advanced strongly. Some of the action reflected positioning ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report, which was released after the close. The report showed a larger-than-expected decline in U.S. supplies of crude oil and an unexpected increase in gasoline stocks. Heating oil supplies rose, as expected. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 22 cents lower to 53 cents higher with October at $33.41 a barrel; heating oil was 1.12 cents to 1.44 cents higher with October at 86.43 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .22 cent lower to .81 cent higher with October at 91.61 cents a gallon. Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, recovering most of the ground lost in the previous session amid talk of possible frost in the Midwest early next week. Most corn futures also advanced but wheat futures retreated slightly. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1{ cents lower with September at $2.59{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.37 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents higher across the board with September at $1.10} a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 7 cents higher with September at $6.22{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures ended mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of Wednesday's monthly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report. The report is expected to show about a 4 percent increase over a year ago in the number of cattle on feedlots in the seven largest producing states. Live cattle settled unchanged to .20 cent higher with October at 79.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .08 cent higher with September at 89.25 cents apound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .47 cent higher with October at 53.47 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .13 cent lower to .17 cent higher with February at 56.82 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises in New York After Overseas Drop; Gold Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded on domestic markets Tuesday after falling in response to a disappointing U.S. trade report. Gold prices were mostly lower, rising only in Hong Kong trading overnight. The dollar dropped after the government reported the trade deficit climbed to $9.33 billion in July from June's revised $5.34 billion. The shortfall was nearly $2 billion greater than forecast. Robert Hatcher, a foreign exchange dealer at Barclays Bank PLC in New York, said the dollar was supported in part by rumors that negotiators in Washington are nearing an agreement to reduce the federal budget deficit by $50 billion. Dealers also said the dollar gained for technical reasons including buying by traders adjusting their holdings. But most of Tuesday's activity focused on other currencies, especially the Japanese yen, which fell sharply, reversing a recent upward trend. The yen has been on a roller-coaster lately, plunging after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and then recovering as Japanese investments regained their appeal. Hatcher said there were again concerns in the market that Japan, which imports 99 percent of its oil, would be hurt economically by the surge in oil prices that has resulted from the Persian Gulf crisis. The dollar gained more than 1 yen Tuesday, closing at 137.75 yen in New York, compared with 136.55 yen late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 137.68 yen from 137.00 yen Monday, and in London, the dollar was quoted at 137.55 yen. Despite the dollar's gains Tuesday, Hatcher warned, ``We are still in a speculative market.'' He said traders were waiting to see what moves the Federal Reserve might make to bring U.S. interest rates down as the economy weakens. In the meantime, ``there's a lot of churning but no real trending,'' Hatcher said, predicting the U.S. currency would remain in a broad trading range. The dollar was unchanged against the British pound in New York, where sterling closed at $1.9140. In London earlier, the pound rose to $1.9190 from $1.9025 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.5525 German marks, up from 1.54865; 1.2900 Swiss francs, up from 1.2768; 5.1995 French francs, up from 5.1870; 1,162.50 Italian lire, up from 1,1160.00; and 1.5895 Canadian dollars, up from 1.5725. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.5480 German marks, down from 1.5575; 1.2825 Swiss francs, down from 1.2865; 5.1845 French francs, down from 5.2160; 1.7535 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7550; 1,160.00 Italian lire, down from 1,165.00, and 1.1573 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1593. Gold fell in New York, where a troy ounce of gold lost $1.80 to close at $387.60 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $388.10, down $2.40 In London, gold fell to a late bid of $388.25 a troy ounce from $389.75 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $387.80 an ounce from $389 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.48 an ounce to close at $389.85. Silver prices rose. Silver gained 2.4 cents and closed at $4.790 on the Commodity Exchange, and it advanced in London to a late bid of $4.82 a troy ounce, up from $4.78 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING
Stock Market Mixed, Helped by Afternoon Rebound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS day to Tuesday from Thursday in 14th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market chalked up scattered gains Tuesday, thanks to an afternoon rebound amid renewed optimism about the chances for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which was off more than 20 points at 2 p.m. on Wall Street, closed up 3.96 points at 2,571.29. It briefly sported a double-digit gain in the last hour of a volatile session. Broader market measures finished with negative readings, however. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 626 up, 854 down and 501 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board expanded to 141.13 million shares from 110.60 million Monday and the highest daily total since 160.15 million on Aug. 27. Activity on Wall Street is expected to slow later this week when some traders take off for Rosh Hashana, the Jewish new year, on Thursday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 169.44 million shares. Two government reports released before trading opened intensified anxiety over the economy's condition. The Labor Department said consumer prices rose 0.8 percent in August, pushed up by the energy price spiral set in motion when Iraq seized Kuwait. The increase in the Consumer Price Index, which was within the range of market estimates, was double the 0.4 percent rise in July and the largest since January, when a severe cold snap pushed costs up 1.1 percent. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the U.S. merchandise trade deficit jumped a dramatic 75 percent to $9.33 billion in July. ``I think we've had a whole series of economic disappointments.,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst at Oppenheimer & Co. ``The question is whether the Fed opts to fight inflation or fight a recession.'' The Federal Reserve Board is widely believed to be weighing whether to pump life into the economy by lowering interest rates. The central bank has indicated it would be inclined to relax its monetary policy if White House and congressional negotiators agree on ways to trim the budget deficit. Inflation considerations might stay the Fed's hand, especially if the Middle East crisis drags on and keeps oil prices rising. But a steep drop Tuesday afternoon in a key interest rate influenced by the Fed sparked speculation that the central bank already was easing. The federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other on overnight loans, fell to 6\ percent from around 8 percent recently. The decline spurred buying enthusiasm for bonds, which spilled over into the stock market. Rumors that Chase Manhattan was having trouble placing its commercial paper temporarily unsettled the market, sending various measures to session lows. Chase denied the rumors and said its funding activities were running normally. Chase stock suffered anyway, sliding ~ to 15 on volume of more than 1.58 million shares. UAL soared 7| to 105. The Wall Street Journal reported that a group of United Airlines unions plans to meet with banks this week to discuss a new offer for United's parent, UAL Corp. The newspaper said the offer could amount to $175 a share to $180 a share. Among active blue chips, International Business Machines advanced 2[ to 107\. But Primerica, another component of the Dow Jones industrial average, tumbled 2| to 23[ amid talk about possible weakness in the company's consumer finance operation. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $1.44 billion, or 0.05 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added 0.26 to 174.88. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.88 to 376.71, and S&P's 500-stock composite index increased 0.83 to 318.60. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.90 to 372.21. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 319.69, off 2.02.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Chief Indicted, Jailed in Securities Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with additional background, civil cases, possibility of restitution, quote from DA; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Also indicted ...' SUBS 16th graf pvs, `District Attorney ... ' to DELETE now redundant first reference to DA. Also moving on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Keating-Chronology; AM-Keating Profile
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Charles H. Keating, the man blamed by the government for the nation's biggest savings and loan collapse, was jailed in lieu of $5 million bail Tuesday after he was indicted on criminal fraud charges. It was the first criminal case filed against Keating, who has become a symbol of the national thrift scandal because of his high pay, lavish personal habits, investments in risky real estate and junk bonds, and alleged use of accounting gimmickry to conceal wrongdoing. The former chairman of American Continental Corp. and three other executives were charged in a 42-count state indictment with selling securities by false statements or omissions, selling securities without qualifications and lying to the California Department of Corporations. The department approved the sale of the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds, technically known as unsecured debentures, at branches of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, which Keating controlled through American Continental. More than $200 million worth of junk bonds were sold to 22,000 investors, many of them elderly. ``I don't know how many bondholders are out there ... but they're dancing in the street tonight. We'd like to get our money back,'' bondholder Shirley Lampel said Monday after the district attorney's office said it had completed its presentation to a special state grand jury. The government seized control of Lincoln in April 1989. Regulators estimate the bailout could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion. Last month, a federal judge in Washington upheld the government takeover of Lincoln, saying the operation of the thrift by Keating and others ``amounted to looting.'' Keating already is charged in several civil cases, including a $1.1 billion racketeering case filed by the agency responsible for the thrift bailout. The federal government is conducting a separate criminal investigation into the alleged looting of Lincoln. The indictment was handed up late last week but kept sealed until Tuesday. It focuses on 20 alleged victims, a case narrow enough that Los Angeles District Attorney Ira Reiner said it could be presented without confusing a jury. ``We could have named 22,000 victims,'' Reiner said. ``But that would have created an unwieldy case that would have gone on forever and a day.'' The felony charges do not seek to recover money for the bond buyers, but a judge could theoretically order restitution as part of sentencing if Keating and the others are convicted, prosecutors said. Keating, 66, a Phoenix developer, has contended that the government has attempted to make a scapegoat out of him because he was an outspoken critic of the thrift regulatory system. He maintains the bondholders would never have lost money if the government hadn't seized Lincoln last year and forced American Continental into bankruptcy court. Also indicted were Judy Elizabeth Wischer, 42, of Paradise Valley, Ariz., former president of American Continental; Ray Charles Fidel, 32, of Newport Beach, former president of Lincoln; and Robin Scott Symes, 37, of Malvern, Ohio, former chief executive officer of Lincoln. All four appeared in Los Angeles County Superior Court but Judge Gary Klousner postponed their arraignment to Oct. 5 because they had not yet read the indictment. Klousner ordered all four held. Bail was set at $1 million apiece for Wischer, Fidel and Symes. Five U.S. senators who received campaign contributions from Keating are currently under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee. The ``Keating Five'' - Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz., and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. - helped arrange a meeting between Keating and federal regulators during the time before the savings and loan collapsed. Symes' attorney, Don Smaltz, called the bail amounts ``outrageous,'' saying they were motivated only by hysteria and politics of the case. The judge said it appeared that if convicted ``the maximum exposure of each defendant would be approximately 10 years'' in prison. Keating has frequently said he is broke and that friends are paying the mortgage on his Paradise Valley, Ariz., home. Reiner said the investigation revealed that elderly Lincoln Savings investors were regularly steered into risky American Continental securities when it came time to renew certificates of deposits. ``They put their money in Lincoln Savings, they put their faith in them,'' Reiner said. He declined to describe in detail how the bonds were misrepresented. Asked what happened to the investors' money, Reiner said: ``The money was transferred to American Continental and from there to Mr. Keating.'' The Department of Corporations has already sued Keating on behalf of the investors. However, the bondholders themselves at one point filed a claim against the department, saying it should never have allowed the bonds to be sold in the Lincoln branches because they ``constituted an extreme risk to the investing public.''

DOC.HEAD: Agreement May Signal New Era of Cooperation, Details Delayed
With AM-Auto Talks-Reax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with report; PICKS UP 13th graf pvs, The absence . . .
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will spend $4.2 billion to protect employees' incomes but remains free to close factories under a tentative agreement with the United Auto Workers union, a newspaper reported. In an industry threatened by a sluggish economy and growing foreign competition, the three-year pact reached after a weekend of round-the-clock negotiations signaled to some the dawning of a new era in U.S. automaking. ``We feel the spirit we developed during the negotiations bodes well for General Motors, the customer and the marketplace,'' said GM Vice President Alfred Warren. Many on the union side, too, were hopeful, even though details of the three-year pact were delayed until Tuesday. ``I was kind of scared we were going to be off today, but since we settled I'm glad,'' said J.D. Boatman, 61, a worker at GM's Cadillac plant in Detroit. The last major strike was six years ago when the union struck selected GM plants for a week. The Detroit Free Press reported in its Tuesday editions that the agreement contains $4.2 billion in income guarantees, eliminates weak plant-closing prohibitions from the previous agreement and increases wages by 3 percent the first year. The agreement also provides for lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years and increases monthly pensions from $1,500 to $1,800 for workers who retire after 30 years, according to union and company officials who spoke to the newspaper on the condition of anonymity. Health insurance provisions remain unchanged, the officials said. The union and the No. 1 U.S. automaker negotiated well past the midnight Friday expiration of the old contract and produced a tentative settlement after 41 hours of nonstop talks. UAW President Owen Bieber said details of the agreement had to be delayed until the information could get out to the 300,000 affected union members. The tentative settlement was announced after 2 a.m. ``Therefore, we couldn't proceed without having the normal material that we would provide for them before they made a decision on the recommended agreement,'' he said. About 300 members of the UAW's GM bargaining council met privately in suburban Dearborn Monday, but postponed review of the agreement until Tuesday morning in Detroit. The absence of public posturing was conspicuous in these talks, which were conducted under a news blackout in the final stages. But GM and the UAW may need all the cordiality they can muster to get through the next three years. GM faces the prospect of shrinking its number of factories - many analysts believe it will have to close at least four assembly plants - and reducing its hourly work force by tens of thousands of people. Bieber told a predawn news conference he was ``very, very satisfied'' with the agreement on pensions, and GM vice president Alfred Warren said the contract gives the company latitude to reduce its work force. Across the border in Canada, where the Canadian Auto Workers and Ford Motor Co. have been negotiating a new contract, relations were more strained. The CAW struck Ford's Canadian operation Saturday, but electe not to break off talks after learning that the company would offer a revised package Tuesday. CAW President Bob White had said if an offer was not forthcoming, he would recess the talks on Wednesday. Ford spokesman Jim Hartford said the offer would include new economic proposals. Because of the lack of details reported on the U.S. agreement, it was difficult to tell what kind of effect the settlement would have on the economy or on pending contract negotiations with Ford and Chrysler Corp. GM common stock closed down 37{ cents to $37.12{ on the New York Stock Exchange. The GM bargaining council, made up of union presidents and bargaining committee chairs, will vote on the tentative pact before it's sent to the rank and file for formal ratification. That process is expected to be completed by the end of the month. If ratified, the contract will be used by the union as a model for agreements with Ford and Chrysler. Union agreements with those two companies, which cover more than 150,000 active workers, also expired at midnight Friday. The union put talks with those automakers on hold pending the outcome of the GM ratification vote. It was expected that Ford would have little trouble matching the GM-UAW agreement. But there was a question for Chrysler, which is in the worst financial shape of the Big Three and may report a loss in the third quarter. The average hourly wage with cost of living adjustments for GM workers is about $15.75 under the expired 1987 agreement. Fringe benefits, particularly health care costs, boost that to nearly $30 per hour, the company has said. At Ford, the figure is about $31 per hour, and Chrysler's was just more than $33.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Members Buoyed by Tentative Deal, Anxious for Details
With AM-Auto Talks Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf with 3 grafs to UPDATE with report; PICK UP 10th graf pvs, Local officials . . .
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union members expressed relief Monday at news of a tentative agreement with General Motors Corp., but many were anxious to learn if the union won more job security. ``They're elated,'' Roger Smith, an alternate committeeman at Local 22 in Detroit, said of members' reaction to the proposed three-year contract reached early Monday. ``They're hoping our president comes back and tells us we've got a good agreement.'' Smith, a quality operator at GM's Cadillac plant and a 26-year union member, is one of about 300,000 UAW-covered workers who worried over the weekend about the negotiations. The 1987 agreement expired at midnight Friday, but was extended while bargainers worked on a new deal, details of which are to be announced Tuesday. UAW contracts at Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. also expired at midnight Friday. The union targeted the No. 1 automaker to reach a contract it could use as a pattern for pacts with Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. After 41 hours of bargaining, UAW President Owen Bieber announced at 2:10 a.m. Monday that negotiators had reached an agreement. ``I was kind of scared we were going to be off today, but since we settled I'm glad,'' said J.D. Boatman, 61, a worker at GM's Cadillac plant in Detroit. The union's 300-member GM bargaining council met in suburban Dearborn on Monday to get a look at the deal. But Bieber rescheduled the meeting for Tuesday because copies of the lengthy agreement still were being printed. If the contract is approved by the council, it will be sent to rank-and-file members for ratification, a process expected to be completed by the end of the month. Details haven't been officially announced, but The Detroit Free Press reported in its Tuesday editions that the agreement contains $4.2 billion in income guarantees, eliminates weak plant-closing prohibitions from the previous agreement and increases wages by 3 percent the first year. The agreement also provides for lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years and increases monthly pensions from $1,500 to $1,800 for workers who retire after 30 years, according to union and company officials who spoke to the newspaper on the condition of anonymity. Health insurance provisions remain unchanged, the officials said. Local officials said Monday they were anxious to hear what gains - if any - had been made. ``We're all starving for information over here,'' said Joe Garcia, financial secretary for Local 645 in Van Nuys, Calif.. ``We want to know what kind of job security they have to offer, what kind of wage increases, what kind of pension increases, what kind of incentives for people that want to retire. ``Those are just some of the questions that are floating in our minds now waiting to be answered.'' Paramount among the union's concerns was job security, an emotional issue in an industry with a history of unexpectedly severe layoffs. ``It's hard to send kids to college when you don't have a paycheck,'' said Local 22 Vice President Frank Serazio, who has seen his local's membership fall from almost 12,000 in 1978 to 5,200 in 1990. In 1987, the UAW built on job-security language introduced in 1984 which prohibited closing a factory unless its product or products suffered a slump in sales. Since then, GM has closed four assembly plants - one each in Atlanta; Framingham, Mass.; Leeds, Mo.; and Pontiac, Mich. UAW members have said they felt betrayed by the automaker. The union challenged the closing of the Pontiac plant before an arbitrator, but lost. Serazio said the 1987 ``plant-idling'' agreement - which has allowed almost 9,000 layoffs - was stressed in this year's talks. Serazio added that union Vice President Stephen Yokich, the UAW's top negotiator at GM, wouldn't let the UAW ``be entrapped in terminology that not everybody has a clear idea on - like plant idling.'' Paul Mitchell, financial secretary of Local 645 in Lake Orion, agreed. ``That really killed us in 1987,'' he said. ``The language wasn't defined. So I would hope and pray that they did try to redefine the meaning of different terms.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Dismisses Antitrust Suit Against Comsat
DOC.TEXT: A Connecticut-based satellite company said Tuesday it would appeal a federal court's dismissal of the firm's $1.5 billion antitrust suit against Comsat Corp. Pan American Satellite said the suit was dismissed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan on grounds that Comsat, a congressionally created corporation, was immune from such antitrust suits. Rene Anselmo, the chairman of Pan American, said ``It's just a question of law ... I would expect we would prevail on appeal.'' Pan American, based in Greenwich, Conn., filed suit in July 1989, charging Comsat with fixing prices and blocking competition for international satellite communications services. Comsat, which stands for Communications Satellite Corp., sells to U.S. companies access to Intelsat, the 117-nation consortium of satellite telecommunications users. Pan American Satellite is the first privately owned international satellite communications company. Anselmo established Pan American in 1984 after then-President Reagan signed a presidential determination that it would be in the national interest to allow so-called alternative satellite systems such as PAS to compete with Comsat and Intelsat. Pan American launched its PAS-1 satellite in June 1988 and began service in September to Latin America and Europe. Congress created Comsat in the Communications Satellite Act of 1962. Comsat is a private, publicly traded company that leases Intelsat circuits to companies such as American Telephone & Telegraph Co., MCI, US Sprint and television networks. Pan American's suit sought $500 million in actual damages, which would be tripled under federal law, and a permanent injunction enjoining Comsat from engaging in alleged illegal activities.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Photo CD Good Development For Kodak
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co.'s new photographic compact disc system is a shrewd move to preserve the company's traditional film market while taking advantage of new electronic technologies, industry watchers said Tuesday. ``Concerns about the threat to Kodak from electronic imaging will subside for a while,'' said Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. The Photo CD system, introduced Tuesday at news conferences in New York, London, Tokyo and Rochester, is being developed jointly with Dutch electronics company N.V. Philips. The system stores photographic images from standard 35 millimeter film onto compact discs, and the pictures can then be replayed on television screens. The system will be available in 1992, Kodak said. As was obvious at Kodak's product demonstration, photographs taken on film are still far superior to those taken electronically. ``Nothing even remotely comes close to conventional film and photo papers in terms of quality and price,'' said Barry Harrand, director of marketing research for the Michigan-based Photo Marketing Association. The Photo CD system is Kodak's first consumer product that combines conventional picture-taking with the conveniences of electronics, Glazer said. Investors have been concerned about the threat posed to Kodak's basic silver-halide film business by new technologies, he said. ``They've essentially successfully defended the role of silver halide technology as the capture medium,'' said Mark Obenzinger, an analyst with Trinity Trading Co. Most analysts said it was too early to predict how many people will want to watch their photographs on television. There may be more demand for the system's applications in desktop publishing, said financial analyst Brenda Landry of New York's Morgan Stanley. Kodak officials said the system could be made accessible to almost any computer. ``It can make virtually any computer an electronic, full-color photo editing workstation,'' said Larry Matteson, vice president and general manager of Kodak's Imaging Information Systems. Obenzinger said the system is well-priced for both consumers and photofinishers. Kodak estimated that the photo disc players, which would also plays audio discs, would cost less than $500, while the discs would cost less than $20. The photofinishing system, including a disc-writer, computer, thermal printer, would cost about $100,000, Kodak said. A 1988 survey by the Photo Marketing Association showed that 57 percent of Americans would be interested in looking at their photographs on television, Harrand said. Harrand said he expects to see all kinds of hybrid technologies introduced onto the photographic market in the next few years. He said he expects such systems should expand the market for photo sales as consumers gain more control over what they can do with their photographs.

DOC.HEAD: Corroon & Black Rejects Aon Offer
DOC.TEXT: Corroon & Black Corp. on Tuesday rejected an unsolicited $840 million takeover bid from Aon Corp., saying it would proceed with its proposed merger with fellow insurer Willis Faber PLC of Britain. Corroon & Black said the planned stock-swap merger ``will serve the best interests of our shareholders, customers and employees.'' Aon, the holding company for the brokerage Rollins Burdick Hunter Group Inc., offered last week to buy Corroon & Black for $40 a share in cash, or about $840 million. Under the approved agreement, Corroon & Black stockholders would receive 7.8 Willis Faber shares for each Corroon & Black share, or $33.49 at current market prices, in a deal valued at $754 million. Corroon & Black shareholders are scheduled to vote on the merger with Willis Faber on Sept. 28. Aon officials could not be reached for comment Tuesday evening shortly after Corroon & Black issued its response. Corroon & Black stock closed at $35.50, down 37{ cents a share, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading Tuesday before the company's announcement. Aon said last week it would not pursue a bid opposed by the Corroon & Black board. Noting that statement, Corroon & Black said it ``has replied to Aon Corp. that it wishes to consider the matter closed and proceed with the merger with Willis Faber.'' Insurance industry analysts expected Corroon & Black to reject Aon's offer, but they said Aon might come back with a higher bid. Corroon & Black and Willis Faber are the world's fifth- and sixth-largest insurance brokerages, respectively. Their tentative merger, announced in early June, would allow both firms to expand in the other's home market and eventually move into continental Europe and the Pacific Rim. The new firm, Britain-based Willis Corroon PLC, was expected to have 1990 revenue of about $1 billion. It would create the world's fourth-largest insurance brokerage in terms of revenue. Corroon & Black has nearly all its business in the United States, while Willis Faber gets about 80 percent of its revenue from Britain. Corroon & Black sold its 29.9 percent interest in the British broker Minet Holdings PLC in February 1988. Aon has operations in the United States, Canada, Europe and the Pacific. Besides Rollins Burdick, its subsidiaries include Combined Insurance Co. of America and Union Fidelity Life Insurance Co.

DOC.HEAD: Amdahl Announces `Most Powerful' IBM-Compatible Computers
DOC.TEXT: Amdahl Corp., a maker of IBM-compatible mainframe computers, announced a new line Tuesday it said includes the most powerful computers ever for the IBM market. The top model of the 10-model line will include eight processors - two more than International Business Machines Corp. says will be in its next-generation mainframe due out next year. According to International Data Corp., a market research firm, Amdahl's new top model will process about 332 million instructions per second, or mips, a standard computer performance measurement. By contrast, IBM's new top model, announced Sept. 5, will run at about 203 mips, IDC says. But IBM's new model will be available in the third quarter of 1991, while Amdahl's won't be ready until the second quarter of 1992, said Peter Burris, an IDC analyst. Amdahl said its new top-of-the-line model, priced at about $32 million, will be the first for the IBM market to use eight processors, which are the ``brains'' of computers. The other maker of IBM-compatible mainframes, Hitachi Data Systems Corp., announced its next-generation high-end model in June. That four-processor machine, to be available next spring, will run at about 150 mips, IDC says. Mainframe computers are used by large corporations to manage hugh amounts of data, such as millions of customer accounts at an insurance company or reservations at an airline. Since mainframes are so costly, companies must make long-range plans for their purchase, Burris said. But he said Amdahl's announcement of a top-end model that won't be ready for more than a year and a half may be too much lead time. Amdahl, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is 43 percent owned by Japan's Fujitsu Ltd. Hitachi Data Systems is partially owned by Hitachi Ltd., another Japanese electronics company. Hitachi and Amdahl traditionally undercut IBM's prices, and their share of the U.S. mainframe market has grown while IBM's slipped in recent years. But IBM still holds about 87 percent of the U.S. high-end mainframe market, according to Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., research firm.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine's List of Best Companies For Working Moms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with one graf to CORRECT to Working Mother magazine; PICK UP 2nd graf pvs, The magazine . . .
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Working Mother-List
DOC.TEXT: The best companies for women offer child care assistance and ``family-friendly'' leave policies, Working Mother magazine said Tuesday in releasing its fifth annual roster of the top employers for working mothers. The magazine didn't rank the companies from best to worst, but cited 10 for exceptionally progressive policies: Apple Computer; Boston's Beth Israel teaching hospital; Du Pont, the chemical company; Fel-Pro, a supplier to the auto industry; HBO; IBM; Merck, the drug maker; Morrison & Foerster, a San Francisco law firm; Procter & Gamble, and SAS Institute, a computer software company. All 75 companies on the 1990 list offered some form of child care program or assistance and long-term unpaid leaves with benefits, some stretching up to three years, the magazine said its in October issue. More than half provide child care either in or near the workplace, 20 percent help with care for aging relatives, and a growing number are offering paid paternity leaves of at least one week. The latest list was expanded to 75 companies from the 60 a year earlier and more than double the 30 companies that appeared in the initial ranking published in 1986. Deputy Editor Susan Seliger said the expansion reflected the increased number of companies that have grown sensitive to the needs of the working mother, one of the fastest growing segments of the American work force. ``These people see the writing on the wall, and it doesn't matter if they're small or large,'' she said. The companies were evaluated on compensation, opportunities for women to advance, support for child care and family-oriented benefits such as parental leave, flexible working hours, job-sharing and working at home. Among what the magazine called the more forward-looking programs were IBM's commitment to spend $22 million on child care and $3 million on elderly care over the next five years; Du Pont's network of child-care centers and a sick-care center near its Wilmington, Del., headquarters; and Fel-Pro's in-home tutoring and $1,000 bond for newborns. Other companies not on the top 10 also were singled out for innovation. America West Airlines offers a 24-hour child care center; Stride Rite, the children's shoe company, has established what the magazine called the country's only intergenerational center caring for both children and elderly relatives of employees; and Lost Arrow, a maker of outdoor clothes, provides up to eight weeks of paid paternity leave. The smallest company on the list, G.T. Water Products of Moorpark, Calif., provides an on-site school for children of its 32 employees. Women hold three of the four top management positions at the company, which makes drain cleaning products for the plumbing industry. Seliger said the list was based on a survey of the benefits and practices of hundreds of companies by author Milton Moskowitz and researcher Carol Townsend, who also worked together on the book The 100 Best Companies to Work For in America. The magazine noted that the companies offering pro-family benefits believe they are good for business. ``SAS Institute, which runs two 100 percent subsidized child care centers, currently has a turnover rate of 7 percent, less than one third the 24 percent average in the software industry,'' the magazine said. It noted that the fastest growing segment of the work force was mothers of chidren under the age of 6, according to government figures. The magazine predicted that by 1995, two thirds of mothers with preschoolers and three quarters of mothers with school-age kids will be working.

DOC.HEAD: Continental to Contribute to Eastern Pension Plan
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines, Eastern's parent company, on Tuesday agreed to immediately pay $80 million to an Eastern pension plan underfunded by as much as $720 million, the government said. Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. also agreed to shoulder most of the future financial responsibility for the plan, the government said. Under the settlement, Continental will pay $80.5 million to cover part of a payment that had been due Monday to Eastern's pension plan, said the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., the federal agency that guarantees pension payments. Eastern, now in the midst of bankruptcy proceedings, has also agreed to pay $30 million by Jan. 15, the PBGC said. Continental has agreed to assume responsibility for about $600 million in remaining underfunded liabilities, less whatever amount the PBGC gets back from its bankruptcy claims, the agency said. PBGC, which had faced a potential loss of nearly $720 million in Eastern pension liabilities, said it would not suffer a loss under the agreement. The deal provides full uninterrupted pension benefits to Eastern's 51,000 workers and retirees, PBGC said. Under the plan, PBGC will terminate seven Eastern pension plans and take over the plans. ``While we believed Continental could assume the yeoman's share of the pension debt, in the interest of fairness and to prevent an unreasonable risk that Continental could not afford the total obligation, some payment was required from Eastern,'' Diane Burkley, the PBGC's deputy executive director, said of the agreement. Negotiators had been working on the matter for nine months, she said. PBGC will establish a separate trust to hold pension assets and to receive the Eastern and Continental payments. It is expected that several of the plans will be funded within a couple of years with the rest fully funded by the year 2002, the PBGC said. The agreement must be submitted to a federal bankruptcy court in New York for approval. PBGC said it would terminate the pension plans in October.

DOC.HEAD: Jobs Announces New Products, Predicts Bright Future For Company
DOC.TEXT: A jubilant Steve Jobs on Tuesday showed off new hardware and software for his Next computer, products he predicted would boost his stalled company to the forefront of the industry in the 1990s. About 2,000 Next Computer Inc. employees, users and industry representatives cheered as the computer pioneer unveiled faster, more powerful versions of Jobs' sleek black cube. They sported floppy disks, built-in networking, color-and-video displays and price tags starting at $4,995 - half that of the current model. Speaking on the same Davies Symphony Hall stage where he announced the Next computer two years ago, Jobs also said more than 100 new applications would be shipped by the end of the year. ``This is the future of Next,'' Jobs said. ``We're going to show you some of the neatest applications for any desktop platform . . . the best color that's ever been.'' The new products answer Next users and critics who complained the Next workstation was too slow and too expensive and lacked a floppy disk, color monitor or adequate software, Jobs said. Customers have listened, he said. The company got 15,000 orders for the new hardware during a two-month period in which prospective customers tested prototypes, Jobs said. ``If we can do that in 60 days - you can do the math,'' he smiled. Jobs, who co-founded Apple Computer Inc. and led the development of the Macintosh, introduced Next at a glitzy, standing-room-only presentation in October 1988. The machine featured sharp graphics, high-quality sound and built-in software making it easier to use the system and write programs for it. Jobs called Next ``the best computer in the world'' and predicted it would revolutionize personal computers. But it was a year before shipments started, and sales have been slow. Because it is privately owned, Next is not obliged to disclose earnings or sales, but International Data Corp., a high-tech research firm, estimates that fewer than 7,000 Nexts were sold as of June. Users and analysts who attended the presentation and product fair said Jobs was moving in the right direction, particularly with the combination of desirable features and a lower price. ``I think it is a very impressive machine. I think that the pricing strategy has them at the right point. Five thousand (dollars) with its capacity is pretty aggressive,'' said John Nguyen, an analyst with Sutro & Co. Inc. in San Francisco. The four new pieces of Next hardware are based on Motoroa's 68040 microprocessor, which Jobs said was at least three times faster than the Motorola 68030 used in earlier models. The updated boxes also feature floppy disks as standard. The originals stored data on a removable optical disk, which provided greater capacity but were criticized as costlier and less flexible. Optical disks are offered as an option on the new machines. Two models with black-and-white monitors - including the $4,995 Nextstation system - will be ready the first quarter of 1991. A $7,995 color version and a $3,995 color board are expected to be available in the first quarter of 1991. New software includes a new, more flexible spreadsheet by Lotus Development Corp., creator of the popular 1-2-3 program. Unlike earlier ones, the new application, dubbed Improv, enables users to click a mouse to move about information and plain English formulas. Improv, $695, will be offered free to anyone who buys a new Next product by the end of the year, Jim Manzi, Lotus' president and chief executive officer. Other new software for Next includes programs by WordPerfect Corp., which has about 70 percent of the word-processing market, Adobe, SAS Institute, Imagine Inc., Sybase Inc. and Oracle.

DOC.HEAD: GM Buys Itself a UAW Contract
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `-Must be...,' to ADD that job bank is just for life of contract; INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf pvs, `-Continued cost...,' to ADD pay figures. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `Bargaining Council...
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. threw more than $4 billion at the United Auto Workers to mollify labor and clear the way for closing unprofitable plants under a three-year deal the union's bargaining council approved Tuesday. The world's largest automaker will make the money available to assure workers will be paid if they are laid off when plants close. Analysts say such closings are inevitable if GM is to become more competitive and regain market share lost to U.S. and foreign rivals. The union made job security its top priority in this year's talks, and said that objective was achieved in the talks with GM. ``Job security and income security go hand-in-hand when you make the income security so high that they have got to make sure that they're going to work on job security,'' UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich said. GM closed four assembly plants in the last three years, putting about 9,000 employees out of work. The 1987 contract language that allowed the closings remains in the tentative agreement. This time, GM will pay dearly to close a plant An affected worker: -May be laid off for no more than 36 weeks from a plant closed because of slow sales of a product made there. -Would be paid 95 percent of base wages from a company-paid supplemental employment benefits fund. -Must be recalled after 36 weeks or be placed in a JOBS bank, also paid for by GM. The jobs may have nothing to do with the auto industry. Workers could stay in the job bank for the life of the contract. GM will spend $3.35 billion on the supplemental benefits fund and the JOBS bank and $663 million on other income-protection programs. The 300,000 UAW-represented workers will vote on the contract over the next two weeks. ``It's a sweetened buyout based on the framework already in place,'' said Harley Shaiken, a labor professor at the University of California at San Diego. ``It gives GM a lot of flexibility.'' The agreement also provides: -A 3 percent base wage increase in the first year and one-time payments equal to 3 percent of annual salary in the second and third years. -Continued cost-of-living adjustments. Union officials said an assembler who now makes $14.01 an hour would receive $16.53 an hour under the new contract, counting both the raise and cost-of-living increases based on an assumption of 4.4 percent annual inflation. Based on that assumption, the wage would rise to $17.19 in the contract's second year and $17.88 the third year. Bargaining Council members who received details in a three-hour meeting Tuesday were largely impressed. The contract will fly with the rank and file, they said. ``It's an OK contract,'' said Local 594 President Don Douglas, an outspoken critic of UAW leadership. If GM shrinks as expected in the next three years, so will the union. ``Here the UAW has achieved some measurable increase in job security at the price of accepting the continued erosion in employment levels,'' Shaiken said. Assuming approval of the agreement, the UAW will move onto Ford Motor Co. or Chrysler Corp., where negotiations have been suspended since Aug. 28 when the UAW picked GM as its bargaining target. The union probably would prefer to take the pattern to Ford next, but that may depend on whether a Canadian Auto Workers strike of Ford's operations there has been resolved. The strike reached a fourth day Tuesday. ``I would think that unofficially we'd be next in the barrel,'' UAW-Ford Vice President Ernie Lofton said. Chrysler, in the worst financial shape of the Big Three, has said it probably couldn't afford a contract tailored at GM or Ford. The No. 3 automaker has plenty of cash on hand from the sale of subsidiaries and interest in other ventures, but it needs the money to develop new cars and trucks. Buying out workers the way GM agreed to could leave Chrysler cash-poor and with no new products. Bieber said he didn't know how much more this contract would cost GM than the 1987 agreement. The income protection commitment alone is three times greater than the last contract, however. ``Overall, its a good agreement, very solid,'' said Jerry Melillo, president of UAW Local 1250 in Cleveland and a member of the union's Ford bargaining committee. Ford's use of overtime to avoid building new plants in the 1980s is targeted in the pattern agreement. The new contract would provide for a 5-percent shift premium for some overtime work. ``That's pointed directly at Ford,'' Shaiken said. ``Those overtime provisions are meant to establish a pattern.'' Ford presented the CAW with a new economic package Tuesday, but it was not favorably received. ``The best I can say is it forms a basis for continuing talks, not a basis for settlement,'' CAW President Bob White said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Settle in Above $33 Per Barrel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs with AAA survey.
DOC.TEXT: Oil for October delivery dipped slightly in the futures market Tuesday, as traders cashed in profits from the record highs of a day earlier. The October contract closed down 22 cents at $33.41 per barrel in the absence of major news from the Persian Gulf, which has transfixed the oil market since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Crude oil contracts for the next three delivery months were up slightly, reflecting the market's attempt to narrow the range of prices for oil delivered in the near term. ``It was sort of a day of consolidation,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Among other petroleum products, home heating oil continued to outpace unleaded gasoline because of seasonal fluctuations. Heating oil was up 1.12 cents to 86.43 cents per gallon on October contracts, with other months also higher. Unleaded gasoline fell .06 cent to 91.61 cents per gallon for October contracts, with November contracts down slightly and later contracts higher. Natural gas rose to $1.560 cents per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts, up from $1.537 on Monday. After the markets closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude imports and the nation's crude stockpile had both fallen last week. Crude imports dropped from to 6 million barrels per day from 6.9 million barrels per day for the week, falling below their level of 6.4 million barrels per day a year earlier, API said. That helped bring the nation's crude stockpile down to 369.8 million barrels, from 374.3 million barrels a week earlier, although the stocks were above the level of 329 million barrels a year earlier, the trade group said in its weekly report. Gasoline imports were up to 282,000 barrels per day from 261,000 barrels per day a week earlier, but down from 355,000 barrels per day a year earlier. Gasoline stocks were up to 217 million barrels, from 211.1 million barrels a week earlier, but they were below the level of 218.6 million barrels a year earlier. The stockpile of distillates, which includes heating oil, was up to 133.3 million barrels, from 131.7 million barrels a week earlier and 121.4 million barrels a year earlier. Distillate imports were up to 394,000 barrels per day, from 242,000 barrels per day a week earlier and 236,000 barrels per day a year earlier. The nation's refineries ran at higher capacity, 94 percent, compared with 93.5 percent a week earlier and 89.9 percent a year earlier, API said. The American Automobile Association reported Tuesday that in its nationwide spot check, the price of self-serve regular unleaded was $1.292 a gallon, down two-tenths of a cent since Sept. 11. The national auto club said the average retail price was 21.7 cents higher than on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.BYLINE: BRIGHT IDEA: GE Expands In Eastern Europe With Light Bulb Venture
DOC.TEXT: BUDAPEST, Hungary - As hammers and saws drone in the background, George Varga spins his vision of how General Electric Co. will increase its stake in the European lightbulb business while benefiting from the newly opened markets of the East. The beachhead is Tungsram, a light bulb company once owned by the government of Hungary. GE bought control of Tungsram last November for $150 million in the largest U.S. investment in Hungary since World War II, and it's Varga's job to turn things around. Slug BC-GE-Tungsram. By Business Writer Bart Ziegler. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 23. With LaserPhotos.
With BC-Eastern Europe-Ventures.
DOC.BYLINE: GLOBE GIRDLING: From Sweaters To Barbie Fashion, Benetton Won't Be Hemmed In
DOC.TEXT: PONZANO VENETO, Italy - The Italian sportswear firm Benetton Group SpA has grown from a small, family-owned business in a backwater city to what some call the McDonald's of fashion - a $1.5 billion, 5,900-outlet retailing giant. The company is celebrating its first quarter-century with a binge of investments in tennis rackets, ski boots and Barbie-doll clothes. Slug BC-Benetton's Birthday. By Dennis Redmont. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept 23.
DOC.BYLINE: RISKS, LOSSES AND VIDEOTAPE: Financial Adviser Costs Investors $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: DENVER - Financial adviser James Donahue, who promised to hedge all his bets, turned up winners consistently in stock-options trading for nearly a dozen years. But his empire collapsed last month, costing investors about $100 million. They learned of the losses via videotape. Slug BC-Personal File-Donahue. By Sandy Shore. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 23. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: TAKING IT TO THE BANK: The Wild Ride of Silverado
DOC.TEXT: DENVER - Silverado was a shooting star - a spectacular burnout that left little but a sleek skyscraper in downtown Denver, a $1 billion bill for the taxpayers, and a raging controversy surrounding one of its directors. The director is Neil Bush, son of the president; this week, he faces hearings on government allegations of a conflict of interest in the demise of the thrift. But Silverado is more than the story of George's boy. It is a tale of profligate spending and lending, of three-card monte played with millions. It is, in fact, the savings and loan fiasco in not-so-miniature. Slug BC-Silverado Saga. By Carl Hilliard. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 23. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.BYLINE: YOU RANG?: Denver School Turns Out American Version Of The English Butler
DOC.TEXT: DENVER - Did your English butler run off with the upstairs maid? Here's a place where you can find a replacement, an American version trained in the art of household finance as well as gracious entertaining. In fact, graduates of this school in Denver prefer to be called ``household managers,'' rather than butlers. Slug BC-Household Managers. By Steve Holzer. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 23. Also moved on AP Newsfeatures. Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.
DOC.BYLINE: TRANSLATING TECH TALK: English Professor Rewrites VCR, Other Manuals
DOC.TEXT: PITTSBURGH - The manual on your fancy new home entertainment system says to ``access the next highest programmed station setting'' on the TV, but warns ``the audio could be muted'' with improper handling. If you didn't understand the instructions to change the channel, and press the right button or risk losing sound, you're not alone. An English professor from Carnegie Mellon University has come to the resuce of the growing ranks of ``techno-dolts,'' those of us who have trouble setting VCR clocks or taping programs. Slug BC-Electronic Lingo. By Jeffrey Bair. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Sept. 24. With LaserPhoto.
With BC-Electrical Lingo-Examples.
DOC.BYLINE: GREETINGS COMPETITORS: Alternative Card Company Sets Lofty Goals
DOC.TEXT: CAMDENTON, Mo. - In the fiercely competitive, multibillion-dollar greeting card industry, Among Friends is a grain of sand on a beach dominated by giants like Hallmark Cards, American Greetings and Gibson Greetings. But the alternative card company has set some lofty goals, and in two years has expanded from selling just a few cards to lake-area shops to marketing a line of assorted cards and gifts in 48 states, Japan and England. Slug BC-Among Friends. By Jerry Nachtigal. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Sept. 24. With LaserPhoto.
